{"uri": "8096724575", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "12:26:30", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T12:26:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T12:26:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "http://www.tribalfootball.com/articles/arne-slot-liverpool-can-third-choice-really-prove-best-choice-4492840?utm_source%3Dmediafed%26utm_medium%3Drss-feed%26utm_campaign%3DFeed-Latest%2BArticles%2Bfor%2BEredivisie", "title": "Arne Slot & Liverpool: Can third choice really prove best choice?", "body": "COMMENT: So can third-choice work out to be best choice? Certainly, Liverpool will be hoping so with a deal for Arne Slot now into it's final stages with Feyenoord...\n\nBut it's done. Settled. Slot, baring any late mishap, will be named new Liverpool manager. Feyenoord's Eredivisie winning coach has already agreed terms with the Reds and also has a deal in place with his current club about the number of staff he will take with him to England.\n\nAs we say, Slot is strictly third-choice. After the much-publicised snub from Xabi Alonso at Bayer Leverkusen - and Sporting CP coach Ruben Amorim's decision to pull back over 'control' issues - Liverpool turned to Slot and were greeted with an immediate enthusiastic response. So much so that there's hope that after just days of negotiations Liverpool and Feyenoord will be able to confirm agreement by the weekend.\n\nWith Slot's contract carrying a \u20ac10m buyout clause, Liverpool are attempting to talk down that fee with their Feyenoord counterparts. Knowing Slot's eagerness to see the deal closed - and the loyalty he showed last season turning down Tottenham - there is a confidence Feyenoord will be malleable over the final compensation.\n\nIn the meantime, as Liverpool's new football CEO Michael Edwards had warned Slot in their first meeting, there is a backroom staff to fill out. Klopp's departure will coincide with his coaching staff also leaving. As mentioned in past columns, it's a strange one, but Liverpool's incoming manager will be required to complete a full rebuild. But they won't all come from Rotterdam.\n\nAs of today, Slot and the Feyenoord board have agreed that only two of his staff will join him at Liverpool: assistant coach Sipke Hulshoff and high performance manager Ruben Peeters. As a source stated: \"Slot has been informed by Liverpool management about the exodus of technical people and that has everything to do with the fact that the entire Team Klopp is resigning.\"\n\nFor their part, unlike with Liverpool, Feyenoord's board \"... will not be flexible, just like with Slot himself, because the club does not want to reorganise a complete coaching panel\". Again, on Liverpool's part, it's a strange one...\n\nBut they have their man, do Liverpool. Well, at least their third choice. And it's a gamble - for both sides. Slot isn't the Klopp of 2015. Nor is the Eredivisie the Bundesliga. The step up will be huge for the 45 year-old. Liverpool have really gone with potential. What they hope can be. This isn't Klopp, nor Rafa Benitez nor Gerard Houllier. Even comparisons with Brendan Rodgers are a stretch. That Slot, unlike Xabi and Amorim, hasn't been mentioned with the jobs at Barcelona or Bayern Munich - nor with any major club this season - does raise doubts. Indeed, just yesterday Peter Bosz was asked why he wasn't considered given his PSV are nine points clear of Feyenoord at the top of table.\n\n\"Yes, but that didn't happen,\" replied PSV's coach. \"Liverpool is of course a big club, so if it all works out, that would be great for Arne. He is more than welcome!\"\n\nThough just as much for Liverpool, it is also a gamble for Slot. It was only a year ago he turned down Tottenham, feeling he wasn't quite ready for such a move. A year on. A title won. And a first Champions League campaign experienced. Slot feels better equipped to take on a Premier League post. And to be fair, as a manager, you don't turn down Liverpool.\n\nBut what will Slot be walking into? Liverpool will end the season with more questions than answers. A first defeat in 14 years to Everton. Beaten at home by Crystal Palace - and by Atalanta to end their Europa League run. One question to be raised by this dramatic fall is: just how reliant has Klopp and Liverpool been on a fully fit and in-form Mohamed Salah?\n\nThis cannot be underestimated. If Salah does leave for the Saudi Pro League this summer, how will Liverpool respond? How will Slot respond? The pressure and expectations around succeeding Klopp is one thing. But trying to succeed without perhaps the most decisive player to wear a Reds shirt this century...? As we say, this is a career gamble for Slot.\n\n\"I am a fan of another football,\" said Slot before facing Jose Mourinho's Roma earlier this season.\n\n\"I can appreciate Mourinho, despite being a (Pep) Guardiola fan. If you really enjoy watching Guardiola's football, that doesn't mean you can't appreciate what another manager is doing.\"\n\nWords and an attitude sure to be welcomed by the Kop. But you fancy, they'll have to be patient with their new manager. Arne Slot isn't the Klopp of 2015. There's no guarantees here. Liverpool can only hope that third-choice can eventually work out to be best choice.", "source": {"uri": "tribalfootball.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "tribalfootball.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "chris_beattie@tribalfootball.com", "name": "Chris Beattie", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arne_Slot", "type": "person", "score": 5, Fabrizio Romano says the Dutchman is a strong candidate and is considered an excellent manager. Slot was linked with a move to Tottenham Hotspur last year.\n\nLiverpool have made direct contact with Feyenoord manager Arne Slot about replacing Jurgen Klopp in the dugout at Anfield this summer, according to journalist Fabrizio Romano.\n\nThe Reds are looking to secure a long-term replacement for Klopp, who will step down from his current role as head coach at the end of the 2023/24 season.\n\nLiverpool have been linked with several names as speculation ramps up, but Slot has been identified as a potential leading candidate for the vacancy. Michael Edwards and Richard Hughes are eager to appoint the right successor to Klopp, who has established himself as a legend for the Merseyside giants.\n\nArne Slot is a 'strong candidate' to replace Klopp\n\nAccording to reports, Liverpool's approach to appoint Arne Slot is 'moving fast' at Anfield and could intensify this week. Last season, the 45-year-old led Feyenoord to an unexpected Eredivisie title before securing the KNVB Cup this term.\n\nSlot has moved ahead of the likes of Sporting CP boss Ruben Amorim and Bayer Leverkusen's Xabi Alonso, who are both unlikely to take the Liverpool job this summer. The Dutchman has previously been linked with a move to Tottenham Hotspur, but talks over his appointment collapsed last year.\n\nRomano has revealed that Slot is considered an excellent manager, with the potential to 'make special things' at the highest level in the Premier League. Speaking via his CaughtOffside column, the Italian journalist said:\n\n\"An important update on the Liverpool job to start with, as Feyenoord manager Arne Slot is now a strong candidate for the job of replacing Jurgen Klopp this summer. He's considered already an excellent manager with a very good style, but also with potential to make special things also at the highest level possible in the Premier League.\n\n\"Some outlets have claimed that Slot has also been on the radar of Barcelona and Bayern Munich as they could also be appointing new managers this summer, but I'm only aware of contacts with Liverpool so far. {"uri": "8094340198", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "06:54:47", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T06:54:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T06:54:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/13121595/crazy-sexy-football-who-is-liverpool-candidate-slot", "title": "Arne Slot: Feyenoord boss at forefront of Liverpool's search for Jurgen Klopp successor", "body": "Sky Sports News's senior reporter Melissa Reddy says Feyenoord's Arne Slot is 'a very strong option' to replace Jurgen Klopp as Liverpool manager.\n\nArne Slot is at the forefront of Liverpool's search for a replacement for Jurgen Klopp.\n\nThe Feyenoord head coach ticks all their key criteria for the position, although Sky Sports News understands the process is not a foregone conclusion, with the Eredivisie club determined to keep Slot.\n\nThere is also interest from other top clubs and Liverpool are still in dialogue with several options, but the 45-year-old is a strong candidate.\n\nSlot, who secured the KNVB Cup last weekend and led Feyenoord to their first title in six years last season, appeals to Liverpool due to his aggressive, full-throttle style.\n\nHe has drilled his team to be adept at turning defensive actions into shooting opportunities and they top the Eredivisie for tackles won in the opposition's final third.\n\nFeyenoord have the best defence in the league and the second-best offensive metrics.\n\nSlot has proved capable of improving individuals as well as the collective, while operating on a smaller budget than his core competitors, and his penchant for a 4-2-3-1 or 4-4-3 formation fits Liverpool's squad.\n\nSlot has previously been approached by Tottenham, Chelsea and Leeds. He signed a new contract last May to keep him at Feyenoord until 2026 but has referenced a desire to make the next step in his career.\n\nCompensation is anticipated to be in the region of \u00a39m if a deal is to be closed.\n\nSporting manager Ruben Amorim was under consideration by Liverpool but sources say he is no longer in the frame, as it stands.\n\nWest Ham are interested in Amorim but Julen Lopetegui, the former Wolves, Real Madrid and Spain boss, and Paulo Fonseca, currently in charge of Lille, are considered the frontrunners.\n\nSlot took over from Dick Advocaat at Feyenoord for the start of the 21/22 season with the club having finished fifth the previous campaign. Just two years later, they were champions of the Eredivisie. He built a pressing team playing intense, attack-minded football while also being able to win.\n\nFeyenoord are second behind PSV Eindhoven this season, nine points adrift with four games to play. In Europe they finished third in their Champions League group before dropping into the Europa League where they were knocked out by Roma on penalties in February.\n\nSpeaking to Sky Sports Dutch football journalist Marcel van der Kraan said: \"He is the prime candidate for Liverpool. It was only a matter of time before another big English club would come knocking on the door. He's not only been a successful manager, he's also been hugely impressive with his playing style of very attack-minded, Pep Guardiola-style football.\n\n\"I don't expect Feyenoord to stand in the way. They know he's a manager in demand but they will demand a big compensation fee. He has two years left on his contract that was a record deal.\n\n\"Never before in Dutch football has a team paid a manager such huge wages. The players like him, the fans love him, the club love him - they won't want him to go. Feyenoord have every right to demand a big fee as there is no clause in his contract which he renewed last year.\n\n\"He's been a successful coach and made Feyenoord champions playing crazy, sexy football. It is sexy what this man brings on a football pitch. There's nothing more to win for him here. The next step for him is to enter a club in a big league and no league is bigger for the Dutch than the Premier League. I will be surprised if Slot doesn't bite at this chance and become the manger of Liverpool next season.\"\n\nLast summer, Slot was one of the leading contenders for the then-vacant Tottenham manager's role and Sky Sports News reporter Gary Cotterill went to Rotterdam to cover the story.\n\nCotterill found Slot to be \"engaging, polite, very smiley, he's got presence and charisma - and he's funny\" when writing about his trip to get the lowdown on the Feyenoord boss, who has been open about his desire to manage in the Premier League.\n\n\"My next step will not be a club in Holland,\" he said in May 2023.\n\n\"If that is my next step, then I've failed completely. The normal next step will be to go abroad and I've always said the best league in the world is the Premier League.\"\n\nSpurs were determined to get Slot last summer after he secured the Eredivisie title with Feyenoord.\n\nHowever, Slot ruled himself out of the running to take over in north London before signing a new contract at Feyenoord a few days later which runs until 2026.\n\n\"I'm not done here yet,\" Slot said after the announcement of his new deal.\n\nThe potential deal with Spurs never got to any formal stage of discussions with him or Feyenoord and Spurs' bosses felt that Slot used their interest in him to get an improved contract in the Netherlands.\n\nAnge Postecoglou was eventually appointed by Spurs from Celtic.", "source": {"uri": "skysports.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8095377569", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "17:38:36", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T17:38:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T17:38:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/arne-slot-green-light-liverpool-job/", "title": "Arne Slot 'Gives Green Light' to Liverpool Move", "body": "The Reds are discussing contract terms with the Dutch manager who they want to replace Jurgen Klopp.\n\nHighlights Arne Slot is 'super keen' on becoming Liverpool's new manager, already discussing contract terms with the club. Feyenoord has respected Slot's wishes to negotiate with Liverpool, but will demand a compensation fee of approximately \u00a39m. Slot's competition for the Liverpool job is diminishing, with him emerging as the clear favorite over other potential candidates like Amorim and De Zerbi.\n\nLiverpool are negotiating Arne Slot's contract terms after getting the green light from the Dutchman as the Reds seek to appoint their new manager, according to journalist Fabrizio Romano.\n\nThe Premier League side have been on the lookout for a Jurgen Klopp replacement since the German announced he will depart at the end of the season back in January, and look to have found their man.\n\nThe Feyenoord boss is reportedly getting closer to making the switch from mainland Europe to England, largely thanks to the Eredivisie side's understanding and respect for their manager's wishes.\n\nSlot 'Super keen' on Liverpool Move\n\nSlot is known to be 'super keen' on succeeding Klopp at Anfield, according to highly respected journalist Fabrizio Romano.\n\nHe said on his X account:\n\n\"Liverpool are already discussing contract terms with Arne Slot, represented by Rafaela Pimenta.\"\n\n\"No issues as he's super keen. He's given his green light to the move on Tuesday, after initial positive contact. Meanwhile, #LFC discussing compensation fee with Feyenoord.\"\n\nThe 45-year old is keen on making the next step in his short but impressive stint in management at both AZ Alkmaar and Feyenoord over the last five years.\n\nFeyenoord Will Allow Slot to Leave for Right Fee\n\nAfter three successful years at the Dutch side, Slot has guided the team to the Eredivisie title last season, as well as a UEFA Europa League final defeat to Roma.\n\nSince he took over at the club in 2021, Slot has managed 144 games in all competitions. Of those 144, Slot has guided Feyenoord to 93 wins, 27 draws and 24 defeats, which sees his win percentage stand at an impressive 70.4%.\n\nThe Dutchman's impressive stint at Feyenoord has developed a progressive and fluent style of play and has drawn Liverpool's attention.\n\nArne Slot's record at Feyenoord\n\nSeason\n\nPoints-per-game (Eredivisie)\n\n2021/22\n\n2.1\n\n2022/23\n\n2.4\n\n2023/24\n\n2.4*\n\nUnderstanding that becoming manager of one of the biggest clubs in the world, Feyenoord have respected Slot's wishes and are allowing him to negotiate with the Reds.\n\nBut, they of course want compensation, which, according to Melisaa Reddy, will cost the Reds approximately \u00a39m if they are to get their man.\n\nSlot's Competition Appears to be Dwindling\n\nWith Slot now the clear favourite for the job, recent candidates in the form of Ruben Amorim and Roberto De Zerbi seem to be disappearing.\n\nAmorim has reportedly been in talks with West Ham about taking over from David Moyes at the end of the season, while talk of Brighton boss De Zerbi replacing Klopp has gone quiet.\n\nThiago Motta, Thomas Tuchel and current Reds assistant manager Pep Lijnders are next in the running, but there has been no concrete evidence that Liverpool are currently or have ever considered any of the trio for the position.\n\nPerhaps Liverpool's primary target following the news of Klopp's departure was Xabi Alonso, who has made a brilliant start to management.\n\nAlonso is a former Liverpool player who has Feyenoord over move to appoint Arne Slot as new manager", "body": "Liverpool are in talks with Feyenoord in their bid to appoint Arne Slot as their new manager, the PA news agency understands.\n\nSlot, 45, has emerged as a leading candidate to succeed Jurgen Klopp at the end of the season and the Dutchman is ready to fulfil his dream move to a top Premier League club.\n\nBut Feyenoord do not want to lose their manager and will demand significant compensation for the man who guided the Dutch club to their first title in six years last season.\n\nFeyenoord currently sit second in the Eredivisie table and won the Dutch Cup at the weekend, while Slot extended his contract with the Dutch club last summer until 2026.\n\nLiverpool can expect Feyenoord to take a tough stance in the negotiations as Slot wants to take some of his backroom staff with him to Anfield.\n\nIt is understood Liverpool consider Slot to fit all the criteria set out in their recruitment process, although they are still looking at other contenders.\n\nIt has been reported that Liverpool will have to pay \"considerably more than 10 million euros\" if they are to land their man.\n\nMichael Edwards, who recently returned to the fold as the chief executive of football for Liverpool's owners Fenway Sports Group, having previously been the club's sporting director, and incoming sporting director Richard Hughes have been tasked with the unenviable task of finding Klopp's replacement.\n\nHaving seen one leading candidate in former Reds midfielder Xabi Alonso commit himself to Bayer Leverkusen, who he has just led to their first Bundesliga title, others such as Sporting Lisbon's Ruben Amorim - now linked with West Ham - and Brighton's Roberto De Zerbi have also been under consideration.\n\nSlot has turned down previous offers to work in the Premier League. "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://www.westerntelegraph.co.uk/resources/images/18006316/", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9504405", "eventUri": "eng-9504405", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2470588235294118, "wgt": 206, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8097147681", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:02:29", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:02:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:02:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.liverpool.com/liverpool-fc-news/features/arne-slot-next-liverpool-manager-29061101", "title": "Arne Slot has already proven exactly why he's perfect next Liverpool manager", "body": "J\u00fcrgen Klopp is leaving and Liverpool has been undergoing a long and extensive process to identify the best possible replacement for the German. Feyenoord head coach Arne Slot appears to be the new frontrunner.\n\nLiverpool doesn't want a complete U-turn in the way that it plays. Why, after all, would it want to move away from a style of play that has been successful? The current playing squad is well set up for a high-intensity pressing game, even if it didn't show a great deal of that against Everton earlier this week.\n\nSlot has proven capable of implementing such a style successfully domestically and in Europe and the Eredivisie boss appears to be a logical fit for Liverpool as a consequence. Over the years, he has said all the right things when it comes to the biggest boxes that Liverpool needs to ensure are ticked with its new manager.\n\nREAD MORE: Arne Slot responds to Liverpool next manager question as Feyenoord boss issues short reply\n\nREAD MORE: Arne Slot could bring $93m Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez upgrade to Liverpool after Jamie Carragher prediction\n\nAhead of the Europa League Conference final against AS Roma two years ago, Slot told UEFA.com: \"We are an attack-minded team that likes to have a lot of the ball, and we play with a lot of intensity. When we don't have the ball, we want to win it back as quickly as possible by being aggressive and pressing to win back possession. I think we are a team that is difficult to beat.\"\n\nThat could easily be a quote from Klopp or his assistant, Pep Lijnders. The latter, in fact, according to Voetbal Zone, could take over at Feyenoord if Slot ends up at Anfield.\n\nA few months later, after signing a contract extension with Feyenoord, Slot told the club's official website: \"I feel that our work is greatly appreciated within the club and among the fans, not only because of the results but above all with regard to the development of players and the attractive, infectious way of playing the fans clearly enjoy.\"\n\nGetting the most out of resources will be a key factor for Liverpool in deciding who takes Klopp's job and there is a clear synergy between the team and the fans in the Netherlands that can only be a big positive as well. Slot's style and preferred way of playing, just like Klopp's, is ideal for fostering that.\n\nWhile he is similar in many ways to Klopp, though, Slot has also made no bones about his admiration for Pep Guardiola. \"He gives me the ultimate pleasure in football,\" he said last year when speaking to the Dutch outlet Voetbal International. \"City has -- and then it is not the intention to compare us with them -- a similar way of playing how we want to do with Feyenoord: 4-3-3, building backwards, wanting to put pressure quickly.\"\n\nIt is interesting that he calls his set-up a 4-3-3 there -- the same formation that Liverpool uses -- when he has also used a 4-2-3-1 system at times. It would not be a huge transition for Liverpool to work within those confines considering that would be a natural evolution from what Klopp has implemented.\n\nIt is for that reason that Slot is the leading contender at this stage for the Liverpool job, though there is potential interest from other clubs around Europe too. Bayern Munich and Barcelona are both looking for new head coaches as well, but Slot has made it clear before that he sees himself in the Premier League at some point.\n\nDuring his coaching career to date, Slot has said exactly what Liverpool would want to hear from a potential new manager. It remains to be seen whether the deal gets done, but it is not hard to see why the Reds might have identified him as a leading candidate.", "source": {"uri": "liverpool.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Liverpool"}, "authors": [{"uri": "matt_addison@liverpool.com", "name": "Matt Addison", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arne_Slot", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Arne Slot"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feyenoord", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Feyenoord"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J\u00fcrgen_Klopp", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "J\u00fcrgen Klopp"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liverpool", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Liverpool"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Liverpool"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manager_(association_football)", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Manager (association football)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eredivisie", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Eredivisie"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Everton_F.C.", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Everton F.C."}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darwin_N\u00fa\u00f1ez", "type": "person", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A.S._Roma", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "A.S. "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.kbc.co.ke/slot-a-leading-candidate-to-succeed-klopp/", "title": "Slot a leading candidate to succeed Klopp - KBC", "body": "Feyenoord's Arne Slot is a leading candidate to take over as Liverpool manager from Jurgen Klopp.\n\nKlopp announced in January he would leave Anfield at the end of the season and the Reds have been conducting extensive research around a number of candidates.\n\nThe 45-year-old, who led Feyenoord to the 2022-23 Eredivisie title, has emerged as a candidate who fits Liverpool's criteria.\n\nFeyenoord have won the Dutch Cup this season and are second in the Eredivisie.\n\nThe decision to appoint Slot has not been made but he has become a strong candidate to succeed Klopp.\n\nHe was linked with Leeds United after they sacked manager Jesse Marsch, while Slot also ruled himself out of contention for the Tottenham Hotspur job last summer before Ange Postecoglou took over.\n\nThe attacking style of Slot, who is also thought to be interesting Barcelona and Bayern Munich, and his ability to develop players are believed to appeal to Liverpool.\n\nSlot became Feyenoord head coach in December 2020 after leaving AZ Alkmaar, where he enjoyed success in his first managerial position.\n\nThe former midfielder spent his entire playing career in the Netherlands, making more than 100 appearances for both FC Zwolle and NAC Breda.\n\nXabi Alonso was linked with the Anfield job but the former Reds midfielder announced in March he would stay on at Bayer Leverkusen, who have since become German champions.\n\nSporting {"uri": "8094881438", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "12:20:36", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T12:20:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T12:20:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/au/premier-league/news/arne-slot-liverpool-tactics-playing-style-trophies-feyenoord-coach/5723fe56cef28b92cffb43ca", "title": "Arne Slot to Liverpool? Tactics, playing style, trophies won for Feyenoord coach touted to replace Jurgen Klopp", "body": "Premier League history shows that there are few jobs tougher then replacing successful, transformative and much-loved managers. Paradoxically, there are also few jobs more attractive to those in the elite coaching fraternity.\n\nSucceeding Jurgen Klopp at Liverpool is unquestionably one of those roles and, perhaps fittingly for a big position on Merseyside, the frontrunners have been changing and jockeying for position like competitors in the Kentucky Derby.\n\nLiverpool fans educated themselves on the tactics, traits and presumed inner workings of Xabi Alonso and Ruben Amorim, but now Feyenoord head coach Arne Slot is the name on everyone's lips.\n\nThe Athletic's David Ornstein reported on April 24 that Liverpool were in negotiations with Slot, who is now their \"preferred choice\".\n\nMORE: Liverpool's title race run-in and projected Premier League finish\n\nSlot is certainly not the first name to be linked with the Anfield job.\n\nXabi Alonso was the early favourite to be installed as Klopp's successor, but is firmly out of the running.\n\nAlonso led Bayer Leverkusen to a historic maiden Bundesliga title and has already confirmed that he will be staying put next year. Given Leverkusen remain in contention for a treble of Bundesliga, UEFA Europa League and DFB-Pokal, who can blame him?\n\nSpeaking at a press conference in late March, Alonso said: \"We've had a lot of speculation regarding my future. We've had a lot of games, been pretty busy, pretty focused, and I wanted to use the international break and reflect and take a decision.\n\n\"Last week I had a very good meeting with Simon [Rolfes] and Fernando [Carro] and informed them of my decision to continue as coach of Bayer Leverkusen.\n\n\"It's the right place for me to be, to develop as a coach. The fans showed great support this year. They have all the reasons to believe and dream we can have a great season. The players gave me so many reasons to keep believing in the team. My job is not over here.\"\n\nThat development further strengthened the position of potential candidates like Ruben Amorim and Roberto De Zerbi, the manager of Brighton & Hove Albion. However, the shift in focus towards Slot does feel like a potentially decisive moment in the saga.\n\nWest Ham's links to Amorim suggest the trail has run cold with the Sporting CP boss as far as Liverpool are concerned.\n\nJulian Nagelsmann was also mentioned as a potential successor to his countryman Klopp but has since committed himself to remaining with the German national team.\n\nWhile acknowledging Slot's reported enthusiasm for the Anfield post, it is worth remembering that the managerial marketplace will be a crowded one at the sharp end of European football this summer. Bayern Munich, Barcelona and potentially AC Milan will be looking for a new boss and Slot's fine work will not have gone unnoticed in those footballing capitals. Liverpool are wise to be acting swiftly.\n\nMORE: Xabi Alonso out of running to replace Jurgen Klopp at Liverpool\n\nThe timing of the latest developments looks ideal for Slot, who further burnished his reputation last weekend by lifting the KNVB Cup with Feyenoord in the Netherlands, in addition to the Eredivisie title triumph he masterminded last season.\n\nPSV Eindhoven are on the verge of taking the title back this time around in Holland and Feyenoord are safely in a Champions League qualification spot, so it's easy to see how negotiations can progress in an atmosphere of \"total respect\".\n\nNo one wants a repeat of the situation of December 2020, when Slot was sacked by AZ having already agreed a deal with Feyenoord, who he led to the UEFA Europa Conference League final in his first season in charge.\n\nThat messy exit is not the defining memory of Slot's time in Alkmaar, however. His average of 2.11 points per game is the highest of any coach in AZ history. He might even have secured an incredible Eredivisie success. In 2019/20, AZ were behind Erik ten Hag's Ajax at the top on goal difference when the Coronavirus pandemic struck and the season was voided.\n\nSlot's work at Feyenoord, a big club with a rich history but not the most financially powerful in Dutch football, has obvious parallels with Klopp's stays at Borussia Dortmund against the all-conquering Bayern Munich and at Liverpool in opposition to Pep Guardiola's Manchester City. There are stylistic similarities too.\n\nSlot is an advocate of high-intensity attacking football. His team play with a high defensive line and look to get the ball forward quickly.\n\nThat obviously chimes with the most romantic remembrances of Klopp's \"heavy metal football\" at Dortmund and Liverpool, with the caveat that the Reds' boss tempered that approach when the necessity of gargantuan points totals to compete with City became apparent.\n\nSlot uses 4-3-3 and 4-2-3-1 setups predominantly. In the latter, it is not uncommon to see his two deeper midfielders operating close to the central defenders during the build-up to bounce passes around the opposition press.\n\nThis is an approach used in the Premier League by De Zerbi, another coach reportedly on Liverpool's radar. It also frees up full-backs to support the attack and might be music to the ears of Trent Alexander-Arnold, Andy Robertson and breakout star Conor Bradley.\n\nOut of possession, the Klopp staple of a high-press is fundamental for Slot. Plenty about his previous work and the characteristics of the Liverpool squad mark him out as a good fit. It will then be on Slot to prove he is not simply \"Klopp-lite\" or any other potentially unflattering labels.\n\nMORE: The best, and tightest, Premier League title races in history\n\nIf negotiations are successful with Slot, Liverpool are going to have to put their hands in their pockets.\n\nThe 45-year-old is contracted to Feyenoord until 2026. Slot confirmed himself upon signing that new deal that there is no release clause in his contract, and a compensation package would likely be somewhere in the region of \u20ac10 million (\u00a38.5m/$10.7m).\n\nWhen Slot was a target for Tottenham last summer, multiple reports suggested Feyenoord improved his annual salary from \u20ac2m to \u20ac2.9m.\n\nMORE: How do Liverpool replace a manager like Klopp?\n\nIf Slot is the man to take over at Anfield, Liverpool fans will have to get used to singing his name on the Kop, just as they have done with Klopp.\n\nReports of Slot being the preferred candidate to take over at Liverpool were also met with a flurry of questions on social media about how to pronounce his name? Well, as with many Dutch names, it's not too complicated for English speakers. His name is pronounced phonetically as it is spelt, \"Ar-ner\" \"Slot\".\n\nTo begin perfecting your pronunciation, Liverpool fans, you can hear it pronounced by a Dutch native here.\n\nSlot would certainly be expected to hit the ground running if he does take over at Liverpool, but he will have an advantage in getting his message across to the talent-packed squad quickly, as he already speaks great English.\n\nSlot has been questioned in press conferences previously by English journalists as part of Feyenoord's European club commitments, including last year when he was linked with Tottenham and promptly showed off his language skills.\n\nKlopp's decision to step down from his role at Anfield caught everyone by surprise.\n\nHe made the announcement in an emotional video and written message on the club's website in January, citing that he was \"running out of energy\" for the demands of managing at the top level.\n\nThe news has hit Liverpool fans hard, but it has also sent reverberations around the Premier League.\n\nKlopp's rivalry with Manchester City boss Guardiola has proved to be the defining battle of its time in English football.\n\nIn 2018, Liverpool dumped City out of the Champions League en route to a final defeat against Real Madrid in Kyiv.\n\nThey also lost to Los Blancos in the 2022 final, but Klopp made sure of Liverpool's sixth European crown when they defeated Tottenham 2-0 at Madrid's Wanda Metropolitano Stadium in 2019.\n\nThat success facilitated glory in the 2019 editions of the UEFA Super Cup and the FIFA Club World Cup. Liverpool also won the domestic knockout double of the Carabao Cup and FA Cup in 2020/21.\n\nLiverpool picked up another trophy as they overcame Chelsea in the Carabao Cup final in February and Klopp has this season pieced together a youthful exciting team featuring the likes of Alexis Mac Allister, Dominik Szoboszlai, Curtis Jones, Darwin Nunez and a rejuvenated Trent Alexander-Arnold.\n\nThey remain firmly in the hunt for the Premier League title in a three-way battle with City and leaders Arsenal, despite a damaging 1-0 home loss to Crystal Palace.\n\nHaving joined the club in October 2015, Klopp offered a clear explanation for his pending departure when speaking to Liverpool's in-house media team on January 26.\n\n\"I will leave the club at the end of the season. I can understand that it's a shock for a lot of people in this moment when you read it for the first time,\" he said.\n\n\"Obviously I can explain it or at least try to explain it. I love absolutely everything about this club, I love everything about this city, I love everything about our supporters, I love the team, I love the staff. I love everything.\n\n\"That I still take this decision probably shows you that I'm convinced it's the one I have to take. It is that I'm...how can I say... I'm running out of energy.\n\n\"I have no problem now. I think I know it already for longer that I will have to announce it at one point. But I'm absolutely fine now, but I also know that I cannot do the job again and again and again and again.\n\n\"After all the years we had together and all the time we spent together, all the things we went through together, the respect grew for you and the love grew for you. The least I owe you is the truth. And that's the truth.\"", "source": {"uri": "sportingnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sporting News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feyenoord", "type": {"uri": "8093555468", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "17:43:38", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T17:43:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T17:43:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-13341547/Arne-Slot-compared-Pep-Guardiola-attack-minded-coach-Netherlands-Johan-Cruyff-holds-power-Feyenoord-Liverpool-fans-expect-replaces-Jurgen-Klopp.html", "title": "What Liverpool fans can expect of contender Arne Slot", "body": "Questioning Stuart Attwell's integrity is a disgrace for Nottingham Forest - Listen to the It's All Kicking Off podcast\n\nReplacing Jurgen Klopp is a difficult job, but in Arne Slot, the Reds might find a strong solution to perform an unenviable task.\n\nThe Feyenoord boss has emerged as a strong contender to succeed Klopp at Anfield this summer, after fan-favourite Xabi Alonso opted to stay at Bayer Leverkusen, while talk has run cold on the prospects of Ruben Amorim making the switch from Sporting Lisbon.\n\nHe is a man who Tottenham supporters will be well aware of, as he looked on course to replace Antonio Conte a year ago after his excellent work in Rotterdam. Yet, there was a twist in the tale, as the 45-year-old opted to stay at Feyenoord and sign a new contract.\n\nDespite his success in the Netherlands, Liverpool fans might hold concerns over what he can bring and if he can fill the very large boots left by Klopp. They will also take one look at their biggest rivals Manchester United, and see how Erik ten Hag is currently struggling at Old Trafford after impressing at Ajax.\n\nBut Slot is a cutting-edge operator with an exciting brand of football, and could prove to be a shrewd appointment if the Reds make a successful move for him.\n\nArne Slot has emerged as a strong contender to take over the Liverpool job from Jurgen Klopp\n\nSlot has impressed many with his work in Rotterdam, winning the Eredivisie title last season\n\nFilling Klopp's boots at Anfield is a massive challenge, but Slot could be a shrewd appointment\n\nYour browser does not support iframes.\n\nHis approach to management is defined by energy, a high-octane pressing style that Klopp himself with his 'heavy-metal' brand of football would give his nod of approval to.\n\nDutch football experts have also likened him to Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola - with Slot said to be a massive fan of the Spaniard.\n\nOne Dutch journalist told Sky Sports last year before his failed move to Tottenham: 'He's a really good manager. I've followed Feyenoord for 40 years. Not since the days of Johan Cruyff at Ajax in the 1980s has there been a coach so attack-minded in the Dutch league. Cruyff only had a few disciples who followed him and one of them was Pep Guardiola.\n\n'I would say Slot is a Guardiola-style manager based on everything I've seen over the past couple of years. The fans of Feyenoord can't believe what they've seen over that time.'\n\nSlot prefers to deploy either a 4-2-3-1 or 4-3-3 system that relies on possession which would fit Liverpool's current squad. He has a focus on regaining the ball as quickly as possible and his side top the Eredivisie for tackles won in the opposition's final third.\n\nHe likes his teams to play with two holding midfielders, while the attacking impetus is placed on wide players to deliver chances for the central striker.\n\nExplaining his approach with Feyenoord, Slot told UEFA: 'We are an attack-minded team that likes to have a lot of the ball, and we play with a lot of intensity.\n\n'When we don't have the ball, we want to win it back as quickly as possible by being aggressive and pressing to win back possession. I think we are a team that is difficult to beat.'\n\nSlot has been described as a 'Pep Guardiola-style manager' thanks to his work at Feyenoord\n\nOne person claimed he plays the most attacking style of football seen in the Netherlands since Johan Cruyff was a manager\n\nSlot prefers to deploy a 4-2-3-1 or 4-3-3 system at Feyenoord with two defensive midfielders and a reliance on wingers to create opportunities for a central striker\n\nA source told Mail Sport last year that Slot 'runs the whole club at Feyenoord' so it might be expected that he would like to have a big say behind the scenes at Liverpool\n\nThe Dutchman also has a reputation of developing youth players, something which will be integral for the Reds going forward, given the amount of youngsters coming through, including Conor Bradley and Jarell Quansah who have impressed since making the step-up to the first time.\n\n'Players like him. He understands people, that's his biggest strength,' a source told Mail Sport last year.\n\nThough he has a charismatic charm and is well liked by players, he was also described as someone who 'isn't necessarily easy'.\n\nAnother source said: 'He is a very friendly and likeable guy, he uses that. Arne's a top coach, but he isn't necessarily easy,' said a source. 'He runs the whole club at Feyenoord, he has all the power.'\n\nSlot previously impressed at AZ Alkmaar, but was abruptly sacked in December 2020 after owner Robert Eenhoorn was informed that the manager attended a clandestine meeting with Feyenoord about replacing then manager, Dick Advocaat.\n\nThough he can be a challenging figure at Feyenoord, his success at the club is not questionable.\n\nThe Eredivisie side have a rich history with players like Ruud Gullit, Ronald Koeman, Robin van Persie and Henrik Larsson all previously playing for the club. They won the European Cup in 1970, the UEFA Cup twice and the Dutch title 16 times.\n\nThey had won the league just once this century before Slot led them to the title last season.\n\nIt even came after they had to deal with losing some of their big players, with the likes of Tyrell Malacia, Luis Sinisterra, Marcos Senesi and Fredrik Aursnes leaving for a combined \u00a360m after they lost in the final of the Europa Conference League to Roma two years ago.\n\nSlot could link up with Dutch compatriots Cody Gakpo, Virgil van Dijk and Ryan Gravenberch at Anfield\n\nBut they continue to buy players wisely, with Mexican forward Santiago Gimenez scoring 47 goals in 85 appearances since he arrived at the club for just \u00a33m in the summer of 2022.\n\nPSV Eindhoven are on the verge of reclaiming the Dutch title this season, but a second place finish for Slot's Feyenoord along with success in the Dutch Cup this month reflects another strong season.\n\nHis Feyenoord side have proven themselves to be efficient in both attack and defence, scoring 77 goals in 30 games while only conceding 23.\n\nDutch legend Marco van Basten is convinced that Slot can become a success at Liverpool if the Reds made a move.\n\n'I hope he stays in the Netherlands longer because it is an enrichment for Dutch football. He can really go anywhere - Bayern Munich, Liverpool... I'm really convinced of that,' Van Basten said of Slot on Ziggo Sport's Rondo.\n\n'I've spoken to him a few times and I think what he does and what he sees is very strong. He gets along very well with the group of players, is tactically well-versed, can explain things well and is calm and intelligent. I think he can go to any club, even at the very difficult clubs, because he is so intelligent.\n\nSlot has two major pieces of silverware during his time at Feyenoord, in a league that has so often been dominated by Ajax and PSV Eindhoven during the 21st century\n\nMarco van Basten believes it would be easier for Slot to succeed at Liverpool with better players and believes he has the quality to become the manager at Anfield\n\n'He has a lot of qualities and he shows it at every level. He first did it at AZ, and now at Feyenoord. And Feyenoord is a really complicated club. He has been doing well for three years, while PSV and Ajax have much more options in terms of money.\n\n'He could really fit anywhere. If you get AZ and Feyenoord to play football, you also get big clubs like AC Milan to play football. You can clearly see his hand where he is the coach.\n\n'I think it will even be easier for him at a higher level because he has better players who understand his ideas faster. I also think he is smart enough to manage stubborn players.'\n\nHis work has not gone unnoticed with Tottenham and Chelsea previously considering moves for him last year, while the likes of Barcelona, Bayern Munich and AC Milan will all have Slot in their thinking as they look for new managers.\n\nSlot himself has also stated that he hoped his next move would be the Premier League.\n\nHe said: 'My next step will not be a club in Holland.\n\n'If that is my next step, then I've failed completely. Slot is seen by Liverpool as their ideal next manager after Klopp's successful tenure. There will likely need to be millions spent for Feyenoord to accept Liverpool's offer, and so delays in negotiations for Slot's arrival have become increasingly likely.\n\nLiverpool seem to be ramping onwards with their bid to bring a new boss to the helm in current Feyenoord gaffer Arne Slot - but according to local reports from the Netherlands, the Reds are set to see their first offer rejected.\n\nSlot has been earmarked as the man to replace Jurgen Klopp, with the German announcing his departure from Anfield at the end of the season in a move that will end a nine-year spell at Anfield, having won eight trophies in that time and firmly putting Liverpool back on the map again after around a decade of mediocrity.\n\nSlot could come in to keep the good times rolling at Anfield, and it's thought that Liverpool chiefs are in agreement that they see him as their next best manager, with 1908.nl suggesting that they have flown out to Rotterdam in a bid to thrash out a deal for Slot. But any hopes of a quick agreement have been dashed after being knocked back with their first offer.\n\nArne Slot: Liverpool Appointment Latest This is a move that could take some time to get right\n\nThe report states that Liverpool officials touched down in Rotterdam on Wednesday morning with an opening bid to prise the manager away from Feyenoord's hands, with the news being no great surprise to many after preliminary talks were opened with Slot to gauge his interest in a move.\n\nThe deal is expected to cost millions, and with Slot having won the Eredivisie with Feyenoord last season, he would likely take assistant Sipke Hulshoff with him alongside other members of his backroom staff - which would leave Feyenoord with more staff to replace.\n\nHowever, there has been a spanner in the works, with the report suggesting that their first offer will be rejected, despite further bids being expected to follow.\n\nAgent Rafaela Pimenta is said to be busy with contract details, with Slot looking more and more likely to leave for Liverpool in the coming weeks after an outstanding three years at Feyenoord. {"uri": "8092951086", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "10:49:38", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T10:49:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T10:49:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/marco-van-basten-names-perfect-29043385", "title": "Marco van Basten names perfect new Liverpool boss and it's not Ruben Amorim", "body": "Marco van Basten has explained why Arne Slot would be a 'really good' replacement for Jurgen Klopp as Liverpool manager. Xabi Alonso was once the favourite for the prospective vacancy at Anfield before committing his future to Bayer Leverkusen, forcing the Reds to expand their search for a new boss.\n\nRuben Amorim has been mooted as an alternative candidate to take the reins. But, with the Sporting CP head coach reportedly entertaining talks with West Ham and keeping his options open, Liverpool are running out of time to appoint a suitable successor.\n\nSo, Van Basten has pointed the Reds in the direction of Slot. After leading Feyenoord to their first Eredivisie title in six years last season, the 45-year-old was heavily linked with a move to Tottenham Hotspur but he signed a new three-year deal at De Kuip instead.\n\nREAD MORE: Jose Mourinho sent clear Liverpool message as Virgil van Dijk anticipates move\n\nREAD MORE: Jamie Carragher names new 'favourite' for Liverpool job after Ruben Amorim update\n\nAs a result, the Lilywhites appointed Ange Postecoglou instead. While PSV Eindhoven are just one win away from snatching Feyenoord's title as Dutch champions, Slot has still managed to get his hands on some silverware this term.\n\nThe Rotterdam-based outfit defeated NEC Nijmegen in the KNVB Cup final at the weekend. Nevertheless, Van Basten has backed his fellow countryman to prosper at either Liverpool or Bayern Munich.\n\n\"I think he's really good,\" said the legendary former striker on Ziggo Sport's 'Rondo', as quoted by the Metro. \"I hope he stays in the Netherlands longer because it is an enrichment for Dutch football.\n\n\"He can really go anywhere - Bayern Munich, Liverpool... I'm really convinced of that. I've spoken to him a few times and I think what he does and what he sees is very strong. He gets along very well with the group of players, is tactically well-versed, can explain things well and is calm and intelligent.\n\n\"I think he can go to any club, even at the very difficult clubs, because he is so intelligent. He has a lot of qualities and he shows it at every level. He first did it at AZ, and now at Feyenoord. And Feyenoord is a really complicated club.\n\n\"He has been doing well for three years, while PSV and Ajax have much more options in terms of money. He could really fit anywhere. If you get AZ and Feyenoord to play football, you also get big clubs like AC Milan to play football.\n\n\"You can clearly see his hand where he is the coach. I think it will even be easier for him at a higher level because he has better players who understand his ideas faster. I also think he is smart enough to manage stubborn players.\"\n\nSinging from the same hymn sheet, Wim Jonk also backed Slot to impress at Liverpool. The former Netherlands international said: \"He gave Feyenoord a face. Arne has made enormous strides, so I would like that. {"uri": "8095183432", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "15:25:02", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T15:25:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T15:24:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://worldsoccertalk.com/news/liverpool-target-slot-has-several-key-similarities-to-klopp/", "title": "Liverpool target Slot has several key similarities to Klopp", "body": "Liverpool has turned their attention in a search for a new manager to Feyenoord's Arne Slot. The Reds have been on the lookout for a successor to Jurgen Klopp since the German announced he was departing the club in January. Klopp is set to leave Merseyside at the end of the current campaign.\n\nThe Premier League side has been linked with a series of coaches in recent months. This list included Xabi Alonso, Roberto De Zerbi, and Ruben Amorim. Nevertheless, Slot is now emerging as a frontrunner for the position. David Ornstein is reporting that Liverpool has already offered a compensation package of about $9.6 million to Feyenoord.\n\nThe Dutch team, however, has rejected this initial offer. Slot does not currently have a release clause with his current club, which means that the two sides must agree to a fee for the coach. Slot is believed to be highly interested in a switch to the Reds this summer though. The Dutchman previously rejected a chance to move to the Premier League last year after Tottenham Hotspur attempted to sign him before switching their attention to Ange Postecoglou.\n\nLiverpool's interest in Slot seemingly makes sense for a few different reasons. First of all, the coach has been successful with Feyenoord. The Dutchman led the club to the Eredivisie title for the 2022/23 season, only their second championship since 2000. The team also just picked up the KNVB Cup on Sunday as well.\n\nNot only has Slot collected trophies at Feyenoord, but his team plays fairly similar to Klopp's Liverpool. Much like the Reds, Slot's Dutch side is an offensive powerhouse that also presses opponents high up the pitch. Feyenoord has averaged 2.57 goals per game this season, which is slightly higher than Liverpool's 2.27. Both clubs also rank inside the top 15 teams among the best 10 European leagues in high turnovers and possession won in the final third of the pitch.\n\nFeyenoord ranks second in the Eredivisie in total shots, while also allowing the fewest shots in the league as well. These figures are very similar to Liverpool under Klopp during the current campaign.\n\nOutside of statistics, Slot also has a reputation for developing young players while at his current club. Due to various injuries to key players, Klopp has had to regularly rely on youthful talent this season. Conor Bradley, Jarell Quansah, and Bobby Clark have all made a series of Premier League starts for Klopp throughout the campaign. Not only have they made unexpected appearances in big games, but the youngsters have also performed well for the club.\n\nThe combination of coaching style and handling of young players would seemingly make for an easy transition for Slot at Liverpool. A deal to bring the Dutchman to Anfield, however, is not yet finalized. The English side still needs to agree to an appropriate compensation package for Feyenoord to sign its target.\n\nOther big English clubs such as Manchester United and Arsenal have struggled in recent years after replacing legendary managers. {"uri": "8093857194", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "22:35:44", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T22:35:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T22:35:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.sportsmole.co.uk/football/liverpool/news/feyenoord-chief-responds-to-arne-slot-links-with-liverpool-job_542032.html", "title": "Feyenoord chief responds to Arne Slot links with Liverpool job", "body": "Feyenoord technical director Dennis te Kloese responds to speculation linking manager Arne Slot with Liverpool. Feyenoord technical director Dennis te Kloese has responded to speculation linking manager Arne Slot with a summer move to Liverpool.\n\nThe Reds are on the lookout for a new boss as Jurgen Klopp will be stepping down from his post at the end of the season after eight-and-a-half successful years in the Anfield hotseat.\n\nXabi Alonso was initially Liverpool's primary target, but he has committed his future to Bundesliga champions Bayer Leverkusen, while Sporting Lisbon's Ruben Amorim has also been under consideration, but it is understood that the 39-year-old is no longer in the frame to succeed Klopp.\n\nSpeculation continues to swirl over who could take the reigns at Liverpool next season, and a new name from the Eredivisie has now emerged as a leading contender.\n\nIndeed, a recent report states that Liverpool have expressed their interest in Feyenoord boss Slot, while journalist Fabrizio Romano claims that the Reds have made 'direct contact' with the 45-year-old.\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nFeyenoord chief confident of keeping Liverpool-linked Slot\n\nHowever, Feyenoord chief Dennis te Kloese has insisted that he is confident Slot will remain in charge of the Dutch giants beyond this summer.\n\nResponding to rumours linking Slot with Liverpool, Te Kloese told ESPN: \"I think it is logical that he is in such a good position.\n\n\"It is very special how he has manifested himself in recent years and has really given Feyenoord a face.\n\n\"We responded by extending his contract (in May last year until 2026). In any case, we assume that he will also be our trainer next year.\n\n\"We have experienced this situation before and will take good care of our own interests.\"\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nIn-demand Slot shining at Feyenoord\n\nSlot has enhanced his reputation over the last three seasons in charge of Feyenoord and boasts a 64% win ratio across his 146 games at the helm.\n\nThe Bergentheim-born boss led Feyenoord to the Europa Conference League final and a third-placed finish in the Eredivisie in his first season in charge, before steering the club to their first top-flight title in six years last season.\n\nThis term, Slot's side sit second in the Eredivisie table and nine points behind leaders PSV Eindhoven, but they did secure the KNVB Beker last weekend courtesy of a 1-0 win over NEC in the final.\n\nSlot is believed to be committed to Feyenoord for the time being, but he has previously suggested that he is open to managing aboard.\n\nSpeaking in May 2023 having previously been linked with the Tottenham Hotspur job, Slot said: \"My next step will not be a club in Holland. If that is my next step, then I've failed completely.\n\n\"The normal next step will be to go abroad and I've always said the best league in the world is the Premier League.\"\n\nSlot is currently {"uri": "8094593369", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "09:31:40", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T09:31:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T09:31:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.rousingthekop.com/2024/04/24/what-people-at-liverpool-are-now-fearing-as-they-chase-arne-slot-as-new-manager/", "title": "What people at Liverpool are now fearing as they chase Arne Slot as new manager", "body": "Liverpool look all set to hire Feyenoord manager Arne Slot as the man to replace Jurgen Klopp.\n\nSlot hadn't previously been mentioned as one of the top candidates to succeed Klopp over the summer.\n\nBut after Ruben Amorim was ruled out, Slot has come to the fore-front. Liverpool are reportedly set to 'move fast' to get a deal for the 45-year-old over the line.\n\nNews of Slot's ascension to FSG's first choice may have come as a surprise to many, some of whom may never even have heard of the Dutchman. However, there are said to be plenty of things that Liverpool really like about Slot.\n\nLike any appointment, there are some worries attached, though. And journalist Mark Ogden has shared what the Reds are 'fearing' as they look to make Slot their new manager.\n\nIt remains to be seen exactly how Liverpool fans greet the potential appointment of Slot. So far, the reaction online has largely been something like bemused cautious optimism.\n\nStill, nothing is done quite yet. Although there have been claims in the Netherlands that Slot is already looking for houses on Merseyside, he isn't Liverpool manager just yet.\n\nAnd according to Ogden, there's still a 'fear' from the Reds that the Feyenoord boss may go elsewhere. Speaking to BBC 5 Live's The Tuesday Night Club last night, the journalist said that Bayern Munich and Barcelona might still derail their attempts to get Slot.\n\n\"He is a leading target, and Liverpool feel that he does match their criteria in terms of style of play, his personality and ability to work within the system,\" Ogden reports.\n\n\"Now, people at Liverpool fear that they might have competition from Bayern Munich and Barcelona but he is a serious candidate which I'm a little bit surprised at.\n\n\"They have been looking at Xabi Alonso but he ruled himself out quite quickly and Ruben Amorim, I'm not saying priced himself out of the market, but Liverpool do seem to be looking elsewhere.\"\n\nAs well as a worry that Slot may go elsewhere, there may also be some trepidation from Liverpool supporters that the step up is too big for him. The Reds themselves don't seem to have this worry, or they wouldn't target him in the first place.\n\nBut, continuing his update last night, Ogden questioned whether the former AZ Alkmaar coach was quite the right man for Liverpool.\n\n\"Arne Slot turned down Tottenham last summer, so that was a surprise that turned down a very good Premier League job to stay with Feyenoord,\" he says.\n\n\"So, Liverpool with due respect to Tottenham, is a much bigger club and a much bigger challenge to replace Jurgen Klopp, so you need a big personality to take that job and big credentials and whether Arne Slot is ready, I don't know.\n\nIn our opinion, for Liverpool to go public with the Slot news, they must be confident of beating Bayern and Barca to him. As for whether he's ready, well, we'll probably soon find out.", "source": {"uri": "rousingthekop.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Rousing The Kop"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-04-333052356", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "19:58:38", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T19:58:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T19:58:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.skysports.com/app/transfer/news/12691/13121595/arne-slot-feyenoord-boss-at-forefront-of-liverpools-search-for-jurgen-klopp-successor", "title": "Arne Slot: Feyenoord boss at forefront of Liverpools search for Jurgen Klopp successor", "body": "Sky Sports News's senior reporter Melissa Reddy says Feyenoord's Arne Slot is 'a very strong option' to replace Jurgen Klopp as Liverpool manager.\n\nArne Slot is at the forefront of Liverpool's search for a replacement for Jurgen Klopp.\n\nThe Feyenoord head coach ticks all their key criteria for the position, although Sky Sports News understands the process is not a foregone conclusion, with the Eredivisie club determined to keep Slot.\n\nThere is also interest from other top clubs and Liverpool are still in dialogue with several options, but the 45-year-old is a strong candidate.\n\nTransfer Centre LIVE! | Paper TalkLiverpool news and rumoursStream Sky Sports with NOW | Get Sky SportsGet Sky Sports on WhatsApp | Download the Sky Sports app\n\nSlot, who secured the KNVB Cup last weekend and led Feyenoord to their first title in six years last season, appeals to Liverpool due to his aggressive, full-throttle style.\n\nHe has drilled his team to be adept at turning defensive actions into shooting opportunities and they top the Eredivisie for tackles won in the opposition's final third.\n\nFeyenoord have the best defence in the league and the second-best offensive metrics.\n\nSlot has proved capable of improving individuals as well as the collective, while operating on a smaller budget than his core competitors, and his penchant for a 4-2-3-1 or 4-4-3 formation fits Liverpool's squad.\n\nSlot has previously been approached by Tottenham, Chelsea and Leeds. He signed a new contract last May to keep him at Feyenoord until 2026 but has referenced a desire to make the next step in his career.\n\nCompensation is anticipated to be in the region of \u00a39m if a deal is to be closed.\n\nSporting manager Ruben Amorim was under consideration by Liverpool but sources say he is no longer in the frame, as it stands.\n\nWest Ham are interested in Amorim but Julen Lopetegui, the former Wolves, Real Madrid and Spain boss, and Paulo Fonseca, currently in charge of Lille, are considered the frontrunners.\n\n'Slot brings crazy, sexy football'\n\nSlot took over from Dick Advocaat at Feyenoord for the start of the 21/22 season with the club having finished fifth the previous campaign. Just two years later, they were champions of the Eredivisie. He built a pressing team playing intense, attack-minded football while also being able to win.\n\nEredivisie table | Eredivisie table\n\nFeyenoord are second behind PSV Eindhoven this season, nine points adrift with four games to play. In Europe they finished third in their Champions League group before dropping into the Europa League where they were knocked out by Roma on penalties in February.\n\nSpeaking to Sky Sports Dutch football journalist Marcel van der Kraan said: \"He is the prime candidate for Liverpool. It was only a matter of time before another big English club would come knocking on the door. He's not only been a successful manager, he's also been hugely impressive with his playing style of very attack-minded, Pep Guardiola-style football.\n\n\"I don't expect Feyenoord to stand in the way. They know he's a manager in demand but they will demand a big compensation fee. He has two years left on his contract that was a record deal.\n\n\"Never before in Dutch football has a team paid a manager such huge wages. The players like him, the fans love him, the club love him - they won't want him to go. Feyenoord have every right to demand a big fee as there is no clause in his contract which he renewed last year.\n\n\"He's been a successful coach and made Feyenoord champions playing crazy, sexy football. It is sexy what this man brings on a football pitch. There's nothing more to win for him here. The next step for him is to enter a club in a big league and no league is bigger for the Dutch than the Premier League. I will be surprised if Slot doesn't bite at this chance and become the manger of Liverpool next season.\"\n\nWhat has Slot said about managing in Premier League?\n\nLast summer, Slot was one of the leading contenders for the then-vacant Tottenham manager's role and Sky Sports News reporter Gary Cotterill went to Rotterdam to cover the story.\n\nCotterill found Slot to be \"engaging, polite, very smiley, he's got presence and charisma - and he's funny\" when writing about his trip to get the lowdown on the Feyenoord boss, who has been open about his desire to manage in the Premier League.\n\n\"My next step will not be a club in Holland,\" he said in May 2023.\n\n\"If that is my next step, then I've failed completely. The normal next step will be to go abroad and I've always said the best league in the world is the Premier League.\"\n\nWhat happened with Tottenham's approach for Slot?\n\nSpurs were determined to get Slot last summer after he secured the Eredivisie title with Feyenoord.\n\nHowever, Slot ruled himself out of the running to take over in north London before signing a new contract at Feyenoord a few days later which runs until 2026.\n\n\"I'm not done here yet,\" Slot said after the announcement of his new deal.\n\nTottenham chairman Daniel Levy was keen on securing Arnie Slot last summer\n\nThe potential deal with Spurs never got to any formal stage of discussions with him or Feyenoord and Spurs' bosses felt that Slot used their interest in him to get an improved contract in the Netherlands.\n\nAnge Postecoglou was eventually appointed by Spurs from Celtic.\n\nAd content | Stream Sky Sports on NOW\n\nStream Sky Sports live with no contract on a Month or Day membership on NOW. Meanwhile, The Times has mentioned a fee of around \u00a38.6million.\n\nThis would make him a cheaper option than Amorim, whose release clause is said to be \u00a312.8million.\n\nWhat can Liverpool fans expect from Arne Slot?\n\nSlot joined Feyenoord in 2021 after impressing at AZ, and continued to go from strength to strength in Rotterdam. The 45-year-old won the Eredivisie title last year and has won the Dutch Cup this season.\n\nHowever, Slot's silverware-winning efforts only tell half the story. He certainly ticks the boxes in terms of what he can bring to Liverpool tactics-wise.\n\nReddy wrote on Sky Sports that Slot 'has drilled his team to be adept at turning defensive actions into shooting opportunities and they top the Eredivisie for tackles won in the opposition's final third.\n\n'Feyenoord have the best defence in the league and the second-best offensive metrics.\n\n'Slot has proved capable of improving individuals as well as the collective, while operating on a smaller budget than his core competitors, and his penchant for a 4-2-3-1 or 4-4-3 formation fits Liverpool's squad.'\n\nFeyenoord's Alireza Jahanbakhsh, formerly of Brighton & Hove Albion, has sung the 45-year-old's praises on a couple of occasions.\n\n\"During my time at AZ, as assistant coach, Arne Slot, was one of the people who helped me to become a better player,\" he said in 2021 following his move to Feyenoord, as reported by The Argus.\n\n\"So when he called and asked if I wanted to come to Feyenoord, I told him I was going to do everything I could to make this transfer. I had no doubts.\"\n\nIn a further interview, the Iran international labelled Slot as \"the best\" in the Netherlands and one of the best managers he's ever worked with.\n\n\"He is one of the best managers I've ever seen,\" he said, as per The Athletic. \"In football terms, even the best. He signed a new contract last May to keep him at Feyenoord until 2026 but has referenced a desire to make the next step in his career.\n\nCompensation is anticipated to be in the region of \u00a39m if a deal is to be closed.\n\nSporting manager Ruben Amorim was under consideration by Liverpool but sources say he is no longer in the frame, as it stands.\n\nWest Ham are interested in Amorim but Julen Lopetegui, the former Wolves, Real Madrid and Spain boss, and Paulo Fonseca, currently in charge of Lille, are considered the frontrunners.\n\nLast summer, Slot was one of the leading contenders for the then-vacant Tottenham manager's role and Sky Sports News reporter Gary Cotterill went to Rotterdam to cover the story.\n\nCotterill found Slot to be \"engaging, polite, very smiley, he's got presence and charisma - and he's funny\" when writing about his trip to get the lowdown on the Feyenoord boss, who has been open about his desire to manage in the Premier League.\n\n\"My next step will not be a club in Holland,\" he said in May 2023.\n\n\"If that is my next step, then I've failed completely. The 'charismatic rap aficionado' now favourite to replace Jurgen Klopp at Liverpool", "body": "Meet Arne Slot, the Feyenoord boss who is being tipped to replace Jurgen Klopp at Liverpool.\n\nBack in January, the world of football was shaken to its core when Liverpool boss Klopp announced his decision to leave the club at the end of the 23/24 season.\n\nThe likes of Xabi Alonso, Ruben Amorim, Roberto De Zerbi and Thomas Tuchel have since been linked with a move to Anfield.\n\nHowever, Alonso revealed last month that he will be staying at Bayer Leverkusen, whilst recent reports indicate that Amrorim moving to Liverpool is unlikely.\n\nMeanwhile, the odds on Slot replacing Klopp have been dropping by the day. So who exactly is the highly-rated Dutchman?\n\nDuring his playing days, the 45-year old played for the likes of FC Zwolle, NAC Breda, Sparta Rotterdam and PEC Zwolle.\n\nAfter retiring in 2013, Slot became a youth team coach at PEC Zwolle before moving to SC Cambuur as an assistant coach.\n\nSlot eventually became the head coach at AZ Alkmaar before COVID-19 hampered his first season in charge.\n\nIn 2020, Slot was sacked after negotiating a deal to take over at Feyernoord.\n\nUnder Slot, Feyenoord finished third in the Eredivisie during his first season in charge, he also took them to the final of the Europa Conference League, in which the Rotterdam club lost to Jose Mourinho's AS Roma.\n\nLast season, he led the club to their first league title since 2017.\n\nSlot has been praised for his presence and charisma, as well as his exciting style of football.\n\nThe former midfielder has also been compared to Pep Guardiola, according to Dutch football journalist Marcel van der Kraan, who said: \"He's a really good manager and sometimes it can come fast and quick. I've followed Feyenoord for 40 years. Not since the days of Johan Cruyff at Ajax in the 1980s has there been a coach so attack-minded in the Dutch league. Cruyff only had a few disciples who followed him and one of them was Pep Guardiola.\n\n\"I would say Slot is a Guardiola-style manager based on everything I've seen over the past couple of years. But Dutchman Slot, 45, is also of interest to Bayern Munich, along with Ralf Rangnick and Roberto de Zerbi, as the German champions look to land Thomas Tuchel's successor.\n\nLiverpool are now making their move though and talks are set to proceed on what settlement package the Eredivisie club will want for their manager, who has a contract with just under two years to run. It's understood that figure will be around \u00a38.6m but talks will take place.\n\nThe fact Liverpool are now opening talks with Feyenoord suggests they've heard the right noises from Slot that he wants to move to Anfield. They've pinpointed the Dutchman as their perfect candidate to replace Klopp due to his ability to improve players and his aggressive, high-octane playing style.\n\nThe Reds had been linked with Bayer Leverkusen boss Xabi Alonso but never really believed he would leave the new Bundesliga champions and last month he confirmed he is staying in Germany. Sporting Lisbon boss Ruben Amorim - another strongly linked with Liverpool - has held discussions with West Ham but is reportedly not currently keen on a move to the London Stadium.\n\nBrighton boss De Zerbi is another on Liverpool's list but Slot is now the most likely. The Dutch manager led Feyenoord to the Eredivisie title last season and won the Dutch cup this term by beating NEC on Sunday.\n\nThey are currently nine points off leaders PSV in this season's title battle with just four games to go so will be relinquishing their Eredivisie crown. They finished third in their Champions League group this season and exited the Europa League after defeat by Roma in February.\n\nArne Slot is the frontrunner to take over at Liverpool\n\nWill Arne Slot be a good appointment for Liverpool? Share your thoughts in the comments below\n\nLiverpool executive Michael Edwards and sporting director Richard Hughes continue to lead the search for Klopp's successor alongside data analyst Will Spearman. Slot was on Tottenham's shortlist last summer before he opted to stay in Holland and Spurs went for Ange Postecoglou.\n\nHe has been backed by Dutch legend Marco van Basten to be a success outside of his homeland. Van Basten said: \"I think Slot is really good. I hope he stays in the Netherlands longer, because it is an enrichment for Dutch football.\n\n\"He can really go anywhere: Bayern Munich, Liverpool... I'm really convinced of that. I hope he stays in the Netherlands, but I am convinced he can do it anywhere. I've spoken to him a few times, and he handles the players very well. Of course, he is also very well versed tactically.\n\n\"I can explain his ideas well; he is calm and intelligent. As far as I am concerned, he is a top trainer. I really think he can go to any club, even difficult clubs. He is very smart in his choice of words.\"\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community and receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. The Feyenoord chief is understood to be open to heading to Anfield despite gaining additional interest from Barcelona and Bayern Munich. Respected journalist Dean Jones believes Liverpool are attempting to prove to Sporting head coach Ruben Amorim that he is not the only contender for the job.\n\nLiverpool have admitted that Arne Slot is a 'contender' to succeed Jurgen Klopp in the Anfield dugout, and journalist Dean Jones has told GIVEMESPORT that the Merseyside giants may have been open in their pursuit of the Feyenoord head coach in a bid to hurry Sporting chief Ruben Amorim into making a decision over his future.\n\nThe Reds have been frustrated in their attempts to identify the ideal candidate to be installed as their next manager as Xabi Alonso confirmed that he will be remaining with the newly-crowed Bundesliga champions Bayer Leverkusen instead of embarking on a fresh challenge with one of his former employers.\n\nFenway Sports Group's chief executive of football Michael Edwards and incoming sporting director Richard Hughes have been leading the search since being handed crucial behind the scenes roles, and time is ticking before Klopp walks away from the Premier League title-chasers next month.\n\nSlot Earmarked as Leading Contender to Secure Reds Role\n\nSlot has emerged as the clear frontrunner to move into the Liverpool hot-seat during the summer as Edwards and Hughes have pinpointed him as the first-choice option to replace Klopp, according to the Telegraph, and the interest will intensify over the course of the coming days even though Feyenoord are desperate to retain his services.\n\nThe report suggests that the Dutch tactician, who has led his current employers to 93 wins from 144 matches at the helm, is enthusiastic about the prospect of building on the success enjoyed under Klopp despite also gaining interest from La Liga heavyweights Barcelona and Bundesliga giants Bayern Munich.\n\nArne Slot's managerial record in the Eredivisie this season compared to Jurgen Klopp in the Premier League\n\nArne Slot\n\nJurgen of 23/04/2024\n\nIt is understood that Liverpool have contacted Slot in a bid to discover whether he is willing to head to the Premier League for the first time in his managerial career, while there
