course of a league campaign during his senior managerial career, while he has won the title on one occasion with Feyenoord\n\nDean Jones - Slot Pursuit Shows Amorim is Not in Control of Situation\n\nHaving told GIVEMESPORT that Slot came to light as a candidate for the Liverpool job over the course of the weekend, Jones has been informed by figures within the Premier League high-flyers that the 45-year-old is firmly on their radar and their interest is increasing as they continue assessing their options.\n\nBut the respected journalist has refused to rule out the possibility of the Reds attempting to put pressure on Sporting head coach Amorim, who has been described as 'outstanding' by Portugal-based reporter Tom Kundert, by emphasising that they will not wait for a final decision and publicly conceding that they are chasing Feyenoord's boss.\n\nJones told GIVEMESPORT:\n\n\"We reported on Tuesday how Arne Slot had emerged as a name in Liverpool's view and was becoming more serious, and that has accelerated to the point of briefings from the club that he is a contender for the job.\n\n\"It is pretty rare to get such a clear indicator of a manager being considered, so I am also slightly sceptical of the reasons behind any such leak of information.\n\n\"The latest reports also point out that other candidates are being considered and, at a time when Ruben Amorim is not yet discarded as an option, the cynic in me wonders if this is a little message to let him know that he cannot dictate how this managerial situation plays out.\"\n\nFenway Sports Group Learn Slot Compensation Package\n\nFeyenoord are seeking a \u00a38.59million compensation package for Slot, according to MailOnline, and the KNVB Cup winners will not entertain the possibility of Slot leaving their dugout unless Liverpool are willing to meet their demands ahead of the 2024/25 campaign getting underway.\n\nThe report suggests that the Dutch giants are willing to allow the former AZ Alkmaar chief to move on, despite him leading the Rotterdam-based outfit to the Eredivisie title last season, as they have become increasingly frustrated with his agent Rafaela Pimenta regularly offering him to other clubs.\n\nAll statistics courtesy of Transfermarkt\n\nRelated How Liverpool Could Raise Over \u00a3170m This Summer Without Selling Mo Salah It looks to be a big summer {"uri": "8093558230", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "17:46:09", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T17:46:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T17:46:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.dailystar.co.uk/sport/football/arne-slot-next-liverpool-manager-32654830", "title": "Meet Arne Slot - what he offers Liverpool, his philosophy and how much he'd cost", "body": "Liverpool's focus in their search for Jurgen Klopp's replacement has turned to highly-rated Dutchman Arne Slot.\n\nKlopp, 56, announced he was stepping down in January, and the Reds have been on the hunt for a new boss ever since. Xabi Alonso and Ruben Amorim have both been linked, and the latest name is Feyenoord manager Slot.\n\nThe 45-year-old has now emerged as a top choice for the Reds to replace Klopp this summer - and he's only added further fuel to the fire by cancelling a press conference in his home country. And off the back of the interest from Liverpool, Daily Star Sport takes a look at the Dutchman's pedigree.\n\nREAD MORE: Arne Slot's Feyenoord press conference cancelled as link to Liverpool emerges\n\nREAD MORE: Arne Slot could become next Liverpool manager with club having scoured Europe\n\nSlot had a middle of the road playing career in his native Netherlands that saw him represent a number of mid-table Eredivise sides. And after hanging up his boots in 2013, Slot embarked into career in management.\n\nAfter numerous roles as a youth coach and an assistant, Slot received his first top job with AZ Alkmaar in 2019. He would last just one season in Alkmaar before moving to Eredivise giants Feyenoord in the summer of 2020.\n\nWhat do you think of Arne Slot being linked with the Liverpool job? Let us know in the comments section\n\nSlot has been a revelation in Rotterdam, restoring the once faltering side to their former glory. He took them to the Europa Conference League final in 2021/22 season, missing out on gold to Jose Mourinho's Roma.\n\nHowever, the good times would soon start to roll - first there was the Eredivise title last season, and he then the claimed the KNVB Cup earlier this year. Slot's brand of football relies on wingers, much like Klopp, and he likes his side to press.\n\nSpeaking to UEFA, Slot explained about his style at Feyenoord: \"We are an attack-minded team that likes to have a lot of the ball, and we play with a lot of intensity.\n\n\"When we don't have the ball, we want to win it back as quickly as possible by being aggressive and pressing to win back possession. I think we are a team that is difficult to beat.\"\n\nSlot has also drawn comparisons to Marcelo Bielsa, the former Leeds United manager who ended their Premier League exile in 2020, thanks to tactics of pushing his full-backs high up the pitch and commanding his centre-backs to move wider.\n\nHowever, unlike Bielsa, and more like Klopp, Slot is seen as a player-manager rather than a tactician. \"He puts his arm around them,\" Dennis van Eersel, of Dutch national TV channel RTV said, \"they like him because he's built a harmony at the club!\"\n\nSlot doesn't have a release clause in his current Feyenoord deal, which expires in 2026, but, according to The Times a fee of less than \u20ac10million euros (\u00a38.6million) could be enough to pry him away from the Netherlands. In comparison, Amorim's release clause is valued at nearer \u00a313m.\n\nLiverpool are back in action on Wednesday evening, as they make the short trip to Goodison Park for the Merseyside Derby.", He is the first choice of Fenway Sports Group chief Michael Edwards and incoming director of football Richard Hughes.\n\nSpeaking ahead of Feyenoord's match against Go Ahead Eagles on Thursday night, the 45-year-old told ESPN: \"I'd like to become new Liverpool manager, my decisions is clear. Feyenoord and Liverpool are in talks to negotiate, I'm waiting to see what will come out of it. I am confident, waiting for the clubs to reach an agreement.\"\n\nTalks are ongoing because Slot has two years left on his Feyenoord deal and it is understood it will cost around \u00a38.6million in compensation for Liverpool to hire him this summer. The Dutch club are consigned to losing their manager and have identified FC Twente boss Joseph Oosting as a target to replace him.\n\nSlot had earlier chosen to avoid answering questions about his links to Liverpool when he was approached by a reporter when getting off the team bus in Deventer. But, having failed to reach an agreement with Tottenham last summer, he appears destined for the Premier League.\n\nThat has always been the plan for the ambitious coach, who admitted last year: \"The next step will not be another club in Holland. If that is the next step, I've failed completely in the upcoming few years. A normal next step would be to go abroad and I've always said that the best league in the world is the Premier League.\"\n\nHAVE YOUR SAY! Is Arne Slot the right man for Liverpool? Comment below.\n\nKlopp announced back in January that he would step down as Liverpool manager at the end of the season, ending his eight-and-a-half-year stint as boss. Xabi Alonso was initially considered the frontrunner for the position, but the former Liverpool midfielder later committed himself to staying with Bayer Leverkusen.\n\nSporting Lisbon manager Ruben Amorim is another who has been linked, but Slot has jumped to the front of the queue. He guided Feyenoord to the Eredivisie title last year and has claimed the Dutch Cup this campaign and his playing style is considered similar to Klopp's.\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community and receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. {"uri": "8094660683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "10:11:22", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T10:11:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T10:11:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://theathletic.com/5441134/2024/04/24/liverpool-next-manager-arne-slot/", "title": "Liverpool make Slot preferred choice to succeed Klopp", "body": "Liverpool have made Arne Slot their preferred choice to succeed Jurgen Klopp when the manager leaves this summer.\n\nThe Anfield club's pursuit of Slot did not emerge until earlier this week as they prioritised discretion and a desire to show Feyenoord respect before Sunday's Dutch Cup final, which they won.\n\nThat approach is sure to be maintained as Liverpool enter negotiations with the 2023 Eredivisie champions and their highly-regarded CEO Dennis te Kloese.\n\nThey are also in contact with Slot, who is enthusiastic about the possibility of moving to Merseyside.\n\nLiverpool are conducting a thorough process and will continue to assess other candidates, although Slot is the focus of their attention at present having emerged as the leading contender to succeed Klopp.\n\nKlopp announced in January he would be leaving the club at the end of the season after nine years.\n\nSlot helped guide Feyenoord to just a second Eredivisie title in 20 years last season and has the side second in the table at present.\n\nLiverpool started the head coach search back in November with Fenway Sports Group's CEO of football Michael Edwards and new sporting director Richard Hughes now leading the process.\n\nSlot's attacking style of play and track record of developing young talent match the criteria set out by the club with Xabi Alonso of Bayer Leverkusen and Sporting Lisbon's Ruben Amorim among those also considered.\n\nSlot, who turned down Tottenham Hotspur last year, has no release clause in his current contract that runs until 2026.", "source": {"uri": "theathletic.com", {"uri": "8093710071", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "20:05:16", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T20:05:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T20:04:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/arne-slot-guardiola-disciple-coaches-200101839.html", "title": "Who is Arne Slot? The Guardiola disciple who coaches like Mikel Arteta", "body": "Arne Slot is the disciple of Pep Guardiola who has strong similarities to Mikel Arteta and Roberto De Zerbi in the way he coaches and the intense playing style he demands.\n\nSlot's Feyenoord side play some of the most exciting, entertaining, high-energy, attacking football on the Continent. It should come as little surprise then that Liverpool are interested in hiring him as J\u00fcrgen Klopp's successor - with Slot a friend of Klopp's assistant Pep Lijnders, who is also leaving Anfield.\n\nThe 45-year-old former midfielder is renowned for his precise coaching methods and his attention to detail. So precise is he that that the 'rondo' - the training drill whereby players attempt to keep the ball while a smaller group aim to intercept - is made extremely specific at Feyenoord.\n\nSlot is concerned the drill does not allow players to 'scan' (to check the options on the pitch) which is one of the fundamentals of passing and so he insists that they can take only one touch, that they cannot return possession to the player who passed to them and, crucially, that the ball always stays below the knee. Players are even encouraged to consider which foot they are passing with.\n\nTelegraph Sport learnt this, as Slot led Feyenoord last year to only their second Dutch league title this century, after being given detailed access into the way he works and his methodology - and ambition.\n\nThis campaign Feyenoord have won the Dutch Cup and are second to PSV Eindhoven in the league - although it should be factored in that he is operating with a fraction of his rivals' finances and also those of Ajax, who are 24 points behind.\n\nFeyenoord may traditionally be the third biggest club in the Netherlands but that gives a false impression. They are far behind the Dutch giants in terms of budget and had been, in recent years, frankly one of its most boring, defensive teams especially under Slot's predecessor Dick Advocaat. How that has changed.\n\nLiverpool are not the first Premier League club to take an interest in Slot who joined Feyenoord from AZ Alkmaar in 2021. But Liverpool are clearly the biggest and most serious proposition. Leeds United tried to hire him in February 2023 after sacking Jesse Marsch (and he would be a natural successor to Marcelo Bielsa) but Slot stayed in Rotterdam.\n\nTottenham Hotspur then made a move before they eventually brought in Ange Postecoglou - with Slot surprisingly deciding to stay at Feyenoord and signing a new contract.\n\nGiven that Feyenoord's style of play is so demanding, it is impressive they suffer so few injuries - in contrast to Leeds under Bielsa, which is why Feyenoord were so interested in Slot.\n\nThe demanding attention to detail is a theme. For example, Slot has concluded that in training sessions for the days immediately after games the players should work in a space no longer than 40 metres. If they play in bigger areas it means they have to accelerate more and sports medical science has proved that running above 20kmph risks more muscle injuries.\n\nSlot does not play games of 11 vs 11 in training as most coaches do and works hard on the mental side of the sport. He has even convinced the Feyenoord players that the more games they play the stronger they will become.\n\nIt does feel that it is only a matter of time before Slot makes his move to England. There is, of course, an obvious comparison with Manchester United's Erik ten Hag who moved from Ajax, and there is always that concern over how Dutch coaches fare outside of the Eredivisie which is clearly not one of Europe's strongest leagues.\n\nYet Liverpool will certainly have run the numbers and the data on Slot, who now has Champions League experience beating Celtic and Lazio but failing to get through the group, and will have been impressed by what they have seen. Not least because his football and pressing game is far more attacking than Ten Hag's. Interestingly when Ten Hag won the league with Ajax it was Slot who won the Rinus Michels Award for Eredivisie manager of the season.\n\nRecommended\n\nStatistics that show why Slot may be perfect fit for Liverpool\n\nRead more\n\nFeyenoord finished third in Slot's first campaign - they were fifth the season before. They subsequently were first and are now second. But that does not provide the full picture as Slot completely overhauled their negative playing style. The club wanted him to do it and, interestingly so did the players, with the coach exploding the myth that 'you can only work with what you have got'. Instead, with a fierce pressing game in which Feyenoord go man-for-man with their opponents all over the pitch, he showed that players can change.\n\nInterestingly it was one of his main motivations for joining Feyenoord: to show the world it can be done.\n\nFor example in Slot's first team meeting he played clips of the 2021 Champions League final between Chelsea and Manchester City and asked the simple question: why were there so few chances despite there being so many good attacking players?\n\nThe answer was equally as simple: it was because all those attackers also made incredible defensive runs to nullify their opponents. Slot then contrasted that with the lack of running Feyenoord had completed the season before and compared the distance covered - far less - to his previous AZ side.\n\nHis approach was also simple - as is his mantra: his teams defend by attacking. While Klopp's Liverpool wait for 'pressing triggers' Slot asks his players to press all the time which sounds exhausting but, after a few weeks, he believes becomes second nature.\n\nThe next part of that is to try to control games by emphasising ball possession which is straight out of Guardiola's play-book.\n\nSlot believes that more defensive football - as espoused by Jose Mourinho - is not only more tiring but less stimulating for the players. He argues they cannot improve by primarily thinking about defending.\n\nIn the Netherlands they call it indoctrineren (indoctrinate) and Slot bombarded the players with stats, with clips and with far more sophisticated and intense training sessions in which every minute is accounted for. It is a clear 'train-the-way-you-play' approach.\n\nImportantly, Slot has achieved all of this on a shoestring - Feyenoord have made significant money in the transfer market every season he has been there - and he has undoubtedly improved players and their value. He likes to work primarily with young players and is popular in the dressing room. There is an inherent risk, given the league he would be coming from, but Slot certainly appears to fit the mould of a 'head coach' whose priority is the training pitch, which Liverpool want, rather than a manager in their new structure led by Michael Edwards and director of football Richard Hughes.\n\nArne Slot and his methods\n\nSlot's Feyenoord were built on a shoestring but delivered fierce pressing and exciting attacking football", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports Canada"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Talk of R\u00faben Amorim taking over has cooled while there is a chance that the option decided on could be more left field.\n\nIn recent days, one name has shot up the odds for the job to become one of the new favorites: Arne Slot. And now, according to The Times, Slot is a 'leading candidate' for Liverpool.\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool Academy star has earned 'trusted player' status and it could affect transfer plan\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool 'agrees Nike to Adidas kit switch' for 2025/26 as FSG set to surpass $61m figure\n\nFeyenoord boss Slot, 45, has compiled a strong body of work in the Netherlands and won the Eredivisie last season. His high-pressing style of play and proven track record of improving players are said to have impressed the Reds. This year, Feyenoord is second in the league standings but has won the Dutch cup.\n\nSlot has impressed since making his move into management. An attacking midfielder during his playing days, in which he turned out for FC Zwolle, NAC Breda, Sparta Rotterdam and PEC Zwolle, he became a youth coach at the latter of those clubs upon his retirement in 2013 before becoming an assistant at Cambuur.\n\nIn 2016, he was made interim coach alongside Sipke Hulshoff of the Leeuwarden-based side, before leaving the club the following year to become John van den Brom's assistant at AZ Alkmaar. He would then go on to succeed Van den Brom as the club's head coach.\n\nHis first season in charge was brought to a premature end by the COVID-19 pandemic, with AZ only trailing leaders Ajax on goal difference with nine games remaining before the campaign was abandoned. His work at the club though was attracting interest from Feyenoord, and later that year, he was sacked by AZ after negotiating a deal with the Rotterdam club.\n\nLiverpool home shirt 2023/2024 Get the Liverpool home kit\n\nLiverpool's home shirt for the 2023/2024 campaign pays homage to Bill Shankly and the legendary Reds manager's final season in charge at Anfield. The Nike shirt features a bright red design with a bold white contrast on the colour and cuffs.\n\nPrices start from \u00a359.95\n\nNike Get it here\n\nSlot's first season at Feyenoord saw them finish third behind Ajax and PSV, while also reaching the final of the Europa Conference League, where they were beaten by Jos\u00e9 Mourinho's Roma. His second season would see Feyenoord clinch its first Eredivisie title since 2017, and also lead to Slot being linked with a move to the Premier League.\n\nHe was touted for the vacant Tottenham job last summer, having also reportedly been in the running for the Leeds United job earlier in the year. Slot though would end up signing a new deal at Feyenoord, keeping him at the club until 2026.\n\nSlot's attacking brand of football has caught the eye in recent years, and has also seen him compared with Pep Guardiola (via TalkSport). What's more, he has already earmarked the Premier League as his next destination.\n\n\"My next step will not be a club in Holland,\" he said last year (via Sky Sports). \"If that is my next step, then I've failed completely. The normal next step will be to go abroad and I've always said the best league in the world is the Premier League.\"\n\nAnd when asked about the possibility of becoming Liverpool boss following Klopp's announcement in January, Slot didn't exactly rule it out. \"What answer can I give that there will be no headlines about it? So next question!\" Slot said, via Voetbal Primeur.\n\nWith the 45-year-old already keen on a move to the Premier League, he could be a name to keep an eye on over the coming weeks. {"uri": "8095151182", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "15:04:54", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T15:04:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T15:04:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpool-two-key-advantages-arne-29051818", "title": "Liverpool's two key advantages in Arne Slot talks after Premier League rejection", "body": "Most coaches would adore the chance to manage Liverpool, but only a few will lick their lips at being the first man in after Jurgen Klopp.\n\nWith Xabi Alonso staying at Bayer Leverkusen and Ruben Amorim seemingly unlikely to move to Anfield, the ECHO understands that Liverpool are in talks with Feyenoord regarding Arne Slot. The Dutchman, 45, won the Eredivisie last May and lifted the Dutch Cup three days ago.\n\nThis, perhaps unsurprisingly, is not the first time Slot has been tipped for a move to the Premier League. He was linked with Leeds United when Jesse Marsch was sacked last year, before penning a new deal with Feyenoord to waive off interest at Tottenham, ahead of Ange Postecoglou's appointment.\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool new manager latest as Feyenoord boss Arne Slot becomes leading contender\n\nREAD MORE: I know why Xabi Alonso turned down Liverpool - it's a job with dangers\n\nLiverpool are in a better position to lure Slot than Leeds and Spurs ever were, not least due to the global scale of the club. Both white-clad clubs were being linked mid-season, something that the manager was not a fan of.\n\nSpeaking last year, he said: \"I think Leeds is a very nice club. The moment in the middle of the season, where you still have so much to play for at Feyenoord, I didn't think that was a good time to leave for England.\"\n\nThere is a feeling Slot is coming to the end of his cycle at Feyenoord after three years at the helm, during which a Premier League switch has infrequently been touted. He previously underlined he wishes to leave his club \"in a positive way\".\n\nHaving won the cup after last year's league success, the summer might be the perfect time to bow out - which is Liverpool's start date. Timing is on FSG's side.\n\nSlot has always been open about his revere for the Premier League. He told ESPN only a year ago: \"I think that at some point there will come a time when, as a trainer, you will also look abroad... The Premier League is of course the number one competition in Europe.\"\n\nA month later, he went on to state: \"A normal next step would be to go abroad and I've always said that the best league in the world is the Premier League.\"\n\nLiverpool, of course, fit that profile and some. But there is another admission of his that puts the Reds in a strong position and gives them an advantage Spurs and Leeds clearly do not boast.\n\nSlot said: \"There are always clubs that come along that - if it were up to me - you can't say 'no' to.\"\n\nLiverpool would surely be one of them, offering a job that few managers could resist - and perhaps for Slot, one he cannot turn down, even if it means coming in after Klopp.", "source": {"uri": "liverpoolecho.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Liverpool Echo"}, "authors": [{"uri": "isaac_johnson@liverpoolecho.co.uk", "name": "Isaac {"uri": "8093732947", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "20:25:37", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T20:25:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T20:25:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2024/04/23/liverpool-arne-slot-guardiola-disciple-coaches-arteta/", "title": "Who is Arne Slot? The Guardiola disciple who coaches like Mikel Arteta", "body": "Slot, who bombards his players with statistics, won the Dutch Cup at the weekend while operating with a fraction of his rivals' finances\n\nArne Slot is the disciple of Pep Guardiola who has strong similarities to Mikel Arteta and Roberto De Zerbi in the way he coaches and the intense playing style he demands.\n\nSlot's Feyenoord side play some of the most exciting, entertaining, high-energy, attacking football on the Continent. It should come as little surprise then that Liverpool are interested in hiring him as J\u00fcrgen Klopp's successor - with Slot a friend of Klopp's assistant Pep Lijnders, who is also leaving Anfield.\n\nThe 45-year-old former midfielder is renowned for his precise coaching methods and his attention to detail. So precise is he that that the 'rondo' - the training drill whereby players attempt to keep the ball while a smaller group aim to intercept - is made extremely specific at Feyenoord.\n\nSlot is concerned the drill does not allow players to 'scan' (to check the options on the pitch) which is one of the fundamentals of passing and so he insists that they can take only one touch, that they cannot return possession to the player who passed to them and, crucially, that the ball always stays below the knee. Players are even encouraged to consider which foot they are passing with.\n\nTelegraph Sport learnt this, as Slot led Feyenoord last year to only their second Dutch league title this century, after being given detailed access into the way he works and his methodology - and ambition.\n\nThis campaign Feyenoord have won the Dutch Cup and are second to PSV Eindhoven in the league - although it should be factored in that he is operating with a fraction of his rivals' finances and also those of Ajax, who are 24 points behind.\n\nFeyenoord may traditionally be the third biggest club in the Netherlands but that gives a false impression. They are far behind the Dutch giants in terms of budget and had been, in recent years, frankly one of its most boring, defensive teams especially under Slot's predecessor Dick Advocaat. How that has changed.\n\nDutchman long fancied by English clubs\n\nLiverpool are not the first Premier League club to take an interest in Slot who joined Feyenoord from AZ Alkmaar in 2021. But Liverpool are clearly the biggest and most serious proposition. Leeds United tried to hire him in February 2023 after sacking Jesse Marsch (and he would be a natural successor to Marcelo Bielsa) but Slot stayed in Rotterdam.\n\nTottenham Hotspur then made a move before they eventually brought in Ange Postecoglou - with Slot surprisingly deciding to stay at Feyenoord and signing a new contract.\n\nGiven that Feyenoord's style of play is so demanding, it is impressive they suffer so few injuries - in contrast to Leeds under Bielsa, which is why Feyenoord were so interested in Slot.\n\nSlot's eye for detail fuels Feyenoord success\n\nThe demanding attention to detail is a theme. For example, Slot has concluded that in training sessions for the days immediately after games the players should work in a space no longer than 40 metres. If they play in bigger areas it means they have to accelerate more and sports medical science has proved that running above 20kmph risks more muscle injuries.\n\nSlot does not play games of 11 vs 11 in training as most coaches do and works hard on the mental side of the sport. He has even convinced the Feyenoord players that the more games they play the stronger they will become.\n\nIt does feel that it is only a matter of time before Slot makes his move to England. There is, of course, an obvious comparison with Manchester United's Erik ten Hag who moved from Ajax, and there is always that concern over how Dutch coaches fare outside of the Eredivisie which is clearly not one of Europe's strongest leagues.\n\nYet Liverpool will certainly have run the numbers and the data on Slot, who now has Champions League experience beating Celtic and Lazio but failing to get through the group, and will have been impressed by what they have seen. Not least because his football and pressing game is far more attacking than Ten Hag's. Interestingly when Ten Hag won the league with Ajax it was Slot who won the Rinus Michels Award for Eredivisie manager of the season.\n\nRecommended\n\nStatistics that show why Slot may be perfect fit for Liverpool Read more\n\nFeyenoord finished third in Slot's first campaign - they were fifth the season before. They subsequently were first and are now second. But that does not provide the full picture as Slot completely overhauled their negative playing style. The club wanted him to do it and, interestingly so did the players, with the coach exploding the myth that 'you can only work with what you have got'. Instead, with a fierce pressing game in which Feyenoord go man-for-man with their opponents all over the pitch, he showed that players can change.\n\nInterestingly it was one of his main motivations for joining Feyenoord: to show the world it can be done.\n\nFor example in Slot's first team meeting he played clips of the 2021 Champions League final between Chelsea and Manchester City and asked the simple question: why were there so few chances despite there being so many good attacking players?\n\nThe answer was equally as simple: it was because all those attackers also made incredible defensive runs to nullify their opponents. Slot then contrasted that with the lack of running Feyenoord had completed the season before and compared the distance covered - far less - to his previous AZ side.\n\nHis approach was also simple - as is his mantra: his teams defend by attacking. While Klopp's Liverpool wait for 'pressing triggers' Slot asks his players to press all the time which sounds exhausting but, after a few weeks, he believes becomes second nature.\n\nThe next part of that is to try to control games by emphasising ball possession which is straight out of Guardiola's play-book.\n\nSlot believes that more defensive football - as espoused by Jose Mourinho - is not only more tiring but less stimulating for the players. He argues they cannot improve by primarily thinking about defending.\n\nIn the Netherlands they call it indoctrineren (indoctrinate) and Slot bombarded the players with stats, with clips and with far more sophisticated and intense training sessions in which every minute is accounted for. It is a clear 'train-the-way-you-play' approach.\n\nImportantly, Slot has achieved all of this on a shoestring - Feyenoord have made significant money in the transfer market every season he has been there - and he has undoubtedly improved players and their value. He likes to work primarily with young players and is popular in the dressing room. There is an inherent risk, given the league he would be coming from, but Slot certainly appears to fit the mould of a 'head coach' whose priority is the training pitch, which Liverpool want, rather than a manager in their new structure led by Michael Edwards and director of football Richard Hughes.\n\nArne Slot and his methods\n\nSlot's Feyenoord were built on a shoestring but delivered fierce pressing and exciting attacking football Read more", "source": {"uri": "telegraph.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Telegraph"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jason_burt@telegraph.co.uk", "name": {"uri": "2024-04-333470314", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "06:52:30", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T06:52:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T16:53:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.liverpool.com/liverpool-fc-news/features/arne-slot-feyenoord-record-liverpool-29047793", "title": "Arne Slot record assessed as Feyenoord boss leading next Liverpool manager race", "body": "Liverpool has been searching extensively for a new manager to take charge at Anfield. J\u00fcrgen Klopp has just five matches left at the helm and Feyenoord boss Arne Slot has emerged as a leading contender to take over from him.\n\nEarlier in the week, The Athletic reported that Sporting CP head coach R\u00faben Amorim was increasingly unlikely to be the man chosen to replace Klopp. And now it has emerged that Slot is the preferred option for the Reds.\n\nLiverpool has been impressed by Slot's high-intensity team and his style of play, according to The Times, as well as the Dutchman's track record of improving the players he has at his disposal. But just how good is he?\n\nREAD MORE: What Arne Slot 'thinks about Liverpool' having previously 'turned down' Tottenham and Chelsea\n\nREAD MORE: 'I've spoken to Arne Slot and he would be a really good J\u00fcrgen Klopp replacement at Liverpool'\n\nFeyenoord won the league title last season, having only previously won it once this century. This year, the Eredivisie side sits second in the table. PSV is the runaway leader, ahead by nine points with four matches left to play.\n\nBut Slot has picked up silverware again, beating NEC Nijmegen (the team that Pep Lijnders briefly managed) in the Dutch cup final last weekend. Brazilian forward Igor Paix\u00e3o scored the only goal of the game.\n\nIn the 146 matches that Slot has overseen at Feyenoord since taking over in 2021, he has won 94 times and lost 23, giving him a win rate of just under two-thirds. In that period, his side has scored 329 goals (an average of 2.25 per game) and conceded 147, which is marginally over one per game.\n\nSlot had 58 matches in charge of AZ Alkmaar prior to that where he won 32 times (55 per cent win ratio). He managed them in Europe (both the Europa League and the Champions League) and finished second to Ajax in the season that was curtailed due to COVID. He beat Napoli with Alkmaar but was fired because the club was annoyed with him for flirting with a move to Feyenoord.\n\nAt AZ Alkmaar, Slot picked up more points per game than any other coach in the club's history. He took them into European competition and punched above his weight before earning the move to Feyenoord where he has been similarly as successful at squeezing the most out of his resources.\n\nLiverpool.com says: Slot is quite clearly a very talented coach and he knows how to get the most from a group of players. The challenge will be doing that at Anfield where the pressure to succeed is much larger and there are many more things to deal with. Liverpool has a good structure around the head coach which should help, but it will still be a big step up.", "source": {"uri": "liverpool.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Liverpool"}, "authors": [{"uri": "matt_addison@liverpool.com", "name": "Matt Addison", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arne_Slot", "type": "person", "score": 5, New contact to follow soon with Slot keen on #LFC job. Understand there's NO release clause included into his contract; Feyenoord would request compensation fee as they did with Tottenham one year ago.\"\n\nAnd Romano explained Liverpool's interest in Slot in more detail in his Caught Offside column, he wrote: \"An important update on the Liverpool job to start with, as Feyenoord manager Arne Slot is now a strong candidate for the job of replacing Jurgen Klopp this summer.\n\n\"He's considered already an excellent manager with a very good style, but also with potential to make special things also at the highest level possible in the Premier League.\n\n\"Some outlets have claimed that Slot has also been on the radar of Barcelona and Bayern Munich as they could also be appointing new managers this summer, but I'm only aware of contacts with Liverpool so far. Let's see if other clubs enter the race, but Liverpool are there for sure.\n\n\"Liverpool have made direct contact with Slot. You may remember one year ago that he was also targeted by Tottenham, but there was no agreement and so Spurs decided to go for Ange Postecoglou. Slot is now on Liverpool's list, there have been direct contacts, and I'm told there is another meeting scheduled for further discussions. Feyenoord also want to keep him, but let's see what happens because Liverpool are there.\n\n\"As for Ruben Amorim, some reports recently suggested that everything was verbally agreed between the Sporting Lisbon manager and Liverpool, but I'm told that this was never the case. Amorim had talks with Liverpool, but it's not true that he ever had an agreement with Liverpool, and now that particular deal looks difficult and unlikely because the situation has been total stand-by for about a week. There have been no fresh contacts.\n\n\"However, Amorim was in London this week with his agent for a meeting with West Ham. Despite these conversations, my understanding for now is that Amorim to West Ham will not happen - there is no agreement and it looks really unlikely. {"uri": "2024-04-333843316", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "11:58:23", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T11:58:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:58:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/sport/football/liverpool-move-arne-slot-compensation-feyenoord-3020691", "title": "Slot's Liverpool move 'almost certain' as Feyenoord demand \u00a310m compensation", "body": "The Dutchman is '100 per cent' interested in replacing Jurgen Klopp but Liverpool will have to increase their current offer\n\nLiverpool will have to pay in excess of \u00a310m for top managerial target Arne Slot after opening negotiations with Feyenoord, understands.\n\nSlot is Liverpool's first choice to replace Jurgen Klopp in the Anfield dugout after engaging in a rigorous, data-driven process. The Reds' hierarchy have made contact with Feyenoord in the last 24 hours and has been told Slot is \"100 per cent interested\" in taking the job.\n\nLiverpool's decision to speed up the process appears to have been taken to ward off interest from Bayern Munich in Slot, whose teams play a similar brand of attacking, fast-paced football to Klopp's.\n\nBut they will have to meet Feyenoord's financial demands. An initial offer under \u00a38m is understood to have been rejected, with Feyenoord looking for sizeable compensation before allowing Slot to talk to Liverpool.\n\nDutch sources have indicated that a move now looks almost certain but Feyenoord will not allow Slot to go on the cheap. Feyenoord, in second place in the Eredivisie and trailing PSV Eindhoven by nine points, travel to Go Ahead Eagles on Thursday but have cancelled a planned press conference due to speculation.\n\nSlot was identified as a candidate whose playing style, values and ability to improve players on the training pitch align closely with the club's values.\n\nSporting Lisbon's Ruben Amorim, Brentford's Thomas Frank and Brighton's Roberto De Zerbi have also been discussed.\n\nWhile Liverpool aren't close to making an appointment - indeed it is understood that formal interviews are yet to take place - there is a sense that things are moving at Anfield. Bayer Leverkusen's Xabi Alonso ruled himself out last month while West Ham's links to Amorim came as Liverpool's interest in him cooled.\n\npreviously reported that the Reds were prepared to make an \"out-of-the-box\" appointment ahead of Michael Edwards' reunion with Liverpool owners Fenway Sports Group as CEO of football. Their detailed recruitment process has seen director of research Will Spearman heavily involved - and Slot's inclusion on the shortlist should not come as a surprise.\n\nIndeed his name figured prominently on a list prepared for by data specialists Analytics FC back in February. Their head of content Alex Stewart told Slot is a \"good stylistic fit\" and his teams play with the same aggression as Klopp's side, favouring longer passes and quick breaks.\n\nSlot's CV is impressive; he won the Dutch Cup last weekend with Feyenoord and won the Eredivisie in 2022-23. He is charismatic and adored by the club's supporters, while he was also a contender for the Leeds United and Tottenham Hotspur vacancies last season, although opted against pursuing either.\n\nHis stance would likely change if Liverpool formalise their interest, with the prospect of replacing Klopp understood to appeal. Feyenoord will likely fight to keep him, though.\n\nThe Reds appear to be trying to steal a march on their rivals in what promises to be a busy managerial market in the summer.\n\nAs well as Liverpool, Bayern Munich and Barcelona are trying to fill managerial vacancies, while Manchester United could join that crop of clubs if Ineos decide to dispense with Erik ten Hag.\n\nThe number of potential candidates seems to be dwindling, with Julian Nagelsmann having committed himself to Germany until 2026.\n\nDe Zerbi, who is admired by incoming Liverpool director of football Richard Hughes, also has admirers at Bayern Munich and there was an element of politicking when news of West Ham's interest in Amorim emerged earlier this week. Meanwhile, they have recently moved away from the pursuit of Ruben Amorim.\n\nPaulo Fonseca emerged as a target lately, but Liverpool were only considering the Italian as an option to replace Klopp. Now, Arne Slot has become a target for Liverpool, with the club already making their approach for the 45-year-old.\n\nSlot only signed a new deal with Feyenoord last summer amid Tottenham's interest on the back of a title-winning campaign in the Eredivisie. he readily uses a 4-3-3 system.\n\nSunday, however, brought Slot his second piece of silverware in two seasons, clinching the club's first KNVB Cup since 2017/18.\n\nIt is another tick in the box for Slot, who only last year stated that his \"next step will not be a club in Holland.\"\n\nHe explained: \"If that is my next step, then I've failed completely. {"uri": "8095139846", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "14:58:24", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T14:58:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T14:57:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/27514606/arne-slot-football-coach-manager-who/", "title": "About Feyenoord coach Arne Slot favoured to replace Jurgen Klopp at Liverpool", "body": "Find out how much Liverpool offered Feyenoord for Slot -- a sum the Dutch side rejected\n\nARNE Slott has emerged as a frontrunner in the race to find Liverpool's next manager.\n\nWith Jurgen Klopp's Anfield departure looming, here's everything you need to know about the current Feyenoord coach.\n\nSlot was born in Bergentheim, Netherlands on September 17, 1978, meaning he is currently 45 years of age.\n\nHis playing career began in 1995 with Zwolle, where he spent seven years in midfield and scored 50 goals in 164 appearances.\n\nSlot spent played for NAC Breda for five years and Sparta Rotterdam for three years, before returning to Zwolle.\n\nHe scored over 100 goals in the course of his 18-year playing career.\n\nSlot became youth coach of Zwolle after retiring from the side as a player in 2013.\n\nIn 2014, he was appointed as an assistant of Henk de Jong at Cambuur.\n\nThe following year he became John van den Brom's assistant at AZ Alkmaar, going on to succeed Van den Brom as the club's head coach in 2019.\n\nSlot made a fine start to the 19/20 season, picking up 19 points from his first eight games in charge.\n\nBut the season was cancelled in April 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic -- AZ were joint top with Ajax on 56 points after 25 games.\n\nHe was sacked before Christmas in 2020 with AZ seventh in the league due to being in talks with Feyenoord, who took over as manager soon after.\n\nIn his first full season at Feyenoord, Slot reached the inaugural Europa Conference League final, losing to Jos\u00e9 Mourinho's Roma.\n\nSlot led Feyenoord to their first League title in six years the following season.\n\nHe was heavily linked to the Spurs job at the beginning of the 23/24 season, but eventually opted to stay in the Netherlands.\n\nIn April 2024, Slot won his second trophy with Feyenoord when they beat NEC in the final of the 2024 Dutch Cup.\n\nFeyenoord are currently second in the Eredivisie, nine points behind PSV after 30 games.\n\nSlot is understood to be keen on taking charge at Anfield, just a year after snubbing Tottenham.\n\nHowever, Feyenoord are reluctant to let Slot go and are demanding a tasty fee in return.\n\nLiverpool have been locked in talks with their Dutch counterparts, and on April 24 offered \u00a38million to release Slot from his contract.\n\nThe couple reportedly has children, but no details about them are available in the public domain.\n\nSlot is very private and prefers to keep his family's personal information out of the spotlight.\n\nSlot's management style encourages his teams to play \"sexy\" and \"attack-minded\" football.\n\nDutch football journalist Marcel van der Kraan told Sky Sports: \"He is the prime candidate for Liverpool.\n\n'It was only a matter of time before another big English club would come knocking on the door.\n\n'He's not only been a successful manager, he's also been hugely impressive with his playing style of very attack-minded, Pep Guardiola-style football.\n\n\"I don't expect Feyenoord to stand in the way. They know he's a manager in demand but they will demand a big compensation fee. He has two years left on his contract that was a record deal.\n\n\"Never before in Dutch football has a team paid a manager such huge wages.\n\n'The players like him, the fans love him, the club love him -- they won't want him to go.\n\n\"Feyenoord have every right to demand a big fee as there is no clause in his contract which he renewed last year.\n\n\"He's been a successful coach and made Feyenoord champions playing crazy, sexy football.\n\n\"It is sexy what this man brings on a football pitch.\n\n\"There's nothing more to win for him here. The next step for him is to enter a club in a big league and no league is bigger for the Dutch than the Premier League.\n\n\"I will be surprised if Slot doesn't bite at this chance and become the manger of Liverpool next season.\"\n\nOne of the reasons Slot is the preferred candidate to succeed Klopp at Liverpool is because he is great at communicating his footballing philosophy to his teams' players.\n\nIn such a successful side, he would certainly be expected to hit the ground running at Anfield if he does take over as manager.\n\nAnd in this respect he already has an advantage over many Slot first made his mark in senior management with AZ Alkmaar in 2019 and his reputation has been on the rise ever since.\n\nHe took the reins at Feyenoord in 2021 and led them to an Eredivisie title two years later, as well as securing a KNVB Cup victory just last weekend. Liverpool job - reports", "body": "London (AFP) - Feyenoord coach Arne Slot has emerged as the leading contender to succeed Jurgen Klopp as Liverpool manager, according to British media reports on Monday.\n\nSlot, 45, led Feyenoord to their first league title in six years last season and won the Dutch Cup on Sunday.\n\nHe had been a front runner to take over at Tottenham a year ago before ruling himself out of contention.\n\nSky Sports, the BBC and The Times all reported that Slot is now leading the race for the unenviable task of following Klopp at Anfield.\n\nHowever, the Reds could face competition from Bayern Munich and Barcelona, who are also looking for new coaches next season.\n\nBayer Leverkusen boss and former Liverpool midfielder Xabi Alonso had been the favourite when Klopp announced his decision in January to stand down at the end of the season after nearly nine years in the role.\n\nHowever, Alonso has committed to staying at Leverkusen after leading them to a first-ever Bundesliga title.\n\nSporting Lisbon coach Ruben Amorim was also linked with the Liverpool vacancy but reportedly held talks with West Ham on Monday about replacing David Moyes next season.\n\nSlot moved to Feyenoord in 2021 after impressing in his first managerial role at AZ Alkmaar.\n\nHe led the Dutch giants to the inaugural Europa Conference League final at the end of his first season, in which they narrowly lost 1-0 to Jose Mourinho's Roma.\n\nSlot then delivered just a second league title in 24 years to De Kuip last season, but his side trail PSV Eindhoven by nine points with only four games remaining in this year's Eredivisie title race.\n\nThe Times said his track record of improving players and a high-octane playing style, not dissimilar to Klopp's, is what is attracting the Liverpool hierarchy.\n\nKlopp has just five games left of a reign that has transformed Liverpool's fortunes after decades in the doldrums and could yet go out on the high by winning {"uri": "8092924272", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "10:32:51", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T10:32:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T10:32:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.thisisanfield.com/2024/04/who-is-arne-slot-the-new-named-linked-as-next-liverpool-manager/", "title": "Who is Arne Slot? The new named linked as next LFC manager", "body": "The latest name thrown into the discussion of the next Liverpool manager is Feyenoord's Arne Slot, but who is he and what could he offer at Anfield?\n\nWe are no closer to discovering who will take over from Jurgen Klopp this summer, but Sporting boss Ruben Amorim became the latest to be all but ruled out - he flew to England for talks with West Ham.\n\nSlot has quickly become the new favourite among the bookmakers, but as he will be a relatively unknown quantity for many, let's get to know him a little bit better.\n\nThe 45-year-old spent the entirety of his playing career in the Netherlands and has followed a similar path in management to date, first with AZ Alkmaar and currently Feyenoord.\n\nHe prefers to deploy a 4-2-3-1 formation but it is far from rigid, his style was previously described to i as \"high-energy attacking football in a 4-3-3 or 4-2-3-1 with two deep-lying midfielders and a reliance on wingers to create chances.\"\n\nHis Feyenoord side, whom he has managed since 2021/22, currently boasts the best defensive record in the Eredivisie - conceding just 23 goals in 30 games - and has the second-most goals scored (77).\n\nAs per the Coaches Voice, Slot doesn't \"overcommit to the high press,\" with his teams \"comfortable dropping into a more reserved block\" if the opportunity to win the ball back is not there.\n\nA key difference to that of Liverpool under Klopp.\n\nHe plays an attractive, attacking brand of football and is someone who is not afraid to trust in youth, while his man-management skills have also been widely praised.\n\nSlot takes a possession-based approach and demands his side to be intense, he doesn't stand for casual movement - which would be a carryover from Klopp.\n\nExplaining his approach with Feyenoord, Slot told UEFA: \"We are an attack-minded team that likes to have a lot of the ball, and we play with a lot of intensity.\n\n\"When we don't have the ball, we want to win it back as quickly as possible by being aggressive and pressing to win back possession. I think we are a team that is difficult to beat.\"\n\nThat last sentence is something we have always heard from Klopp!\n\nHe has been a senior manager for only five years but has drawn comparisons to Marcelo Bielsa's style, he likes his full-backs high up the pitch and his centre-backs to move wider.\n\nWith a place in the Europa Conference League final in his first season at the club, and having won the Eredivisie title in his second and the KNVB Cup in his third, it's understandable Slot has attracted interest.\n\nOnly last summer, he was a strong candidate to take over at Tottenham and despite the growing spotlight, Feyenoord technical director Dennis te Kloese is working under the assumption he will not be on a new manager search this year.\n\nHe told Voetbal International:\n\n\"I think it is logical that he is in such a good position. It is very special how he has manifested himself in recent years and has really given Feyenoord a face.\n\n\"We responded by extending his contract. In any case, we assume that he will also be our trainer next year.\n\n\"We have experienced this situation before and will take good care of our own interests.\"\n\nThe Liverpool job is all-encompassing, a manager cannot simply tick one box, he has to tick plenty - and a lot of that revolves around character.\n\nSky Sports previously described him as \"engaging, polite, very smiley, he's hot presence and charisma - and he's funny.\"\n\n\"He can be angry with his players, of course,\" Dennis van Eersel, of Dutch national TV channel RTV, explained. \"But he also puts his arm around them. They like him because he's built a harmony at the club.\"\n\nIf you were wondering, he can speak fluent English, and during the time Tottenham were linked last year, he spoke on his future plans, as quoted by Sky Sports.\n\nHe said: \"My next step will not be a club in Holland.\n\n\"If that is my next step, then I've failed completely. The normal next step will be to go abroad and I've always said the best league in the world is the Premier League.\"", "source": {"uri": "thisisanfield.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "This Is {"uri": "8094267388", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "06:01:54", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T06:01:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T06:01:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/liverpool-manager-news-bid-appoint-arne-slot-moving-fast/", "title": "Liverpool move for Arne Slot set to 'intensify'", "body": "Highlights Liverpool are set to 'intensify' their pursuit of Feyenoord boss Arne Slot this week as they look to secure Jurgen Klopp's successor at Anfield. Feyenoord are demanding compensation exceeding \u20ac10m (close to \u00a39m) for Slot. The Reds are set to conduct formal manager interviews as they seek a fitting replacement for Klopp.\n\nLiverpool's bid to appoint Feyenoord manager Arne Slot as their next head coach at Anfield is \"moving fast\", according to journalist Ben Jacobs.\n\nThe Reds are on the lookout for a new boss after Jurgen Klopp confirmed that he would be leaving his current post at the end of the 2023/24 season.\n\nLiverpool have been linked with names such as Bayer Leverkusen's Xabi Alonso, and Sporting CP's Ruben Amorim, but it now seems they have turned their attentions elsewhere. Slot has previously been linked with the Tottenham Hotspur post, having impressed in his current role as Feyenoord boss.\n\nLiverpool will 'intensify' Slot pursuit this week Feyenoord will want compensation for their current boss\n\nIt's been a busy week in Liverpool's race to appoint a new head coach at Anfield. On Monday afternoon, The Athletic's David Ornstein revealed that a move for Sporting CP's Ruben Amorim was 'unlikely' ahead of the 39-year-old's unsuccessful talks with West Ham United. The Reds have now turned their attentions to Feyenoord boss Arne Slot.\n\nAccording to journalist Ben Jacobs, Liverpool will 'intensify' their pursuit of Slot this week, with the end of the 2023/24 season and Jurgen Klopp's reign drawing ever closer. The 45-year-old, dubbed a \"super attacking\" manager by Dutch journalist Marcel van der Kraan, has impressed over the last two seasons with the Rotterdam-based giants.\n\nLast term, Slot helped secure an unexpected Eredivisie title ahead of the likes of Ajax and PSV Eindhoven. Though only able to achieve a second-placed finish at best this term, he has still brought home the KNVB Cup following their triumph over NEC Nijmegen last weekend.\n\nGIVEMESPORT Key Statistic: Slot has earned a points per match record of 2.12 across the current campaign, having taken charge of 43 games.\n\nJacobs understands that Feyenoord want a compensation package in excess of \u20ac10m (close to \u00a39m) for their manager, which is not as high as the \u20ac20m (\u00a317m) Spurs were quoted last summer. Things are 'moving fast', and Liverpool have a positive relationship with his agent, Rafaela Pimenta. Providing an update on X, Jacobs said:\n\n\"Liverpool will intensify their pursuit of Arne Slot this week. Contact expected with Slot and Feyenoord. Understand compensation Feyenoord want is \u20ac10m+. Not as high as the \u20ac20m Spurs quoted. Things moving fast. #LFC have a good relationship with Slot's agent Rafaela Pimenta.\"\n\nLiverpool starting to think about 'formal manager interviews' The Reds are hoping to appoint a worthy successor to Jurgen Klopp\n\nJacobs has recently told GIVEMESPORT (23rd April) that Liverpool are starting to consider formal manager interviews as they hurry along to the next process of replacing Jurgen Klopp. They will need to think hard about a potential successor to the German boss, who has guided the Reds to one of the most successful periods in their history, having won both the Champions League and Premier League.\n\nThe journalist has revealed that Liverpool are 'on track', having earmarked mid to late April as the time to start approaching and interviewing managers about potentially taking the hot seat at Anfield. However, the date of those talks can differentiate, with the six-time European Cup winners keen not to disrupt a manager's season if there's something to play for in the late stages.\n\nAll statistics now linked with West Ham - and Brighton's Roberto De Zerbi have also been under consideration.\n\nHowever, Slot appears to have moved up the pecking order significantly, but having only signed a new three-year contract last summer, the Eredivisie side will be keen to keep him.\n\nBut the 45-year-old Dutchman, who is understood to have previously turned down Tottenham and Chelsea, is also understood to be under consideration by Bayern Munich and Barcelona as they look to replace departing coaches Thomas Tuchel and Xavi respectively.\n\nFormer Netherlands striker Marco van Basten believes Slot would fit in at any of Europe's elite clubs.\n\n\"I think he's really good. I hope he stays in the Netherlands longer because it is an enrichment for Dutch football,\" he told Dutch TV channel Ziggo Sports.\n\n\"He can really go anywhere... Bayern Munich, Liverpool... I'm really convinced of that.\n\n\"I've spoken to him a few times and I think what he does and what he sees is very strong.\n\n\"He gets along very well with the group of players, is tactically well-versed, can explain things well and is calm and intelligent.\n\n\"I think he can go to any club, even at the very difficult clubs, because he is so intelligent.\"\n\nFormer Netherlands midfielder Wim Jonk told the same channel: \"He (Slot) gave Feyenoord a face. Read his archive here and follow him on Twitter: @MarkOgden_.\n\nLiverpool have identified Feyenoord coach Arne Slot as a leading candidate to succeed Jurgen Klopp as manager after cooling their interest in Sporting CP coach Ruben Amorim, sources have told ESPN.\n\nWith top target Xabi Alonso last month ruling himself out of the running for a return to the club he represented as a player by choosing to stay with newly-crowned Bundesliga champions Bayer Leverkusen, Slot has emerged ahead of Amorim and Brighton's Roberto De Zerbi in the race to replace Klopp.\n\n- Stream on ESPN+: LaLiga, Bundesliga, more (U.S.)\n\nHowever, sources have said that Liverpool expect a battle with Barcelona and Bayern Munich to appoint Slot and are therefore planning to continue to assess other candidates.\n\nKlopp, who has won the Champions League and Premier League with Liverpool since replacing Brendan Rodgers at Anfield in October 2015, announced in January that he will step down from his position at the end of this season.\n\nFollowing Klopp's surprise announcement -- the 56-year-old informed Liverpool's owners, Fenway Sports Group (FSG) of his decision last November -- Liverpool CEO Billy Hogan said that the club would take a \"data-led\" approach to finding a new manager.\n\nFormer sporting director Michael Edwards returned to Anfield last month as head of football operations with the responsibility of identifying and hiring Klopp's successor, and sources have told ESPN that Slot, who guided Feyenoord to the Dutch title last season, has become a strong contender to land the Liverpool job.\n\nThe 45-year-old rejected Premier League advances from both Chelsea and Tottenham last season in order to remain at Feyenoord. Slot signed a new three-year contract with the Rotterdam-based team in May 2023, thereby committing himself to the club until 2026.\n\nSources have told ESPN that the Liverpool hierarchy, led by Edwards and Hogan, believe that Slot fits all their criteria in terms of style of play, personality and ability to work within the club's structure.\n\nThere is an acceptance within Anfield that Sporting CP coach Ruben Amorim.\n\nBut with Liverpool aware of rival interest in Slot from Bayern Munich and Barcelona, contact has been made with Feyenoord in an effort to win the race for the former does not have a buy-out clause in the three-year contract he signed last summer.\n\nSlot has become one of the most coveted coaches in Europe, and Liverpool want to secure a deal amid interest in the Feyenoord coach from Barcelona and Bayern Munich.\n\nThe fact the situation has advanced so far indicates Liverpool are confident they have their man, with Slot enthusiastic about the prospect of building on Klopp's legacy.\n\nFeyenoord want to keep their coach but may realise it is now about negotiating an amicable settlement.\n\nLiverpool are engaged in formal talks with the Dutch club and Slot's representative, Rafaela Pimenta, to conclude a recruitment process which has significantly advanced in the last 24 hours.\n\nSlot's name rose up a managerial shortlist which has been dwindling {"uri": "8094820998", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "11:46:03", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T11:46:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:45:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2024/0424/1445404-liverpool-begin-talks-with-feyenoord-over-slot-move/", "title": "Liverpool begin talks with Feyenoord over Slot move", "body": "Liverpool are in talks with Feyenoord in their bid to appoint Arne Slot as their new manager.\n\nSlot, 45, has emerged as a leading candidate to succeed Jurgen Klopp at the end of the season and the Dutchman is ready to fulfil his dream move to a top Premier League club.\n\nBut Feyenoord do not want to lose their manager and will demand significant compensation for the man who guided the Dutch club to their first title in six years last season.\n\nFeyenoord currently sit second in the Eredivisie table and won the Dutch Cup at the weekend, while Slot extended his contract with the Dutch club last summer until 2026.\n\nLiverpool can expect Feyenoord to take a tough stance in the negotiations as Slot wants to take some of his backroom staff with him to Anfield.\n\nIt is understood Liverpool consider Slot to fit all the criteria set out in their recruitment process, although they are still looking at other contenders.\n\nIt has been reported that Liverpool will have to pay \"considerably more than 10 million euros\" if they are to land their man.\n\nMichael Edwards, who recently returned to the fold as the chief executive of football for Liverpool's owners Fenway Sports Group, having previously been the club's sporting director, and incoming sporting director Richard Hughes have been tasked with the unenviable task of finding Klopp's replacement.\n\nHaving seen one leading candidate in former Reds midfielder Xabi Alonso commit himself to Bayer Leverkusen, who he has just led to their first Bundesliga title, others such as Sporting Lisbon's Ruben Amorim - now linked with West Ham - and Brighton's Roberto De Zerbi have also been under consideration.\n\nSlot has turned down previous offers to work in the Premier League. He opted not to take on the Leeds job after they sacked Jesse Marsch in February last year.\n\nIt has also been reported that he ruled himself out of the running for the vacancy at Tottenham before Ange Postecoglou was appointed last summer.\n\nDespite Slot's desire to manage in the Premier League, Liverpool could face competition from Bayern Munich and Barcelona as they look to replace departing coaches Thomas Tuchel and Xavi respectively.\n\nWe need your consent to load this YouTube contentWe use YouTube to manage extra content that can set cookies on your device and collect data about your activity. I can confirm that. That is clear, the fans do not have to be afraid.\n\n\"It was a compliment that a club like Leeds was interested, but we are doing something great with Feyenoord. We are in a great position in the league, the cup and Europe.\"\n\nSlot was also linked with the vacant Chelsea role after the sacking of Graham Potter, with Dutch outlet AD claiming that he held talks with Blues chairman Todd Boehly.\n\nThe report added, though, that Boehly couldn't convince the Feyenoord boss to sign on the dotted line, and Mauricio Pochettino was appointed instead.\n\nThe third club that could have appointed him was Tottenham, but Slot signed a new three-year contract at Feyenoord last summer instead. Although he was reportedly considered the club's initial top target, Spurs' attentions quickly turned towards Celtic's Ange Postecoglou.\n\nExplaining last summer why he chose not to leave - and perhaps foreboding a move to Liverpool this summer - Slot explained: \"I'm not done here yet. We have had a wonderful season with Feyenoord, with the championship [Eredivisie 2022/23] a wonderful reward for all the hard work that has been put in.\n\n\"But I really want to continue building. After the summer, an adventure awaits in the Champions League, and there is a national title to defend.\n\n\"Enough to look forward to, so I am proud to be and remain Feyenoord's trainer in {"uri": "8093589246", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "18:13:37", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T18:13:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T18:13:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/arne-slot-emerges-leading-contender-143000915.html", "title": "Liverpool make move for Arne Slot to replace Jurgen Klopp", "body": "Slot is now the clear front runner to take over at Anfield and although there is work to be done to strike a deal, Telegraph Sport understands the Merseyside club will intensify their interest in the 45-year-old over the coming days.\n\nSlot has become one of the most coveted coaches in Europe, with Liverpool aware that Barcelona and Bayern Munich are also interested in the Dutchman.\n\nDespite that competition, Slot is understood to be enthusiastic about the prospect of building on Klopp's legacy.\n\nFeyenoord are prepared to fight to keep their coach, and Liverpool will need to engage with formal talks with the club and Slot's representative, Rafaela Pimenta, to conclude a recruitment process which has significantly advanced in recent days.\n\nSlot's name rose up a managerial shortlist which has been dwindling over recent weeks.\n\nFormer Kop favourite Xabi Alonso ruled himself out by choosing to stay at Bayer Leverkusen, while the likelihood of Sporting Lisbon's Ruben Amorim moving to Anfield receded, the club having decided to move on to alternatives following initial interest in the Portuguese coach.\n\nSlot was pursued by Tottenham Hotspur last summer, but rejected the chance to move to the Premier League and committed his future to Feyenoord. It was felt then that it was only a matter of time before he joined one of Europe's top clubs having already turned down a number of opportunities.\n\nSlot rose to prominence after guiding Feyenoord to only their second Eredivisie title success this century last season. Last weekend he added the Dutch Cup to his honours list.\n\nOne of the attractions of Slot is the style of football achieved on a modest budget. A year ago, he was being talked about much like Alonso in the Bundesliga in 2024, as Feyenoord took on and beat Ajax and reached the Europa League quarter-finals. A year earlier he led the club to the first Europa Conference League final.\n\nSlot shifted perceptions of Feyenoord from a dull, defensive side to one of the most exciting in the Eredivisie. He has been described as a football disciple of Pep Guardiola, with a coaching style similar to Mikel Arteta and Roberto De Zerbi.\n\nDe Zerbi has also been referenced as a contender for the Anfield post.\n\nLiverpool's recruitment process is being overseen by Michael Edwards, who recently returned as owner Fenway Sports Group football chief executive, with sporting director Richard Hughes. Hughes officially starts in his new role this summer, but will undoubtedly have a huge input in the identity of the next manager.\n\nAs an up-and-coming coach whose achievements give the impression he is punching above his club's financial weight, it is easy to see why Slot has so many admirers at Anfield.\n\nArne Slot and his methods\n\nSlot's Feyenoord were built on a shoestring but delivered {"uri": "2024-04-332913122", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "17:09:15", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T17:09:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T16:40:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/liverpool-news-reds-eyeing-feyenoord-boss-potential-jurgen-klopp-successor", "title": "Liverpool eyeing Feyenoord boss as potential Jurgen Klopp successor", "body": "Liverpool is still in search of their next manager, with Jurgen Klopp set to leave Anfield this summer after nine seasons at the helm. And with top target Xabi Alonso announcing he will stay at Bayer Leverkusen moving forward after winning the Bundesliga, the Reds have shifted their focus elsewhere.\n\nSporting Lisbon boss Ruben Amorim was on the club's radar but he's also planning to stay in Portugal. Now, Liverpool has identified Feyenoord gaffer Arne Slot as a leading candidate to take over for Klopp in 2024-25, via Mark Ogden of ESPN.\n\nThat being said, ESPN's sources say that both Barcelona and Bayern Munich are also interested in Slot, which means Liverpool may have some competition for his services.\n\nSlot's managerial resume\n\nLiverpool will continue to assess other candidates, but Slot is an interesting option. The Dutchman was appointed as Feyenoord manager in July of 2021 and has compiled a 64.3 winning percentage since then, leading the Eredivisie giants to the title in 2022-23. They were also the runner-up in the 2021-22 UEFA Europa Conference League. Prior to joining the club, Slot was in charge of AZ Alkmaar for just over a year.\n\nSlot is an advocate for an attacking brand of football, which is undoubtedly appealing to Liverpool because Klopp is very similar. He also has an impressive track record of developing young talent. Slot only tasted defeat twice last season en route to the most prized trophy in the Eredivisie.\n\nDifficult for Liverpool to replace Klopp\n\nLet's be honest. It will be extremely difficult for the Merseysiders to replace a coach like Klopp, who has an infectious energy and a special connection with all of his players and the fans. The German has enjoyed boatloads of success at Anfield, winning eight trophies in total. That includes a Premier League title, a Champions League title, and two Carabao Cups. Liverpool was also a runner-up in Europe's most prized competition on two occasions.\n\nKlopp reportedly told the Liverpool board last November his intention to step down this summer, with the club making it clear they will take a \"data-led\" approach to find their next boss, per ESPN. Slot reportedly fits their criteria perfectly.\n\nAlthough the 45-year-old put pen to paper on a new deal with the Rotterdam outfit that will last until 2026, the Reds do believe they can lure Slot away from the club for a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity with Liverpool. Slot already turned down managerial opportunities with Chelsea and Tottenham previously.\n\nReds looking to finish Klopp era strong\n\nLiverpool was shockingly knocked out of Europa last week by Serie A standouts Atalanta in the quarterfinals, leaving them with just one trophy left to play for: The Premier League title. Klopp's men are currently second in the table behind Arsenal ahead of the Merseyside Derby against Everton on Wednesday.\n\nWith just five games left on the schedule, the Reds must be at their absolute best. After visiting the Toffees, West Ham, Tottenham, Aston Villa, and Wolves are up next. Everyone thought Ruben Amorim was destined to be the club's next manager. But things haven't panned out that way.\n\nAmorim at this current moment in time seems like an unlikely candidate. Instead, Liverpool have turned towards other options.\n\nWho those options are at this stage we can only speculate. It's a list that currently includes plenty of names. But there is one who seems to have emerged out of nowhere and who is on a lot of peoples' lips at the moment.\n\nOne possible candidate for Liverpool right now could be Arne Slot. The 45-year-old has done a great job at Feyenoord winning the Eredivisie league title there last season.\n\nHe's still relatively young but players an exciting brand of football, and he's now been tipped to succeed at Liverpool.\n\nSpeaking on Ziggo Sport as per FC Updates, both Wim Jonk and Marco van Basten - two iconic names in Dutch football - have backed Slot to do well at Liverpool.\n\n\"He has given Feyenoord a face,\" Jonk said.\n\n\"Just like Peter Bosz does now at PSV, and Erik ten Hag years ago at Ajax. Arne has made great strides, so in that respect I would like it. Especially at a club like Liverpool, which is of course a bit like the Feyenoord of England with the attacking football they play there.\"\n\nMarco van Basten agreed.\n\n\"I hope he stays in the Netherlands for a long time, because it is an enrichment for Dutch football. He can really go anywhere: Bayern Munich, Liverpool... I am really convinced of that.\"\n\n\"I am convinced he can do it anywhere. I've spoken to him a few times, and he handles the player groups very well. He is of course also very well versed tactically. He can explain his ideas well, he is calm and intelligent. As far as I am concerned, he is really a top trainer,\" Van Basten added.\n\nSlot was a relatively unremarkable football player who played for various mid-table Eredivisie sides. But as a manager he has achieved great things with AZ Alkmaar before moving onto Feyenoord.\n\nDuring his time at the club, he has led Feyenoord not only to a league title but the final of the UEFA talks with Feyenoord in an attempt to negotiate a deal for the club's head coach, Arne Slot, to become J\u00fcrgen Klopp's successor as manager at Anfield, sources told ESPN.\n\nESPN reported on Tuesday that Slot, 45, had emerged as the leading contender for the Liverpool job following Xabi Alonso's decision to remain at Bayer Leverkusen and a cooling in the Premier League club's interest in Sporting CP coach Ruben Amorim.\n\nBut with Liverpool aware of rival interest in Slot from Bayern Munich and Barcelona, contact has been made with Feyenoord in an effort to win the race for the former AZ Alkmaar coach.\n\nSlot rejected approaches from Leeds United and Tottenham Hotspur last year -- Chelsea also expressed an interest in him -- and chose instead to sign a new three-year contract with the Rotterdam team, having led the club to the 2022-23 Eredivisie title.\n\nAs a consequence of Slot committing himself to Feyenoord until 2026, Liverpool would have to pay a compensation package in the region of \u00a39 million ($11.2m) to prise him from his contract.\n\nLiverpool's search for a new manager is being led by Michael Edwards, who hired Klopp in 2015 during his previous role as sporting director, following his return to the club last month as head of football for Fenway Sports Group, Liverpool's American owners.\n\nKlopp announced in January that he will leave his post at "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.sportsmole.co.uk/football/liverpool/news/liverpool-could-confirm-next-manager-by-this-weekend_542110.html", "title": "Liverpool 'could confirm next manager by this weekend'", "body": "Liverpool could reportedly confirm Feyenoord boss Arne Slot as Jurgen Klopp's successor before this weekend.\n\nThe Reds have been searching for a new manager since Jurgen Klopp announced in January that he would leave his role at the end of the season.\n\nBayer Leverkusen boss Xabi Alonso emerged as the initial favourite, before he confirmed his intention to stay with the Bundesliga side for at least one more season.\n\nSporting Lisbon head coach Ruben Amorim soon became the new frontrunner, but it now appears unlikely that the 39-year-old will be the next Liverpool manager.\n\nIn the last 48 hours, Feyenoord's Slot has moved into pole position to replace Klopp ahead of the 2024-25 campaign.\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nLiverpool closing in on Slot appointment\n\nAccording to the Daily Mail, Liverpool could confirm Slot as their new manager before the weekend, with the situation moving at a rapid pace.\n\nThe report claims that the Reds submitted their first compensation offer on Wednesday for the Feyenoord boss, who does not have a release clause in his contract.\n\nWith Slot's deal set to expire in two years, there is a belief that it will take an offer of at least \u00a310m to prise him away from De Kuip.\n\nIf the Dutchman is appointed Liverpool's new manager, he will likely bring several members of his coaching staff with him, including his assistant Sipke Hulshoff.\n\nSlot's pre-match press conference for Thursday's clash with Go Ahead Eagles was scrapped without an official reason, but it is unclear whether the cancellation was linked to the current speculation surrounding his future.\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nSlot's managerial career so far\n\nSlot took on his first full-time managerial role in the summer of 2019 when he stepped up from his role as assistant to over the reins at AZ Alkmaar.\n\nThe 45-year-old spent around 18 months with the Eredivisie side before he was sacked in December 2020 because he was reportedly in contact with Feyenoord about their manager's position.\n\nAfter becoming Feyenoord boss in the summer of 2021, Slot led the club to the Europa Conference League final in his first season in charge.\n\nSlot then guided the Dutch giants to the 2022-23 Eredivisie crown, ending Feyenoord's six-year wait for a league title.\n\nThe Feyenoord boss recently claimed his second major trophy as a manager, with his side winning 1-0 in Sunday's KNVB Beker final against NEC.\n\nID:542110:1false2false3false:QQ:: from db desktop :LenBod:collect4082:", "source": {"uri":
