{"uri": "8095490480", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "19:11:19", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T19:11:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T19:11:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11669/13122219/liverpools-move-for-feyenoords-arne-slot-shows-lack-of-top-managers-says-jamie-carragher", "title": "Liverpool's move for Feyenoord's Arne Slot shows lack of 'top managers', says Jamie Carragher", "body": "Jamie Carragher feels Arne Slot may find the step up from Feyenoord to Liverpool difficult as he would have to meet the club's current demands to compete for the biggest trophies every season\n\nJamie Carragher says Liverpool's move for Arne Slot demonstrates the lack of \"top managers\" currently available.\n\nLiverpool are in talks with Feyenoord over appointing Slot as the successor to Jurgen Klopp, who is standing down at the end of the season.\n\nThe Dutch champions turned down Liverpool's opening offer of \u00a37.75m, with a fee closer to \u00a39m expected to be enough to secure the 45-year-old.\n\nLiverpool were strongly linked with Xabi Alonso until their former midfielder announced he was staying at Bayer Leverkusen.\n\nSporting boss Ruben Amorim - who is a candidate for West Ham should David Moyes leave - and Brighton's Roberto De Zerbi were also reportedly under consideration by Liverpool.\n\nThomas Tuchel and Xavi will also be available in the summer when they depart Bayern Munich and Barcelona, respectively, but Liverpool appear to have focused their intentions on Slot.\n\nSpeaking to Sky Sports, former Liverpool defender Carragher said: \"From Feyenoord to Liverpool is a huge jump and I think it shows at this moment that there's probably a dearth of real top managers out there, when you look at who Liverpool are going for.\n\n\"Initially it was Xabi Alonso - it's only his first full season as a manager - then there was talk of Ruben Amorim from Sporting, who's only 39. Now Arne Slot is the favourite.\"\n\nCarragher added the scenario potentially facing Slot at Anfield differs from the one Klopp inherited in 2014 after his time in charge of Borussia Dortmund, or the one Rafa Benitez walked into in 2004 after leaving Valencia.\n\n\"I don't think it's like Benitez coming in, or Klopp,\" he said. \"Benitez coming in on the back of two LaLiga titles and a UEFA Cup, or Klopp winning a couple of league titles and getting to a Champions League final. Liverpool were actually in a different space then.\n\n\"That Liverpool team, certainly under Benitez that I was part of, we were the team trying to qualify for the top four. The same with Klopp when he came in.\n\n\"But Liverpool are in a different era now. They actually fancy themselves to challenge for the Premier League every season. Next season, in the Champions League they'd expect to get to the quarter-finals at least.\n\n\"I think it's a huge jump but he's obviously a great coach with a great track record so far. We'll see.\"\n\nGary Neville admitted his \"surprise\" at Liverpool opting for Slot as their choice to replace Klopp, adding: \"Jamie Carragher had told me two different managers so it wasn't what he was expecting either.\n\n\"He's a successful coach in Holland. I love Dutch coaches. There's a way of coaching that comes back through some of the great coaches of the game.\n\n\"Obviously it's a change going from the Dutch league to the English league. It's a very different approach to Jurgen Klopp but I don't think they could ever really appoint a manager that's got the personality, character and force of Klopp.\n\n\"It's interesting. It's obviously something that's been driven by Michael Edwards, in terms of them wanting a different approach.\n\n\"Maybe that's why Edwards left Liverpool - because he clashed with Klopp. But now he's got his own way and he's bringing in someone he thinks is going to take Liverpool forward.\n\n\"We don't know how that's going to go. The reality of it is that we've seen the post-Arsene Wenger era at Arsenal has been difficult. The post-Sir Alex Ferguson era at Manchester United has been difficult. Klopp is massive in Liverpool so they've got to try to get that right.\n\n\"We thought it was going to be Xabi Alonso originally and then Ruben Amorim. Now it's Arne Slot.\n\n\"Maybe he wasn't No 1 on the list but the fact of the matter is that, if you can't pin down who you want, you've got to move to the next one on the list. They'll still have a good coach.\"\n\nNeville believes Liverpool's set-up behind the scenes could make the transition into a post-Klopp era a smoother process than Man Utd and Arsenal endured when replacing Ferguson and Wenger, respectively.\n\n\"What Manchester United and Arsenal had when they replaced those two managers was a quite traditional, old-school approach, where the managers ran the club,\" he said.\n\n\"They didn't really have a sporting department beneath them. They were the heads of the sporting department. They were the heads of recruitment, sporting director, manager and coach - all in one.\n\n\"Liverpool have a better set-up, with more depth and more structure. There's still going to be an element of risk replacing Klopp with anybody but it has to happen. Klopp is leaving.\"\n\nSlot, who secured the KNVB Cup last weekend and led Feyenoord to their first title in six years last season, appeals to Liverpool due to his aggressive, full-throttle style.\n\nHe has drilled his team to be adept at turning defensive actions into shooting opportunities and they top the Eredivisie for tackles won in the opposition's final third.\n\nFeyenoord have the best defence in the league and the second-best offensive metrics.\n\nSlot has proved capable of improving individuals as well as the collective, while operating on a smaller budget than his core competitors, and his penchant for a 4-2-3-1 or 4-3-3 formation fits Liverpool's squad.\n\nSlot has previously been approached by Tottenham, Chelsea and Leeds. He signed a new contract last May to keep him at Feyenoord until 2026 but has referenced a desire to make the next step in his career.", "source": {"uri": "skysports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8094797103", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "11:31:09", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T11:31:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:31:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/soccer/who-arne-slot-you-need-32659882", "title": "Who is Arne Slot? All you need to know about the man who could replace Klopp", "body": "The hunt for a new manager at Liverpool is heating up and Arne Slot has emerged as the top contender to replace Jurgen Klopp in the Anfield hotseat.\n\nKlopp announced earlier this year that he was leaving the Reds in the summer bringing an end to a glorious nine-year spell on Merseyside which Liverpool fans will be hoping ends in a second Premier League triumph.\n\nSince his announcement, speculation has run wild over who will be the man to replace Klopp. Xabi Alonso seemed the obvious choice, but the Spaniard has opted to spend another season with his all conquering Bayer Leverkusen side who wrapped up the Bundesliga last weekend and are in the Europa League semi-finals along with the DFB-Pokal final.\n\nWith Alonso ruled out, Feyenoord boss Slot is the favourite for the job with reports this week suggesting Liverpool have made contact with the Dutchman.\n\nWith that in mind, here's all you need to know about the man who could be the next Liverpool manager.\n\nWhere is Arne Slot from?\n\nBergentheim, Netherlands.\n\nAge\n\nHe was born on September 17th 1978, making him 45-years-old.\n\nFamily life\n\nNot much is known about Slot's personal life as he keeps it very private.\n\nWe know that he is married to Miriam and that he has children.\n\nHis children are believed to be in secondary school.\n\nWhat was his playing career like?\n\nSlot's playing career began in 1995 with Zwolle, where he spent seven years scoring 50 goals in 164 games from midfield.\n\nHe spent five years at NAC Breda and three years at Sparta Rotterdam before returning to Zwolle.\n\nHe scored more than 100 goals across his 18-year playing career.\n\nWhat has he done as a manager?\n\nAfter retiring as a player in 2013, Slot became interim manager of .\n\nHis first permanent role came in 2019 when he took over AZ in the Eredivisie.\n\nSlot made a fine start to the 19/20 season and picked up 19 points from his first 8 games in charge.\n\nThe season was cancelled in April 2020 due to the covid pandemic. At the time, AZ were joint top with Ajax on 56 points after 25 games.\n\nHe was sacked before Christmas in 2020 with AZ 7th in the league due to his talks with Feyenoord, who he soon took over.\n\nIn his first full season at Feyenoord, Slot reached the innaugural Europa Conference League final but lost to Roma. The following season, Slot led Feyenoord to their first League title in six years.\n\nHe was heavily linked to the Spurs job at the beginning of the season but opted to stay in the Netherlands. Earlier this month, he won his second trophy with Feyenoord when they beat NEC in the final of the 2024 KNVB Cup.\n\nFeyenoord are currently second in the Eredivisie, 9 points behind PSV with 30 games {"uri": "8094906639", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "12:36:00", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T12:36:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T12:35:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.westmeathindependent.ie/2024/04/24/liverpool-in-talks-with-feyenoord-over-move-to-appoint-arne-slot-as-new-manager/", "title": "Liverpool in talks with Feyenoord over move to appoint Arne Slot as new manager | Westmeath Independent", "body": "Liverpool in talks with Feyenoord over move to appoint Arne Slot as new manager RSS Syndicated Content Published: Wed 24 Apr 2024, 1:06 PM Last updated: Wed 24 Apr 2024, 1:31 PM\n\nBy PA Sport Staff\n\nLiverpool are in talks with Feyenoord in their bid to appoint Arne Slot as their new manager, the PA news agency understands.\n\nSlot, 45, has emerged as a leading candidate to succeed Jurgen Klopp at the end of the season and the Dutchman is ready to fulfil his dream move to a top Premier League club.\n\nBut Feyenoord do not want to lose their manager and will demand significant compensation for the man who guided the Dutch club to their first title in six years last season.\n\nFeyenoord currently sit second in the Eredivisie table and won the Dutch Cup at the weekend, while Slot extended his contract with the Dutch club last summer until 2026.\n\nLiverpool can expect Feyenoord to take a tough stance in the negotiations as Slot wants to take some of his backroom staff with him to Anfield.\n\nIt is understood Liverpool consider Slot to fit all the criteria set out in their recruitment process, although they are still looking at other contenders.\n\nIt has been reported that Liverpool will have to pay \"considerably more than \u20ac10 million\" if they are to land their man.\n\nMichael Edwards, who recently returned to the fold as the chief executive of football for Liverpool's owners Fenway Sports Group, having previously been the club's sporting director, and incoming sporting director Richard Hughes have been tasked with the unenviable task of finding Klopp's replacement.\n\nHaving seen one leading candidate in former Reds midfielder Xabi Alonso commit himself to Bayer Leverkusen, who he has just led to their first Bundesliga title, others such as Sporting Lisbon's Ruben Amorim - now linked with West Ham - and Brighton's Roberto De Zerbi have also been under consideration.\n\nSlot has turned down previous offers to work in the Premier League. He opted not to take on the Leeds job after they sacked Jesse Marsch in February last year.\n\nIt has also been reported that he ruled himself out of the running for the vacancy at Tottenham before Ange Postecoglou was appointed last summer.\n\nDespite Slot's desire to manage in the Premier League, Liverpool could face competition from Bayern Munich and Barcelona as they look to replace departing coaches Thomas Tuchel and Xavi respectively.\n\nRSS Syndicated Content Published: Wed 24 Apr 2024, 1:06 PM Last updated: Wed 24 Apr 2024, 1:31 PM", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8094875466", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "12:17:09", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T12:17:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T12:16:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.thisisanfield.com/2024/04/how-to-pronounce-arne-slot-liverpool-new-manager-latest/", "title": "How to pronounce Arne Slot - Liverpool new manager latest", "body": "With Liverpool looking to appoint Feyenoord boss Arne Slot as the new Liverpool manager, plenty of fans have been asking how you pronounce the Dutchman's name?\n\nSlot is from eastern Holland and has spent his whole career in the Netherlands so far. With Liverpool approaching the 45-year-old to take over, many are wanting to pronounce his name properly.\n\nIn his native Dutch, Arne Slot is pronounced 'Arn-uh Slot'.\n\nThink about how you would say ex-Liverpool an Norway international John Arne Riise's name. Arne is pronounced in the same way.\n\nThough Slot is generally just said in the same way in English and Dutch, there are regional variations that you might hear that vary the sound.\n\nPA Media outlined how he has reached the top of Dutch football...\n\nFormer midfielder Slot, 45, spent his playing career in the Netherlands with Zwolle, Sparta Rotterdam and Breda.\n\nAfter moving into coaching roles at Cambuur and then AZ Alkmaar, Slot stepped up into the manager's job with the latter for the 2019-20 season, which was interrupted by the Covid pandemic. AZ finished second behind Ajax on goal difference in the shortened campaign.\n\nSlot left for Feyenoord in December 2020, succeeding Dick Advocaat, and brought former Arsenal and Manchester United forward Robin van Persie onto his staff.\n\nIn May 2022, Feyenoord reached the first Europa Conference League final, losing to Roma, and finished third in the Eredivisie.\n\nSlot's second season at De Kuip saw Feyenoord win the Eredivisie title - the first for the club since 2017. Earlier this month, Feyenoord beat NEC Nijmegen to lift the 2024 KNVB Cup.\n\nNo matter who eventually takes over as Liverpool's new manager, they will be expected to be able to deliver more memorable European nights at Anfield.\n\nSlot would bring plenty of that experience with him. While at AZ, Slot took his side into the Europa League - where they played Manchester United in 2019. After moving to Feyenoord, Slot guided the club to the Europa Conference League final in May 2022.\n\nEredivisie success brought with it a crack at the Champions League for 2023-24. Despite beating Celtic and Lazio in their group, the Dutch side did not qualify for the knockout stage and then lost out to Roma in the Europa League play-off round.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8095330095", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "17:04:29", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T17:04:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T17:04:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/next-liverpool-manager-arne-slot-32663899", "title": "Liverpool's plan with Arne Slot now No.1 pick to replace Jurgen Klopp as manager", "body": "Arne Slot has emerged as the leading candidate to take charge at Anfield\n\nJurgen Klopp brought plenty of thrills to Liverpool as well as silverware but now the Merseysiders will be hoping they've hit the jackpot with Arne Slot.\n\nKlopp's red machine will become the Slot machine should they agree a compensation package with Feyenoord.\n\nThe German arrived in 2015 and brought his gegenpressing style of play to the red half of Merseyside and the Anfield crowd loved it. Liverpool didn't win every season but the home fans who made the trip to the fabled ground were rarely bored.\n\nNow it will be up to Slot to build on Klopp's success of a Premier League title, a Champions League crown, an FA Cup and two Carabao Cups. But it will also be to ensure the supporters are entertained.\n\nThat's believed to be one of the reasons Michael Edwards and soon-to-be sporting director Richard Hughes have pushed the button on Slot.\n\nThe 45-year-old Dutchman is known for bringing energetic, attacking football and is flexible in formations with 4-2-3-1 a favourite but 4-3-3 another option. He started out as a manager at AZ Alkmaar and those there suggest it took him a while to develop his style but once he found his way, it was exciting football.\n\nSlot, who is openly an admirer of Pep Guardiola, favours aggression but also considers possession important too and potentially will look to control the game more with the ball than just press.\n\nBut at Feyenoord he's brought entertainment and trophies with an Eredivisie title and a Dutch Cup.\n\nLiverpool have launched talks with Arne Slot and Feyenoord\n\nArsenal midfielder Reiss Nelson, who spent a season on loan with him in 2021-22, called him a 'great manager' who had a personal touch helping a young player away from home.\n\nFeyenoord players can't speak highly enough of him. They were delighted he turned down Tottenham last season and are understood to be gutted he now looks set to leave.\n\nThe reason Liverpool have opted for him is his age profile, character and style. He's similar to the others linked with the job in Xabi Alonso and Ruben Amorim. Youthfulness with just enough experience is key. They believe he ticks as many boxes as they feel any manager can that is within their reach.\n\nBut whoever they replace Klopp with will be a gamble so what better way to do that than at the Slot machine.\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community and receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. The Reds are seeking the best candidate for the role with the German set to depart in just five games' time.\n\nSlot has impressed with Feyenoord because of his ability to get the most out of players, winning the Eredivisie last season and the Dutch cup last weekend. He plays an attractive, intense style of play and his ideas could translate nicely across to Liverpool, even if the size of the club will be a big step up.\n\nLast summer, Spurs and Chelsea both spoke with Slot but he opted to stay in the Netherlands. But Dutch journalist Martijn Krabbendam, who covers Feyenoord, says he would 'jump at the chance' to move to Anfield.\n\nREAD MORE: 'I've spoken to Arne Slot and he would be a really good J\u00fcrgen Klopp replacement at Liverpool'\n\nREAD MORE: Who is Arne Slot? 'Leading candidate' to be next Liverpool manager is 'like Pep Guardiola'\n\n\"In the Champions League he left a good impression with his football,\" Krabbendam told FR12. \"A club like Liverpool is also the only club he is leaving for. He doesn't get out of bed for Brentford.\"\n\nWith four matches remaining, Feyenoord is nine points behind PSV in the table as things stand, so it is set to miss out on retaining the title. In Europe, the Dutch side finished third in its Champions League group, ahead of Celtic but behind Atl\u00e9tico Madrid and Lazio. It was then knocked out of the Europa League on penalties by AS Roma.\n\nLiverpool.com says: As a coach, there is no doubt that Slot is clearly very talented. His style of play would be appealing and it could apply nicely to the squad that Liverpool currently has. His principles are not drastically different from what Klopp has deployed and he is used to coming up against teams that he is expected to win against.\n\nBut the only real question that Liverpool would need to answer is whether the step up to the Premier League is something that Slot would be able to deal with. In order to be a success at Anfield, he would need to be able to deal with the pressures that come with the job and be able to take on an awful lot beyond just coaching. though he now looks more likely to end up at West Ham - while the likes of Roberto De Zerbi and Thiago Motta were also linked.\n\nBut now Slot appears to be the frontrunner to replace Klopp at Anfield after three superb seasons in charge of Feyenoord, most recently winning this season's KNVB Cup.\n\nAccording to The Telegraph, Liverpool's hierarchy believe the 45-year-old is the manager they need to lead the post-Klopp era and they will intensify their interest over the coming days.\n\nSlot is very much a manager in demand and has also been linked with the Barcelona and Bayern Munich jobs, but the Dutchman is understood to be 'enthusiastic' about the prospect of taking over at Liverpool and following in Klopp's footsteps.\n\nFeyenoord, however, are prepared to put up a fight to keep their manager and Liverpool will need to hold talks with both the Eredivisie club and Slot's representative, Rafaela Pimenta - who now runs Mino Raiola's old empire.\n\nTottenham made a move to appoint Slot last summer but were frustrated in negotiations and the former AZ Alkmaar boss decided to remain in Rotterdam, also signing a three-year contract extension.\n\nBack then, Spurs were looking at paying a compensation fee of around \u00a36million but the cost now could be as much as twice that.\n\nFeyenoord's technical director Dennis te Kloese was asked about the speculation surrounding Slot and told ESPN: 'I think it is logical that he finds himself in such a good position.\n\n'It is very special how he has conducted himself in recent years and he has really given Feyenoord a face. We responded by extending his contract.\n\n'In any case, we assume that he will also be our coach next year. We have experienced this situation before and will take good care of our own interests.'\n\nFollowing last season's Eredivisie title win - their first since 2017 - Feyenoord lost a number of key players, most notably captain Orkun Kokcu to Benfica, but Slot rebuilt the squad once again.\n\nThey have tied up second place in the Eredivisie table, scoring 77 goals along the way - a tally only bettered by champions-elect PSV - and also lifted the Dutch Cup.\n\nFeyenoord will be playing Champions League football once again next season, having lost four of their six group games this season - with Lazio and Atletico Madrid progressing ahead of them - while they were knocked out of the Europa League by familiar foes Roma, who also beat them in the 2022 Europa Conference League final.\n\nMORE : Harry Maguire backs Erik ten Hag amid speculation over Manchester United manager's future\n\nMORE : Ex-Arsenal and Manchester United striker Robin van Persie set for first managerial {"uri": "8092827815", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "09:31:13", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T09:31:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T09:31:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2024/04/23/ballon-dor-winner-tips-45-year-old-for-liverpool-job-after-tottenham-snub/", "title": "Ballon D'Or winner tips 45-year-old for Liverpool job after Tottenham snub", "body": "Jurgen Klopp's managerial story is one of continuous improvement. Of a man who proved himself at a lower level, at a club with lower expectations, and then gradually climbed the ladder, from Mainz to Borussia Dortmund and, eventually, to Liverpool.\n\nKlopp's journey shares a few similarities, certainly, with a coach one former Ballon D'Or winner feels would be a potentially inspired replacement in the Anfield dugout.\n\nIn his first coaching role, the Dutchman turned AZ Alkmaar into one of the most watchable sides in the Eredivisie. If the 2019/20 season had not been terminated due to the COVID pandemic, AZ might just have snatched the title from under Ajax's nose.\n\nIt would not take long for Arne Slot to get his hands on the Eredivisie trophy, however. Like Klopp at Dortmund, Slot woke something of a sleeping giant from it's slumber, guiding Feyenoord to only their second league title since the turn of the Century?\n\nThe natural next step, Marco van Basten feels, is one of the continent's A-list clubs, the Dutch legend confident that Slot can step into even Klopp's massive shoes.\n\n\"I think Slot is really good,\" Van Basten, the AC Milan icon, tells Ziggo Sport. \"I hope he stays in the Netherlands longer, because it is an enrichment for Dutch football. (But) he can really go anywhere. Bayern Munich, Liverpool... I'm really convinced of that.\n\n\"I've spoken to him a few times, and he handles the player groups very well. Of course, he is also very well versed tactically.\n\n\"I can explain his ideas well. He is calm and intelligent. As far as I am concerned, he is really a top coach. I really think he can go to any club, even difficult clubs. He is very smart in his choice of words.\"\n\nInterestingly, HITC understands that Slot could follow in Klopp's footsteps, not at Liverpool but at Dortmund. The 45-year-old, who's free-flowing attacking style has been likened to Pep Guardiola's, is one of the candidates to succeed Edin Terzic at the German giants, alongside Graham Potter.\n\n\"He has a lot of qualities and he shows it at every level,\" adds Van Basten, a Ballon D'Or winner on no fewer than three occasions. \"He first did it at AZ, and now at Feyenoord. And Feyenoord is a really complicated club. He has been doing well for three years, while PSV and Ajax have much more options in terms of money.\n\n\"It could really fit anywhere. If you get AZ and Feyenoord to play football, you also get big clubs like AC Milan to play football. You can clearly see his hand wherever he is the coach.\n\n\"I think it will even be easier for him at a higher level, because he has better players who understand his ideas faster. In the end, I also think he is smart enough to manage stubborn players.\"\n\nSlot, once labelled the 'best coach in the world' by Feyenoord winger Alireza Jahanbakhsh, turned down Leeds United, Chelsea and Tottenham Hotspur back in 2023. He distanced himself from those Liverpool rumours immediately after Klopp announced his departure.\n\nLiverpool's pursuit of a new manager, meanwhile, is proving to be somewhat more difficult than expected.\n\nXabi Alonso, their first-choice target, is staying at Bundesliga champions Bayer Leverkusen. Ruben Amorim is now in talks with West Ham - he may have reservations about potentially becoming Liverpool's David Moyes or Unai Emery - while Julian Nagelsmann extended his contract with the German {"uri": "8093544365", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "17:33:40", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T17:33:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T17:33:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.sportsmole.co.uk/football/liverpool/news/eredivisie-manager-in-pole-position-to-succeed-klopp-at-liverpool_542027.html", "title": "Eredivisie manager 'in pole position to succeed Klopp at Liverpool'", "body": "Liverpool are reportedly considering Feyenoord manager Arne Slot as a possible successor to Jurgen Klopp, with the 45-year-old emerging as a top candidate for the role. Liverpool are reportedly interested in recruiting Feyenoord's Arne Slot as a successor to Jurgen Klopp.\n\nThe German coach announced earlier in the campaign that he would be ending his nine-year stay on Merseyside at the conclusion of the current season.\n\nKlopp has guided Liverpool to both Premier League and Champions League trophies, and the former Borussia Dortmund man still has the chance to seal a domestic double this term.\n\nThe Reds lifted their 10th EFL Cup trophy with a Wembley win over Chelsea in February, and Klopp's troops are currently in the midst of a three-way title race.\n\nLiverpool occupy second position in the Premier League standings, level on points with first-placed Arsenal with just five matches of the term remaining.\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nLiverpool looking at Slot to replace Klopp?\n\nAccording to Sky Sports News, a new candidate has emerged in the race to succeed Klopp at Liverpool ahead of the 2024-25 campaign.\n\nThe report claims that the Reds are keen on securing the services of Feyenoord head coach Slot, who has enjoyed a three-year spell in charge of the Dutch side.\n\nIt is understood that the Merseysiders are moving their focus away from Sporting Lisbon's Ruben Amorim, who is no longer favourite to take over at Anfield.\n\nLille's Paulo Fonseca has also been touted as a possible replacement for Klopp, whilst a rogue contender has emerged at the beginning of this week.\n\nIt has been reported that Liverpool have held initial talks with Wolverhampton Wanderers boss Gary O'Neil over potentially swapping Molineux for Merseyside.\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nSlot's time at Feyenoord\n\nSince taking the reins at Feyenoord during the summer of 2021, Slot has enjoyed a productive three-year spell at the club, especially last season.\n\nThe 45-year-old guided the Pride of South to their first Eredivisie title in six years, beating the likes of PSV Eindhoven and perennial champions Ajax to the Dutch crown.\n\nThis season has proved harder for Slot's side following a group-stage exit in the Champions League, but Feyenoord are currently unbeaten in normal time since the trip to Brendan Rodgers's Celtic on December 13.\n\nUnfortunately for Slot, the formidable form of PSV has given them a nine-point advantage at the top of the Eredivisie with four matches left, meaning that Feyenoord are unlikely to achieve back-to-back league honours.\n\nHowever, the Liverpool-linked boss has still nurtured an effective, front-footed style of play at Stadion Feijenoord - an approach which has clearly peaked the interest {"uri": "8093494538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "16:53:07", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T16:53:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T16:52:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.con-telegraph.ie/2024/04/23/feyenoord-coach-arne-slot-in-contention-to-replace-jurgen-klopp-at-liverpool/", "title": "Feyenoord coach Arne Slot in contention to replace Jurgen Klopp at Liverpool | Connaught Telegraph", "body": "Feyenoord coach Arne Slot in contention to replace Jurgen Klopp at Liverpool RSS Syndicated Content Published: Tue 23 Apr 2024, 5:30 PM Last updated: Tue 23 Apr 2024, 5:46 PM\n\nBy Carl Markham, PA\n\nFeyenoord coach Arne Slot has emerged as a leading candidate to succeed Jurgen Klopp when he leaves as Liverpool manager at the end of the campaign.\n\nSlot guided the Dutch club to their first title in six years last season and currently has them in second place in the Eredivisie table, having won the Dutch Cup at the weekend.\n\nThe PA news agency understands Liverpool consider Slot to fit all the criteria set out in their recruitment process, although they are still looking at other contenders.\n\nMichael Edwards, who recently returned to the fold as the chief executive of football for Liverpool's owners Fenway Sports Group, having previously been the club's sporting director, and incoming sporting director Richard Hughes have been tasked with the unenviable task of finding Klopp's replacement.\n\nHaving seen one leading candidate in former Reds midfielder Xabi Alonso commit himself to Bayer Leverkusen, whom he has just led to their first Bundesliga title, others such as Sporting Lisbon's Ruben Amorim - now linked with West Ham - and Brighton's Roberto De Zerbi have also been under consideration.\n\nHowever, Slot appears to have moved up the pecking order significantly, but having only signed a new three-year contract last summer, the Eredivisie side will be keen to keep him.\n\nBut the 45-year-old Dutchman, who is understood to have previously turned down Tottenham and Chelsea, is also understood to be under consideration by Bayern Munich and Barcelona as they look to replace departing coaches Thomas Tuchel and Xavi respectively.\n\nFormer Netherlands striker Marco van Basten believes Slot would fit in at any of Europe's elite clubs.\n\n\"I think he's really good. I hope he stays in the Netherlands longer because it is an enrichment for Dutch football,\" he told Dutch TV channel Ziggo Sports.\n\n\"He can really go anywhere... Bayern Munich, Liverpool... I'm really convinced of that.\n\n\"I've spoken to him a few times and I think what he does and what he sees is very strong.\n\n\"He gets along very well with the group of players, is tactically well-versed, can explain things well and is calm and intelligent.\n\n\"I think he can go to any club, even at the very difficult clubs, because he is so intelligent.\"\n\nFormer Netherlands midfielder Wim Jonk told the same channel: \"He (Slot) gave Feyenoord a face. Arne has made enormous strides. Liverpool is also a bit like the Feyenoord of England.\"\n\nRSS Syndicated Content Published: Tue 23 Apr 2024, 5:30 PM Last updated: Tue 23 Apr 2024, 5:46 PM", "source": {"uri": "con-telegraph.ie", Liverpool's typically meticulous approach hasn't aligned with the painstaking current search for a new boss. Arne Slot is the reported top candidate for the Liverpool job, with talks taking place to agree a fee with Feyenoord.\n\nGary Neville has admitted that he has been shocked by Liverpool's lack of 'precise' planning in terms of their new manager search - with the club not on their reported third target in Arne Slot.\n\nThe Reds have been preparing to bring in a new manager since Jurgen Klopp's announcement that he would be leaving the club at the end of January, and having seen Xabi Alonso's exploits at Bayer Leverkusen, it seemed for all the world that he would be next to the Anfield throne. But having announced that he would stay at Leverkusen, new targets were sought after.\n\nRuben Amorim was next, yet developments earlier in the week saw him become likely to stay at Sporting Lisbon, which has led the club to Feyenoord boss Slot. And with the managerial search dragging on, Neville can't quite believe how complicated the situation has become - as he imagined Liverpool to have \"boxed off\" their replacement for Klopp almost instantly.\n\nNeville: \"I Did Not Expect This from Liverpool\" Liverpool have usually been quick to do transfer business\n\nSpeaking on The Overlap on Thursday morning, the Manchester United legend admitted that he expected a more \"precise\" approach from the Reds, having been so exact in their recruitment in years gone by. He said:\n\n\"I didn't expect this from Liverpool. I expected them to be quite precise because six months out, Klopp has told them so that they can get the next appointment right.\n\n\"The idea of Klopp going early was so that they could plan for the end of the season, and get everything sorted. I'm thinking 'they already know who they have got'.\n\n\"I thought with Liverpool, just because how efficient they have been, I thought they would have already had it boxed off at the point where Klopp hands his notice in because they obviously already have someone locked in, and you're thinking 'Xabi Alonso is tied in'.\n\n\"That goes, and the next guy goes, and you're thinking [shrugs]. I imagined Liverpool having it boxed off.\n\n\"I thought with Alonso, if he says he'd have taken the Liverpool job in the February or March, which he would've had to have done, it would never have kept quiet. That could have derailed what is happening at Leverkusen, which to be fair is the biggest thing that could happen in his managerial career at this stage. He could not distract at winning the league away from that.\n\n\"He had to commit, not just because he wanted to stay another year, but if it was that he was leaving partway through a season where he hadn't won the league yet, he had to get that job done and get focused on that.\"\n\nArne Slot to Liverpool: Manager Search Latest Arne Slot has been fast-tracked into frontrunner for the Liverpool job\n\nThe latest reports on Slot are that Liverpool have opened negotiations with Feyenoord to secure his services after his short-yet-sweet career in Rotterdam.\n\nHaving taken over the role in 2021, Slot has already won an Eredivisie title, the Dutch Cup and dragged Feyenoord to the Europa Conference League final in 2022, where they lost to Marseille.\n\nGIVEMESPORT Key Statistic: Liverpool won their first top-flight title in 30 years under Jurgen Klopp\n\nLiverpool have reportedly made a bid of \u00a37.75million for the 45-year-old manager, though it will cost them \u00a39m if they are to land their man, according to Sky Sports.\n\nSlot is said to tick all the key criteria for the Liverpool role, with reports in Holland suggesting that the process could move quickly with Slot keen on a move to Anfield.\n\nRelated Premier League Rule For 2024/25 Might Have Disallowed Everton Goal vs Liverpool Things will be rather different next season with the introduction of new technology - so much so that Branthwaite's goal may not have stood.\n\nStatistics courtesy of Transfermarkt. {"uri": "2024-04-334790608", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "07:05:03", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T07:05:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T07:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/sport/football/pep-energy-4-3-3-arne-slot-liverpool-3022104", "title": "Pep-like energy and 4-3-3 with a twist - what Arne Slot would bring to Liverpool", "body": "Slot's exploits at Feyenoord had Premier League clubs on alert last year, but back then he had a job to do, one that he was eager to complete.\n\nThe 45-year-old Dutchman would go on to win the Eredivisie, steering the Rotterdam club to their first Dutch title since 2017 and only their second this century.\n\nThe taste for silverware has continued into this current campaign. Feyenoord won the Dutch Cup on Sunday, and though second behind PSV in the league, a 16-game unbeaten run stretching back to December means they are all-but guaranteed a place in the next season's Champions League group stages.\n\nThat had been a key reason for staying on last summer. Slot fended off interest from Leeds in early 2023 and was linked with Tottenham last spring, but with Spurs seemingly searching in the dark and having failed to qualify for Europe, the prospect was not so enticing.\n\nThe crown Klopp is vacating will be heavy - Xabi Alonso opted to stay at Bayer Leverkusen -but Slot may find this offer simply too good to refuse.\n\nSlot's 'green flags'\n\nLiverpool's hierarchy and fans alike will be craving a seamless transition, so too the players who have become ingrained in Klopp's ways on Merseyside.\n\nSomeone who can slot right in, essentially, and so no surprise then that Liverpool's data-driven search has landed them on Slot, who operates what Transfermarkt calls a defensive 4-3-3 - \"defensive\" in shape, not outlook.\n\n\"His style is high-energy attacking football in a 4-3-3 with two deep lying midfielders and a reliance on wingers to create chances,\" Football Oranje editor Michael Bell told last year.\n\n\"Slot is a Pep Guardiola-type more than a Jose Mourinho. He wants to entertain, he wants to attack and he wants his players to give it all on the pitch. He uses tight budgets, improves young players and plays nice to watch attacking football.\n\n\"He is doing all this with a good manner and is well liked by his players and the fans. All this will be green flags to any club looking at Rotterdam.\"\n\nThough likened to Guardiola, the Klopp similarities are evident too, and his reliance on wingers will inevitably put the spotlight on Mohamed Salah, who would appear to be the most likely key player to move on this summer.\n\nThat decision may be beyond Slot, or whoever takes charge, but nevertheless out wide is an area where Liverpool have flourished under Klopp - and should Salah go, it would be a position they may look to reinforce with any money they get.\n\nSlot's style in focus\n\nDefensively, Feyenoord are bettered only by league leaders PSV for fewest goals conceded this season. With four matches remaining, Feyenoord's 23 goals conceded in 30 games is on course to be an improvement on last term, when they shipped in 30 en route to winning the title.\n\nUp front, Feyenoord are again second to PSV for goals (77), while Santiago Gimenez alone has 24 goals in all competitions this season, the same amount as Salah and six more than Darwin Nunez. What odds, then, of Slot wanting to bring the promising 23-year-old Mexican along to Anfield for the ride?\n\nWhen in possession, Feyenoord are second for short passes and second bottom for long passes completed in the Eredivisie this season, per FBref, a contrast in Liverpool's style given the Premier League club's tendency to also play it long - they are third behind Fulham and Manchester City for long passes completed.\n\n\"Hoof-ball\" that is not. Liverpool's accuracy with long balls (or diagonals) for their wingers has been a tactic that has repeatedly worked under Klopp. Slot may want to adjust his own philosophy to fall in line with Liverpool's strengths, such as the precision of their defenders' passes and the pace of their wide players.\n\nFor crosses, Liverpool are second and Feyenoord fifth in their respective leagues this season, once more making out wide a key focus - although when it comes to switching play the two sides contrast once again. Liverpool are second in this regard (attempting 129 switches), with Feyenoord bottom among all Eredivisie clubs (57).\n\nThese differences hint at the subtle changes Liverpool fans may see under Slot in attack, although off the ball it should be more of the same.\n\nIn the Premier League, Liverpool are second for tackles in the attacking third and third for tackles in the middle third this season, while Feyenoord are first in both of those categories for the Eredivisie.\n\nThe high press, therefore, won't be disappearing when Klopp does.\n\nBy Mark Douglas\n\nSlot should at least have the charisma to match the impact of the departing Klopp, with one Premier League executive telling that he came away from a meeting with him \"very impressed\" by not only what he'd heard but the way the Feyenoord boss was able to articulate and sell his vision.\n\n\"It does not surprise me one bit that Premier League clubs are interested in him - he carries himself very well,\" they said. Slot's influence has been pivotal in persuading some of Feyenoord's recent signings to pick the club, even when bigger or better financial offers were elsewhere.\n\nFew other clubs demand their manager to be a leader like Liverpool. Klopp didn't just manage the Reds well, he led from the front, articulating the club's values perfectly. Slot has been backed to do the same.\n\n\"As well as being an absolutely excellent coach he's also eloquent, funny and clever. The press over here really like him - he gives straight answers and doesn't play any games. He is himself in press conferences,\" Martijn Krabbendam, Feyenoord correspondent for Voetbal International, says.\n\n\"The only doubt around him is how he copes under pressure - but that's because he has done so well at Feyenoord and AZ Alkmaar. He has not agitated to leave, I just think he wants to test his ideas and systems with world class players, which is what he will find at Liverpool.\"\n\nAny cracks in the armour?\n\nSlot would represent a gamble, but in truth very few managers wouldn't.\n\nKlopp was not \"Premier League ready\" but had impressed in the Bundesliga with Mainz and then Borussia Dortmund, and so Slot can only hope his time at AZ Alkmaar and then Feyenoord has suitably prepared him for his next challenge.\n\nBeing an affable character should certainly stand him in good stead at a club where the manager is a key representative of this fiercely passionate city, and Slot could soon learn of the many roles that come with taking charge of Liverpool Football Club.\n\nWhat will matter most, though, are results, and the ability to combine a tilt at the title with a European push.\n\nOn that front, Feyenoord fell short this season, exiting the Champions League at the group stages and then losing to Roma in the Europa League - albeit only on penalties in the knockout round play-offs.\n\nThe fact Feyenoord's title defence has also fallen short is a case of fine margins, given they have lost just two league games all season. Notably, Feyenoord could yet outscore last season's title-winning points total of 82, with 84 still possible.\n\nIt has been less of a title relinquished, therefore, and more of a title won by PSV, who have lost once in the league this season and boast a goal difference of +78 - scoring 95 times in 30 games so far and conceding just 17.\n\nSlot and Feyenoord could do little to stop this - just like Klopp and Liverpool may find in the coming weeks.", "source": {"uri": "inews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "inews.co.uk"}, "authors": [{"uri": "michael_hincks@inews.co.uk", "name": I felt like Arne Slot is a great manager,\" he said, as per the Daily Star.\n\n\"He really got me into my rhythm. He gave me a lot of opportunities to play and I excelled.\n\n\"It was really cool, like I said we got to the final. It was just the little things with the personal life, not my family around, the Corona situation. So it was a bit tough. But football-wise, it was perfect.\"\n\nSlot has been linked with Premier League clubs before, having notably turned down Leeds and been in contention for previous vacancies at Chelsea and Spurs.\n\nHe only signed a two-year contract extension with the Rotterdam outfit in May but did also hint that his next managerial job will be in England.\n\n\"My next step will not be a club in Holland,\" he said.\n\n\"If that is my next step, then I've failed completely. The normal next step will be to go abroad and I've always said the best league in the world is the Premier League.\"\n\nSporting CP boss Ruben Amorim and Roberto De Zerbi are still believed to be {"uri": "8094754098", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "11:06:36", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T11:06:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:06:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpool-manager-arne-slot-breaking-29051017", "title": "Liverpool new manager latest as fresh Slot details emerge after Feyenoord talks", "body": "Liverpool have opened negotiations with Feyenoord as they ramp up their efforts to make Arne Slot the successor to Jurgen Klopp as manager.\n\nThe Reds have identified 45-year-old Slot as the preferred candidate for the role, which Klopp will vacate at the end of the season after almost nine years in charge.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, senior sources at Feyenoord refused to rule out a move from Slot this summer amid Liverpool interest with officials from Anfield now in contact with the Eredivisie side's CEO Dennis te Kloese to discuss the terms of a potential move.\n\nREAD MORE: Jurgen Klopp shares surprise at 'over the top' Everton and Liverpool reaction he wants\n\nREAD MORE: 'It's not enjoyable' - Jurgen Klopp explains what he won't miss about Liverpool before final derby\n\nThe Dutchman is under contract until 2026 but is understood to welcome the opportunity of a move to Anfield. It's been suggested Slot would be keen to bring assistant Sipke Hulshoff with him to Merseyside should he succeed Klopp and Liverpool's backroom staff will be in need of a rebuild as Klopp's assistants Pep Lijnders and Peter Krawietz get set to walk away alongside elite-development coach Vitor Matos.\n\nLiverpool are keen to show Feyenoord respect throughout the process and wanted to avoid any disruption to Slot's preparation ahead of his team's successful KNVB Beker final meeting with NEC, but the pathway for negotiations has become easier to navigate since Sunday's 1-0 win at home stadium De Kuip.\n\nSlot is understood not to have a release clause in his contract with suggestions Feyenoord may be willing accept a fee of less than \u20ac10million as compensation for losing their head coach.\n\nLiverpool have a good relationship with Slot's agent, Rafaela Pimenta, the Brazilian lawyer who also looks after the interests of Manchester City striker Erling Haaland among others. Pimenta was a guest at Anfield for a Premier League game last season.\n\nWhile Slot is now an overwhelming favourite to become their next manager, the Reds are continuing to assess other targets with the deal no means a formality. It's believed Bayern Munich and Barcelona are among other clubs to have also been impressed by Slot's work in Holland.\n\nOn Tuesday, Feyenoord cancelled a regular press conference for Wednesday to preview their game at Go Ahead Eagles the following day.\n\nSlot has been in charge of the Dutch side for three seasons, reaching the Europa Conference League final in 2022 and then winning their first Eredivisie title in six years last term. Feyenoord are second in the table this campaign and at the weekend won the Dutch Cup.\n\nIt is understood Slot has become strongly fancied by the Anfield hierarchy given he fits all of the criteria that have been set out during the process of finding Klopp's replacement, which is being led by Fenway Sports Group chief executive of football Michael Edwards.\n\nFSG have known about the need for a new manager since Klopp told them of his decision to stand down back in November but the process of securing a replacement has only intensified in recent weeks with the Boston-based organisation keen to restructure the club before sourcing a successor.\n\nThat meant former sporting director Edwards was appointed last month to effectively replace Mike Gordon as the head of the club while Richard Hughes will leave his post as Bournemouth's sporting director at the end of the campaign to take up a similar position at Anfield from June 1.\n\nHe will bring with him Mark Burchill, the Cherries' chief scout, who will support Barry Hunter and Dave Fallows in the recruitment department alongside director of research Will Spearman and his team.", "source": {"uri": "liverpoolecho.co.uk", {"uri": "8094774797", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "11:18:10", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T11:18:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:18:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/how-liverpool-could-line-up-29050735", "title": "Possible Liverpool XI under Slot with three transfers", "body": "Arne Slot is the leading candidate to replace Jurgen Klopp as the Liverpool manager over the summer. The current Feyenoord boss is now in talks with the club over a possible move.\n\nIt has come extremely quickly for the 45-year-old after Liverpool had made Xabi Alonso their priority target. Ruben Amorim and Julien Nagelsmann were other names linked whilst Roberto De Zerbi has been on the periphery of conversations.\n\nSlot, who was close to joining Tottenham 12 months ago, has now emerged as the frontrunner to be in the Anfield dugout next season. Coming off the back of winning Eredivisie in the 2022/23 campaign, Slot won the Dutch Cup at the weekend and has built an impressive resume in his time as a manager so far.\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool new manager latest as Feyenoord boss Arne Slot becomes leading contender\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool could end Nike kit partnership with Adidas 'poised' to take over\n\nHe has a track record of developing young players and has come to be the standout candidate currently in Michael Edwards' search for a new head coach. Slot only signed a new deal last year keeping him in Holland until 2026, though that may not be enough to keep Liverpool from their man.\n\nNow, with things really ramping up, Liverpool Echo has taken a look at how Slot could line up with a dream summer of transfers.\n\nThe defence is in a position to stay largely the same. Trent Alexander-Arnold and Virgil van Dijk signing new contracts with the club would be a major boost and as a period of transition after nine years goes on, Slot working with an unchanged backline will be beneficial.\n\nIbrahima Konate is a player that can form part of the next great Liverpool defence whilst Andy Robertson on the left still has plenty to offer. Finding a new full-back to support him will be a priority - perhaps someone of Antonee Robinson's style - but for now it's no change at the back.\n\nMidfield is more interesting. This was the area of most movement last summer so the places for Alexis Mac Allister and Dominik Szboszlai are cemented. Watauro Endo has been a splendid addition but Slot may well look to find someone of his own to go alongside them.\n\nLiverpool are all too familiar now with Atalanta's Teun Koopmeiners, but they could be in to learn more about the versatile Dutchman. He played two seasons under Slot at AZ Alkmaar, scoring 21 times in 58 games with seven assists. Capable of operating practically anywhere on the pitch, it wouldn't be a surprise to see the pair reunited at Anfield.\n\nThe frontline has been hit-and-miss for Liverpool this season but the exit of Klopp could also see the same for Mohammed Salah. If another big offer from Saudi Arabia comes then parting ways could be on the cards.\n\nLiverpool would need to replace him and here is where things get interesting. Nobody is entirely convinced of Darwin Nunez becoming a more consistent player, and someone that Slot has seen excel under his coaching is Mexican marksman Santiago Gimenez.\n\nThe 23-year-old was snapped up by Slot in 2022 and hasn't looked back since. He is reportedly a target for a host of Premier League teams and with 47 goals and 10 assists in 85 games it's easy to see why. It wouldn't be a surprise to see the Feyenoord man follow his manager to Merseyside.\n\nWho plays on the wings is a trickier one. Luis Diaz may well be ready to step up to the mantle left by Salah but he will be on the left. Diogo Jota is a versatile option across the board and currently Liverpool's best finisher but more additions could still be made.\n\nHarvey Elliot is another player ideal for depth and options but on the right there could be another signing. West Ham's Jarrod Bowen, anyone?\n\nThe 27-year-old is proven in the Premier League and would offer experience and immediate quality to the attack. He's not the glamorous name that most expect but he regularly puts up impressive numbers for a defensive Hammers side.\n\nHe only signed a new contract last year but with David Moyes possibly moving on, Bowen could look for the transfer of a lifetime himself. This squad also leaves plenty of room for rotation with Nunez and Liverpool's glowing youth.\n\nHow do you think Liverpool would line up if Slot was to join? While Rubin Amorim and Roberto De Zerbi have been linked with the Merseyside club, it seems 45-year-old Slot is their top choice.\n\nSlot won't be short of options though, with Liverpool's sporting hierarchy, including the returning Michael Edwards and sporting director Richard Hughes, needing to make a compelling case. The Feyenoord boss is also said to be attracting interest from Bayern Munich, who will be parting ways with former Chelsea manager Thomas Tuchel at the end of the season.\n\nSlot's work in the Netherlands has not gone unnoticed by Premier League clubs. The former Zwolle and Breda midfielder led Feyenoord to second place in the Europa Conference league in his first year in charge, followed by an Eredivisie title in his second year and a KNVB Cup win in 2023/24.\n\nTottenham had Slot on their shortlist last summer but he opted to stay in the Netherlands before Spurs appointed Ange Postecoglou. But Dutchman Slot, 45, is also of interest to Bayern Munich, along with Ralf Rangnick and Roberto de Zerbi, as the German champions look to land Thomas Tuchel's replacement.\n\nLiverpool haven't decided on who their next manager will be but Slot is a real candidate as they scour Europe for the right man to replace Klopp. The Reds had been linked with Bayer Leverkusen boss Xabi Alonso but never really believed he would leave the new Bundesliga champions and last month he confirmed he is staying in Germany.\n\nSporting Lisbon boss Ruben Amorim - another strongly linked with Liverpool - has held discussions with West Ham but is reportedly not currently keen on a move to the London Stadium.\n\nThere has been no progress or approach from Liverpool for the Sporting manager. They are currently nine points off leaders PSV in this season's title battle with just four games to go so will be relinquishing their Eredivisie crown.\n\nThey finished third in their Champions League group this season and exited the Europa League after defeat by Roma in February. Liverpool executive Michael Edwards and sporting director Richard Hughes continue to lead the search for Klopp's successor alongside data analyst Will Spearman.\n\nSporting Lisbon's Ruben Amorim is another man linked with the role\n\nSlot was on Tottenham's shortlist last summer before he opted to stay in Holland and Spurs went for Ange Postecoglou. He has been backed by Dutch legend Marco van Basten to be a success outside of his homeland.\n\nVan Basten said: \"I think Slot is really good. I hope he stays in the Netherlands longer because it is an enrichment for Dutch football. He can really go anywhere: Bayern Munich, Liverpool... Of course, he is also very well-versed tactically. I can explain his ideas well; he is calm and intelligent. As far as I am concerned, he is a top trainer. {"uri": "8094895694", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "12:29:24", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T12:29:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T12:29:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/sport/soccer/arne-slot-a-closer-look-at-jurgen-klopps-potential-successor-at-liverpool-FFX2AO2FTJOF7FU7HMKWGVXDJI/", "title": "Arne Slot: A closer look at Jurgen Klopp's potential successor at Liverpool", "body": "The 45-year-old Dutchman is reportedly being lined up as the next Reds boss.\n\nLiverpool are understood to be in discussions with Feyenoord about appointing Arne Slot as Jurgen Klopp's successor.\n\nHere, the PA news agency takes a closer look at the Dutch coach and what he might bring to Anfield.\n\nFormer midfielder Slot, 45, spent his playing career in the Netherlands with Zwolle, Sparta Rotterdam and Breda. After moving into coaching roles at Cambuur and then AZ Alkmaar, Slot stepped up into the manager's job with the latter for the 2019-20 season, which was interrupted by the Covid pandemic. AZ finished second behind Ajax on goal difference in the shortened campaign.\n\nSlot left for Feyenoord in December 2020, succeeding Dick Advocaat, and brought former Arsenal and Manchester United forward Robin van Persie onto his staff. In May 2022, Feyenoord reached the first Europa Conference League final, losing to Roma, and finished third in the Eredivisie. Slot's second season at De Kuip saw Feyenoord win the Eredivisie title - the first for the club since 2017. Earlier this month, Feyenoord beat NEC Nijmegen to lift the 2024 KNVB Cup.\n\nNo matter who eventually takes over as Liverpool's new manager, they will be expected to be able to deliver more memorable European nights at Anfield. Slot would bring plenty of that experience with him. While at AZ, Slot took his side into the Europa League - where they played Manchester United in 2019. After moving to Feyenoord, Slot guided the club to the Europa Conference League final in May 2022. Eredivisie success brought with it a crack at the Champions League for 2023-24. Despite beating Celtic and Lazio in their group, the Dutch side did not qualify for the knockout stage and then lost out to Roma in the Europa League play-off round.\n\nSlot has grown into an attack-minded coach, also with an eye on bringing through talent - plenty of which would await in Liverpool's youth ranks. Feyenoord - who sit second behind Eredivisie rivals PSV Eindhoven this season - also press high, winning plenty of tackles in the opposition's final third, and are comfortable in different formations, whether that is with one up top or a fluid 4-3-3. Slot was linked with a switch to Tottenham last summer, but the Liverpool job is expected to prove too good an opportunity for the ambitious Dutch coach to pass up.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8094953538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "13:04:31", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T13:04:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T13:04:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.planetfootball.com/liverpool/arne-slot-quotes-manager-guardiola-cruyff-feyenoord", "title": "9 quotes on Liverpool target Arne Slot: 'One of the best managers I've ever seen'", "body": "Feyenoord manager Arne Slot has emerged as the frontrunner to succeed Jurgen Klopp at Liverpool.\n\nIt remains up in the air who will sit in Liverpool's dugout next season. Long-running favourite Xabi Alonso has committed his immediate future to Bayer Leverkusen, while Sporting Lisbon boss Ruben Amorim has been linked more firmly with West Ham in recent days.\n\nNow, well-connected Times journalist Paul Joyce reports that Slot is a \"leading candidate\" for the Liverpool job this summer. The 45-year-old Dutchman reportedly turned down Tottenham last year but is said to be open to a move to Merseyside.\n\nWant to know a bit more about him? We've compiled nine quotes - from players, coaches and journalists to the man himself - to give you an idea about the man who could be at the helm for Liverpool next season.\n\n\"Some players you can see are going to be coaches,\" Slot's former NAC Breda team-mate Edwin de Graaf told The Athletic.\n\n\"I also played with Alfred Schreuder (the former Ajax manager) and both him and Slot... nobody is surprised now they're both coaches.\n\n\"He would ask the coach why they were using certain tactics. And in the dressing room, he would talk to the group about (for example) a way of pressing or defending. He would ask: 'Why were we doing it this way? Would it be better to do it this way?'. He would make suggestions to his coaches.\n\n\"But he would do it in such a good way. He wouldn't do it with an attitude: he would ask the coach: 'What do you think about this?'. He would also very quickly see what the opponents were doing.\"\n\nREAD: Seven brilliant (and terrible) managers that have rejected the Liverpool job\n\n\"I got the impression Slot was watching FC Barcelona all day and night,\" Bert Konterman - technical manager when Slot was playing at PEC - told Dutch daily paper Algemeen Dagblad.\n\n\"He was watching the positional play, the way they took on free-kicks. When he arrived at the club the next morning, he was so excited what he had seen!\"\n\n\"I don't want to compare myself with Pep at all, but he's a control freak just like me,\" Arne Slot himself told Voetbal International.\n\n\"If I look at myself, I want to win a match during the week before kick-off. I try to imprint the chosen tactic to my players as much as I can.\n\n\"That's why I can be very frustrated when a referee even makes the slightest mistake to your disadvantage. This can have so much influence while you're not able to control anything. All preparation can be ruined because of a referee mistake. This can be my biggest frustration!\n\n\"Guardiola gives me the ultimate pleasure in football. I'd rather watch Manchester City than any other team in the world, although now I enjoy watching Napoli, Arsenal and Brighton as well.\n\n\"I don't want to compare Feyenoord with City, but we more or less play football according to the same philosophy: 4-3-3, building up from the back, wanting to put pressure on the opponent rather quickly.\n\n\"There are quite a few similarities of which I think: can I steal some of this? But I always make sure that it fits with my own players.\"\n\n\"You can't obliviously attack, attack, attack. Dutch managers like Frank de Boer and Peter Bosz were like this - Erik ten Hag wasn't and Slot isn't,\" Dutch journalist Kevin Van Nunen told TNT Sports when Slot was linked with the Tottenham vacancy last year.\n\n\"It's almost like Dutch coaches matured. Slot is a natural successor to Ten Hag as an exponent of new generation of Dutch managers. When you have a steady defence and all players know what to do, you can go on and play attacking football.\n\n\"Definitely Ajax, possibly PSV and maybe even AZ, have better individual players than Feyenoord, but they can't deliver as a team. One plus one doesn't always equal two, but at Feyenoord there's a team that equals 11 and that has been their real strength this season [2022-23].\"\n\nREAD NEXT: 8 times Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp was the nicest bloke in the world\n\nTRY A QUIZ: Can you name every Liverpool manager of the post-war era?\n\n\"Holland was great for me. I felt like Arne Slot is a great manager. He really got me into my rhythm. He gave me a lot of opportunities to play and I excelled,\" Arsenal's Reiss Nelson told the Colney Carpool podcast.\n\n\"It was really cool, like I said we got to the final. It was just the little things with the personal life, not my family around, the Corona situation. So it was a bit tough. But football-wise, it was perfect.\"\n\n\"For me, he's the best [manager I've worked under]\" former Feyenoord winger Oussama Idrissi told Dutch outlet AD.\n\n\"He can develop players and make teams play fun football.\n\n\"Slot was the best,\" Idrissi repeated when it was pointed out he's also played under the likes of Julen Lopetegui, Herve Renard and Erik ten Hag.\n\n\"He is one of the best managers I've ever seen,\" said former Brighton forward Alireza Jahanbakhsh, who currently plays under Slot at Feyenoord.\n\n\"In football terms, even the best. At the moment, he is the best in the Netherlands.\"\n\n\"He's a really good manager and sometimes it can come fast and quick,\" says Dutch football journalist Marcel van der Kraan.\n\n\"I've followed Feyenoord for 40 years. Not since the days of Johan Cruyff at Ajax in the 1980s has there been a coach so attack-minded in the Dutch league. Cruyff only had a few disciples who followed him and one of them was Pep Guardiola.\n\n\"I would say Slot is a Guardiola-style manager based on everything I've seen over the past couple of years. The fans of Feyenoord can't believe what they've seen over that time.\"\n\nTRY A QUIZ: Can you name the top 20 Dutch goalscorers in Premier League history?\n\n\"My next step will not be a club in Holland,\" Slot said last year.\n\n\"If that is my next step, then I've failed completely. The normal next step will be to go abroad and I've always said the best league in the world is the Premier League.\"\n\n\"What answer can I give that there will be no headlines about it? So next question,\" was Slot's curt response when asked about the Liverpool vacancy when Klopp announced his decision to step down.\n\nBut he found the time to praise the Liverpool manager: \"I think it is incredibly impressive that [Klopp] has been so good at that level for so long, with so much energy for nine years.\n\n\"I see it as a special achievement that you can maintain that level for nine years with so much dedication and passion. Especially when you consider how many games we play. {"uri": "8094266049", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "06:00:52", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T06:00:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T06:00:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.90min.com/features/arne-slot-everything-need-know-liverpool-target", "title": "Arne Slot: Everything you need to know about the Liverpool target", "body": "Slot is highly regarded by the Reds after his work in the Eredivisie\n\nJurgen Klopp announced in January that he would step down as Liverpool manager at the end of the season, leaving the club searching for someone to continue his legacy.\n\nSporting CP boss Ruben Amorim, Bayer Leverkusen's Xabi Alonso and even Wolves' Gary O'Neil have all been linked with a move to Anfield, but now Feyenoord boss Arne Slot has emerged as a serious contender, having done a remarkable job in the Eredivisie.\n\nHere's everything you need to know about the Dutch boss.\n\nSlot's playing career was spent entirely in the Netherlands. The midfielder spent time at PEC Zwolle, NAC Breda and Sparta Rotterdam, winning the Eerste Divisie twice in 2002 and then ten years later in 2012.\n\nThe attacking player hung up his boots in 2013, moving into the coaching department at PEC Zwolle. He perfected his craft in the club's youth system, before making the move to Cambuur to take up the role of assistant coach.\n\nIn 2017, Slot took a move to AZ Alkmaar, once again as an assistant coach. Two years later, he was appointed head coach, guiding the club through a troubled period in the Covid pandemic.\n\nWhen football resumed, Slot led his side to a second place finish in the Eredivisie, level on points with Dutch giants Ajax.\n\nHis success opened further doors and in 2021 he was offered the chance to lead Feyenoord, guiding them to the league title during his second season with the club. His achievements with Feyenoord were even more commendable as Slot charged through the league with a very young squad at his disposal.\n\nThen 22-year-old Santiago Gimenez and 25-year-old Justin Bijlow led the squad at either ends of the pitch, attracting the eyes of footballing fans everywhere.\n\nSlot has been known to use an aggressive, out of possession approach, with defenders committed to intense pressing. He relies on a willingness to create chances, with similarities to how Klopp currently sets up his squad.\n\nHis use of wingers to formulate chances very much resembles that of Klopp, who often turns to Luis Diaz and Mohamed Salah to feed the central striker. The Dutchman's teams play on the front foot when it comes to attack, fighting to create chances and score goals.\n\nFeyenoord's pressing has become the most successful of any team across Europe's top seven leagues. In comparison, Feyenoord have made 722 interceptions, with Liverpool making 706 at the time of writing.\n\nThe Eredivisie side also lead the way in terms of points won from losing positions, sitting at 62 points, interestingly the same number as Liverpool.\n\nFeyenoord's boss has also been known to study Pep Guardiola's training methods, focusing on controlling through possession - a quality that Liverpool may grab with both hands.\n\nSlot's charismatic approach also draws similarities to that of the Reds' boss, often appearing engaging and smiley. Slot could bring this presence to the Premier League, stepping into the shoes that once belonged to Klopp.\n\nSlot's statistics speak for themselves, but it's impossible to ignore the fact that he has no Premier League experience, either as a player or manager.\n\nHowever, his ideologies and style will suit Liverpool tenfold, and may be their best bet of replicating the magic that Klopp has brewed at Anfield. The Reds heavily rely on a gegenpressing style of football, something that Slot has also mastered.\n\nIn order to apply pressure on teams high up the pitch, a squad needs defenders who lack fear squeezing behind their midfielders. Both Ibrahima Konate and Virgil van Dijk are excellent at this, even if it means leaving space for opponents behind. Their style of play may fuse perfectly with what Slot aims to achieve, unlocking a potentially even stronger Van Dijk.\n\nSlot could be tempted to purchase an attacking midfielder, offering another option alongside Dominik Szoboszlai. This could open the door even more for Teun Koopmeiners to arrive at Anfield, continuing a relationship between himself and Slot.\n\nIt is thought that Slot is ready to take the next step in his managerial career, despite being contracted with his current team until 2026.\n\nReports state that a fee of less than \u20ac10m (\u00a38.6m) could be enough to see him leave the Dutch side, but there is no release clause in his contract, making a move significantly easier.", "source": {"uri": "90min.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "90min.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Last season, he helped them win the Eredivisie title for the first time since 2017.\n\nThis term, Feyenoord are second in the Eredivisie table but they have won the KNVB Cup. Slot's attack-minded philosophy aligns with Liverpool and he plays a similar system to Klopp so this appointment should not see the Premier League giants change too much.\n\nSlot's Feyenoord are in action in the Eredivisie on Thursday night as they face Go Ahead Eagles. Dutch Cup on Sunday after leading Feyenoord to their first league championship in six years the previous season.\n\nA year ago, before ruling himself out of the running, he was the clear favorite to take over at Tottenham.\n\nAccording to reports from Sky Sports, the BBC, and The Times, Slot is currently in the lead for the coveted position of succeeding Klopp at Anfield.\n\nHowever, Barcelona transformed Liverpool's fortunes after decades in the doldrums and could yet go out on the high by winning the Premier League.\n\nLiverpool sit behind Arsenal only on goal difference at the top of the {"uri": "8094848789", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "12:02:23", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T12:02:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T12:02:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://talksport.com/football/1840339/arne-slot-liverpool-jurgen-klopp-pep-guardiola-tottenham/", "title": "Slot is the Dutch Guardiola, who rejected Tottenham and could replace Klopp", "body": "Arne Slot is a name Premier League fans need to start learning about because he looks bound for England.\n\nThe Dutchman has transformed Feyenoord into a sublime team since his appointment as manager in 2021, and Liverpool are big admirers.\n\ntalkSPORT understands Slot is a contender to replace Jurgen Klopp when the German leaves Anfield at the end of the season.\n\nThe Reds are yet to finalise their shortlist for Klopp's replacement, but they are impressed by Slot's work.\n\nThe 45-year-old also ranks highly on the data-driven process Liverpool like to use, so it's very possible he will be in the hot seat at Anfield next year.\n\nHowever, on a different timeline, he would already be in England as Tottenham boss.\n\nThis is because before Spurs went for Ange Postecoglou in 2023 they tried to bring Slot to north London.\n\nInterestingly, the Dutchman was relatively low down on the list of targets after Vincent Kompany, Roberto De Zerbi and Julian Nagelsmann all ruled themselves out.\n\nBut despite Spurs coming close to agreeing a compensation package, Slot rejected the chance to take the Spurs job.\n\nAnd speaking about why he turned Tottenham down, the Feyenoord boss revealed that the key factor was the Champions League or lack of it.\n\nTalking after the deal fell through, he said: \"The decisive factor was playing the Champions League.\n\n\"The fantastic work with the staff and the players, the fact that I'm having a great time privately and being able to build on the past two seasons.\n\n\"I didn't know what would happen [with Tottenham]. I weighed everything up, including whether the people who work with me would want to come with me.\n\n\"You can think of it, but I don't think it's chic to say! But my intention is to stay because that already raises an expectation.\"\n\nHowever, with Liverpool now almost certain to be playing with Europe's elite next season, the Champions League won't be an issue for the Reds should they decide Slot is the man.\n\nLooking at his track record, you can see why Liverpool are so impressed by the Dutchman.\n\nSlot enjoyed a relatively quiet career as a player, spending the majority of his time with FC Zwolle before retiring in 2013.\n\nHe immediately became a youth coach at Zwolle before joining SC Cambuur as assistant manager, where he remained until moving to AZ Alkmaar.\n\nSlot was the club's assistant for two years but became the first-team boss in the summer of 2019.\n\nHis Alkmaar team were prolific, scoring 118 goals in 58 matches, while he helped the club qualify for the Europa League.\n\nHe also boasted the highest win ratio in the club's history, but he was sacked surprisingly in 2020 due to Alkmaar's belief he'd lost focus on the job amid links with Feyenoord.\n\nOf course, he ended up at Feyenoord less than a year later, and the rest is history.\n\nThey won the Eredivisie last season and won the KNVB Cup this year to hand Slot his first pieces of silverware.\n\nThe 45-year-old has been compared to Pep Guardiola by Dutch football journalist Marcel van der Kraan, who said: \"He's a really good manager and sometimes it can come fast and quick.\n\n\"I've followed Feyenoord for 40 years. Not since the days of Johan Cruyff at Ajax in the 1980s has there been a coach so attack-minded in the Dutch league. Cruyff only had a few disciples who followed him, and one of them was Pep Guardiola.\n\n\"I would say Slot is a Guardiola-style manager based on everything I've seen over the past couple of years. The fans of Feyenoord can't believe what they've seen over that time.\"\n\nOf course, the key thing for Liverpool fans is the style of play, and Slot likes to entertain.\n\nSpeaking to UEFA about his brand of football, he said: \"We are an attack-minded team that likes to have a lot of the ball, and we play with a lot of intensity.\n\n\"When we don't have the ball, we want to win it back as quickly as possible by being aggressive and pressing to win back possession. I think we are a team that is difficult to beat.\"\n\nIn many ways, this is exactly how Klopp and Guardiola play, so the transition should be straightforward for Liverpool fans and players.\n\nSlot and Atletico boss Diego Simeone found themselves in a shoving match - after a friendly in 2021.\n\nIt was a lost in translation moment when Simeone thought Slot was trying to wind him after Feyenoord's 2-1 win.\n\n\"At that moment, at the end of the match, I turned to Simeone to tell him how passionate he was even in a friendly match,\" he said ahead of the team's Champions League clash in 2023.\n\n\"Then, he misinterpreted the smile I had at that moment and pushed me. This says a lot about him, how easily he gets irritated and frustrated. It doesn't matter who he is in front of, he is like that, I don't think he has anything against me.\"\n\nAway from the field, he is a huge rap fan - at least his daughter is, having taken her to see Dutch rapper Jonna Fraser in Amsterdam.\n\nHe'll be in good hands with members of the squad such as John Aldridge, who performed the 1988 hit 'Anfield Rap', still knocking about.\n\nThe Reds have other options to become their new manager, but the more you learn about Slot, it seems like a perfect fit.", "source": {"uri": "talksport.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "talkSPORT"}, "authors":
