{"uri": "8096374048", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "08:56:05", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T08:56:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T08:55:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/liverpool-arne-slot-klopp-replacement-32666706", "title": "Slot sent blunt Liverpool warning and told '40 people' will leave with Klopp", "body": "Arne Slot has been warned about the task he faces at Liverpool\n\nArne Slot has been warned that an exodus is coming at Liverpool as Jurgen Klopp prepares to leave Anfield.\n\nKlopp has been in charge of the Reds since 2015, transforming them into one of England's top teams. His reign will come to an end this summer though, in a move the German boss announced in January.\n\nSlot is the current favourite to replace him, with Xabi Alonso having ruled himself out and Ruben Amorim pausing talks. Liverpool chiefs have already opened discussions with Feyenoord over Slot's future.\n\nThe Dutchman has impressed in his native Netherlands, leading Feyenoord to the Eredivisie title last season and the KNVB Cup this year. But former Liverpool star Ryan Babel has warned Slot it will not be smooth sailing if Slot takes over a Anfield.\n\n\"Apart from Klopp, I understand that at least forty more people within the club are leaving. From kitchen people to staff and analysts. A trainer who comes has to replace that, and that doesn't seem easy to me,\" Babel told VoetbalPrimeur.\n\nBabel later clarified that the people set to leave had been brought to Anfield by Klopp. And while he did not name Slot specifically, his comments clearly serve as a warning to the Dutchman.\n\nHe tweeted: \"Any manager having the desire to take the #LFC job has to know that it has to bring more than just a coaching staff to the club. More than 30 people behind the scenes who Klopp brought in, who were a MAJOR part of #LFC success over the years are leaving too. Tough job.\"\n\nHAVE YOUR SAY! Is Arne Slot the right choice by Liverpool? Comment below.\n\nFormer Liverpool star Ryan Babel believes as many as 40 members of staff will exit alongside Jurgen Klopp\n\nBabel is not the only former Liverpool star to be concerned about Slot taking over. Reds legend Jamie Carragher has warned that moving to Anfield from Feyenoord will be a 'huge jump' for Slot to handle.\n\n\"What I would say from Feyenoord to Liverpool is a huge jump and I think it shows in this moment a lack of real top managers out there when you look at who Liverpool were going for. Initially probably Xabi Alonso but it was only his first full season as a manager,\" he told Sky Sports.\n\n\"There was talk of Amorin from Sporting Lisbon but he's only 39. Now Arne Slot looks like he is the favourite right now. I don't think it's like Rafa Benitez coming on or Jurgen Klopp coming in. Benitez came off the back of winning two La Liga titles and a UEFA Cup.\n\n\"Jurgen Klopp coming after winning a couple of titles with Borussia Dortmund and getting to a Champions League final. Liverpool were in a different space then, and that was a Liverpool team under Rafa Benitez that I was part of that was trying to qualify for the top four.\n\n\"The same with Jurgen Klopp when he came in. Liverpool are in a different area now and fancy themselves to challenge for the Premier League next season and the Champions League, they will be expected to reach the quarter-finals at least. I think it is a huge jump, he's obviously a great coach and has a good track record with the clubs he has had so far, so we will see.\"\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community and receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. {"uri": "8094805275", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "11:36:35", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T11:36:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:36:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.thisisanfield.com/2024/04/the-4-key-criteria-liverpool-have-used-to-pick-manager-arne-slot-as-favourite/", "title": "The 4 key criteria Liverpool have used to pick Arne Slot as favourite", "body": "With Arne Slot is now Liverpool's favourite choice to replace Jurgen Klopp as Liverpool manager, we looked at the four key criteria used by the Reds to find the next boss.\n\nArne Slot has become the latest figure to be linked to the Liverpool job, with the Athletic reporting Liverpool have already had their first offer for the Feyenoord manager rejected.\n\nHe, along with the others touted for the role, all have certain skills in common.\n\nPieter Zwart, who is editor-in-chief at Dutch football magazine Voetbal International, wrote about Liverpool looking for four characteristics in particular, and we looked at how Slot fits in to those.\n\nAs Liverpool continue to compete against oil-rich clubs like Man City and Newcastle, being able to elevate a team through good coaching is a vital skill the new manager must have.\n\nDuring his time at Feyenoord, he has actually had a positive net spend with the club often utilising loans, meaning Slot has to work with a large turnover of players.\n\nAgainst PSV and Ajax who have bigger budgets, he won last season's Eredivisie title and recently won this year's Dutch Cup.\n\nAs AZ Alkmaar manager, on an even smaller budget, he had a potential league title taken away when the 2019/20 season was curtailed due to coronavirus while his team were joint-top with Ajax.\n\nSlot tends to play a 4-2-3-1 but doesn't stick to the formation religiously.\n\nHis style was described to the i as \"high-energy attacking football in a 4-3-3 or 4-2-3-1 with two deep-lying midfielders and a reliance on wingers to create chances.\"\n\nAs per the Coaches Voice, Slot doesn't \"overcommit to the high press,\" with his teams \"comfortable dropping into a more reserved block\" if the opportunity to win the ball back is not there.\n\nThis varies slightly from Klopp who rarely sees his team sit deep to soak up pressure.\n\nIn 2022, Slot told UEFA: \"When we don't have the ball, we want to win it back as quickly as possible by being aggressive and pressing to win back possession. I think we are a team that is difficult to beat.\"\n\nSomething that may have edged Liverpool in the direction of Slot over Ruben Amorim, is the fact that the Portuguese manager would potentially have to act more in the transfer market to ensure the squad suits his three-at-the-back system.\n\nWhile Xabi Alonso and Amorim have similar attacking principles to Klopp, Slot sticking with a definite four in defence allows for a smoother transition.\n\nLiverpool managers need to be good communicators and have a strong relationship with supporters. Also, modern football often requires managers to be sympathetic towards their players, a trait Slot shares with Klopp.\n\n\"He can be angry with his players, of course,\" Dennis van Eersel, of Dutch national TV channel RTV, explained. \"But he also puts his arm around them. They like him because he's built a harmony at the club.\"\n\nThe Dutchman already has a good grasp of English, something that seemingly ruled Internazionale boss Simone Inzaghi out of the running Football365", "body": "Liverpool are lining up Arne Slot's first signing as Reds boss with Michael Edwards making Eintracht Frankfurt's Willian Pacho a key target, according to reports.\n\nThe Reds are set for a summer of change after Jurgen Klopp announced earlier this year that he will be leaving Anfield at the end of the season to take a break from football.\n\nFormer Liverpool sporting director Michael Edwards has already returned as Fenway Sports Group's new CEO of football, while Bournemouth's Richard Hughes is joining as their new sporting director.\n\nLiverpool also look set to appoint Feyenoord boss Slot as their new manager with the Reds currently negotiating a compensation fee in order to confirm the move.\n\nTransfer expert Fabrizio Romano has brought an update on the situation with Slot keen to take over at Liverpool in the summer.\n\nRomano wrote in his Caught Offside column: \"It was also an important day in Liverpool's manager search as they spent all day in negotiations with Arne Slot and Feyenoord.\n\nREAD MORE: Premier League winners and losers: Arsenal, Fernandes, Mateta amazing but Chelsea and Liverpool shocking\n\n\"In the morning, Liverpool made contact to start the conversations with Feyenoord, and from what I understand, the Dutch club don't want to say anything about it in public because the talks are going very well.\n\n\"Their relationship is good, talks have been very positive, and that's also the case with Liverpool and their conversations with Slot's agent Rafaela Pimenta.\n\n\"Slot wants the Liverpool job, conversations so far have been super positive, so now it's about reaching an agreement with Feyenoord. It's going well and Slot is now the big favourite to become the next Liverpool manager.\"\n\nFollowing Ibrahima Konate's unconvicing performances in recent months, Liverpool are looking to provide Slot or another new manager a left-sided centre-half.\n\nAnd Italian journalist Gianluca Di Marzio insists Frankfurt's Pacho is 'the target of the Reds to strengthen the rearguard for next season' with Liverpool 'already working' on a deal.\n\nEdwards is 'looking for a new left-footed central defender' and has 'identified the right profile' of player in Pacho, who has already played 40 times for the Bundesliga side in his first season after moving Belgian side Royal Antwerp.\n\nThere have been rumours that some of the Reds' senior players could follow Klopp out the door in the summer but Virgil van Dijk has already been singing Slot's praises.\n\nSpeaking to ViaPlay, Van Dijk said on Slot: \"I think Slot is one of the better Dutch coaches at the moment. With the way he plays and the philosophy he has, he can be a Liverpool coach. But I read and hear that it is far from complete. We shall see. We will focus on that next season, but that is still a long way off.\"\n\nAdding more details on the potential deal to sign Slot, former CBS Sports journalist Ben Jacobs wrote on X: \"More talks today, with things moving fast. \u20ac10m+ compensation required, as revealed. Could be closer to \u20ac15m. {"uri": "8094503998", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "08:39:37", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T08:39:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T08:39:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/liverpool-arne-slot-feyenoord-tottenham-32657987", "title": "Liverpool have 'decisive factor' in Arne Slot talks after rejecting rival", "body": "Feyenoord boss Arne Slot has been installed as the favourite to replace Jurgen Klopp at Liverpool and the Reds could match one of the Dutchman's major demands at Anfield\n\nLiverpool's place in the Champions League could see them finally tempt Arne Slot to make a move to the Premier League.\n\nThe Dutchman has been installed as the favourite to take over the Anfield hot seat once Jurgen Klopp leaves. Reports have suggested that the Reds are ready to move for the current Feyenoord boss after being left frustrated in their pursuits of Xabi Alonso and Ruben Amorim.\n\nIt is not the first time that Slot has been linked with a Premier League switch. Ahead of appointing Ange Postecoglou, it was reported that Tottenham were interested in his services.\n\nThe North London side even went so far as to table an offer to Slot. However, he rejected the chance to move, with managing in the Champions League as one of his key demands.\n\n\"The decisive factor was playing the Champions League,\" the 44-year-old revealed. \"The fantastic work with the staff and the players, the fact that I'm having a great time privately and being able to build on the past two seasons.\n\n\"I didn't know what would happen [with Tottenham]. weighed everything up, including whether the people who work with me would want to come with me. You can think of it, but I don't think it's chic to say! But my intention is to stay because that already raises an expectation.\"\n\nSlot's current side Feyenoord secured a spot in the competition this term after winning the Eredivisie this campaign. They failed to get out of their group - subsequently dropping into the Europa League - and were then eliminated by Serie A giants Roma.\n\nArne Slot wants to manage in the Champions League\n\nWould Arne Slot be a good appointment for Liverpool? Share your thoughts in the comments below\n\nAs it stands, Liverpool could match Slot's demands for a spot in the Champions League next season. The Reds currently sit second in the Premier League and 14 points clear of fifth-placed Tottenham.\n\nTwo wins from their next five games would guarantee Liverpool returning to the top table of European football next term. They are unlikely to be satisfied with that given the Reds could also realistically secure a second Premier League title under Klopp before the end of the season.\n\nElsewhere, Slot could potentially be reunited with Feyenoord next season. The Dutch side are also on the verge of booking their Champions League spot. Slot's side sit second in the Eredivisie but 12 points clear of Twente with four matches of the campaign remaining.\n\nSlot, 45, has two years remaining on his contract in Rotterdam. It has been suggested that it would take \u00a38.59million for Liverpool to buy him out of that deal.\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community and receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.tbsnews.net/sports/liverpool-talks-feyenoord-over-slot-replace-klopp-835656", "title": "Liverpool in talks with Feyenoord over Slot to replace Klopp", "body": "Slot was heavily linked with a possible move to Tottenham Hotspur last year, but opted to stay at Feyenoord and signed a contract extension with the Dutch side until 2026.\n\nLiverpool have lined up Feyenoord coach Arne Slot as successor to departing manager Juergen Klopp and have opened negotiations with the Eredivisie club, Dutch media reported on Wednesday.\n\nThe Algemeen Dagblad newspaper said Liverpool made contact with Feyenoord on Wednesday morning.\n\nSlot was heavily linked with a possible move to Tottenham Hotspur last year, but opted to stay at Feyenoord and signed a contract extension with the Dutch side until 2026.\n\nReports added that Liverpool will have to pay an undisclosed sum to Feyenoord for Slot's services.\n\nHe has been widely praised for his innovative, attacking football with Feyenoord, winning the league title in the 2022-23 season, as well as the KNVB Cup on Sunday.\n\nIn his first season at Feyenoord, he also led the Rotterdam club to the final of the inaugural Europa Conference League.\n\nSlot, who was a journeyman midfielder as a player, began his coaching career at AZ Alkmaar, first as an assistant under John van den Brom, and then head coach from 2019-20.\n\nEarlier this week, Feyenoord CEO Dennis te Kloese responded to questions over Slot's future in an interview with ESPN, saying: \"We assume that he will also be our trainer next year.\n\n\"We have experienced this situation before and will take good care of our own interests.\"\n\nReuters has contacted Liverpool for comment.\n\nLiverpool were linked with a move for their former player and Bayer Leverkusen manager Xabi Alonso earlier this year, but the Spaniard opted to commit his future to the Bundesliga champions.\n\nSporting Lisbon coach Ruben Amorim was also among the names linked with the top job at Liverpool.\n\nKlopp announced in January that he would stand down as Liverpool manager at the end of the season.\n\nThe German joined the club in October 2015 and has won the Champions League, Premier League, Club World Cup, FA Cup, League Cup and Super Cup, as well as the Community Shield.\n\nIn his final campaign, Liverpool have won the League Cup and remain in contention for the Premier League title. Liverpool sit second in the standings with 74 points from 33 matches, three behind leaders Arsenal but with a game in hand.\n\nThey visit local rivals Everton in a league match later on Wednesday.", {"uri": "2024-04-333744948", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "10:40:21", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T10:40:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T23:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.liverpool.com/liverpool-fc-news/features/arne-slot-jurgen-klopp-liverpool-29048205", "title": "Arne Slot already had say on J\u00fcrgen Klopp and Liverpool and hinted at next move", "body": "Feyenoord boss Arne Slot has become a leading contender to take over from J\u00fcrgen Klopp at Liverpool. And the Dutchman has already had his say on the Reds and the job that the German has done.\n\nWhen Klopp announced his departure from Liverpool back at the end of January, Slot was speculated as being a possible option for the Reds. He was directly asked about the Liverpool job and gave an interesting response.\n\n\"What answer can I give that there will be no headlines about it?\" he asked. \"So next question!\" However, in the same press conference, Slot also opened up on his thoughts on Klopp.\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool may be set to pile pressure on Pep Guardiola as Man City disadvantage clear\n\nREAD MORE: Arne Slot's playing style and what Liverpool fans can expect from top contender to be next manager\n\n\"I think it is incredibly impressive that he has been so good at that level for so long, with so much energy for nine years,\" Slot explained, via Voetbal Primeur. \"I see it as a special achievement that you can maintain that level for nine years with so much dedication and passion -- especially when you consider how many games we play, let alone how many they play in England.\"\n\nSlot has previously also spoken about a desire to move abroad and challenge himself in a league away from the Netherlands. The Premier League is the obvious choice for him, though he rejected Spurs last summer.\n\n\"My next step will not be a club in Holland,\" Slot said in May 2023, via Sky Sports. \"If that is my next step, then I've failed completely. The normal next step will be to go abroad and I've always said the best league in the world is the Premier League.\"\n\nLiverpool.com says: There are similarities between how Slot plays and how Klopp has set Liverpool up, which has probably been a key determinant in him being high up on the Reds' shortlist. After all, why would you want to go for something completely different when A) this system works and B) you already have the players to excel like that?\n\nLiverpool has been guided by the data available to Michael Edwards and the group of people tasked with identifying the best possible Klopp successor. {"uri": "2024-04-333924236", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "13:01:55", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T13:01:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T12:47:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/five-reasons-arne-slot-perfect-29051922", "title": "Five reasons why Arne Slot is perfect new Liverpool manager as major step taken", "body": "Liverpool have been given an insight into how Feyenoord boss Arne Slot would adapt to taking over the Reds.\n\nThe club are searching for Jurgen Klopp's replacement and Slot is one of the most recent names to be linked with the upcoming vacancy at Anfield. The ECHO understands that Slot has emerged as a leading contender for the job and that Liverpool have opened negotiations with Feyenoord.\n\nSlot led Feyenoord to the Eredivisie title last season, the club's first since 2017, and has claimed the KNVB Cup this term. The 45-year-old coach was touted with the Tottenham Hotspur job last summer and Europan football expert Andy Brassell has spoken about Slot's suitability to become Liverpool manager, including his past successes and willingness to develop teams.\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool legend was found 'safe and well' after reunion absence sparked bizarre online search\n\nREAD MORE: Jurgen Klopp shares surprise at 'over the top' Everton and Liverpool reaction he wants\n\n\"I think if you look at Feyenoord's points total and the way they've played, in any normal season they are winning the league again but PSV have been absolutely outstanding. They have won the Dutch Cup and this is a guy who has got a consistent record of success and playing attacking football over a number of years,\" Brassell told Sky Sports News, reflecting on Slot's domestic record.\n\n\"In the Covid season, in 2019/20, he could have easily won the league with AZ [Alkmaar] had the league not been brought to an abrupt halt.\"\n\nIn terms of working with Liverpool's squad, Brassell believes that Slot's playing style would not be a wild departure from Klopp's current tactics. The journalist added that Slot developed a rivalry with former Liverpool nemesis Jose Mourinho, with Feyenoord coming up against his Roma side in each of the last three seasons, including the 2022 Europa Conference League final.\n\n\"I think that the idea of developing teams and working with younger players as well is something that really chimes with Liverpool at the moment,\" he explained. \"I think the way he wants to attack is something that would really appeal to Liverpool fans. Someone who wants his teams to always find a way to put pressure on the opposition, to press to score goals. They do that in Europe as well.\"\n\n\"No one is quite like Klopp in front of the media but Slot is no shrinking violet at all,\" Brassell added. \"We've seen this in those Roma games when he's come face-to-face with Jose Mourinho, upset him, and not backed down.\"\n\nThere would be understandable question marks regarding whether Slot could achieve the same level of success, moving across from the Eredivisie to the Premier League. However, Brassell insists that somewhat inevitable comparisons to Manchester United boss Erik ten Hag would be wide of the mark.\n\n\"Premier League clubs have known he would fit here well for quite a while. The Premier League has moved towards possession and being on the front-foot so it's probably the right time,\" Brassell continued.\n\n\"Of course, there's a gap [between the Eredivisie and the Premier League] but it's different to being a player because he will have better players at his disposal. If you look at Erik ten Hag, something that's never really talked about, Ajax had a tonne of defensive problems in his last six months.\n\n\"Even when Erik ten Hag was doing pretty well with Manchester United last year, in some of the defeats they really bottomed out, particularly defensively, so it suggests that some of those issues are something he hasn't really worked on.\n\n\"Whereas, Feyenoord have pretty much the best defensive record in the Eredivisie and they have done over the last two seasons.\"", "source": {"uri": "liverpoolecho.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8097026078", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "15:34:40", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T15:34:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T15:34:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.transfermarkt.co.uk/why-liverpool-want-arne-slot-is-jurgen-klopps-mooted-replacement-the-next-erik-ten-hag-/view/news/436594", "title": "Why Liverpool want Arne Slot - Is J\u00fcrgen Klopp's mooted replacement the next Erik ten Hag?", "body": "Liverpool's title challenge effectively ended after a devastating 2-0 defeat to Everton at Goodison Park on Wednesday night. Sean Dyche's men inflicted a near-fatal blow to their arch rivals' dream of lifting the Premier League title in J\u00fcrgen Klopp's final season at Anfield. The German manager announced his decision to step down in January to recharge his batteries and take a one-year sabbatical from football.\n\nLiverpool were still strongly in contention to win four trophies when Klopp made his announcement but it now looks incredibly likely that the League Cup will be their only silverware this season. With Liverpool's title prospects hanging by a thread, attention has switched to Klopp's replacement at Anfield. Xabi Alonso was their first choice but the Spaniard committed his future to Bayer Leverkusen for another season and Arne Slot has now emerged as the favourite. It's understood that talks have commenced between the Feyenoord manager's representatives and Liverpool's hierarchy. We've taken a closer look at Slot's managerial history and style with fantastic insight from Transfermarkt's Eredivisie experts.\n\nThe reports of Slot being Liverpool's preferred candidate has split opinion amongst supporters who originally had their hearts set on Alonso returning to Anfield. Fittingly, Slot ended Ajax's dominance in the Eredivisie by winning the title with Feyenoord last season after Erik ten Hag departed for Manchester United. Feyenoord, however, endured a difficult start to this season and PSV can secure the title this evening with a win over Heerenveen. It's difficult to avoid comparisons between Slot and Ten Hag given the jobs they undertook in the Eredivisie and Kevin Lux, Transfermarkt's Area Manager for the Netherlands, admits similarities exist.\n\n\"It is always hard to say if a manager from the Eredivisie is a good fit in the Premier League, same as for players,\" Lux said. \"Look at Erik ten Hag, who was brilliant at Ajax, but doesn't seem to get United on track again. Liverpool is an even harder task in my opinion, because the new manager has to succeed a club icon in Klopp. In many ways, Slot could be called the new Ten Hag, because he made a Dutch team into a team that did well in Europe. He made the Conference League final two years ago and played well in the Europa League a year later. Just like Ten Hag at Ajax, Slot had to replace his most important players every year and every year, he succeeded in building a competitive team very quickly. It was bad luck that he had an impossible to beat PSV in the Eredivisie this year, otherwise, he would have been champions again this year.\"\n\nWhile Ten Hag's debut season in England was ultimately successful after leading Man United to their first silverware in six years and a third-place finish, it's been a difficult second campaign. United are languishing in sixth place and their tactical plan has been severely criticised. Replacing Klopp is widely viewed as an unenviable task given the transformation he's overseen at Liverpool but Lux believes Slot will bring \"fun\" to Anfield - if he's afforded time. \"I'm curious to see how he does when he has to perform in the best league in the world at one of the best clubs in the world. When he started at Feyenoord, there was no pressure whatsoever, so when he managed to get them back in contention, he was the instant hero in Rotterdam. That was the reason he got away with a relatively slow start this season. Liverpool probably doesn't give him that time and luxury. But when he gets the time he needs to build his own team, I am confident Liverpool will have a lot of fun with Slot.\"\n\nNow in only his fifth season as a senior head coach, 44-year-old Slot has taken football in the Netherlands by storm and has quickly established himself as one of the most promising coaches in all of European football. Following youth and first team coaching roles at PEC Zwolle and Cambuur, Slot was hired by AZ Alkmaar as the club's assistant coach in 2017 and then went on to step up to the main job in 2019. And in no time at all, the Bergentheim-born tactician got to work on turning the Dutch club around. After finishing fourth the previous year, Slot took the club to second place, missing out on the top spot by little more than goal difference in a campaign that was cut short due to the COVID pandemic.\n\nAnd before long Feyenoord had come calling for the young manager. Tasked with replacing Dick Advocaat and building a squad that could improve on being the best of the rest in Dutch football, Slot hit the ground running immediately and guided Feyenoord to a third-place finish in his first season before winning the title in his second season with a second-place finish likely this season. \"Arne Slot embodies the new generation of Dutch managers,\" notes Kevin Lux, Transfermarkt's content manager in the Netherlands. \"Together with Erik ten Hag, he has shown to be able to transform underdogs into contenders, both at AZ and now Feyenoord. He knows how to give his teams a tactical advantage and players he works with show incredible improvement.\"\n\nThere's little doubt that Slot's success in Dutch football is clear for all to see on paper, but what kind of football do his teams actually play? \"One of the key components is that all of his teams are extremely fit,\" says Lux, when asked about the Slot style of football. \"Slot lets his team play in an organised, attacking way. There is a lot of movement on the midfield and on the wings, which makes it hard to defend. The key component is, however, their level of fitness.\"", "source": {"uri": "transfermarkt.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "transfermarkt.co.uk"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": stiff competition", "body": "Liverpool have entered into talks with Feyenoord for Arne Slot after identifying the Dutchman as their preferred candidate to take over from Jurgen Klopp.\n\nSlot, who won the Dutch Cup last week and the Eredivisie last season, has two years left on the three-year contract extension he signed last summer.\n\nLiverpool could face competition for the 45-year-old from Barcelona and Bayern Munich with Slot emerging as a potential contender for several of the major jobs that will be on offer this summer.\n\nThe Merseyside club have known since November that they would need to appoint a successor to Klopp, but the process has accelerated since Michael Edwards agreed to return to Anfield as Fenway Sports Group's CEO of football, while Richard Hughes will also join as sporting director.\n\nLiverpool have assessed the credentials of various managers, with Sporting Lisbon's Ruben Amorim one who attracted their interest, but the early favourite for the job, Xabi Alonso, instead decided to stay at Bayer Leverkusen.\n\nSlot has earned a reputation for playing high-energy attacking football and for improving players, some of the criteria for Liverpool as {"uri": "8095091095", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "14:26:58", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T14:26:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T14:26:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://thesportsgrail.com/who-is-arne-slot-linked-to-liverpool-bio-age-height-wife-style-of-play-tactics-and-teams-coached/", "title": "Who is Arne Slot linked to Liverpool, bio, age, height, wife, style of play, tactics and teams coached", "body": "Arne Slot is a Dutch manager who is currently linked to becoming the next Liverpool manager, find out more about him below along with his family and wife\n\nSlot has quickly become the new favorite, but he remains a relatively unknown figure to a lot of people in the Premier League.\n\nWith Jurgen Klopp set for a possible exit this summer, Sporting boss Ruben Amorim was the probable favourite who got ruled out following talks with West Ham.\n\nArend Martijn Slot is a Dutch professional football coach and former player who was born on September 17, 1978, in Bergentheim, Netherlands. He is currently working as the head coach of Eredivisie side Feyenoord. He started out his career in football as a midfielder who played for teams like FC Zwolle, NAC Breda, and Sparta Rotterdam before retiring as a player following a return at PEC Zwolle.\n\nHe is married to Miriam and that he has children and his children are believed to be in secondary school.\n\nArne Slot is of Dutch nationality.\n\nArne Slot is currently 45 years old and stands at a height of 1.84 m (6 ft).\n\nPrior to becoming a manager, Arne Slot was a professional footballer who spent his entire playing career in the Netherlands. After retiring, he chose a path in management and first managed AZ Alkmaar from 2019-2020 and now manages Feyenoord.\n\nSlot led the club to a Europa Conference League final in his first season at the club and has already led them to an Eredivisie title in his second year. And during his third season, he helped them win the KNVB Cup. Just last summer, he was a strong candidate to take over at Tottenham.\n\nArne Slot usually prefers to play a fluid 4-2-3-1 formation described as \"a high-energy attacking football in a 4-3-3 or 4-2-3-1 with two deep-lying midfielders and a reliance on wingers to create chances.\"\n\nArne Slot has managed Feyenoord ever since 2021/22 and the team currently boasts the best defensive record in the Eredivisie. Feyenoord have conceded just 23 goals in 30 games, and also have the record of the second-most goals scored (77). While explaining his approach with Feyenoord, Slot shared:\n\nWe are an attack-minded team that likes to have a lot of the ball, and we play with a lot of intensity.\n\nWhen we don't have the ball, we want to win it back as quickly as possible by being aggressive and pressing to win back possession. I think we are a team that is difficult to beat.\"\n\nArne likes to trust in his youth and has a good man-management skills. Despite being a senior manager for just five years, he has already drawn comparisons to Marcelo Bielsa's style. The 45-year-old likes to play his full-backs high up the pitch with his centre-backs simultaneously moving wider.\n\nLiverpool are a big club and cannot have just any manager leading the club. However, by the looks of things, Arne could have the qualities of a top manager. Sky Sports have previously described him as \"engaging, polite, very smiley, he's got presence and charisma; and he's funny.\" While possessing all these characteristics, he can also be stern and strict with his players.\n\nMoreover, despite his Dutch background, he can speak fluent English, and has previously expressed interest in joining the Premier League. He said in an interview:\n\nMy next step will not be a club in Holland.\n\nIf that is my next step, then I've failed completely. The normal next step will be to go abroad and I've always said the best league in the world is the Premier League.\"", "source": {"uri": "thesportsgrail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Slot has impressed during his time at Feyenoord, guiding them to the Eredivisie title last season and a KNVB Cup triumph this year.\n\nHe was a contender for the Tottenham job before Ange Postecoglou took over last summer and admitted he was interested in a move to the Premier League. \"The next step will not be another club in Holland,\" he said.\n\n\"If that is the next step, I've failed completely in the upcoming few years. A normal next step would be to go abroad and I've always said that the best league in the world is the Premier League.\"\n\nAccording to the Daily Mail, it would cost Liverpool \u00a38.59m in compensation to appoint the Dutchman as he is under contract until 2026, having signed an extension last summer after deciding against a move to Spurs.\n\nHowever, Slot is also the subject of interest from Bayern Munich as they search for Thomas Tuchel's replacement. He is one of several contenders for the job, alongside De Zerbi and Ralf Rangnick.\n\nAnd Dutch legend Marco van Basten believes Slot has what it takes to be a success outside the Netherlands. \"I think Slot is really good. I hope he stays in the Netherlands longer because it is an enrichment for Dutch football,\" Van Basten said.\n\nArne Slot is also attracting interest from Bayern Munich\n\n\"He can really go anywhere: Bayern Munich, Liverpool... I'm really convinced of that. I hope he stays in the Netherlands, but I am convinced he can do it anywhere. I've spoken to him a few times, and he handles the players very well.\n\n\"Of course, he is also very well-versed tactically. I can explain his ideas well; he is calm and intelligent. As far as I am concerned, he is a top trainer. I really think he can go to any club, even difficult clubs. He is very smart in his choice of words.\"\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community and receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. In his final campaign, Liverpool have won the League Cup and remain in contention for the Premier League title.\n\nLiverpool have lined up Feyenoord coach Arne Slot as successor to departing manager Juergen Klopp and have opened negotiations with the Eredivisie club, Dutch media reported on Wednesday.\n\nThe Algemeen Dagblad newspaper said Liverpool made contact with Feyenoord on Wednesday morning. Slot was heavily linked with a possible move to Tottenham Hotspur last year, but opted to stay at Feyenoord and signed a contract extension with the Dutch side until 2026.\n\nReports added that Liverpool will have to pay an undisclosed sum to Feyenoord for Slot's services. He has been widely praised for his innovative, attacking football with Feyenoord, winning the league title in the 2022-23 season, as well as the KNVB Cup on Sunday.\n\nIn his first season at Feyenoord, he also led the Rotterdam club to the final of the inaugural Europa Conference League. Slot, who was a journeyman midfielder as a player, began his coaching career at AZ Alkmaar, first as an assistant under John van den Brom, and then head coach from 2019-20.\n\nEarlier this week, Feyenoord CEO Dennis te Kloese responded to questions over Slot's future in an interview with ESPN, saying: \"We assume that he will also be our trainer next year. \"We have experienced this situation before and will take good care of our own interests.\"\n\nReuters has contacted Liverpool for comment. Liverpool were linked with a move for their former player and Bayer Leverkusen manager Xabi Alonso earlier this year, but the Spaniard opted to commit his future to the Bundesliga champions.\n\nSporting Lisbon coach Ruben Amorim was also among the names linked with the top job at Liverpool. Klopp announced in January that he would stand down as Liverpool manager at the end of the season.\n\nThe German joined the club in October 2015 and has won the Champions League, Premier League, Club World Cup, FA Cup, League Cup and Super Cup, as well as the Community Shield. In his final campaign, Liverpool have won the League Cup and remain in contention for the Premier League title. Liverpool sit second in the standings with 74 points from 33 matches, three behind leaders Arsenal but with a game in hand.\n\nThey visit local rivals Everton in a league match later on They're currently second and about to relinquish their crown, but given the frankly remarkable form of table-toppers PSV this season, that's nothing to be sniffed at.\n\nEnglish clubs have tried to nab Slot before, with the 45-year-old turning down both Tottenham and Leeds last year. Known for his eye-catching football style and a knack for nurturing young talent, Slot could be a perfect fit at Anfield. Klopp have been slashed, and the Dutchman has already made his feelings clear on a potential move to Liverpool.\n\nLiverpool are on the hunt for a new manager with Jurgen Klopp set to leave the club at the end of the season.\n\nBack in January Klopp made the surprise announcement that he will step down from his position, and since then plenty of top coaches have been linked with the vacancy.\n\nXabi Alonso was the firm favourite to replace Klopp, but the former Liverpool star committed his future to current side Bayer Leverkusen.\n\nSince then Ruben Amorim has heavily linked with the role, although earlier this month the Sporting CP boss was forced to deny reports he had agreed a deal with the Premier League side.\n\nBrighton manager Roberto De Zerbi is another favourite, but the odds on Feyenoord manager Arne Slot have now been slashed by betfair.\n\nThe 45-year-old guided Feyenoord to the 2022 Europa Conference League final in his first season in charge, before winning the Eredivisie in 2022-23 and the Dutch Cup this season.\n\nThe odds on him replacing Klopp have been slashed to 4/1, making him the second favourite for the position after Amorim.\n\nAnd going off his previous comments, the Dutchman would be up for the job if approached by Liverpool.\n\n\"My next step will not be a club in Holland,\" he said last year, via Sky Sports.\n\n\"If that is my next step, then I've failed completely. The normal next step will be to go abroad and I've always said the best league in the world is the Premier League.\"\n\nLast year Slot was linked with both Leeds United and Tottenham Hotspur, before he ended up penning a new deal with Feyenoord.\n\nWhen asked earlier this year about the possibility of replacing Klopp, Slot said, via Voetbal Primeur: \"What answer can I give that there will be no headlines about it? The likes of Rubin Amorim and Roberto De Zerbi have been linked with making the move to Merseyside but it appears Liverpool have made the 45-year-old their priority.\n\nIt does not appear Slot will be short of options, and the club's sporting hierarchy, including the returning Michael Edwards and sporting director Richard Hughes, will have to prove persuasive. The Feyenoord boss is said to also be fielding interest from Bayern Munich, with Thomas Tuchel to depart this summer.\n\nLiverpool are not the first members of the Premier League to have been impressed by Slot's work in the Netherlands either. The former Zwolle and Breda midfielder finished as runner-up in the Europa Conference league in his first year managing Feyenood, before adding an Eredivisie title in his second and he lifted the KNVB Cup with his side in 2023/24.\n\nSlot was on the shortlist of Tottenham last summer but chose to stay in his home nation, before the Lilywhites appointed Ange Postecoglou. Across north London lies a figure who may know him better than most in the Premier League however.\n\nReiss Nelson played under Slot 31 times at Feyenoord and was impressed in his time at the club. \"Holland was great for me,\" the winger said of his loan spell in 2021/22.\n\n\"I felt like Arne Slot is a great manager. He really got me into my rhythm. He gave me a lot of opportunities to play and I excelled.\n\nReiss Nelson celebrates after helping Feyenoord reach the Conference League final\n\n\"It was really cool, like I said we got to the final. But football-wise, it was perfect.\"\n\nLiverpool are planning talks over a settlement package with Feyenoord in a bid to prise their manager away. PASS named after him", "body": "ARNE SLOT was a good enough player to have a type of pass named after him.\n\nBut the question Liverpool are pondering is whether Slot would make a better fist of running one of the biggest clubs in the world than Ten Hag so far has at Old Trafford.\n\nSlot, 45, was certainly easier on the eye as a player than centre back Ten Hag.\n\n\"The Arne Slot Ball\" was something he perfected as a silky No 10 - a back-to-goal, first-time, 180-degree spin and flick behind the defensive line for a winger to run on to deep in the opposition half.\n\nBram van Polen was Slot's team-mate when he ended his playing career with a three-year spell back at first pro club PEC Zwolle.\n\nVan Polen, now Zwolle captain, saw Slot the coach emerging in their spell together and said: \"You sometimes still see things in the game at Feyenoord.\n\n\"The Arne Slot ball still exists with us at PEC and Kokcu [Feyenoord's Turkish playmaker] also wants to play those type of passes.\n\n\"We also did a lot of pressing and played exactly the same as Feyenoord now.\n\nIt is also no surprise that Slot is high on Liverpool's shortlist to succeed Jurgen Klopp, just as Ten Hag was an attractive candidate for United.\n\nIn fact, but for the pandemic, Slot might have put himself in a position to be considered by United as well or at least raised questions about Ten Hag's credentials.\n\nAfter cutting his teeth at Cambuur, Slot moved to AZ Alkmaar in 2017 as assistant before becoming head coach for the 2019/20 season.\n\nIn March 2020, AZ won 2-0 at Ajax to put themselves level on points with Ten Hag's defending champions with nine games to go.\n\nBut when Covid-19 took hold, the Dutch season was abandoned, denying Slot the chance to win his first title.\n\nIn contrast, the Premier League campaign resumed later in the year and Klopp was able to guide Liverpool to their first championship for three decades\n\nSlot had another bump in the road when AZ found out in December 2020 that he had been talking to Feyenoord about replacing outgoing boss Dick Advocaat.\n\nHe was sacked and spent six months playing golf before taking up the post in Rotterdam.\n\nSlot showed he could mix it with the best even before his first season began.\n\nAfter a bad-tempered friendly against Atletico Madrid, he and Diego Simeone got physical.\n\nSlot later explained: \"At that moment, at the end of the match, I turned to Simeone to tell him how passionate he was even in a friendly match.\n\n\"Then, he misinterpreted the smile I had at that moment and pushed me.\"\n\nFeyenoord reached the Europa Conference League final in Slot's debut campaign, losing to Jose Mourinho's Roma.\n\nAlthough Ten Hag led Ajax to a third title in a row, it was Slot who won the Netherlands' Manager of the Year award.\n\nTen Hag left for Old Trafford that summer of 2022 but key Feyenoord players Luis Sinisterra and Marcos Senesi also moved to the Premier League, to Leeds and Bournemouth, and other sales left the Rotterdam club looking short of quality and depth.\n\nYet Slot took Feyenoord to their first Dutch title for six years, playing an exciting brand of football with a team mostly aged 24 or under.\n\nLike Klopp, he is said to be an expert man-manager who communicates clearly to his players what he expects from them.\n\nSlot turned down the chance to join Tottenham last year and signed a new deal with Feyenoord.\n\nFeyenoord did not get out of their Champions League group, despite beating both Celtic and Lazio, and lost their title to a PSV side having an incredible season.\n\nBut Slot led the club to Dutch Cup triumph recently and his star remains in the ascendent.\n\nIt's fair to say coaches from the Netherlands have had mixed fortunes in England.\n\nNo Dutchman has won a Premier League title and former Eredivisie champions like Louis van Gaal, Frank de Boer and now Ten Hag have all found life tough, for various reasons.\n\nSlot ticks a lot of boxes for Liverpool. His teams have consistently played attractive football and competed with rivals with even bigger budgets. He improves players and gives youngsters a chance. He is funny, likeable and charismatic.\n\nBut to match Klopp's achievements, Slot will have to do better than any of his compatriots, including Ten Hag.", "source": {"uri": "thescottishsun.co.uk", {"uri": "2024-04-333503763", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "07:24:08", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T07:24:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T05:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.liverpool.com/liverpool-fc-news/features/arne-slot-liverpool-transfers-formation-29048227", "title": "Four things happen if Liverpool hires Slot including transfers and formation", "body": "Arne Slot is the new favorite to take over from J\u00fcrgen Klopp at Liverpool. The 45-year-old Dutch coach has an impressive track record in the Netherlands, where he won the Eredivisie title last season, and he is an intriguing option.\n\nMichael Edwards, now FSG's CEO of football, has always been guided by the data during the ongoing process of identifying the best candidate for the Liverpool head coach role. And it is not hard to see why Slot scores highly: his side is intense, aggressive, and performs above its expected level.\n\nSlot has experience of fighting at the top end of the table and plays in a broadly similar way to how Klopp has at Liverpool, so the Reds squad would not need a complete overhaul. The only question would be how quickly he could adapt to A) the Premier League and B) managing a massive club of Liverpool's size.\n\nREAD MORE: Six players could benefit if Arne Slot replaces J\u00fcrgen Klopp amid Liverpool next manager latest\n\nREAD MORE: Arne Slot already had say on J\u00fcrgen Klopp and Liverpool and hinted at next move\n\nThese are the four things that Liverpool.com believes will 'definitely' happen if Slot does take over at Anfield. He is a leading option for the club, and a very interesting one at that.\n\nFormation decision made\n\nAt the moment, Slot plays with a double pivot in midfield as part of a 4-2-3-1 system. But that would not necessarily have to remain the same if he were to move to Liverpool.\n\nThe Dutch coach likes broadly similar things from his team to what Klopp does and he could easily adapt his ideas to more of a 4-3-3 formation. With Liverpool having so many good midfield options, that might make more sense.\n\nInevitable transfer links\n\nLiverpool might want to strengthen in a couple of places this summer and it will not be signing anyone based only on the manager who comes in. If it is R\u00faben Amorim, that won't mean an influx of Sporting CP players. Likewise, Slot coming in will not mean a sudden arrival of Feyenoord stars.\n\nThe links, though, are inevitable. Dirk Kuyt, speaking to the ECHO, has previously suggested that Liverpool should sign Lutsharel Geertruida and Orkun K\u00f6k\u00e7\u00fc, though the latter has already moved to Benfica.\n\nStyle of play evolves again\n\nSlot and Klopp both like a high-pressing, high-energy way of playing. The counter-press is king when it comes to playmaking and ensuring that their sides win the ball back high upfield.\n\nBut Liverpool cannot exclusively use that method. Most teams in the Premier League sit back and defend against the Reds and that is something that Slot would have to get used to quickly. He would have more than enough quality at his disposal to be able to do that, though, and it would be particularly interesting what plan he might have for Trent Alexander-Arnold.\n\nXabi Alonso and R\u00faben Amorim comparisons\n\nBefore Slot's name emerged, Xabi Alonso and then R\u00faben Amorim both appealed to Liverpool fans. Alonso, in particular, would have been a shoo-in for getting fans onside but he opted to stay with Bayer Leverkusen.\n\nWhoever comes in at Liverpool -- Slot or someone else entirely -- will face inevitable comparisons not just to Klopp but to the others that Reds supporters wanted to see installed as head coach. The new appointment will need to be their own person, however.\n\nTrying to be a version of Klopp would never go well. Get a few positive results early on, though, and play an exciting brand of football, with this exciting group of Liverpool players, there is a real chance to build on what is left behind.", "source": The Portuguese Man of War had a score to settle with Arne Slot and was determined to say his piece.\n\nSlot, the man who is expected to become Liverpool's next king, had lit the blue touch paper in a pre-match press conference. The first leg between the sides had ended in a 1-1 draw and ahead of the return, Slot was asked if he had watched any of Roma's recent games to learn about them.\n\nWith a wry smile, Slot replied he'd seen \"one or two\" but made it clear his idea of learning was watching Pep Guardiola's Manchester City. His style of football and views on how fluently the game should be played are closely aligned with the Catalan's, not the prosaic functionality of Mourinho.\n\nBeing the man that he is, Mourinho was never going to let it lie.\n\nFeyenoord manager Arne Slot is the man expected to succeed Jurgen Klopp at Liverpool this summer\n\nJurgen Klopp has just five games left as Liverpool manager before he ends a near nine year stay at the club\n\nSlot led Feyenoord to only their second Eredivisie title in 24 years last season\n\nPodcast All episodes PODCAST: Listen to our EXCLUSIVE interview with Phil Foden IAKO! - Nottingham Forest are making fools of themselves! Play on Apple Spotify\n\n'Hey!' he shouted when seeing Slot milling around outside his dressing room. 'Maybe you should have watched those games - you might know what it takes to be a winner!'\n\nIf only he had kept his mouth closed. Three months later, Slot had turned Feyenoord into Champions of The Netherland for just the second time in the 21st century, their charge to the title seeing them rack up 11 straight wins after that trip to Rome.\n\nThe significance of the triumph should not be underestimated. There are three huge clubs in The Netherlands but Feyenoord had for long been the poor relation of Ajax and PSV Eindhoven, until Slot brought them back to the summit. Does that narrative sound familiar?\n\nREAD MORE: Arne Slot's hefty compensation fee revealed as Liverpool consider move for Feyenoord boss to replace Jurgen Klopp Advertisement\n\nTo stand any chance of succeeding Jurgen Klopp, Liverpool's next manager will require a certain character and Slot, evidently, will not be found wanting when it comes to standing up for himself or saying it how he sees it. In many respects, he is similar in that way to the German.\n\nBut the next man in charge at Anfield is also going to have to win matches - and lots of them - to prevent a post-Klopp hangover from creeping in and there is reason to believe that Slot will do that: one thing for certain is that there won't be any Mourinho conservativism.\n\nTwo weeks before that game in Rome, Feyenood had played in a KNVB cup tie at home to NEC Nijmegen. Those in the De Kuip stadium had been left flabbergasted by what they had seen from Slot's team in terms of relentless attacking.\n\nRemarkably, over 120 minutes, Feyenoord had 50 shots on goal, 27 of which were on target. There were 17 corners, an avalanche of possession. Somehow the game finished 4-4 - NEC converted four of their six chances on the counter - but the hosts' progressed via a penalty shootout.\n\nIt wasn't so much the result that was notable that night, more how Feyenoord had played. Afterwards, phones were buzzing amongst the Rotterdam hierarchy that they felt they had their own version of Guardiola. They also knew that his progress was not going to go unnoticed.\n\nAround that time, Leeds were keen to recruit him and their former Director of Football Victor Orta flew into Rotterdam to see if he could do a deal. Feyenoord were never going to entertain, nor was Slot - a married father to a son and daughter - who had grander ambitions than Elland Road.\n\nThe significance of the triumph should not be underestimated, considering how far Feyenoord's stock has fallen in recent years\n\nFeyenoord claimed the KNVB Cup last weekend after a 1-0 win over NEC Nijmegen\n\nQuinten Timber, twin brother of Arsenal defender Justin, has flourished under Slot's guidance\n\nOpportunities presented themselves again last summer. He could have gone to Tottenham, he could have even gone to Chelsea but such was Feyenoord's commitment to keeping him, Chairman Toon van Bodegom rewarded him with the biggest contract ever given to a manager in The Netherlands.\n\nNobody had been put on deal of \u00a35million a year but Slot, they were adamant, was worth every penny. He backed up their faith again this season, delivering the KNVB Cup last Sunday with a 1-0 win over NEC Nijmegen - a far more controlled affair than their previous meeting.\n\nSlot has a bond with his players - Quinten Timber, twin brother of Arsenal defender Justin, has flourished under his guidance, as has Slovakian defender David Hancko - that stems from his commitment to improvement every single day.\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool close in on Arne Slot as their next manager with talks developing quickly to take over from Jurgen Klopp - and deal for Dutchman could even be concluded by THIS WEEKEND Advertisement\n\n'Feyenoord players always say: \"Everything the trainer predicted, we saw in the game\",' says one Rotterdam-based source. 'Arne is a workaholic. He's also happy to work with staff and delegate. He has a coach for this, a coach for that, and for that and that and that!\n\n'They have to feed him with information and then he makes his tactical plan. Feyenoord and Ajax have the biggest fanbases but Slot brought them back to the top. There was Luis Sinisterrra who didn't work out at first and everyone wanted to give up on him.\n\n'I don't know what Slot did but all of a sudden, he was filling his potential. He went to Leeds for \u00a325m, one of Feyenoord's biggest sales ever. Before Slot he could have gone for a nickel and dime! He puts belief in players. He rebuilt the club when best players left.'\n\nCritics will argue that Slot's team trail PSV in the title race this time around but the irony is they have more points than at this stage 12 months ago and recently obliterated Ajax 6-0: PSV, for their part, have been like a runaway train, with just one defeat and one draw.\n\nAll this has been noted by Liverpool. The key requisites for Klopp's replacement was that he had to develop players, be able to build a connection with fans and have a commitment to the club's style of play and he ticks all the boxes.\n\nIt would be wrong to bill as Klopp 2:0 but it is easy to see parallels in their respective careers in that they started out at good solid, clubs - for Mainz and Klopp, read AZ Alkmaar and Slot - before going to be grander stages.\n\nSlot, really, could have won the title with AZ but his time there ended in frustration, with the club's top brass telling him on Saturday morning he had to leave immediately after it became clear he was not going to sign another contract, amid interest from Feyenoord.\n\nSlot's ability to connect with his players has been noted as one of his key strengths\n\nFeyenoord humiliated their old rivals Ajax by beating them 6-0 in Rotterdam earlier this month\n\n'As a club, we have chosen to say goodbye immediately,\" director of football Max Huiberts said in a statement on the club's website. 'We want to have a head coach leading the team who is fully focused on AZ.' The manner of that departure still rankles Slot.\n\nHow will it end in Rotterdam? That remains to be seen but the end, seemingly, could happen very soon. Liverpool made contact with Feyenoord on Wednesday morning and the intention is for getting the deal done as quickly as possible, once a compensation package can be resolved.\n\nThen Slot will be clear to start a new chapter, for him and for his new club. The 45-year-old is looking certain to become the next Liverpool boss, if the latest reports are to be believed.\n\nWith Slot, the Merseyside club cannot only expect attacking football, similar like they have experienced under Jurgen Klopp, but also shrewd recruitment.\n\nAccording to the Express, the appointment of Slot could help Liverpool sign one of their long term transfer targets.\n\nSigning Atalanta midfielder Teun Koopmeiners might become a possibility for Liverpool if they appoint Slot.\n\nThe Dutch midfielder made 58 appearances for Slot at AZ Alkmaar. He scored 21 goals in that period and provided seven assists.\n\nKoopmeiners is familiar with Slot's system, which might be extremely helpful when a new boss takes over.\n\nIt is believed that an offer of about \u00a343 million should be sufficient to get Koopmeiners to sign.\n\nBence Bocsak on X has revealed how crucial Koopmeiners was under the management of Slot and how he could be the one The 45-year-old ticked all the key criteria for the position at Anfield, although the process is not a foregone conclusion, with the Eredivisie club determined to keep him.\n\nLiverpool's interest in Slot stems from his aggressive, full-throttle style of play. He has drilled Feyenoord to be adept at turning defensive actions into scoring opportunities, and they top the Eredivisie in tackles won in the opposition's final third. Feyenoord also boasts the best defence in the league and the second-best offensive metrics.\n\nSlot has proved capable of improving individual players and the collective while operating on a smaller budget than his competitors. His preferred formations, 4-2-3-1 or 4-4-3, fit Liverpool's squad. He has previously been approached by Tottenham Hotspur, Chelsea, and Leeds, but he signed a new contract last May, keeping him at Feyenoord until 2026.\n\nHowever, Slot has referenced a desire to take the next step in his career. {"uri": "8097325086", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "19:25:14", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T19:25:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T19:24:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.thenationalnews.com/sport/football/2024/04/25/arne-slot-confident-of-being-named-new-liverpool-manager/", "title": "Arne Slot 'confident' of being named new Liverpool manager", "body": "Feyenoord coach Arne Slot says he has \"every confidence\" of a deal being concluded that will see him replace Jurgen Klopp as Liverpool manager.\n\nLong-serving boss Klopp, whose side saw their Premier League title ambitions dealt a hammer blow in a 2-0 defeat to Merseyside rivals Everton on Wednesday night, is stepping down at the end of the season.\n\nSlot emerged as a leading contender for the role this week, with multiple reports suggesting that the Reds had begun negotiations with his Rotterdam club.\n\nSpeaking to ESPN Netherlands, Slot confirmed his interest in the role.\n\nThe 45-year-old said: \"The clubs are negotiating. I am waiting to see what will come out of it. It will be no secret that I would like to go to Liverpool. Now I am waiting for the clubs to reach an agreement. I have every confidence in that.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Liverpool captain Virgil van Dijk welcomed the potential arrival of his countryman, saying that his attacking tactics could be an ideal match for the Premier League club.\n\n\"I find it hard to answer of course, but I think Arne Slot is perhaps one of the better Dutch coaches at this moment,\" Van Dijk told Viaplay following Liverpool's defeat at Everton.\n\n\"I think the way of playing and the philosophy he has, that he could be a Liverpool coach.\n\n\"Only I think from what I read and hear is that it's still far from being completed. We shall see.\"\n\nIf Slot is chosen to take over from Klopp, who led Liverpool to the Premier League title in 2020 and won the Champions League the year before, he will likely have to lift a team that is set for a disappointing finish to the season.\n\nLiverpool's loss at Goodison Park left them three points behind leaders Arsenal with four games left.\n\nThird-placed Manchester City will retain the title if they win their last six matches. After quarter-final defeats in the FA Cup and Europa League, Klopp's farewell season is fizzling out, and Van Dijk admitted they don't deserve to win the title.\n\n\"Games likes these, the bare minimum is fight. We were lacking that at so many moments in games,\" Van Dijk added.\n\n\"If you play like we did, obviously even if we create two or three clear-cut chances again, you don't deserve to win the league.\n\n\"It's crunch time and we've not been good enough in the way we finished the chances off, in the way we defended together and also the fight. I think we have to show much more.\n\n\"But we have to look in the mirror and each and every one of us has to think like 'listen, you can't accept this. You can't accept the way we let our season end'.\"\n\nAfter Bayer Leverkusen boss Xabi Alonso ruled himself out of the running to replace Klopp, Slot is the frontrunner and his record suggests he could make an impact in English football.\n\nSlot was also a leading candidate to take charge at Tottenham last year before choosing to stay in the Eredivisie as Ange Postecoglou eventually joined the north Londoners.\n\nEmploying an attacking philosophy, Slot led Feyenoord to the Dutch title in 2023 and won the Dutch Cup this season. He came close to winning the league with former club AZ Alkmaar in 2019-20 only to narrowly miss out to Ajax on points-per-game after the pandemic saw the league curtailed in April.\n\nFeyenoord are currently second in the table, nine points behind PSV Eindhoven with four games left.", "source": {"uri": "thenationalnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The National"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8095526265", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "19:42:32", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T19:42:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T19:42:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.dailystar.co.uk/sport/football/arne-slot-liverpool-feyenoord-manager-32664596", "title": "Footage of Arne Slot has Liverpool fans convinced whether he's right man for job", "body": "Whomever succeeds Jurgen Klopp at Liverpool will need to have lofty ambitions, and in that sense Arne Slot appears to tick the right boxes.\n\nAt least that's what many Liverpool fans believe after witnessing one of the Dutchman's team talks en route to clinching last season's Eredivisie crown. His side became the first Feyenoord team in 17 years to beat Ajax in Amsterdam, which helped pave the way for the club ending its six-year wait for a league title.\n\nNot to be content with that 3-2 triumph alone, however, Slot was quick to remind his charges of their responsibility to aim higher. And that's precisely the attitude Reds fans will be hoping to see in any Klopp replacement as they target new heights in the years to come.\n\nREAD MORE: Arne Slot nearing Liverpool appointment with negotiations on over Feyenoord compensation\n\nREAD MORE: New Liverpool line up under Arne Slot could see Mo Salah sold and three big transfers\n\n\"The reason we are where we are is because you work your a***s off every single day, and that's the reason why you could beat this team here in their own stadium without our fans even being here,\" the 45-year-old told his players following a famous victory in March 2023. \"But, that again is an obligation for the upcoming weeks because you guys are going all to the national teams. Some will play, some don't but we need to stay fit boys.\n\n\"This is only a win. It's not more than a win. It's a big win but it's not more than a win. We have a bigger goal this season and only winning for the first time in 17 years in Amsterdam.\"\n\nWhich manager would be Liverpool's dream replacement for Jurgen Klopp? Let us know in the comments section below.\n\nFollowing in the footsteps of one of Liverpool's greatest coaches will be no easy task for whomever ultimately receives the honour. But plenty of supporters were quick to gush over the mentality on display.\n\n\"Okay. . .I'm impressed,\" wrote one fan. \"He can be the right one to fill the Slot Klopp left.\" Another emotional admirer commented: \"Genuinely tearing up watching this speech. We've bagged an elite manager.\"\n\nMeanwhile, a third remarked: \"Guys I'm excited now I've come around to the idea of him as manager.\"\n\nSlot is contracted in Rotterdam until the summer of 2026, but it's reported Liverpool are negotiating with Feyenoord regarding a compensation fee for the tactician. Slot led Feyenoord to victory in the KNVB Cup on Sunday and won the Eredivisie title last season. He also reached the inaugural Europa Conference League final in his first season in charge after replacing Dick Advocaat.\n\nLiverpool's search for Klopp's successor is being driven by Michael Edwards, the new chief executive officer of football for Fenway Sports Group, Liverpool's owner, and incoming sporting director Richard Hughes.\n\nThe former Liverpool midfielder Xabi Alonso was the initial top target but, after committing his immediate future to the new Bundesliga champions Bayer Leverkusen, the Anfield club has considered numerous alternatives, including Sporting Lisbon's R\u00faben Amorim, who is wanted by West Ham, and Brighton's Roberto De Zerbi.\n\nLiverpool's targets had been sounded out via intermediaries since Klopp publicly announced his shock departure in January and Slot is the first candidate they have made an official move for, a sign of the confidence of Edwards and Hughes in hiring a coach who was wanted by Tottenham last season. - {"uri": "8094629048", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "09:53:04", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T09:53:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T09:52:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/liverpool-news-arne-slot-feyneoord-32659045", "title": "Feyenoord identify Arne Slot successor as Liverpool ramp up Jurgen Klopp plan", "body": "Feyenoord boss Arne Slot has emerged as a top contender for the Liverpool job this summer, with Anfield chiefs have cooling interest in Sporting CP's Ruben Amorim\n\nFeyenoord have identified FC Twente boss Joseph Oosting as one of their top managerial targets should they lose Arne Slot to Liverpool.\n\nSlot has emerged as a leading contender to replace Jurgen Klopp at Anfield this summer, though Feyenoord are still awaiting a formal approach from the Reds for the 45-year-old Dutch tactician.\n\nHis current contract in Rotterdam, which has two years left to run, does not contain a release clause meaning Liverpool would have to hold negotiations with Feyenoord over a compensation fee.\n\nHowever, the Eredivisie side are now mindful that Slot has had his head turned by the Reds after previously rejecting approaches from Leeds and Tottenham last year.\n\nOosting is now in Feyenoord's crosshairs after an eye-catching season with FC Twente, who currently sit third in the Eredivisie table. But he is not the only candidate for the potential vacancy even though Dutch sources are already briefing that he would be the clear frontrunner for the job.\n\nRobin van Persie, who currently coaches Feyenoord's U18 side, is not thought to be in the running for the De Kuip hot-seat, should it become available.\n\nThe former Arsenal and Manchester United striker is instead close to taking his first senior managerial role with Heerenveen. Feyenoord have held talks with the ex-Netherlands frontman over possibly taking over their U21 side next season but discussions have so far failed to bear fruit.\n\nAnd coaching novice Van Persie is understood to favour the prospect of sharpening his tools elsewhere before taking a high-pressure job despite his own personal desire to manage Feyenoord's first-team in the future. Slot's agent Rafaela Pimenta is expected to hold talks over her client's future with Feyenoord imminently as speculation intensifies.\n\nArne Slot is now the frontrunner to replace Jurgen Klopp\n\nWhile Liverpool are yet to register their interest directly with the Dutch giants, reports suggest they have already held at least one meeting with Slot to discuss the vacancy. If successful, Slot would be keen to bring his current assistant boss Sipke Hulshoff with him to Merseyside as part of a new-look coaching setup.\n\nThe Feyenoord manager was due to address the media on Wednesday ahead of his current side's fixture against Go Ahead Eagles on Thursday but the press conference was cancelled, though club sources insist the decision had already been made before Liverpool's interest was made public.\n\nMeanwhile, Sporting CP head coach Ruben Amorim is no longer in the running after the Portuguese boss flew to London on Monday for talks with West Ham. Barring a drastic U-turn, Amorim is not expected to take up either position next season, though he has also attracted interest from elsewhere.\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community! {"uri": "8093510667", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "17:06:19", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T17:06:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T17:05:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/liverpool-arne-slot-formation-transfers-32654989", "title": "Liverpool's possible line up under Slot with three new signings and Salah axed", "body": "Arne Slot has emerged as one of the top contenders to replace Jurgen Klopp as Liverpool manager this summer - and it is easy to see why the club are interested.\n\nAfter lots of talk about Xabi Alonso and Ruben Amorim, Feyenoord boss Slot has now jumped to the front of the queue. The managerial market is a busy one, with Bayern Munich, Barcelona and Liverpool all searching in the same pool of candidates and plenty could change between now and the summer.\n\nBut Slot appears to be a good fit for Liverpool due to his playing style and coaching philosophy, which echoes the Klopp playbook. \"We are an attack-minded team that likes to have a lot of the ball, and we play with a lot of intensity,\" he told UEFA of his style with Feyenoord. \"When we don't have the ball, we want to win it back as quickly as possible by being aggressive and pressing to win back possession. I think we are a team that is difficult to beat.\"\n\nSlot came close to taking over at Tottenham last May, but they could not agree a financial package with Feyenoord and ended up with Ange Postecoglou instead. The 45-year-old Dutchman doesn't just fit theoretically, he has also won trophies, claiming the Eredivisie title last season and the Dutch Cup this term.\n\nBut what might his arrival upon Merseyside mean for the Liverpool team? Gazing into our crystal ball, Mirror Football has pondered that very question.\n\nFirst thing's first, Slot's formation is clear: a 4-2-3-1 in possession, which can be flexible to accommodate attacking talent. He played it with AZ Alkmaar and Feyenoord and wouldn't need to change much at Liverpool, who play in a similar 4-3-3 formation under Klopp.\n\nLiverpool's backline has been disrupted by injuries this season, with Alisson, Trent Alexander-Arnold, Ibrahima Konate and Andy Robertson all spending time on the sidelines, but - if fully fit - they are likely to continue as the first-choices next season, alongside Virgil van Dijk.\n\nLiverpool already known Teun Koopmeiners well\n\nIt is further forward where changes could be made. To play a 4-2-3-1 formation, Slot would perhaps like to sign an attacking midfielder, because other than Dominik Szoboszlai, the Liverpool squad is lacking a player capable. That could give Slot the excuse for a reunion with Teun Koopmeiners, who Liverpool know all too well.\n\nKoopmeiners has enjoyed an exceptional season with Atalanta and was part of the side which stunned the Reds with a 3-0 win at Anfield. The 26-year-old has 11 goals and four assists in Serie A so far this season and has played primarily as an attacking midfielder. Slot is a known fan, having coached him during the 2019/20 campaign at AZ Alkmaar.\n\nAnother player Slot is a huge fan of is Santiago Gimenez - the Feyenoord striker who has 24 goals and seven assists in 40 games this season. The 23-year-old has already been talked up as a potential transfer target across Europe this summer and could follow his current boss to Anfield. Darwin Nunez has enjoyed a fruitful season, but his erratic finishing and Diogo Jota's injury problems means a new striker could be beneficial this summer.\n\nA possible Liverpool XI under Arne Slot\n\nHAVE YOUR SAY! What changes would you like to see at Liverpool this summer? Comment below.\n\nThat brings us to the elephant in the room: Mohamed Salah. The Liverpool icon is under contract until June 2025, but the lure of Saudi Arabian riches has not gone away and is sure to rear its head again in the summer transfer window.\n\nLiverpool are sure to want to keep Salah, who is showing few signs of slowing down at 31, but they are not in a particularly strong position. They will either need to sell for the highest fee, secure him to a fresh contract, or risk losing him for nothing next summer. So, how about replacements?\n\nBoth West Ham's Jarrod Bowen and Wolves ' Pedro Neto have frequently been linked with Liverpool - and both remain targets. With Michael Edwards back on board with Fenway Sports Group and Richard Hughes coming in as the new sporting director, the Reds won't be short of scouting expertise - but both of these players are known quantities. Neto has struggled with injuries this season and Bowen has shown a real eye for goal in 2023/24, netting 19 times in all competitions, so he gets the nod.\n\nLiverpool's possible XI under Arne Slot (4-2-3-1): Alisson; Alexander-Arnold, Van Dijk, Konate, Robertson; Mac Allister, Szoboszlai, Koopmeiners; Bowen, Diaz, Gimenez\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp communityand receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. negotiations with the Eredivisie club, Dutch media reported on Wednesday.\n\nThe Algemeen Dagblad newspaper said Liverpool made contact with Feyenoord on Wednesday morning.\n\nSlot was heavily linked with a possible move to Tottenham Hotspur last year, but opted to stay at Feyenoord and signed a contract extension with the Dutch side until 2026.\n\nReports added that Liverpool will have to pay an undisclosed sum to Feyenoord for Slot's services.\n\nHe has been widely praised for his innovative, attacking football with Feyenoord, winning the league title in the 2022-23 season, as well as the KNVB Cup on Sunday.\n\nIn his first season at Feyenoord, he also led the Rotterdam club to the final of the inaugural Europa Conference League.\n\nSlot, who was a journeyman midfielder as a player, began his coaching career at AZ Alkmaar, first as an assistant under John van den Brom, and then head coach from 2019-20.\n\nEarlier this week, Feyenoord CEO Dennis te Kloese responded to questions over Slot's future in an interview with ESPN, saying: \"We assume that he will also be our trainer next year.\n\n\"We have experienced this situation before and will take good care of our own interests.\"\n\nReuters has contacted Liverpool for comment.\n\nLiverpool were linked with a move for their former player and Bayer Leverkusen manager Xabi Alonso earlier this year, but the Spaniard opted to commit his future to the Bundesliga champions.\n\nSporting Lisbon coach Ruben Amorim was also among the names linked with the top job at Liverpool.\n\nKlopp announced in January that he would stand down as Liverpool manager at the end of the season.\n\nThe German joined the club in October 2015 and has won the Champions League, Premier League, Club World Cup, FA Cup, League Cup and Super Cup, as well as the Community Shield.\n\nIn his final campaign, Liverpool have won the League Cup and remain in contention for the Premier League title. Liverpool sit second in the standings with 74 points from 33 matches, three behind leaders Arsenal but with a game in hand.\n\nThey visit local rivals Everton in a league match later on Wednesday.
