{"uri": "8096779739", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "13:01:43", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T13:01:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T13:00:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/arne-slot-best-eredivisie-season-compared-erik-ten-hag/", "title": "Arne Slot's best Eredivisie season compared to Erik ten Hag's will concern Liverpool fans", "body": "Liverpool fans will be hoping Slot's Premier League career pans out very differently to Ten Hag's\n\nHighlights Liverpool have engaged in talks with Feyenoord's Arne Slot as a potential successor to Jurgen Klopp. Slot could follow in the footsteps of Manchester United's Erik ten Hag, as the Dutch coach also moved from the Eredivisie to the Premier League. Ten Hag's best season in the Dutch league was superior to Slot's, but he has struggled in England, and Jamie Carragher has expressed concern about how tough a challenge Slot faces at Liverpool.\n\nIt looks like Liverpool are closing in on a Jurgen Klopp successor, with Feyenoord's Arne Slot reportedly engaging in talks with the club about taking over in the summer. The Dutchman has built a solid reputation as a coach through his work with Feyenoord in the Eredivisie. He's won a league title with the club, he's still relatively young and it seems like the next plausible move for him is to make that step up and manage in the Premier League.\n\nWe've heard all of this before though, haven't we? Manchester United were in a similar position a couple of years ago when they needed to replace Ole Gunnar Solksjaer, and they too turned to the Netherlands where they handpicked Erik ten Hag as their next boss. The 54-year-old was held in high regard by many all over the world for the excellent job he did in charge of Ajax.\n\nRelated How Liverpool Could Line Up Under Arne Slot The Feyenoord manager is in talks to take over from Jurgen Klopp and this is how his side could line up next season\n\nTen Hag took them to several league titles and even saw relative success in Europe, with an impressive run to the Champions League semi-finals. His time in England hasn't been quite as fruitful, though. At Old Trafford, the Dutchman has struggled to replicate his success with Ajax and has often come under scrutiny for the manner in which his side has underperformed. It's hard to say how Slot will fare in England if he is to take the Liverpool job, but considering his career looks to be following a similar trajectory to Ten Hag, let's compare their best seasons in the Eredivisie.\n\nErik ten Hag's Best Season Came in 2020/21 He guided Ajax to a domestic double\n\nWhile he may have his sceptics and doubters now, Ten Hag was beloved at Ajax and for good reason. Across five years with the Dutch club, he enjoyed great success, but it was the 2020/21 season that was his best. Coming off the back of two straight league titles, there's a risk that a team can grow stagnant and lose the motivation to keep performing at such a high level.\n\nThat wasn't the case for Ten Hag's Ajax, though, who had their best season under him to record their third straight league title. That year, the club lost just two league games, finishing 16 points clear of PSV Eindhoven in second. With 88 points and a miraculous goal difference of +79, they completely blew their opponents out of the water all year long.\n\nAjax scored 102 goals that campaign, and there have been few sides quite as impressive in recent memory. They weren't just successful in the league, though, winning the KNVB Cup as well, completing a domestic double. He was ultimately given the Rinus Michels Award that year, a trophy annually presented to the best coach in Eredivisie. It was his second of two straight seasons where he won the award, something that's only been matched by three other coaches and interestingly, Slot is one of them.\n\nErik ten Hag's 2020/21 Eredivisie season\n\nPoints\n\n88\n\nGames won\n\n28\n\nGames drawn\n\n4\n\nGames lost\n\n2\n\nGoals scored\n\n102\n\nPoints-per-game\n\n2.59\n\nArne Slot's Best Season Came in 2022/23 He took Feyenoord to their first league title in six years\n\nWith Ten Hag leaving Ajax in the summer of 2022, there was an opportunity to usurp the club and that's exactly what Slot and his Feyenoord team did the very next season. He took the team to the top of the division, winning their first league title in six years and just their second in the 21st century. They picked up 82 points along the way, the joint-highest tally the club has ever won, a testament to the incredible work that they were doing.\n\nGIVEMESPORT Key Statistic: Erik ten Hag and Arne Slot are two of just four managers to win the Rinus Michels Award in two straight years\n\nSimilar to Ten Hag's best Ajax season, Feyenoord lost just twice in the league during Slot's best season. They recorded a goal difference of of +51 and finished seven points clear of PSV Eindhoven in second place. They failed to win any other trophy, but their manager was presented with the Rinus Michels Award for the second straight year.\n\nSlot's best season at Feyenoord wasn't anywhere near as dominant as Ten Hag's strongest campaign with Ajax, but that doesn't necessarily mean he'll fare worse if he is to come to England. Only time will tell how a potential appointment at Liverpool would play out for the 45-year-old.\n\nArne Slot's 2022/23 Eredivisie season\n\nPoints\n\n82\n\nGames won\n\n25\n\nGames drawn\n\n7\n\nGames lost\n\n2\n\nGoals scored\n\n81\n\nPoints-per-game\n\n2.41\n\nJamie Carragher Isn't Convinced About Slot The ex-defender thinks the jump from Feyenoord to Liverpool might be too big\n\nReplacing Jurgen Klopp is always going to be a difficult job. The Reds coach has become a club legend over the last nine years, and Liverpool need to get his replacement nailed on. Otherwise, they risk taking a huge step back and undoing a lot of the work he's done.\n\nWhether that is Slot or not, Jamie Carragher isn't too confident about the potential hire. Speaking ahead of the Reds' Premier League match with Everton, the former defender admitted he thought the jump from Feyenoord to Liverpool was a big one.\n\n\"I think from Feyenoord to Liverpool is a huge jump. Slot is the favourite right now. I don't think it's like Rafa Benitez coming in, or Jurgen Klopp. When Rafa Benitez is coming in off the back of two La Liga titles and a UEFA cup, or Jurgen Klopp coming in winning a couple of league titles with Borussia Dortmund and getting to a Champions League final.\n\nLiverpool were actually in a different space then. We were a team trying to qualify for the top four. Liverpool are in a different area now. They're actually fancying themselves to challenge for the Premier League every season. I think it's a huge jump.\"\n\nWith Xabi Alonso ruling himself out of the running and publicly stating his intention to remain at Bayer Leverkusen, Slot might just be the best possible option left on the table for Liverpool. Whether he has a similar experience to Ten Hag in England remains to be seen, but with Klopp's departure coming in just over a month, the Reds might find out soon enough.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8095506315", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "19:24:12", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T19:24:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T19:24:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/arne-slot-liverpool-manager-carragher-32664554", "title": "Jamie Carragher sends Arne Slot warning & comments on reality of Liverpool move", "body": "Feyenoord manager Arne Slot has emerged as a top target for Liverpool as they look to replace Jurgen Klopp, but Jamie Carragher has issued a word of warning over the Dutchman\n\nLiverpool legend Jamie Carragher has warned Arne Slot he would be taking a \"huge jump\" by leaving Feyenoord to take over at Anfield.\n\nSlot, 45, has emerged as the Reds' top contender to replace Jurgen Klopp at the end of the season. The former AZ boss led his team to the Eredivisie title last season and is on course for a runner-up finish this time around.\n\nKlopp is leaving in the summer after nearly nine years at the helm, having delivered Liverpool their first league title of the Premier League era. The Merseyside club also won the Champions League in 2019 and reached the final on two other occasions, but their quest for Europa League glory this term fell short.\n\nSlot's links with Liverpool come with another Eredivisie winner, Erik ten Hag, struggling in his second season in charge of Manchester United. Speaking on Sky Sports ahead of the Merseyside Derby, Carragher offered a reminder to the potential new boss, while comparing his attributes to those of Xabi Alonso and Ruben Amorim after the pair were also linked after Klopp's exit announcement.\n\n\"What I would say from Feyenoord to Liverpool is a huge jump and I think it shows in this moment a lack of real top managers out there when you look at who Liverpool were going for,\" Carragher said. \"Initially probably Xabi Alonso but it was only his first full season as a manager. There was talk of Amorin from Sporting Lisbon but he's only 39.\n\n\"Now Arne Slot looks like he is the favourite right now. I don't think it's like Rafa Benitez coming on or Jurgen Klopp coming in. Benitez came off the back of winning two La Liga titles and a UEFA Cup and Jurgen Klopp coming after winning a couple of titles with Borussia Dortmund and getting to a Champions League final.\n\n\"Liverpool were in a different space then, and that was a Liverpool team under Rafa Benitez that I was part of that was trying to qualify for the top four, the same with Jurgen Klopp when he came in. Liverpool are in a different area now and fancy themselves to challenge for the Premier League next season and the Champions League, they will be expected to reach the quarter-finals at least. I think it is a huge jump, he's obviously a great coach and has a good track record with the clubs he has had so far, so we will see.\"\n\nIs Arne Slot the best fit for Liverpool? Have your say in the comments section\n\nJamie Carragher has reminded Arne Slot of the size of task that he could face\n\nBayer Leverkusen boss Alonso, a former team-mate of Carragher's at Anfield, was heavily linked with a return as manager before committing his future to the German club. Leverkusen have gone the whole season unbeaten, clinching the Bundesliga title with time to spare and still vying for the Europa League and DFB-Pokal.\n\n\"Last week I had a very good meeting when I informed them [Leverkusen's directors] of my decision to continue being coach of Bayer Leverkusen,\" the former Spain midfielder said when confirming he would stay put. \"For sure all the decisions you need to analyse well. I try to take the right ones, I try to take them in a natural way.\n\n\"At the moment this is the right place for me to develop as a coach, I am a young coach. Right now this is the right place. I have to thank the management. The club had been supportive and I feel respected by all departments.\n\n\"The fans they have shown great support and they have reasons to believe and dream we will have a great season. I have a great staff to help me work day by day, and so for sure the players.\"\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp communityand receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. We were lacking that at so many moments in games,\" Van Dijk said after the Everton defeat.\n\n\"If you play like we did, obviously even if we create two or three clear-cut chances again, you don't deserve to win the league.\n\n\"It's crunch time and we've not been good enough in the way we finished the chances off, in the way we defended together and also the fight. There was talk of Amorim from Sporting, he's only 39. And Arne Slot looks like he's the favourite right now.\n\n'I don't think it's like Rafa Benitez coming in or Jurgen Klopp coming in. Benitez came in off the back of two La Liga titles and a UEFA Cup. Klopp came in off winning a couple of league titles with Borussia Dortmund and getting to a Champions League final.\n\n'And Liverpool were actually in a different space then. I was part of the team before Benitez when we were just trying to qualify for the top four. Same with Klopp when he came in.\n\n'Liverpool are in a different area now. They're actually fancying themselves to win the Premier League every season and next season the Champions League, they'll be expecting to get to the quarter-finals at least.\n\n'I think it's a huge jump. But he's obviously a great coach, he's got a great track record in the clubs that he's had so far. We'll see.'\n\nMORE : PSV manager Peter Bosz responds to rumours Arne Slot could leave Feyenoord for Liverpool\n\nMORE : Chelsea legend John Terry predicts where Arsenal will finish after taking lead {"uri": "8096323666", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "08:24:10", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T08:24:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T08:23:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/liverpool-van-dijk-arne-slot-32666701", "title": "Liverpool captain Van Dijk delivers Slot appointment verdict after Everton loss", "body": "Virgil van Dijk has delivered his verdict on the potential arrival of Arne Slot\n\nArne Slot has the backing of Liverpool captain Virgil van Dijk as Anfield chiefs edge closer to striking an agreement with Feyenoord over a compensation package for the Dutch boss.\n\nSlot is in line to replace Jurgen Klopp at the end of the season and Van Dijk, who has just over one year left to run on his current contract, believes his 45-year-old compatriot would be a fine fit for the job.\n\nVan Dijk told ViaPlay after the Reds saw their Premier League title hopes all but ended by rivals Everton : \"I think Slot is one of the better Dutch coaches at the moment.\n\n\"With the way he plays and the philosophy he has, he can be a Liverpool coach. But I read and hear that it is far from complete. We shall see. We will focus on that next season, but that is still a long way off.\"\n\nLiverpool saw an opening offer worth around \u00a37.7million including bonuses rejected by Feyenoord on Wednesday morning. The Reds tabled an initial \u00a36m upfront with a further \u00a31.7m in performance-related bonuses but Feyenoord are believed to be holding out for a total package of \u00a38.5m.\n\nFurthermore, Liverpool are also facing additional challenges replacing an array of Klopp's departing backroom staff.\n\nSlot hopes to bring his assistant coach Sipke Hulshoff with him to Merseyside while his current head of performance, Ruben Peeters, is also likely to join Liverpool, replacing Andreas Schlumberger.\n\nHowever, Slot's assistant trainer John de Wolf looks likely to stay put in Holland having recently extended his contract at De Kuip and he could form part of the new-look coaching setup in Rotterdam if Slot does indeed depart.\n\nArne Slot is in line to be Liverpool's next manager\n\nLiverpool will also need to replace Pepijn Lijnders, goalkeeping coach John Achterberg, Peter Krawietz, fitness chief Andreas Kornmayer and nutritionist Nona Meyer among others.\n\nMeanwhile, Slot's agent Rafaela Pimenta is currently negotiating his contract with the Reds. Face-to-face discussions between Liverpool and the Dutch giants are expected to take place in the coming days but Feyenoord director Dennis te Kloese is understood to have been in Madrid this week on a separate business venture.\n\nThe Reds still have four games left before their season is complete as they face trips to West Ham and Aston Villa while also hosting Tottenham and Wolves at Anfield.\n\nKlopp is believed to have had no involvement in the search for his replacement as the process is being led and driven by Michael Edwards and Richard Hughes.\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community! {"uri": "8094421837", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "07:49:11", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T07:49:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T07:49:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://sportslens.com/news/dutch-duo-liverpool-manager/", "title": "Dutch Duo Tip Liverpool To Sign 45-Year-Old As Klopp's Successor", "body": "Former Netherlands internationals Marco van Basten and Wim Jonk have explained why Feyenoord manager Arne Slot will be a great successor to Jurgen Klopp at Liverpool. While Van Basten believes the 45-year-old can do even better at a bigger club with more resources, Jonk thinks he will do well at the \"Feyenoord of England.\"\n\nSince Klopp announced his decision to step down as manager at the end of the 2023-24 season, Liverpool have been scouring the market for his successor. Ex-Liverpool star and Bayer Leverkusen manager Xabi Alonso was initially the hot favorite for the job. But the Spaniard quickly put those rumors to bed by committing his future to the Bundesliga champions. Sporting CP boss Ruben Amorim then emerged as a top candidate but according to top journalists, including Fabrizio Romano, talks have stalled between the manager and the club and may not resume.\n\nWith Amorim also out of the picture, Feyenoord manager Slot has become a prime candidate for the Liverpool job. Romano has reported that the two parties have already met, confirming the legitimacy of the rumors.\n\nVan Basten and Jonk have discussed Slot's potential switch to Liverpool, explaining why he will be a great appointment.\n\nDutch legend Van Basten began by saying (via TeamTalk):\n\n\"He can really go anywhere - Bayern Munich, Liverpool... I'm really convinced of that.\n\n\"I've spoken to him a few times and I think what he does and what he sees is very strong. He gets along very well with the group of players, is tactically well-versed, can explain things well and is calm and intelligent. I think he can go to any club, even at the very difficult clubs, because he is so intelligent.\"\n\nHe added:\n\n\"He could really fit anywhere. If you get AZ and Feyenoord to play football, you also get big clubs like AC Milan to play football. You can clearly see his hand where he is the coach.\n\n\"I think it will even be easier for him at a higher level because he has better players who understand his ideas faster. I also think he is smart enough to manage stubborn players.\"\n\nJonk, meanwhile, claimed Slot's success at Feyenoord will help him at Anfield.\n\nHe noted:\n\n\"He [Slot] gave Feyenoord a face. Arne has made enormous strides, so I would like that. Liverpool is also a bit like the Feyenoord of England.\"\n\nSlot guided Feyenoord to the Eredivisie title in the 2022-23 season and the KNVB Cup this year. He has managed them in 144 games over the last three seasons, guiding them to 93 wins, 27 draws, and 24 defeats.", "source": {"uri": "sportslens.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sportslens.com"}, {"uri": "8095558542", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "20:12:01", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T20:12:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T20:11:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/slot-control-freak-inspired-guardiola-193354229.html", "title": "Slot - the 'control freak' inspired by Guardiola", "body": "Doing well in the Dutch Eredivisie does not guarantee success in the Premier League, but the Liverpool hierarchy must be confident that Arne Slot can continue his fine achievements in England.\n\nHe has constantly overachieved with his teams in the Netherlands so far. Just ask Dutch legend Marco van Basten, who has been hugely impressed with his work.\n\n\"I really think he is that good,\" the former striker told Rondo, a Dutch talkshow on Ziggo Sport. \"He could end up anywhere. Bayern Munich, Liverpool, you name it. I'm really convinced of that.\"\n\nLiverpool's owners are adamant that will be their club, as Slot has impressed them with his attacking blend of football, constantly pressing opponents high up the field - reminiscent of the football played at Anfield under Jurgen Klopp.\n\nJust like the German manager, Slot is prepared to take that approach against anyone.\n\nA telling example was Feyenoord's Champions League match at Atletico Madrid earlier this season.\n\nTheir intensity helped them achieve seven shots on target, a total last bettered by a visiting side against Atletico in the Champions League when Real Madrid managed eight in 2015, according to Opta.\n\nThis season was Feyenoord's first Champions League's campaign in six years, but they excelled in winning the ball high up the pitch, resulting in dangerous situations.\n\nIn their six group matches, they won the ball back 59 times in the last 40 metres of the pitch in open play, with only four teams doing that more often.\n\nSlot's teams play well in possession, and his players overlap to provide an extra layer of unpredictability.\n\n\"I've spoken to him a few times and what he does and what he sees is very good,\" explains Van Basten. \"He gets on with the squad very well, is tactically very astute, can explain things well and is calm and intelligent.\n\n\"I think he can go to any club, yes. Even to the very difficult clubs, because he is so intelligent.\"\n\nApart from his tactical expertise and meticulous preparations, Slot is also good at building a team with modest resources.\n\nSeven players who started the 2022 Europa Conference League final defeat by Roma left Feyenoord that summer. Slot, though, built a team with new recruits such as Santiago Gimenez, Sebastian Szymanski and Mats Wieffer - all for nominal fees - who would prove pivotal in securing a first Dutch title in six years.\n\nLast summer, again, they lost important players in Szymanski and Orkun Kokcu, but have had a strong season once more, winning the Dutch Cup last Sunday.\n\nFeyenoord spent around \u00a330m on players in each of the past two campaigns, whereas Ajax have had an outlay of almost \u00a3100m in each of theirs.\n\nOn top of that, Slot gives young talent a chance.\n\nQuinten Timber - twin brother of Arsenal's Jurrien - and Quilindschy Hartman have developed very well under his tutelage and become pillars of the team, with both making their debut for the Dutch national team this season as well.\n\nSlot is inspired by Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola, studying every small detail.\n\n\"I certainly don't want to compare myself to Pep, but he is a control freak just like me,\" Slot said in an interview with Voetbal International in May 2023.\n\n\"If I look at myself, I try to win a match in the week before it is played, by conveying the training, pre-match team talks and tactics to the players as perfectly as possible.\"\n\nHe said previously watching Guardiola's teams gives him the \"ultimate joy in football\".\n\n\"There is no team in the world I would rather watch than Manchester City, followed by Napoli, Arsenal and Brighton,\" added Slot.\n\n\"But City - and again it is not my intention to compare us with them - have a similar style of play to how we want to play with Feyenoord: 4-3-3, building up from the back, wanting to apply pressure quickly.\"\n\nLast season, Leeds and Crystal Palace were said to be interested and Tottenham were very keen on his services, but Slot opted to stay in the Netherlands, where he had just won the title and was looking ahead to guiding Feyenoord in the Champions League.\n\nVan Basten doesn't think a move to the Premier League would be a step too high.\n\n\"If you get AZ and Feyenoord to play [good] football, you will also get the big clubs to play [good] football,\" says Van Basten.\n\n\"I think it would only become easier for him because you have better players who understand quicker what you want. Those players are also more stubborn, but I think Slot is smart enough to manage that.\"\n\nThe Dutchman has a calm and balanced approach, which works well with his players and was highlighted in one of his post-match dressing room talks last season.\n\nAfter Feyenoord beat rivals Ajax for the first time away in the league in 17 seasons, a video released by the club showed Slot talking about the importance of the weeks to come.\n\n\"Because this is only a win. It's not more than a win, it's a big win, but it's not more than a win,\" said Slot in the video. \"We have a bigger goal this season than only winning for the first time in 17 years in Amsterdam. Our goal is bigger than that.\"\n\nFeyenoord duly went on to clinch the league title.\n\nThis year they are in good form again and could even get a higher points tally than last season's 82, but PSV's impressive form means they will probably have to settle for second, which would still guarantee Champions League football.\n\nNow Slot could be set to embrace another rivalry, this time with a manager he so admires in Guardiola.", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports Canada"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Klopp's successor as manager at Anfield, sources have told ESPN.\n\nESPN reported on Tuesday that Slot, 45, had emerged as the leading contender for the Liverpool job following Xabi Alonso's decision to remain at Bayer Leverkusen and a cooling in the Premier League club's interest in Sporting CP coach Ruben Amorim.\n\nBut with Liverpool aware of rival interest from Bayern Munich and Barcelona in {"uri": "8094354805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "07:04:31", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T07:04:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T07:04:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/arne-slot-liverpool-feyenoord-signings-32654692", "title": "Liverpool target Arne Slot's last 10 transfers and what it says about him", "body": "As Liverpool prepare to move on from Jurgen Klopp, the summer transfer window will be a key one, and it could be Arne Slot making the big decisions.\n\nFeyenoord manager Slot has emerged as the leading candidate to take the reins when Klopp ends his nine-year tenure in the summer. The Dutchman, who turned down Spurs before the London club appointed Ange Postecoglou, is set to follow up last season's title win with a second-place finish behind PSV Eindhoven this term.\n\nThe returning Michael Edwards is likely to have a major say in any transfer business over the summer, but Klopp had involvement during Edwards' previous spell. Slot has overseen significant player turnover across the last 12 months, just as Klopp did with his midfield rebuild at Anfield, and he knows how to bring starters into a squad.\n\nFeyenoord signed more than 10 players - either permanently or on loan, since the summer of 2023. Here, Mirror Football has taken a look at the last 10 to get a feel for what Liverpool fans might expect if the 45-year-old comes in.\n\nAnis Hadj Moussa\n\nSlot's most recent signing is a player who hasn't actually joined Feyenoord yet. Algerian forward Hadj Moussa will arrive in the summer, just a few months after making his Eredivisie debut on loan at Vitesse.\n\nThe 22-year-old has two goals and two assists in all competitions in the Netherlands, having begun the season in the Belgian second tier. His arrival suggests a willingness to back a player of limited top level experience as long as the promise is there.\n\nMikki van Sas\n\nAnother youngster, Van Sas joined from Manchester City's academy in September. The 20-year-old goalkeeper has yet to make his senior Feyenoord debut, but has been on the bench in the Champions League and Europa League this term.\n\nThe Dutch Under-19 international revealed upon his unveiling that he had been scouted by the Rotterdam club as a teen. Previous rejections appear to be no barrier to deals further down the line.\n\nLuka Ivanusec\n\nWould Arne Slot be a good fit for Liverpool? Have your say in the comments section\n\nCroatia international Luka Ivanusec is one of Slot's more experienced recent signings\n\nThe first name on the list to have represented Feyenoord at the time of writing, Ivanusec joined from Dinamo Zagreb in his homeland of Croatia. The winger played three times for his country at Euro 2020, showing Slot is prepared to add more experienced figures when the price is right.\n\nArriving for just \u00a36.7m (according to Transfermarkt), Ivanusec has struggled with injury this season but has still managed 20 league outings. He scored a hat-trick for Dinamo in Champions League qualifying, but has only netted once in the Eredivisie.\n\nOndrej Lingr\n\nLingr, 25, joined on a season-long loan from Slavia Prague in August. Another full international, the attacking midfielder arrived with a record of contributing goals from a withdrawn role, with successive double-figure seasons in the Czech Republic.\n\nHe has been used out wide as well as in the number 10 role, but Slot has so far been sparing with him. All 21 of Lingr's outings have come from the bench, with the manager prepared to let the new man work for his first start.\n\nBart Nieuwkoop\n\nDutch defender Nieuwkoop arrived from Union SG, where he spent last season linking up with Brighton winger Simon Adingra. The 28-year-old started out at Feyenoord, failing to hold down a first-team place, but Slot has been prepared to give him a second chance.\n\nBart Nieuwkoop is back at Feyenoord for a second spell\n\nWhile the first half of his season was interrupted by injury, Nieuwkoop has featured more since the turn of the year. He made four appearances in the run to KNVB Cup glory, starting the victory over NEC in the final.\n\nKostas Lamprou\n\nLamprou is another player who demonstrates Slot's willingness to offer second chances. The Greek goalkeeper returned to De Kuip nine years after departing, having done the rounds in the top two tiers of Dutch football.\n\nLiverpool boss Klopp hasn't been afraid to add experienced backup keepers on a free, with Adrian and Alex Manninger among those brought to Anfield during his tenure. With the former out of contract this summer, might there be room for another similar deal?\n\nAyase Ueda Japan striker Ayase Ueda hasn't quite hit his stride in Rotterdam\n\nThe most expensive signing on the list, Ueda still only cost a relatively reasonable \u00a36.9m. The Japan international was part of his country's 2022 World Cup squad but not one of the star names - rather, he was a star in waiting when he moved to Rotterdam.\n\nAs with a few others, the striker has mostly been used as a sub despite hitting 22 in Belgium the season prior, scoring twice in less than 500 Eredivisie minutes. He enjoyed a breakout Asian Cup, though, ending the tournament as his country's top scorer with four goals in as many starts.\n\nCalvin Stengs\n\nDutch international Stengs was hot property when he left Slot's AZ for Nice in 2021. It didn't quite work out for him in Ligue 1, but Slot wasn't going to turn down the chance to reunite with the 25-year-old.\n\nFormer AZ man Calvin Stengs is working under Arne Slot at a second club\n\nStengs has hit double figures for assists this term, with only PSV duo Luuk de Jong and Joey Veerman besting his tally. He also has five league goals - plus one in the Champions League victory over Celtic - suggesting the reunion has gone pretty well so far.\n\nThomas Beelen\n\nYoung defender Beelen set Feyenoord back just \u00a32.3m, coming through the same PEC Zwolle production line that produced current Liverpool defender Sepp van den Berg. A tall centre-back, just like Klopp likes them, the 22-year-old has featured in more than half of Feyenoord's games this term.\n\nLiverpool will need to make decisions at centre-back, namely on whether to hand Joel Matip a new deal and how they deal with Virgil van Dijk entering the final year of his own contract. Klopp hasn't been afraid to trust in youth, and Slot isn't too different.\n\nYankuba Minteh Yankuba Minteh has impressed since joining Feyenoord on loan from Newcastle\n\nSpeaking of youth, 19-year-old Minteh has been backed despite his tender age. Liverpool might not need to test the water with top teams' youngsters, but Gambia international Minteh has enjoyed his season on loan from Newcastle.\n\nWith nine league goals, the winger sits joint-second in the club's scoring charts behind Premier League linked Santiago Gimenez. Liverpool have benefited greatly from goals from out wide, so this may be music to fans' ears.\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp communityand receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. We also treat our community members to special offers, promotions, and adverts from us and our partners. If you don't like our community, you can check out any time you like. {"uri": "8094316754", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "06:38:23", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T06:38:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T06:37:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.rousingthekop.com/2024/04/24/maniac-manager-now-convinced-hes-joining-liverpool-hes-already-looking-for-houses/", "title": "'Maniac' manager now convinced he's joining Liverpool, he's already looking for houses", "body": "Liverpool are starting to get serious in their attempts to hire Jurgen Klopp's replacement.\n\nThere are now just five games left of Klopp's reign with the Reds. That will become four once this evening's Merseyside Derby is done and dusted.\n\nAs a result, Liverpool are not far out from being without someone in charge of the first-team squad. Things need to move fast.\n\nThankfully, it now finally looks as though they are. The Reds have taken their time - and ruled out some pretty big names in the process - but it looks like it's all coming together at Anfield.\n\nAnd as updates slowly start to filter through about who the new man could be, it seems that one manager is already house-hunting in the Liverpool area.\n\nThroughout the process of deliberation over who should follow Klopp at Liverpool, FSG have seemingly remained calm.\n\nChoosing the successor to the Reds most loved and trophy-laden manager of the modern era was never going to be easy. Cool heads were needed.\n\nThankfully, Michael Edwards is about as cool as they come. FSG'S CEO of football was reportedly prepared to be 'bold not popular' with his decision and that looks to have come to fruition.\n\nAs has been reported just about everywhere by now, Feyenoord's Arne Slot is the man Liverpool are now zoning in on to be in the dugout next season. And according to Dutch outlet 1908.NL, Slot himself is getting excited over the move.\n\nThey claim that the 45-year-old is 'very charmed' by the idea of joining the Reds and is gently pushing to leave Feyenoord. In fact, so 'convinced' is Slot said to be, that he and his agent, Rafaela Pimeata are ready to discuss the final details of the contract with Liverpool.\n\nThe expectation from there is reportedly that Slot with become new Liverpool manager. However, it's claimed that the deal is not done yet. Meetings are said to be scheduled 'in the coming days.' In preparation for that, the Dutchman is said to be now looking for houses 'in and around Liverpool.'\n\nThis all sounds to be very promising indeed. Unless anything dramatic happens from here, we'd suggest that the Reds have found their man.\n\nIn our opinion, we're not quite sure how to feel about it all just yet. We still can't imagine the club with Jurgen. But, in terms of Slot, Liverpool will reportedly be getting a coach who is 'almost like a maniac' [TalkSPORT] in the way his teams attack.\n\nIt all sounds intriguing and when the time comes, Arne will be welcomed to the area with open arms. He has also secured the Dutch Cup this campaign, while the side currently sit second in the table with four games remaining.\n\nIt is not just the record of success already in his managerial career that will have caught the eye of the Liverpool hierarchy, but his brand of aggressive, attack-minded football too.\n\nWhen compared with current boss Klopp and other suggested candidates for the role, Slot stacks up well.\n\nAccording to Opta, the former AZ Alkmaar coach has the second best win percentage out of the five with 61.8% - behind only Sporting Lisbon manager Ruben Amorim - but having managed the least amount of games.\n\nHis sides score plenty of goals too and without conceding all that many, averaging 2.19 goals per game for and 0.98 goals against.\n\nWhen looking at where his side rank among teams in the top 10 leagues across Europe this season alone, it is eye catching.\n\nAs shown by Opta, Slot's Feyenoord outrank Klopp's Reds in win percentage, possession, goals, high turnovers and possession won in the final third.\n\nRanking fourth and third in those final two stats in particular will be pleasing to those of a red persuasion as it highlights the style of play he manager who may actually be better for Liverpool than Arne Slot", "body": "Liverpool's Premier League title hopes appear to be coming to an end after a disastrous 2-0 defeat away at Merseyside rivals Everton on Wednesday night.\n\nThe Reds have endured a difficult few weeks and the Jurgen Klopp era is in danger of ending on an uncharacteristically low note.\n\nThe disappointing draw at Manchester United, the defeat to Crystal Palace, the Europa League exit at the hands of Atalanta... this has been a tricky period.\n\nWednesday's defeat to Everton was the tip of the iceberg though as Liverpool not only saw the Toffees claim bragging rights but also leave Liverpool's title hopes in tatters.\n\nEverton were first to the ball and caused mayhem from set pieces, with both of their goals in a 2-0 win coming from dead balls.\n\nThe Toffees now appear safe from relegation and denting Liverpool's title hopes was just an added bonus for Toffees fans.\n\nKlopp is now in the final weeks of his time as Liverpool boss and the club's new boss appears to be emerging...\n\nHITC understands that Feyenoord boss Arne Slot is emerging as a top target for Liverpool.\n\nMichael Edwards is a big fan of Slot and Liverpool are moving towards landing the Dutchman to replace Klopp.\n\nSlot may not be a big name but he has completely transformed Feyenoord since his 2021 arrival.\n\nThe 45-year-old won the Eredivisie title last season and made himself a hero at De Kuip, not too dissimilar to Klopp at Anfield.\n\nFeyenoord have a reputation as a 'nearly club' but that title win, with Feyenoord sweeping aside all of the competition in style, showed the quality of Slot's coaching.\n\nNot all Liverpool fans seem to be enthused by Slot becoming the top target and Jamie Carragher actually prefers somebody else...\n\nCarragher has spoken on Stick to Football and believes that Thomas Tuchel may have actually been a better fit for Liverpool.\n\nTuchel is leaving Bayern Munich this summer and his availability if bound to attract interest.\n\nThe German won the Champions League with Chelsea back in 2021 but left the club less than 18 months later and hasn't really got his managerial career back on track.\n\nCarragher has now suggested that Tuchel would have made more sense for Liverpool because of his history in the Champions League.\n\nTuchel's Bayern are now in the semi-finals and if he goes a step further, it will be yet another final for him after previously getting there with Paris Saint-Germain and Chelsea.\n\nCarragher accepts that Tuchel's time at Bayern hasn't gone to plan, but believes he has 'something about him' which would have Liverpool fans backing him to challenge Pep Guardiola and Manchester City.\n\n\"It's not like you're bringing in a Champions League sort of manager in,\" said Carragher. \"And the reason I wanted to mention this is because Liverpool are always going to be data-driven and the one manager who's out there who is proper, where you go 'oof' and is available is Tuchel, and I just don't think that Liverpool would go for those type of managers now, with the setup they've got behind the scenes.\"\n\n\"I just think of... it feels like an appointment you'd make when Liverpool were almost maybe trying to get back into the top four. Right now, Liverpool are probably in the best top five or six teams in Europe and they have been for a few years and that's why I go back to Tuchel.\"\n\n\"He's beat Pep. I just think of a guy standing on the sideline and you're a Liverpool supporter and you're looking at him thinking 'he can go up against him'. If he gets to the final, he'll have been in three of the last six Champions League finals. Now, I know it hasn't gone perfectly at Bayern Munich for him, but the job he did at Chelsea and trying to take on Klopp's Liverpool and Pep's Man City, he's got something about him - that's my thing,\" he added.\n\nSlot won't head to Anfield with that kind of reputation in place but Tuchel had to earn it and so did Klopp, building up their standing in the game through results.\n\nSlot impressed at AZ Alkmaar and Feyenoord and is now ready for the next step in his career.\n\nPerhaps the jump from Feyenoord to Liverpool is a big one, but Slot deserves a chance to show that he can go The transfer payments in football are bizarre anyway.\n\n'Actually, as a club it makes much more sense to pay a lot for a coach than for a left back. A coach is so incredibly decisive. Slot has proven this at Feyenoord in recent years. If I worked at Feyenoord, I wouldn't let him go easily.'\n\nMiedema is also a huge fan of Slot's brand of football, believing he will bring in players who 'fit his vision'.\n\n'Feyenoord is a noisy club, where there is always something going on. He is honest and radiates peace and security. His specific way of playing football appeals to me.\n\n'Playing forward and applying pressure, with players who fit into that system. He has forced the club to buy players who fit his vision. {"uri": "8097174170", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:21:12", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:21:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:21:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/arne-slot-interview-liverpool-feyenoord-32672707", "title": "Arne Slot in awkward exchange with reporter over Jurgen Klopp questions", "body": "Arne Slot was approached by a reporter as he got off the team bus\n\nArne Slot refused to answer any questions about Liverpool after being surprised by a persistent Sky Sports reporter.\n\nLiverpool have opened talks with the Feyenoord manager over succeeding Jurgen Klopp as they try to get ahead of potential competition from Bayern Munich. Slot is considered a good fit to build on Klopp's work due to his playing style at Feyenoord and is the number one choice of Fenway Sports Group chief Michael Edwards and incoming director of football Richard Hughes.\n\nSlot has two years left on his Feyenoord deal and it will cost around \u00a38.6million in compensation to hire him this summer. The Dutch club are consigned to losing their manager and have already taken steps towards finding a replacement, having identified FC Twente boss Joseph Oosting as a target.\n\nHowever, despite the wheels being in motion, Slot remains Feyenoord boss and is in the City of Deventer on Thursday night to manage his side against Go Ahead Eagles in the Eredivisie. It was there that he was quizzed by Sky Sports reporter Gary Cotterill as he got off the team bus.\n\nCotterill tried his very best to put his questions to Slot, but struggled with a security guard ushering him away. \"You're in the news,\" Cotterill began, to which Slot smiled and replied: \"I am, I can't deny that.\" Cotterill then said: \"You said you wanted to go to the Premier League - is it a possibility?\"\n\nSlot was not sticking around to hear anything else he had to stay, quickly climbing up the steps with his shirt and suitcase in hand. With a suited security guard shadowing him, Cotterill only managed to get out the words \"well, Liverpool want you\" and \"good luck\" before his target disappeared.\n\nLiverpool aren't the first Premier League side to try and hire Slot - Tottenham came close to doing so last May, but couldn't agree terms and ended up going for Ange Postecoglou instead. While careful to be respectful of his employers, Slot has not tried to hide his ambitions.\n\nGary Cotterill followed him up the steps, but had little success\n\nSpeaking around the time that Spurs were chasing him, the 45-year-old said: \"The next step will not be another club in Holland. If that is the next step, I've failed completely in the upcoming few years. A normal next step would be to go abroad and I've always said that the best league in the world is the Premier League.\"\n\nHe won the Eredivisie with Feyenoord last season and has secured the Dutch cup this season - and it is his playing style which has attracted Liverpool. Slot is known for his high-pressing, high-energy style that bears many hallmarks of Klopp's with the Reds.\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community and receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. Kuyt played 208 times for Liverpool, scoring 51 goals, and he has now moved into coaching including having a stint with Feyenoord.\n\nLast year, Kuyt suggested that Liverpool should be taking a look at a couple of Feyenoord players. He was also quick to praise Slot's work, long before anyone knew that Klopp was leaving and the former AZ Alkmaar boss could be an option to replace the German.\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool candidate Arne Slot 'questioned' Mikel Arteta methods before Jos\u00e9 Mourinho 'row'\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool injury latest and return dates before Everton as J\u00fcrgen Klopp gives Diogo Jota update\n\nLutsharel Geertruida and Orkun K\u00f6k\u00e7\u00fc were the two stars in question. I hope Liverpool is interested in Feyenoord players, and I am an example it can work!\"\n\nGeertruida is a versatile 23-year-old who can play at center-back, right-back and holding midfield, and signing a new defender would appear to be logical for Liverpool this summer given that Jo\u00ebl Matip is set to leave at the end of his contract. Geertruida has played 43 times so far this term for Feyenoord and he has scored seven times and assisted another four.\n\nK\u00f6k\u00e7\u00fc, meanwhile, is a holding midfielder, but he no longer plays for Feyenoord. Last summer, he moved to Benfica for a fee of around $32m (\u00a326m/\u20ac30m). Liverpool had been linked tentatively with a move for him at the time amid its midfield revamp.\n\nLiverpool.com says: If it is to be Slot that takes over at Anfield, there will be no repeat of the Erik ten Hag situation at Manchester United where he was simply allowed to sign as many of his favorite players from his former club as possible, no matter the cost. Just because a player has impressed with Feyenoord, that does not mean that he will suddenly shoot up Liverpool's list.\n\nKuyt clearly rates Slot, though, and the Feyenoord boss' record speaks for itself. He won the Eredivisie last season and the Dutch cup this year, and his sides always perform well above where they should based on how much they spend. {"uri": "2024-04-334032217", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "14:29:39", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T14:29:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T14:18:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/arne-slot-feyenoord-manager-talks-141857069.html", "title": "Who is Arne Slot? The Feyenoord manager in talks to replace Jurgen Klopp at Liverpool", "body": "Liverpool, currently in a three-way race for the Premier League title, were hit in their search when early favourite Xabi Alonso decided to stay at Bayer Leverkusen. Sporting Lisbon boss Ruben Amorim has also been linked with the job.\n\nBut Slot, who this season has won the Dutch Cup and won the Eredivisie last year, is now the favourite - yet who is the 45-year-old and what has he done to be a frontrunner for the Anfield vacancy?\n\nPrior to his coaching journey, Slot enjoyed an 18-year playing career as a midfielder in the Netherlands, playing for seven years at FC Zwolle and five years at NAC Breda.\n\nHe was part of a promotion-winning side at the former from the second tier to the top-flight, while he finished fourth in the Eredivisie at Breda and played in the UEFA Cup against Newcastle United in 2003, losing 6-0 on aggregate.\n\nSlot, known for his passing and vision, later had spells at Sparta Rotterdam and PEC Zwolle before retiring in 2013 at the age of 35.\n\nBut in the last 10 years, he has developed steadily as a coach. The Dutchman moved straight away onto the coaching staff at first division club PEC Zwolle, working as a youth coach for one year before moving on to be assistant at then-Eredivisie side Cambuur.\n\nHe was a No 2 under three different head coaches before he took interim charge in October 2016, with the club 14 in the second division. However, he helped them to third in the league, missing out on promotion in the play-offs and a spot in the Dutch Cup final - having earlier beaten Ajax - on penalties in the semi-finals.\n\nDespite his impressive first outing as a head coach, Slot moved to AZ Alkmaar to be assistant to John van den Brom. He stayed in his role for two seasons before he succeeded Van den Brom as head coach. He finished second behind Ajax on goal-difference but the Eredivisie was cancelled due to the Covid pandemic.\n\nSlot was then sacked as AZ head coach in December 2020, having negotiated a deal to join rivals Feyenoord for the following season. The coach left with 2.11 points per game in the league, the highest of any coach in AZ history.\n\nBut his time in Feyenoord has been an overwhelming success. He guided the team to the inaugural UEFA Conference League final in his first season, losing to Roma in the final, and third in the Eredivisie.\n\nHaving extended his contract in the summer of 2022, Slot guided Feyenoord to their 16 league title and first since 2017. They were, however, again knocked out of Europe by Roma, this time at the quarter-final stage of the Europa League.\n\nSlot then reportedly turned down the Tottenham job last summer, penning a new deal to 2026, and embarked on another season with Feyenoord. His side won the Dutch Cup on Sunday, beating NEC in the final, and are currently second in the Eredivisie. Liverpool were keen to act respectfully and did not make any approach prior to the final.\n\nNow, Slot looks set for a highly-anticipated move away from the Netherlands. He is said to be eager to join Liverpool, with compensation set to be around the \u00a310m mark, and the release clause in his contract can't be activated until next year.\n\nSlot is known for his aggressive, dominant style of football and places a big emphasis on developing young players and improving senior stars at his disposal. He plays with a high defensive line and usually utilises a 4-3-3 or 4-2-3-1 formation. Out of possession, his teams press high, making his philosophy not too far away from Klopp and the style he could inherit at Liverpool.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8093507553", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "17:03:43", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T17:03:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T17:03:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.rousingthekop.com/2024/04/23/the-four-things-liverpool-really-like-about-arne-slot-as-he-becomes-leading-contender-for-manager/", "title": "The four things Liverpool really like about Arne Slot, as he becomes leading contender for manager", "body": "Liverpool's new manager search took another twist today with a new leading candidate named.\n\nThe Reds have been anything but straightforward in their hunt to find the right man to replace Jurgen Klopp.\n\nAnd after Ruben Amorim's name was seemingly dropped from consideration on Monday, Liverpool supporters were left scratching their heads.\n\nThere were still a number of viable options from the reported five-man shortlist they were working from a couple of weeks ago. But none of them seemed especially likely.\n\nNow, on Tuesday afternoon, new filtered through that a name who was not on that list at all - Feyenoord's Arne Slot - is now the 'leading contender.'\n\nThis news will have come as quite a surprise to Liverpool fans. Slot has been mentioned sporadically throughout the search so far, but never as a prominent candidate.\n\nNevertheless, it had frequently been claimed that the Reds were prepared to be 'bold' rather than popular with their choice. So, it shouldn't be a huge shock that a left-field name has been plucked.\n\nAnd, to be honest, when you look at the reasons The Athletic put forward for Slot to be considered, we can't say it doesn't make sense.\n\nThey claim that the 45-year-old has actually filled 'many of the relevant' criteria that Michael Edwards and Richard Hughes were looking for.\n\nOne of these is said to be Slot's style of football. Described as being an 'aggressive, dominant style of play,' the Dutchman is said to be a good fit for Liverpool's current first-team squad. He also reportedly has a good track record in youth development and can demonstrate 'title-winning success' while sticking to these principles.\n\nLastly - and perhaps this will feed the critics slightly - Slot is claimed to have shown that he can achieve success without 'frivolous spending.' This one is said to be 'attractive' to FSG in particular.\n\nAll of this sounds good, but you can't get away from the fact that many Liverpool fans will be left asking 'Who is Arne Slot?' tonight. Well, let us try to give you a little bit of background.\n\nSlot, a former midfielder, spent the whole of his playing career in his native Netherlands. Never capped for his country, he retired at PEC Zwolle in 2013.\n\nFrom there, he moved to Cambuur, where he worked as an assistant and briefly and interim manager. A move to AZ Alkmaar then beckoned where Slot again worked behind the scenes before taking on the top job in 2019.\n\nHis first stint as a head coach was promising and Slot may well have led AZ to the title in 2020 were the season not prematurely ended by the Coronavirus pandemic. Slot's side were level on points with Ajax at the top when the campaign finished without awarding a winner.\n\nArne then joined Feyenoord where he has been ever since. A Europa Conference League runners-up medal in 2021/22 was followed up with Eredivisie title win the following year, and a KNVB Cup this time. They will reportedly 'move fast' to tie up a deal to bring Slot from Feyenoord this week.\n\nThere are plenty of reasons to be excited about the 45-year-old, although the jury will very much be out on whether he's good enough to step into Klopp's shoes.\n\nNevertheless, Slot is now quite clearly Liverpool's first choice option. With Amorim now said to be off the table, it would be interesting to know why.\n\n\"Between Ruben Amorim and Liverpool, what's happening?\" posed the transfer expert. \"Some media reported in recent weeks that everything was verbally agreed between Amorim and Liverpool. I'm told that this was never the case.\n\n\"Amorim had conversations and talks with Liverpool but never had an agreement with Liverpool. But now it looks difficult, unlikely. The situation is in standby already since last week. No fresh contacts between Liverpool and Amorim.\n\n\"So, active talks with Arne Slot, no direct contacts with Amorim in the last seven, ten days.\"\n\nIt's possible that we'll never really know exactly what went on between Amorim and Liverpool. In many ways, the 39-year-old seemed like the ideal appointment for the Reds.\n\nWith his Sporting team on the verge of a second league title in four years, Amorim looked poised to make the step up.\n\nIt's obviously possible that Liverpool were also talking to Slot at the same time and always preferred the Feyenoord boss. But we just don't buy that.\n\nAmorim is the outstanding candidate on paper. He must have been ahead in the running. He's also claimed to have firmed up his choice for assistant manager, too.\n\nNevertheless, things aren't over the line for Slot and Liverpool just yet. And with other clubs said to be lurking for the Dutchman, the Reds reportedly have two other options on stand-by.\n\nThere have been plenty of names mentioned as FSG look to find their ideal Klopp replacement this summer. For the most part though, Slot had not really been one of them.\n\nInstead, the press have largely focused on names like Julian Nagelsmann, Ruben Amorim and Roberto De Zerbi.\n\nNow, Nagelsmann took himself out of the running last week by surprisingly extending his stay as the Germany national team manager. Slot, it's claimed, is a 'strong candidate' but the Reds could reportedly face 'competition' for the Feyenoord manager from Bayern Munich, Barcelona and AC Milan.\n\nAs a result, Liverpool need to have some back-up options. And these would appear to be Amorim and De Zerbi. For all of the candidates, it's claimed that the Reds have not held face-to-face talks. Instead, they have been 'sounding out' potential new managers via intermediaries.\n\nThroughout the past three months or so, Liverpool have really kept people guessing as to who will follow Klopp at Anfield.\n\nBack when Jurgen announced his intention to leave in January, not many people had Slot down as the man who would take up the mantle.\n\nPlenty had suggested both Amorim and De Zerbi though, and perhaps it will still end up being one of those two managers.\n\nBut the only scenario that looks possible is if Slot is either poached by another club or decides to stay at Feyenoord. After yesterday's press briefing, Liverpool seem confident that that won't happen.\n\nOne thing appears to be certain for now, then. This is the Reds' final shortlist. religiously when his team are on the pitch.\n\nHis style was described to the i as \"high-energy attacking football in a 4-3-3 or 4-2-3-1 with two deep-lying midfielders and a reliance on wingers to Pep Guardiola", "body": "Arne Slot, who has emerged as the front-runner to succeed Jurgen Klopp at Liverpool, has become one of Europe's most coveted coaches after building an exhilarating team at Feyenoord.\n\nSlot's side not only won the Eredivisie at a canter last season, they did so with a flourish, playing high-octane, attacking football which was characterised by aggressive, non-stop pressing.\n\nThe 45-year-old's intense, front-foot approach would make him a good fit to build on Klopp's legacy, but Slot has also earned comparisons with Pep Guardiola and Mikel Arteta for the way his sides seek to control possession.\n\nAfter swapping AZ Alkmaar (who he led to joint-top of the Eredivisie when the 2019-20 season was called off) for Feyenoord, Slot inherited a squad which played uninspiring, defensive football under his predecessor and quickly transformed their style.\n\nFeyenoord finished third and reached the Conference League Final in his first season in charge, but their squad was gutted in the following summer, with just four starters from the XI which had started the defeat to Jose Mourinho's Roma remaining at De Kuip.\n\nSlot, however, built an even better team, breaking Ajax's stranglehold on the league with only Feyenoord's second title this century.\n\nThough Feyenoord will not retain the championship this term, largely due to an extraordinary campaign by PSV Eindhoven, he has added the Dutch Cup to his list of honours.\n\nStrong-willed and charismatic, Slot is adored by his squad and has built a team largely using young players, another factor which should appeal to Liverpool as they prepare for a new youth-centric project.\n\nWhile Slot is also said to be attracting interest from Barcelona and Bayern Munich, Liverpool may be wary that importing 'With the way he plays and the philosophy he has, he can be a Liverpool coach.\n\n'But I read and hear that it is far from complete. We shall see. Benitez came in off the back of two La Liga titles and a UEFA Cup. Klopp came in off winning a couple of league titles with Borussia Dortmund and getting to a Champions League final.\n\n'And Liverpool were actually in a different space then. I was part of the team before Benitez when we were just trying to qualify for the top four. Same with Klopp when he came in.\n\n'Liverpool are in a different area now. They're actually fancying themselves to win the Premier League every season and next season the Champions League, they'll be expecting to get to the quarter-finals at least.\n\nI think it's a huge jump. Now Arne Slot is the favourite.\"\n\nCarragher added: \"I don't think it's like Benitez coming in, or Klopp. Benitez coming in on the back of two LaLiga titles and a UEFA Cup, or Klopp winning a couple of league titles and getting to a Champions League final. Liverpool were actually in a different space then.\n\n\"That Liverpool team, certainly under Benitez that I was part of, we were the team trying to qualify for the top four. The same with Klopp when he came in.\n\n\"But Liverpool are in a different era now. They actually fancy themselves to challenge for the Premier League every season. Next season, in the Champions League they'd expect to get to the quarter-finals at least.\n\n\"I think it's a huge jump but he's obviously a great coach with a great track record so far. We'll see.\"\n\nMohamed Salah has again been linked with a possible move to Saudi Arabia ahead of the summer and Carragher thinks Liverpool could now be questioning whether to hang onto him or not for the first time.\n\nCarragher continued: \"There is a real discussion for the new manager about what the future holds for Mo Salah - it's the first time we've asked that question. He only has a year to go on his contract.\n\n\"He's looked a shadow of himself for a lot of this season but especially since he's come back from injury. take on the task of replacing Klopp.\n\nThe Dutchman has succeeded on a modest budget at Feyenoord, winning the Eredivisie and KNVB Cup during his time in charge, as well as reaching the Europa Conference League final.\n\nThose achievements had led to interest from Tottenham, whose advances were rejected last summer before they ultimately turned to Ange Postecoglou.\n\nChelsea had also management with AZ Alkmaar in 2019.\n\nAfter a season-and-a-half in charge, he left to make the switch to Feyenoord, who he led to the Eredivisie title in his second campaign in 2022/23.\n\nFeyenoord {"uri": "8093709582", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "20:04:47", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T20:04:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T20:04:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/article-13339675/Liverpools-SIX-contenders-succeed-Jurgen-Klopp.html", "title": "Who could Liverpool turn to if Ruben Amorim is no longer an option?", "body": "Prejudice and bias are dangerous claims from these clubs. Liverpool, Arsenal and now Forest. It's embarrassing - Listen to the It's All Kicking Off podcast\n\nFinding Jurgen Klopp's successor was never going to be an easy task. The German has left big boots to fill and, while taking over the reins at Anfield may be an exciting prospect for any aspiring manager, acquiring a coach to step in to replace Klopp is seemingly proving a difficult task for sporting director Richard Hughes and CEO Michael Edwards.\n\nAfter the disappointment of missing out on Xabi Alonso, it appears Liverpool have also been dealt a blow in their bid to land Ruben Amorim as their next manager. The in-demand Sporting Lisbon boss has this week been on a flying visit to London to meet with representatives at West Ham.\n\nHe arrived in the capital on Monday and spoke with Hammers' executives about a potential deal to take over from David Moyes, according to CNN Portugal. The 39-year-old returned to Portugal on Tuesday, and was met by journalists who pressed him on his future. While he laughed off their questions, Portuguese news outlet A Bola are claiming that West Ham have offered him 'considerably more' than what Liverpool tabled.\n\nBut money isn't everything, with West Ham also set to give him the 'freedom to build his squad as he wishes'. That whole package could prove to be a big lure for the Portuguese manager and it is understood that Amorim could be available to the English club for around \u00a312.8million.\n\nThe 39-year-old has repeatedly dismissed claims that he could become the next Liverpool boss and it is now looking less likely that the Merseyside club will land him in the summer, meaning Edwards and Hughes will have to look elsewhere - but who is still in the running to succeed Klopp?\n\nWest Ham held talks with Sporting Lisbon boss Ruben Amorim on Monday in London\n\nAmorim was met by a swarm of journalists after landing back in Portugal late on Tuesday\n\nLiverpool are continuing to search for a successor to Jurgen Klopp, who will leave this summer\n\nYour browser does not support iframes.\n\nArne Slot\n\nFeyenoord boss Slot emerged a shock frontrunner to replace Klopp on Tuesday as Liverpool ramped up their search for a successor.\n\nTottenham fans, who were keen on luring the manager before hiring Ange Postecoglou last summer, were left fuming when Slot announced that he would be staying at Feyenoord this season.\n\nREAD MORE: Ruben Amorim speaks for the first time after flying to London to hold talks with West Ham about becoming their next manager - with Sporting Lisbon boss 'offered higher terms than Liverpool could offer to join the club' Advertisement\n\nIt turns out things didn't work out too badly for Spurs, despite missing out on their main target, with Ange Postecoglou joining in the summer and subsequently becoming a fan favourite at the club.\n\nAfter holding exploratory talks over a move to north London, Slot announced that he would be staying in the Netherlands - having won the Dutch Eredivisie title with Feyenoord last season.\n\nWhile he hasn't been able to repeat that feat during the 2023-24 campaign, Slot has pushed Feyenoord to second in the league standings, using his attacking and entertaining brand of football.\n\nHe is an innovative manager who understands how modern-day footballers operate - meaning he can deliver a rousing team talk or dish out a telling off, should it be required. And his tactics are similar to those that Liverpool deploy under Klopp - with the 45-year-old instructing his players to deploy an intensive man-marking strategy and win the ball back early.\n\nThere is a concern that new CEO of football Edwards may have to dip deep into his coffers to sign the Dutchman though, with Slot agreeing a three-year deal to stay at Feyenoord in May, 2023 after snubbing a move to Spurs.\n\nArne Slot's move to join Tottenham fell through last year after he decided to snub the club\n\nThere is a concern that Edwards (left) may have to dip deep into his coffers to sign Slot\n\nRoberto De Zerbi\n\nFormerly a leading contender to take the Liverpool job after Hughes, who previously worked as Bournemouth's sporting director, wanted to appoint the Italian coach as the Cherries boss.\n\nREAD MORE: Jamie Carragher believes Roberto De Zerbi is the new favourite for the Liverpool job after reports Ruben Amorim was 'unlikely' to replace Jurgen Klopp at Anfield Advertisement\n\n'Richard Hughes wanted De Zerbi at Bournemouth, so he must be the favourite if this is true,' Carragher said.\n\nDe Zerbi's success deploying a fast and entertaining brand of football at Brighton has earned him plenty of praise over the years, with the 44-year-old taking over from Graham Potter in 2022, before guiding Brighton to qualify for the Europa League last season.\n\nHe has grown in stature to becoming one of the most well-respected managers in the Premier League - and that casts some doubt over whether he would leave Brighton to join a top-flight rival - especially considering the team he has built.\n\nDavid Ornstein has also claimed that the move might not go ahead, telling The Athletic FC Podcast: 'My information is that it's incredibly unlikely that Liverpool will go for De Zerbi.'\n\nAmid the conflicting rumours, the Italian has been on Liverpool's radar at points during their search for a new manager, according to Sky Sports.\n\nConflicting rumours have emerged over whether De Zerbi would join Liverpool from Brighton\n\nThiago Motta\n\nBologna boss, Motta, is another manager who has reportedly been on Edwards and Hughes' radar of late. The former Paris Saint-Germain midfielder has plenty of experience winning trophies over the years and that will no doubt entice Liverpool into hiring him.\n\nREAD MORE: The SIX managers Man United 'are considering to replace Erik ten Hag' REVEALED - with concerns over whether Brighton's Roberto De Zerbi 'has the personality to handle the pressure' Advertisement\n\nThe 41-year-old has an impressive managerial CV too. He started his coaching journey taking charge of the PSG U19 team, before enjoying stints with Genoa and Spezia Calcio. With Bologna, the former Italy international has guided the Rossoblu up to fourth in the Serie A standings - with the club on the verge of securing Champions League football for the first time in their history next season.\n\nHis agent Alessandro Canovi, has not ruled out a move to Liverpool either, claiming that 'interesting offers' could come in the next few weeks. He told TMW Radio via Calcio Mercato: 'There are no agreements or dialogues. At the moment the only reality is that Motta has an expiring contract with Bologna.\n\n'Will he stay at Bologna? I can't say, because I don't have negotiations with anyone. We cannot talk about things that do not exist.\n\n'The situation of the big names? The confirmation of Xabi Alonso at Bayer Leverkusen has opened up several important candidates for Liverpool and Bayern Munich. As well as Barcelona. They are three interesting and highly coveted benches now.'\n\nWhile it might be unlikely that he wil leave his current club just as they secure a berth in the Champions League, Motta's agent's comments are curious to say the least.\n\nBologna boss, Motta, is another manager who has reportedly been on Liverpool's radar\n\nThomas Frank\n\nThe Dane has been touted as a managerial successor to Klopp for some time. Speculation from TeamTALK suggests that the Reds are considering the Brentford boss as a serious contender to take over from the German.\n\nHe has been at the forefront of success at the Gtech Community Stadium since he was appointed first-team coach in 2018. Frank would oversee their promotion to the top-flight in 2021, with the ever-charismatic tactician having kept Brentford in the the Premier League for the last three seasons.\n\nWhat's more is that he's established them as one of the toughest teams in the league to beat - thanks to their extreme energy around the park. He and Klopp share very similar ideas of how their teams should operate - with Frank emploring his players to run their opponents off the pitch.\n\n'There's a lot of rumours out there,' Frank said to Sky Sports in February on the links to Liverpool. 'I think we all have kind of an ego and the ego likes that little bit of sugar but at the end of the day, I'm at Brentford. I'm very happy here.'\n\n'Do I have ambitions? Yes. Am I going to stay at Brentford forever? Maybe but probably not. So who knows what's going to happen in the future? What I know is that I'm here at Brentford and I'm very happy with it.'\n\nBrentford boss Thomas Frank has been touted as a successor to Jurgen Klopp for some time\n\nThomas Tuchel\n\nCould the German make a return to the Premier League, following his disappointing exit from Chelsea in 2022?\n\nThere is some speculation that Tuchel may not fit the right persona to succeed as the Liverpool manager - with Mail Sport columnist Danny Murphy previously telling talkSPORT that the outgoing Bayern Munich boss 'is too divisive' and that 'he's not a Liverpool manager.'\n\nThis season, Bayern have conceded the German title to Alonso's Bayer Leverkusen, with Tuchel announcing that he will leave the side at the end of the season.\n\nAccording to The Telegraph, the former Champions League winning manager will prioritise a move back to England, putting several Premier League clubs on red alert.\n\nCould Thomas Tuchel make his Premier League return, after his exit from Chelsea in 2022?\n\nPaulo Fonseca\n\nPaulo Fonseca's Lille side suffered an agonising defeat on penalties by Aston Villa last week. It was a tough result, but the French side look set to qualify for European football again this season and go one better than their achievements in the 2022-23 campaign, by securing a berth in the Champions League qualifiers.\n\nIn the latest plot twist of Liverpool's manager hunt, speculation is growing that the Portuguese coach is the latest candidate to be added to Liverpool's managerial shortlist.\n\nHe possesses plenty of experience having worked at big clubs across Europe, including Shakhtar, Roma and Porto. He had also been on the verge of a move to Tottenham in 2021, but that deal fell through because then-sporting director Fabio Paratici wanted Spurs to play a little more defensively.\n\nLille manager Fonseca is the latest coach to have been linked with the Liverpool post\n\n'I have some principles,' Fonseca said on his failed move to Spurs. 'I wanted to be coach of the great teams but I want the right project and a club where the people believe in my ideas, my way to play, and this didn't happen with the managing director.'\n\nPerhaps
