"dmoz/Shopping/Vehicles/Trucks,_Vans,_and_Sport_Utility", "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Vehicles/Trucks, Vans, and Sport Utility", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Advice/Syndicated", "label": "dmoz/Society/Advice/Syndicated", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 73}], "image": "https://insidefutbol.com/app/uploads/2024/04/Feyenoord_Arne_Slot3-300x207.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9504405", "eventUri": "eng-9504405", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.0117647058823529, "wgt": 166, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8093473056", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "16:35:27", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T16:35:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T16:35:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://theathletic.com/5439036/2024/04/23/arne-slot-liverpool-manager-profile/", "title": "Arne Slot: A champion with Feyenoord and now a leading contender for Liverpool", "body": "This is an updated version of an article first published on May 14, 2023.\n\nIn 2020-21, the season before Arne Slot became their manager, Feyenoord finished 29 points behind champions Ajax. They came fifth, the same number of points from the top of the table as they were from the bottom three, with the football under Dick Advocaat very uninspiring.\n\nTwo years later, the Rotterdam club were champions, having spent virtually the whole season leading the Eredivisie. It was a remarkable turnaround which prompted a succession of English clubs to seek to secure his services.\n\nCrystal Palace were among them, as were Leeds, who had Slot on their list of possible replacements for Jesse Marsch in February 2023 and held talks with him in the Netherlands. Those discussions did not develop.\n\nTottenham, meanwhile, thought they had persuaded him to move to north London in May 2023, with Feyenoord apparently resigned to losing him until Slot surprisingly decided to stay put. Spurs turned to Ange Postecoglou instead.\n\nAlmost a year on, and Slot's stock has continued to rise. Feyenoord have not been able to defend their Eredivisie title but they have only been denied by a remarkable campaign by PSV, who have lost just once all season. Slot's side have only been beaten twice in the league - and not at all since December 3 - and won the Dutch Cup last weekend.\n\nNow it has emerged that Slot is a leading contender for the Liverpool job which will be vacated by Jurgen Klopp this summer.\n\nBut why is he attracting such interest - and who exactly is he?\n\nArne Slot was slow.\n\nAs a player, Slot was a perfectly decent midfielder, with the bulk of his appearances coming in the Dutch second tier. He was technically very good, usually playing as an attacking midfielder or No 10 but, in the words of his former team-mate Edwin de Graaf, he was \"not so fast\". Slot the coach once said that he would not have picked Slot the player.\n\nThis meant he had to rely on others around him to do a lot of the running. \"I was a hard worker, he was the more technical player,\" says De Graaf, who played alongside him at NAC Breda.\n\nBut his limitations as a player have helped him become the coach he is today because they enhanced his appreciation of how to make a team function as a cohesive unit. He was living proof that one player cannot do his job unless a colleague is doing theirs.\n\nHe was always going to be a coach, moving from the playing squad to the coaching staff at PEC Zwolle immediately after his retirement.\n\n\"Some players you can see are going to be coaches,\" says De Graaf. \"I also played with Alfred Schreuder (the former Ajax manager) and both him and Slot... nobody is surprised now they're both coaches.\n\n\"He would ask the coach why they were using certain tactics. And in the dressing room, he would talk to the group about (for example) a way of pressing or defending. He would ask: 'Why were we doing it this way? Would it be better to do it this way?'. He would make suggestions to his coaches.\n\n\"But he would do it in such a good way. He wouldn't do it with an attitude: he would ask the coach: 'What do you think about this?'. He would also very quickly see what the opponents were doing.\"\n\n\"At that time, he was already looking in an analytical way,\" Henk ten Cate, who brought Slot to Breda, told Voetbal International in 2022. \"He was busy with tactics and asked questions at training.\"\n\nIt is worth noting this was not when Slot was in the twilight of his career and was worrying about what would come next. Slot and Ten Cate worked together in 2002-03 when Slot was 24. He was one of those players who used his time on the pitch as an extended apprenticeship for when he moved to the touchline.\n\nSlot hung up his boots in 2013 after playing for PEC Zwolle and immediately joined the club's youth academy as a coach.\n\nHe then spent three years as a coach at Cambuur, who had just been promoted to the Eredivisie, after which he moved to AZ Alkmaar to be assistant to manager John van den Brom, still only 39 when he took that job. \"We always searched for young, new coaches,\" says Van den Brom. \"He was an interesting coach because he wanted to develop.\"\n\nIt was during these years Slot clarified what sort of football he wanted to play, helped by a series of formative relationships with other coaches.\n\nAt AZ, there was Van den Brom and Pascal Jansen (who managed AZ for four years), while at Cambuur he worked closely with Marcel Keizer, who would go on to manage Ajax and Sporting Lisbon. He also shared ideas with Pep Ljinders, now Klopp's assistant at Liverpool, and, with a group of other coaches, created a bespoke player database. At the time, the data resources available to them were far from adequate, so they built their own.\n\n\"What was nice for me is that he always thought in an attacking way,\" says Van den Brom, before mentioning something that comes up time and again whenever you speak to someone about Slot.\n\n\"(His focus was) how can we make it clear to the players how we want to play? We were always searching for different ideas.\"\n\nIt is fine for a coach to have ideas, but they have to be clearly transmitted to the players. Slot's biggest quality and one he places significant emphasis on -- he believes only 60 per cent is the idea and 40 per cent is how clearly you explain it -- is his ability to communicate. His ideas are projected onto the pitch because his thoughts are clear and his words are carefully chosen.\n\nSo what are those ideas?\n\n\"They're very attacking, very aggressive, with a lot of pressing,\" says Martijn Krabbendam, a journalist for Voetbal International who has covered Slot's Feyenoord. \"High intensity, a lot of energy, and they can only do that if they're very fit.\n\n\"He always wants to play attacking football, he always wants possession, he always wants a good set-up from the goalkeeper to find free space and free players in the midfield. It's no secret he is crazy about Guardiola -- he's an example.\"\n\nVan den Brom adds: \"We used a lot of videos of Manchester City and Bayern -- he was crazy about Pep. How his teams create space, how they attack.\"\n\nGuardiola is the name that keeps coming up, but Slot also takes inspiration from a variety of other coaches: Marcelo Bielsa, Jorge Sampaoli, Jurgen Klopp, Luciano Spaletti, Mikel Arteta. All have their own ideas, so does he, but one thing they all have in common is their intensity.\n\nBefore he became Breda coach, De Graaf spent a week with Slot at Feyenoord, observing how he works. \"Every session is with high intensity,\" he says. \"Every workout, passing drill, or five vs five -- everything is with high intention and everything is with an idea. Every player knows exactly what he wants from them. He's good at making clear why he's doing certain exercises.\n\n\"He's as honest as possible, so the players really like him.\"\n\nSlot believes his teams have to be intense because it essentially gives them two ways to win: if the quality of their play is lower than that of their opponents or they are having an off day, they can win by outrunning and outworking whoever they are playing.\n\nThere is also a recognition of, and mitigation against, the fitness concerns that come with such an intense style of not just playing, but training. He works closely with his data and fitness teams: when they tell him a player's numbers are dropping or they are in the 'red zone', he will ease off.\n\nTransitions are quick and passing is certain. Slot likes to work with younger players who are keen to learn. \"If you have a young group, then, as a trainer, you can take the boys through videos in your desired playing style,\" he said a few years ago.\n\nFor example, when Tyrell Malacia left Feyenoord in 2022 for Manchester United, he chose to replace him at left-back with the 20-year-old youth team product Quilindschy Hartman. When he needed a central midfielder, he took 22-year-old Mats Wieffer from Excelsior Rotterdam in the Dutch second tier. Both were subsequently called up to the Dutch national team. Most of the key players in Feyenoord's title-winning season were aged 24 and under.\n\nHis focus is on the collective. He believes the team makes the individual look good.\n\nMost of all, the priority is on entertaining football. The goal is not to win at any cost, but to provide exciting, as well as winning, football. Voetbal International wrote: \"He believes that special football is more remembered than a prize with boring, uninspiring football.\"\n\nPlayers seem to adore Slot.\n\nOussama Idrissi, who played a key part in Slot's teams at both AZ and Feyenoord, was asked last year by the Dutch newspaper AD where Slot ranks in the coaches he has played under. \"For me, he's the best,\" said the Moroccan winger. \"He can develop players and make teams play fun football.\"\n\nWhen it was pointed out that he has also played under Julen Lopetegui, Herve Renard and a guy called Erik ten Hag, Idrissi reiterated: \"Slot was the best.\"\n\nYou will not struggle to find other players with similarly effusive things to say about him. \"He is one of the best managers I've ever seen,\" said Alireza Jahanbakhsh, the Iranian forward currently playing under Slot at Feyenoord. \"In football terms, even the best. At the moment, he is the best in the Netherlands.\"\n\nReiss Nelson spent the 2021-22 season on loan at Feyenoord, becoming a regular in the second half of the campaign. \"Arne Slot is a great manager,\" he told the Colney Carpool podcast. \"He really got me into my rhythm. He gave me a lot of opportunities to play and I excelled.\"\n\n\"It's a shame,\" said Myron Boadu, shortly after Slot left AZ. \"Arne is a fantastic person and a fantastic trainer who really let us play football in the style of Manchester City or Barcelona in the good times.\"\n\n\"He's as honest as possible, so the players really like him,\" says De Graaf.\n\nSlot has not gained the backing of these players just by being straightforward, though. The players like him because they win under him. But, perhaps more than that, they follow him because most of the things he tells them come true.\n\n\"Before playing Marseille (in the Europa Conference League semi-finals in 2022), during training he told his midfielders to play long balls out to the wingers, over the top,\" explains Krabbendam. \"(Orkun) Kokcu, the midfielder, was so tired of it -- he asked: 'Why do we have to keep playing these long balls?'. Slot said he would explain later.\n\n\"In 20 minutes, Feyenoord were up 2-0 and both goals came from long balls behind the Marseille defence. He knew that was a weakness of Marseille. If you speak to the Feyenoord players -- and it doesn't matter which players -- they will tell you that whatever this coach says, it happens. It's remarkable. They have blind confidence in him because what he says comes true.\"\n\nHe is no hardliner or a particular disciplinarian. He emphasises positivity. When his video analysts put selections of clips together for players to watch, allowing them to scrutinise their own performances, he asks that most of them are positive. In particular, the last one is always positive so the players leave their session feeling good about themselves.\n\nArguably, the player who most benefitted from Slot's tenure at Feyenoord was Kokcu, who came through the ranks at Feyenoord.\n\nPreviously regarded as a talented but slightly insubstantial No 10, Kokcu came back from Euro 2020 with Turkey to find things had changed. No longer would he be able to create and let his team-mates do his running for him.\n\nAfter Slot's first competitive game in charge, a Europa Conference League game against Kosovan side SF Drita, the new coach sat down next to Kokcu on the flight home and explained that he needed more from him. More running, more pressing, more chasing back. And it worked.\n\nEven after only a few weeks of working together, Slot convinced Kokcu that he had to significantly improve physically.\n\nKokcu is close friends with Malacia (the two came through the Feyenoord youth team together) and had observed the defender's physical development since he started working with a physical trainer in Rotterdam. Kokcu went to the same trainer and, within weeks, had become the worker Slot demanded.\n\n\"If you see him now, he's a modern midfield player,\" says Krabbendam.\n\nTo illustrate this point, take a look at this touch chart for Kokcu in Feyenoord's Europa League quarter-final first-leg victory over Roma in April 2023. The concentration is in the middle, but there are very few areas of the pitch he did not cover.\n\nThe disruption to football caused by COVID-19 produced many 'what ifs', but there cannot be many bigger than for Slot.\n\nIn his first season as AZ head coach, they had already beaten Feyenoord and PSV 3-0 and 4-0 away respectively before a 2-0 win at Ajax in March 2020 put them level on points at the top of the Eredivisie with the Amsterdam giants. There were still nine games remaining but AZ had the momentum.\n\nThe following week, the season was suspended as the pandemic took hold. The campaign was ultimately cancelled completely in April and the chance to win just the third title in AZ's history was scuppered.\n\nThey started the following season in similar style, going undefeated until the start of December. Then it all ended quite abruptly.\n\nFeyenoord announced that veteran manager Advocaat would be leaving at the end of that campaign. Slot was the obvious replacement but, a few days later, the AZ board got wind of talks between Slot and the Rotterdam club and promptly sacked him. He was clearly ready for a step up, but it was far from the way he wanted to leave the club.\n\n\"You always want to leave by the front door,\" says Van den Brom. \"So it wasn't good for Arne and it wasn't good for the club.\"\n\nHe spent the intervening months playing golf and planning for the move.\n\nIt worked. The improvement in Feyenoord's football -- and results -- was almost instant, moving from a distant fifth to a closer third, scoring more goals, conceding fewer and winning more games. They also reached the Europa Conference League final, where they lost to Roma. Slot won the Rinus Michels award for best coach in the Eredivisie.\n\nIf you want to quantify Feyenoord's improvement under Slot, consider FiveThirtyEight's Soccer Power Index, which uses underlying metrics to calculate a team's attacking and defensive strength. Slot's arrival at the club coincided with a steady rise up the rankings, peaking on a score of 76.6, the 21st-highest in world football. Not bad for an Eredivisie club.\n\nBut here is perhaps the most compelling evidence that Slot has something.\n\nIn the summer after that first season, his Feyenoord team was gutted. Top scorer Luis Sinisterra was sold to Leeds. Malacia went to United. Marcos Senesi to Bournemouth. Nelson's loan spell ended and he returned to Arsenal. Midfielder Fredrik Aursnes joined Benfica. Guus Til (on loan at Feyenoord from Spartak Moscow) moved to PSV. All four players who had chalked up double-figure goal tallies the previous season had left.\n\nAnd yet, Feyenoord improved. Kokcu and a few others stayed, but in came Santiago Gimenez, who has gone on to be their top scorer. Slovakian defender David Hancko arrived from Sparta Prague and excelled. Idrissi, who starred for Slot at AZ, was rescued from Sevilla on loan. Wieffer and Hartman were essentially plucked from nowhere and are now full internationals.\n\nThey took top spot in the Eredvisie just before the World Cup break and did not relinquish it.\n\nPSV may have deposed them this season but there is no sense that there has been a significant drop-off in performances: Feyenoord could yet surpass their league-winning points tally from last season of 82.\n\nSlot is revered for winning just Feyenoord's second Eredivisie title since the turn of the century, and he now has Champions League experience - albeit he was unable to lead the club out of the group stage, despite beating Lazio and Celtic.\n\nLiverpool's interest is understandable. Any club that wants a young, forward-thinking coach who prioritises fast, intense, attacking football would be foolish not to take a look.", "source": {"uri": "theathletic.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8094277003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "06:09:45", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T06:09:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T06:08:34Z", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8094751003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "11:04:54", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T11:04:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:04:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.rousingthekop.com/2024/04/24/how-liverpool-could-line-up-with-arne-slot-if-he-was-appointed-as-jurgen-klopps-replacement/", "title": "How Liverpool could line-up with Arne Slot if he was appointed as J\u00fcrgen Klopp's replacement", "body": "This is how Arne Slot's Liverpool side could look next season if he was appointed as manager of the club.\n\nChanges are afoot at Anfield. With Jurgen Klopp leaving at the end of the season, Liverpool have been behind the scenes to find his replacement.\n\nAnd it seems very likely that they might have just found him. Arne Slot seems to be inching closer to be appointed as the club's new manager.\n\nHe is very much the favourite for the Liverpool job at this stage, and it seems likely that he will be in the dugout for the club next season.\n\nIt's an interesting appointment for Liverpool. Slot is not a well-known name in English football, but he does have an excellent track record in the Netherlands. He's playing style also very closely resembles Jurgen Klopp's.\n\nLike Klopp Slot's football is focused on high intensity. He wants his players to press forward and create overloads all over the pitch.\n\nExpect Liverpool to play a very similar kind of pressing football under Slot next season. This definitely won't change from Klopp's tenure.\n\nBut there are key differences in the way Slot likes to play football as well. His build-up is a lot more controlled. Meanwhile, in the final third Feyenoord are known to play quick incisive passes, and are very good at breaking down opponents.\n\nSlot also traditionally plays with a slight variance to Klopp's 4-3-3 formation. Slot's formation is probably more closer to a 4-2-3-1 with two deep lying midfielders and one more advanced one.\n\nIn terms of how Liverpool could line-up, there won't be too many changes at the back. Alisson Becker will be in goal. Trent Alexander-Arnold, Ibrahima Konate, Virgil van Dijk and Andy Robertson will make up the back four.\n\nIn midfield, it would not be a surprise to see Slot bring in another holding midfielder. However, at this current moment in time, the two deep lying roles suit Alexis Mac Allister and Wataru Endo the best.\n\nMeanwhile, the more advanced midfielder could be Dominik Szoboszlai or Harvey Elliott.\n\nUp top, expect the likes of Mohamed Salah, Darwin Nunez, Luis Diaz, Cody Gakpo and Diogo Jota to maintain very similar roles in the front three.\n\nIn terms of where Slot may look to strengthen, it would not be a surprise to see him bring in a left-sided centre-back.\n\nDavid Hancko is someone who has done very well under the Dutch manager, and he's been followed by Liverpool as well so he is an obvious choice.\n\nAs mentioned above, Slot could also look at bringing in a holding midfielder. But the Reds could also strengthen at left-back, and depending on what happens with the club's attackers, they may also be in the market for a new player for the forward line.", "source": {"uri": However, Slot does seem like an ideal fit.\n\nHe's affable with the media, plays an exciting brand of football and is still relatively young in his coaching career.\n\nThat's pretty much every box ticked in terms of the main criteria of what Liverpool fans want to see at Anfield.\n\nIt may be obvious to some, but if Arne Slot is appointed as Liverpool's new manager, it's looking like he will bring some of his own coaching staff from Feyenoord with him.\n\nThis could include his current assistant manager, Sipke Hulshoff. The pair have known each other and have worked together during their time at SC Cambuur back in 2016.\n\nHulshoff is currently Slot's assistant manager at Feyenoord and he is highly regarded. He's also working as an assistant manager for the Dutch national team, so he's already got experience training with the likes of Cody Gakpo and Virgil van Dijk as well.\n\nIf Slot becomes Liverpool manager, we should expect some changes in the playing squad as well. Not everyone will fit into Slot's philosophy.\n\nSome players may want to leave. Others may be brought in as well. However, given Slot doesn't differ too much in terms of his preferred formation and style to Klopp, there won't be major changes afoot.\n\nSlot's appointment means continuity, which is exactly what Liverpool wanted. He will ensure things will operate in relatively the same way and that will give the club's players massive assurances as well.\n\nFinally, we will put an end to the longstanding saga that has gone on for the last few months. We were lacking that at so many moments in games,\" Van Dijk said after the Everton defeat.\n\n\"If you play like we did, obviously even if we create two or three clear-cut chances again, you don't deserve to win the league.\n\n\"It's crunch time and we've not been good enough in the way we finished the chances off, in the way we defended together and also the fight. {"uri": "8094861237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "12:09:17", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T12:09:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T12:09:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.rousingthekop.com/2024/04/24/three-liverpool-players-who-will-absolutely-thrive-under-arne-slot-next-season/", "title": "Three Liverpool players who will absolutely thrive under Arne Slot next season", "body": "There are three Liverpool players who could really benefit from Arne Slot's system next season if he is appointed as the club's new manager.\n\nArne Slot seems to be the frontrunner for the Liverpool job at this stage. After all the talk of Xabi Alonso and Ruben Amorim, it seems like Liverpool have had their eyes on Slot all along.\n\nIt's an interesting and perhaps surprising choice at first glance. However, under the microscope, it's a choice that makes absolute sense for Liverpool.\n\nSlot's high intensity gegenpressing playing style is eerily reminiscent of the way Jurgen Klopp likes to play at Liverpool.\n\nIn this way, there won't be too much overwhelming change for Liverpool's players. Slot very much means continuity for the club.\n\nOf course, Slot's isn't identical to Klopp. He will make minor changes at the club. His formation and system isn't completely the same as Klopp.\n\nOne of the key variances is that Slot likes to play a double pivot in midfield, and use a more advanced midfielder as a number ten. In this sense, he very much plays a triangle midfield, which is a little bit different compared to Klopp's diamond.\n\nBut it's a system that could suit someone like Alexis Mac Allister really well. He is pretty much tailor made to play in a double pivot and could thrive with the way Slot wants his players to make quick and incisive passes.\n\nAnother player who could absolutely flourish in this new midfield shape under Slot is Dominik Szoboszlai. The Hungarian is a typical number ten and in this system he will be able to play in a more advanced role where he could bring out his qualities in the final third.\n\nGiven the fact that Szoboszlai is also a pressing machine, he will also really suit the way Slot wants his players to press really high up the pitch.\n\nFor Liverpool's young players, Slot's appointment is also a massive advantage for their development. Slot likes to play young players, and he has always played with a really young team both at AZ Alkmaar and Feyenoord.\n\nThis means youngster will get plenty of opportunities under Slot. Among them, the one who could benefit the most is Bobby Clark.\n\nHe's probably been one of the more impressive players who has broken through from the academy into the first team this season.\n\nLike Szoboszlai, Clark is pretty much tailor made for that number ten role in Slot's system, and he could be getting plenty of opportunities under Liverpool's new potential boss if Slot is appointed.", {"uri": "8094967112", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "13:12:12", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T13:12:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T13:11:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/orkun-kokcu-liverpool-news-arne-slot/", "title": "Liverpool Tipped to Sign Kokcu if Arne Slot is Appointed", "body": "Liverpool are pushing to appoint Feyenoord manager Arne Slot, and a Serbian scout has suggested that he could target Orkun Kokcu.\n\nHighlights Liverpool are targeting Feyenoord's Arne Slot to replace Klopp, and negotiations have begun for the 45-year-old to take over at Anfield. Serbian Football Scout suggests Slot may target Benfica's Orkun Kokcu, a midfielder with impressive stats in Portugal. Teun Koopmeiners could also be on Slot's radar in the summer transfer window.\n\nLiverpool are pushing to appoint Feyenoord manager Arne Slot to replace Jurgen Klopp this summer, and Serbian Football Scout on X has suggested that he wouldn't be surprised to see the Dutch manager look to target Orgun Kokcu.\n\nWith Klopp announcing earlier in the season that he would be heading through the exit door at the end of the campaign, the decision-makers at Liverpool are now searching for his replacement. It's a vital period for the Merseyside club as they look to shape their future under a new regime.\n\nAccording to Paul Joyce of The Times, the Reds have now opened negotiations with Feyenoord to attempt to thrash out a deal to bring Slot to Anfield. It appears that the 45-year-old is now a leading contender for the soon-to-be vacant position.\n\nLiverpool Could Target Orkun Kokcu He has a good relationship with Arne Slot\n\nPosting on X, Serbian Football Scout has discussed who Slot could look to sign if he moves to Liverpool in the summer. One player he suggests that he wouldn't be surprised to see follow the Dutch manager to Anfield is Benfica midfielder Kokcu...\n\nBut I wouldn't be surprised if he went for Kokcu. He's the midfielder dropping deep in the clip above. They were really close and he knows how to best use him.\n\nFormer Liverpool player Mohamed Sissoko once described Kokcu as the next Luka Modric before he made the move to Portugal. The Reds are unlikely to be able to secure him at a bargain price, with Benfica inserting a release clause of around \u00a3130m in his contract.\n\nLiverpool underwent a major midfield overhaul during the previous summer transfer window, with Dominik Szoboszlai, Wataru Endo, Ryan Gravenberch, and Alexis Mac Allister all arriving through the door. Despite the numbers they have in the middle of the park, Slot will likely want to bring in some of his own players.\n\nWhether Richard Hughes and Michael Edwards would allow Slot to identify and recruit new additions is another story, with the backroom duo likely to have a major say in recruitment this summer. Allowing a manager to have too much influence on transfers can be an issue at times, so it will be interesting to see how their summer window plays out if Slot is appointed.\n\nGIVEMESPORT Key Statistic: Orkun Kokcu has scored five goals and provided seven assists in 23 games for Benfica in the league this season.\n\nRelated Who is Arne Slot - Dutch Manager Now Favourite For Liverpool Job A closer look at Arne Slot, the Dutch manager who has emerged as the new favourite to succeed Jurgen Klopp at Liverpool. Slot Could Bring in Koopmeiners for Liverpool He once appointed him as captain\n\nJournalist Bence Bocsak has also claimed that Teun Koopmeiners could be a player that Slot considers advising the recruitment team to bring in if he arrives at Anfield. The Dutch midfielder thrived under the guidance of the Feyenoord coach while he was also made captain by Slot.\n\nKoopmeiners could be utilised in a deeper midfield role if he was to make the switch to Merseyside. {"uri": "8093388003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "15:33:49", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T15:33:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T15:33:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.football.london/tottenham-hotspur-fc/news/inside-arne-slots-tottenham-manager-29046542", "title": "Inside Slot's Spurs manager U-turn as Liverpool make Klopp replacement plan", "body": "A familiar name to Tottenham fans may well be in the Liverpool dugout come the start of the 2024/25 Premier League campaign. Following January's shock news that Jurgen Klopp will depart as Liverpool manager at the end of the current season, the Reds are on the lookout to find his long-term replacement.\n\nThe Carabao Cup winners have a monumental task on their hands trying to find the German's successor and whoever takes on the hotseat has huge shoes to fill at Anfield. Previously looking like former Liverpool midfielder Xabi Alonso would return to Merseyside going on his fine work in Germany with Bayer Leverkusen, the Spaniard recently committed his future to the Bundesliga club and that has left everyone questioning who will win the race for the Liverpool job over the coming weeks.\n\nTottenham head coach Ange Postecoglou was previously mentioned in regards to the hotseat after making a wonderful start to his Premier League career following his Celtic exit. Quizzed in press conferences about the speculation and the fact that he supported Liverpool growing up, the Australian quickly dismissed all the talk of a move north.\n\nSporting CP boss Ruben Amorim, who was previously linked with replacing Antonio Conte at Tottenham prior to Postecoglou's appointment, has been tipped to become the Reds' next manager but he is now no longer the favourite with the bookmakers to be appointed. It is Feyenoord's Arne Slot who has seen his odds slashed dramatically over the past 24 hours to become favourite having been a 50/1 outsider previously.\n\nTottenham supporters will be well aware of Slot's work in Rotterdam as he looked on course to replace Conte at the helm almost one year ago. Having transformed his Feyenoord side following a major rebuild and managed to guide them to the Europa Conference League final in his first season at the club, the 45-year-old led his players to the Eredivisie title twelve months later.\n\nDoing so by playing an attractive brand of football and developing youth team players and his signings in the transfer market, it was no surprise why Tottenham were interested in securing Slot's services in their quest to get back to their previous heights. Spurs themselves needed to undergo a major rebuild and the Dutchman appeared to be the perfect candidate going on his fine work in Rotterdam.\n\nREAD MORE: Tottenham face Son Heung-min dilemma for Arsenal North London Derby as Postecoglou makes changes\n\nREAD MORE: Ange Postecoglou's Tottenham wildcard option vs Arsenal has big Radu Dragusin benefit\n\nThere was to be a twist in the tale, though. Odds-on to swap Feyenoord for Tottenham and looking on the verge of departing De Kuip, Slot instead produced a U-turn and penned a new contract with the Dutch club to extend his Feyenoord stay. It was a decision that only plunged Spurs' managerial search into even more chaos.\n\nSince electing to remain with the Eredivisie side, Slot has once again had Feyenoord challenging at the top of the league but they are on course to lose their crown with PSV holding a nine-point advantage over them with four games remaining. Their Champions League campaign unfortunately came to an early end after finishing third in a group containing Atletico Madrid, Lazio and Celtic, with a Europa League exit then following in February after losing on penalties to Roma in the knockout round play-offs.\n\nSlot has managed to lead Feyenoord to another piece of silverware, though, after his team secured a 1-0 win over NEC Nijmegen in the KNVB Cup final on Sunday evening. That could well be his last trophy in Rotterdam if he is to make the move to the Premier League one year on from all the Tottenham speculation.\n\nWhoever replaces Klopp at Liverpool has an incredibly tough act to follow. It's no surprise to see why Slot's odds for the job have tumbled by some way over the past couple of days given what he's achieved with Feyenoord.\n\nCompleting a successful rebuild of the club and implementing an attacking-brand of football that is easy on the eye, Slot is also not afraid to put his trust in youth, something which will no doubt please Reds fans given the likes of Conor Bradley who have starred for the first team recently. Slot is also someone who has enjoyed great success in the transfer market and managed to take players - both current ones and new signings - to greater heights.\n\nWhile it may be Klopp in the Anfield dugout for one last time when Tottenham visit Anfield at the start of May, it could be a familiar name in Slot in charge of the Reds when Spurs make the trip to Merseyside next campaign. Time will tell if that is to be the case.\n\nWant breaking and top Tottenham stories sent straight to you? Join our Spurs WhatsApp community by clicking this link. {"uri": "8095146503", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "15:02:10", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T15:02:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T15:01:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/a-ton-problems-erik-ten-29051430", "title": "'A ton of problems' - ten Hag and Slot truth clear as Reds follow Man Utd path", "body": "Liverpool could follow Manchester United's approach if they decide to appoint Feyenoord boss Arne Slot to replace Jurgen Klopp at Anfield\n\nLiverpool are looking to follow a similar approach to Manchester United after opening negotiations with Feyenoord boss Arne Slot about the possibility of replacing Jurgen Klopp.\n\nThe Reds will say farewell to the German boss at the end of the season and have taken a huge step in finding Klopp's successor. Xabi Alonso, who was installed as the frontrunner, ruled himself out of the job by deciding that he would stay another season at Bayer Leverkusen.\n\nThe likes of Ruben Amorim and Roberto De Zerbi have also been mooted as potential candidates, but The Athletic claim that Slot is the club's preferred option. They add that the Dutchman is 'enthusiastic about a potential move' though there are still other targets on Liverpool's list.\n\nREAD MORE: Sir Dave Brailsford's stark message to Man United players behind closed doors that Ten Hag must fear\n\nREAD MORE: How United should line-up vs Sheffield United at Old Trafford\n\nIf the Reds do choose to appoint Slot, comparisons will naturally be drawn following United's decision to poach Erik ten Hag from the Eredivisie in 2022. The Red Devils boss joined from Ajax.\n\nHowever, European football expert Andy Brassell has shut down any comparisons. He told Sky Sports: \"I think if you look at Erik ten Hag, his last six months at Ajax, something never really talked about, is Ajax had a ton of defensive problems.\n\n\"Even when ten Hag was doing pretty well with Manchester United last year, in some of the defeats they really bottomed out, particularly defensively, so it suggests those issues are something he hasn't really worked on.\n\n\"Whereas Feyenoord, have pretty much the best defensive record in the Eredivisie and they have done over the last two seasons. In terms of those issues, he's not really bringing anything with him.\"\n\nSlot previously snubbed a move to Tottenham Hotspur and signed a three-year contract extension. It's a big win but it's not more than a win.\"\n\nSlot goes on: \"We have a bigger goal this season and only winning for the first time in 17 years in Amsterdam. Our goal is bigger than that. So take care of your body, make sure come fit as you soon can back to the club so we can go for the last two months and make this season even more special than you already have.\n\n\"We're not gonna be small. It's only a win in Amsterdam. That what we did here. I would say before but that's not completely true. A trainer who comes has to replace that, and that doesn't seem easy to me.\"\n\nHe later clarified that those set to leave had been brought in by Klopp. He tweeted: \"Any manager having the desire to take the #LFC job has to know that it has to bring more than just a coaching staff to the club.\n\n\"More than 30 people behind the scenes who Klopp brought in, who were a MAJOR part of #LFC success over the years, are leaving too. {"uri": "8096599042", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "11:08:09", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T11:08:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T11:07:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.rousingthekop.com/2024/04/25/50-year-old-premier-league-manager-has-already-been-interviewed-by-liverpool-in-case-arne-slot-doesnt-join/", "title": "50-year-old Premier League manager has already been interviewed by Liverpool in case Arne Slot doesn't join", "body": "Liverpool are continuing in their attempts to lure Feyenoord manager Arne Slot to the club.\n\nSlot has been installed as the front-runner to replace Jurgen Klopp. After three months of searching, the wait looks to be almost over.\n\nOn Wednesday, reports claimed that Liverpool had made an opening offer to Feyenoord for the 45-year-old. That bid was rejected.\n\nWith another reportedly set to come on Thursday, FSG are seemingly pushing hard to wrap a deal up before the end of the season.\n\nAnd although it looks likely that they'll be able to do that, nothing is certain just yet. With other top clubs also claimed to be circling Slot, nobody at Liverpool should be counting their chickens. And, as it turns out, the Reds do indeed appear to have a back-up plan.\n\nPrior to Slot being named as the new favourite to take over at Anfield, Ruben Amorim had looked like the outstanding candidate.\n\nThe 39-year-old is even said to have tried to 'put pressure' on Liverpool to hire him by engaging in talks with West Ham earlier this week.\n\nBut, unmoved, it seems as though the Reds might have actually discounted Amorim from consideration altogether.\n\nThe same though cannot be said for Brentford boss Thomas Frank. According to Tipsbladet - an outlet from Frank's native Denmark - the 50-year-old has been under consideration by Liverpool 'for a long time.'\n\nThere is even said to have been an interview take place between Frank's representatives and the Reds' decision makers.\n\nUltimately though, it's noted that Liverpool have opted to move forward with Slot instead. Given the paper's insistence that Frank was a 'serious candidate' to replace Klopp though, it might be wise to now install him as an official back-up.\n\nFrank's name has been in the mix more or less ever since Klopp announced his decision to leave three months ago.\n\nThe Dane has done a superb job at Brentford and looks set to keep them in the Premier League for a third season running.\n\nA positive and charismatic figure, you can understand why Frank would appeal to Liverpool. But it's also true that he has won nothing at all as a manager.\n\nAlthough his knowledge of English football could be a bonus, his lack of a trophy-winning track record will count against the former Brondby boss.\n\nFor now, it's rightly all eyes on Slot. {"uri": "8094633564", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "09:55:50", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T09:55:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T09:55:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/arne-slots-last-10-signings-29050427", "title": "Arne Slot last 10 signings and what they could mean for Liverpool transfer plan", "body": "As Liverpool gear up to transition from Jurgen Klopp, the summer transfer window will be crucial, and it could be Arne Slot making the significant decisions.\n\nFeyenoord's manager, Slot, has emerged as the frontrunner to take over when Klopp concludes his nine-year stint in the summer. The Dutchman, who previously declined Spurs before the London club appointed Ange Postecoglou, is on track to follow last season's title win with a second-place finish behind PSV Eindhoven this term.\n\nThe returning Michael Edwards is expected to play a significant role in any summer transfer business, but Klopp had input during Edwards' previous tenure. Slot has managed substantial player turnover over the past 12 months, similar to Klopp's midfield overhaul at Anfield, and he understands how to integrate starters into a team.\n\nSince the summer of 2023, Feyenoord has signed more than 10 players - either permanently or on loan. Here, we examine the last 10 to give Liverpool fans an idea of what they might expect if the 45 year old takes over.\n\nREAD MORE: What goal difference means for Liverpool in title race after Arsenal earn 'extra point' advantage\n\nREAD MORE: I shouldn't have played in infamous Merseyside derby - It was my second Liverpool appearance and we finished with nine men\n\nAnis Hadj Moussa.\n\nSlot's most recent signing is a player who hasn't actually joined Feyenoord yet. Algerian forward Hadj Moussa will arrive in the summer, just a few months after making his Eredivisie debut on loan at Vitesse.\n\nThe 22 year old has two goals and two assists in all competitions in the Netherlands, having begun the season in the Belgian second tier. His arrival suggests a willingness to back a player of limited top level experience as long as the promise is there.\n\nMikki van Sas.\n\nAnother youngster, Van Sas joined from Manchester City's academy in September. The 20 year old goalkeeper has yet to make his senior Feyenoord debut, but has been on the bench in the Champions League and Europa League this term.\n\nThe Dutch Under-19 international revealed upon his unveiling that he had been scouted by the Rotterdam club as a teen. Previous rejections appear to be no barrier to deals further down the line.\n\nLuka Ivanusec.\n\nThe first name on the list to have represented Feyenoord at the time of writing, Ivanusec joined from Dinamo Zagreb in his homeland of Croatia. The winger played three times for his country at Euro 2020, showing Slot is prepared to add more experienced figures when the price is right.\n\nArriving for just \u00a36.7m (according to Transfermarkt), Ivanusec has struggled with injury this season but has still managed 20 league outings. He scored a hat-trick for Dinamo in Champions League qualifying, but has only netted once in the Eredivisie.\n\nOndrej Lingr.\n\nLingr, 25, joined on a season-long loan from Slavia Prague in August. Another full international, the attacking midfielder arrived with a record of contributing goals from a withdrawn role, with successive double-figure seasons in the Czech Republic.\n\nHe has been used out wide as well as in the number 10 role, but Slot has so far been sparing with him. All 21 of Lingr's outings have come from the bench, with the manager prepared to let the new man work for his first start.\n\nBart Nieuwkoop.\n\nDutch defender Nieuwkoop arrived from Union SG, where he spent last season linking up with Brighton winger Simon Adingra. The 28 year old started out at Feyenoord, failing to hold down a first-team place, but Slot has been prepared to give him a second chance.\n\nWhile the first half of his season was interrupted by injury, Nieuwkoop has featured more since the turn of the year. He made four appearances in the run to KNVB Cup glory, starting the victory over NEC in the final.\n\nKostas Lamprou.\n\nLamprou is another player who demonstrates Slot's willingness to offer second chances. The Greek goalkeeper returned to De Kuip nine years after departing, having done the rounds in the top two tiers of Dutch football.\n\nLiverpool boss Klopp hasn't been afraid to add experienced backup keepers on a free, with Adrian and Alex Manninger among those brought to Anfield during his tenure. With the former out of contract this summer, might there be room for another similar deal?\n\nAyase Ueda.\n\nUeda, the priciest signing on the list, was still a relatively reasonable acquisition at \u00a36.9m. The Japanese international was part of his nation's 2022 World Cup squad but wasn't one of the standout names - instead, he was a rising star when he made the move to Rotterdam.\n\nLike several others, the forward has primarily been used as a substitute despite netting 22 goals in Belgium the previous season, scoring twice in less than 500 Eredivisie minutes. However, he had a breakout Asian Cup, finishing the tournament as his country's top scorer with four goals in as many starts.\n\nCalvin Stengs.\n\nWhen Dutch international Stengs left Slot's AZ for Nice in 2021, he was highly sought after. His time in Ligue 1 didn't quite go as planned, but Slot wasn't going to pass up the opportunity to reunite with the 25 year old.\n\nThis season, Stengs has reached double figures for assists, with only PSV duo Luuk de Jong and Joey Veerman outdoing him. He also has five league goals - plus one in the Champions League victory over Celtic - suggesting the reunion has been successful so far.\n\nThomas Beelen.\n\nYoung defender Beelen cost Feyenoord just \u00a32.3m, emerging from the same PEC Zwolle production line that produced current Liverpool defender Sepp van den Berg. A tall centre-back, just as Klopp prefers them, the 22 year old has played in more than half of Feyenoord's matches this season.\n\nLiverpool will have to make some tough calls at centre-back, particularly regarding whether to offer Joel Matip a new contract and how to handle Virgil van Dijk as he enters the last year of his current deal. Klopp has shown no fear in placing trust in young players, and Slot is no exception.\n\nYankuba Minteh.\n\nOn the topic of youth, 19 year old Minteh has received support despite his young age. Liverpool may not need to dip into the pool of top teams' young talent, but Gambia international Minteh has had a successful season on loan from Newcastle.\n\nWith nine league goals to his name, the winger is second only to Premier League-linked Santiago Gimenez in the club's scoring charts. Liverpool has reaped significant benefits from goals scored from wide positions, which could be music to the ears of fans.", "source": {"uri": "liverpoolecho.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-04-333412880", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "05:51:34", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T05:51:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T00:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.liverpool.com/liverpool-fc-news/features/liverpool-next-manager-arne-slot-29048207", "title": "Six Liverpool players who could benefit most if Arne Slot replaces J\u00fcrgen Klopp", "body": "Arne Slot is not a name that most Liverpool fans will know a huge amount about. But the 45-year-old is a leading contender to take over from J\u00fcrgen Klopp at Anfield.\n\nWith an attack-minded, high-intensity playing style and a track record of getting the most out of his resources, Slot has impressed the Liverpool hierarchy. And his record in the Eredivisie, where he won the title last season, is also exceptional.\n\nBut what might Liverpool look like if Slot does take over? The Reds squad looks well-suited to the system that he uses at the moment, where the principles are broadly similar to what Klopp and his staff have instilled.\n\nREAD MORE: Arne Slot already had say on J\u00fcrgen Klopp and Liverpool and hinted at next move\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool may be set to pile pressure on Pep Guardiola as Man City disadvantage clear\n\nFeyenoord mainly uses a 4-2-3-1 system, which is subtly different from how Liverpool sets up. Klopp uses one number six (Wataru End\u014d or Alexis Mac Allister) where Slot usually goes with a double pivot, though the Dutchman could adapt.\n\nWho could benefit most if he does go with a double pivot? Mac Allister played in that role for Brighton (and has for Argentina) and it could suit Ryan Gravenberch too. He was used to playing in that way for Ajax and Bayern Munich.\n\nEnd\u014d might benefit from having someone alongside him as well when the Japanese plays there. His energy levels have been good this season but the older he gets, the more help he might end up needing.\n\nHarvey Elliott and Curtis Jones might suit playing wide (or as a number 10) in a 4-2-3-1 system, and Dominik Szoboszlai could do that comfortably as well. But there would be a question mark with those three when you factor in the attacking options that Slot would have to work with. Mohamed Salah and Luis D\u00edaz would have to play wide.\n\nUltimately, one of the appealing factors with Slot would be that his system would not be massively different from how Liverpool plays now. Considering the number of midfield options that the Reds have, he could reconfigure that part of the pitch within his attacking masterplan to fit more of them in.\n\nOr Slot could have four out of five senior forwards on the pitch in an ultra-attacking version of the formation that he currently favors. Both options would be on the table without changing much from what he does in the Netherlands at the moment.\n\nThere would still be questions about how certain positions change from the Klopp era. Most notably, what would Slot want Trent Alexander-Arnold to do? He could easily play as part of a midfield pivot, but he basically does that anyway at the moment from full-back, giving Liverpool an additional option in possession.\n\nBut broadly speaking, the attacking concepts and the full-throttle counter-press would continue. It would be the specifics of each role that needed to be worked out rather than a complete redesign of the set-up -- and much less disruptive, for example, than moving to a back three, for instance.", "source": {"uri": "liverpool.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Liverpool"}, "authors": [{"uri": "matt_addison@liverpool.com", "name": "Matt Addison", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], {"uri": "8097147734", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:02:37", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:02:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:02:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.thisisanfield.com/2024/04/arne-slot-the-dutch-football-view-on-likely-new-liverpool-manager/", "title": "Arne Slot: Dutch football view on likely new Liverpool manager", "body": "With the news that Liverpool are on the verge of appointing Arne Slot as the club's new manager, we spoke with Dutch football expert Arthur Renard to get the lowdown on the incoming boss.\n\nYeah, there is definitely a similarity, I think especially in the the high pressing, there's definitely a similarity with the current Liverpool [but] Jurgen may be is a little bit different. You could maybe say that that Jurgen is a bit more direct.\n\nArne Slot likes to build and play a little bit more football through the whole pitch, whereas maybe Klopp you could argue, he's maybe more direct.\n\nWhat I like about Slot is that he likes to play his game and the pressing game wherever he plays and against anyone. So it doesn't matter if he plays, let's say Real Madrid away or whatever game, he plays his style. And that is something I think Liverpool fans will like a lot.\n\nHe's a big fan of Guardiola, so I would say his style even more towards Guardiola [than Klopp], although I guess with Guardiola and Klopp they'd both like their teams to have the ball to attack.\n\nHe's a huge admirer of of Guardiola. He [Slot] said: \"Pep Guardiola gives me the ultimate joy in football.\n\n\"There is no team in the world I would rather watch than Manchester City, followed by Napoli, Arsenal and Brighton.\n\n\"But City - and again it is not my intention to compare us with them - have a similar style of play to how we want to play with Feyenoord: 4-3-3, building up from the back, wanting to apply pressure quickly.\"\n\nThe striker, Santiago Gimenez, he came also for not that much money (\u20ac6m) and he has proved, especially in the title-winning season last year, he proved such an important player.\n\nSlot's managed to get some really good players on the cheap - and that must be music to the ears of the Liverpool owners.\n\nThere's been quite a few players in the last few years and they've developed pretty well. He also has some young talents. There is one, Quilindschy Hartman, who actually made his debut for the Dutch national team as well (recently). If he is fit, I wouldn't be surprised if he will play at the Euros. He's a bit like Trent, a local guy, a wingback kind of player.\n\nHe [Slot] definitely has an eye for young talent and also has the kind of guts to give them a chance in the team. That's something Liverpool and definitely its owners will like.\n\nHe seems to get on really well with his players. You don't really hear players being unhappy. He seems to have a very straightforward and relaxed approach.\n\nThere's a clip of of of him at a team talk away at Ajax after the game, he's he's not really too emotional but but just kind of like (how) he is.\n\nYou can see he connects with his players but he still keeps some kind of like calm kind approach.\n\nI think it's a good point - and in the end of the day you never know whether somebody will be a success or not.\n\nPersonally I think to succeed Jurgen Klopp is just very tough regardless who you are. Even Xabi Alonso, who seems to be at the moment the, the top of the top, probably would find it difficult.\n\nIn terms of comparisons with Ten Hag it's difficult to compare. But the budgets [available at Ajax vs. Feyenoord] I think the last two years Feyenoord of has spent around maybe 30 million on players where Ajax had an outlay of around 200 million and [Feyenoord] finished both seasons above Ajax.\n\nAn interesting quote is from Marco van Basten, who was talking in a Dutch TV talk show, and he said he is just sure he [Slot] can do it at Liverpool.\n\nHe said 'he can go to Bayern Munich, Liverpool, you name it, you know, and he will do well'. And he says 'players at Liverpool are even better.' So it's easier for them to kind of translate his message on the pitch.\n\nI think he can manage that, if Van Basten says that, that obviously tells you something.\n\nThat definitely tells you something [and] probably it's also a thing of you don't get the Liverpool job offered every day! So that's also a factor.\n\nI think that's a good thing about him, he's not thinking too much in in dilemmas, in, in difficulties, in obstacles.\n\nIt is obviously a massive challenge to succeed someone like Klopp but he's really positive; a really positive kind of person. He doesn't really think in obstacles, but more in kind of like chances. And it's a huge chance for him to to do well.\n\nI think that they should be definitely optimistic.\n\nI like to look at what he's done so far. Because even before Feyenoord, he was the manager of AZ Alkmaar and he was doing really well; they were actually first or second in the league when the season got suspended because of corona - and in Holland, for him, unfortunately, the season was cancelled.\n\nMaybe he could have won the league that year [2020].\n\nIf you can do it at different clubs; Liverpool fans should be really kind of, enthusiastic, because why would he not do that at Liverpool?\n\nI think there's a lot of reasons to be optimistic.\n\nA massive thanks to Arthur for his insight. {"uri": "2024-04-332962320", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "18:04:02", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T18:04:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T17:59:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/sport/football/liverpool-arne-slot-interested-feyenoord-fight-3020691", "title": "Arne Slot interested in Liverpool job - but Feyenoord will fight to keep him", "body": "Feyenoord cancelled a press conference scheduled for Wednesday as news of Liverpool's interest emerged - although sources played down talk that a move for the 45-year-old was at an \"advanced stage\".\n\nBut Slot is now one of the front-runners to succeed Klopp after Liverpool's due diligence identified him as a candidate whose playing style, values and ability to improve players on the training pitch align closely with the club's values.\n\nunderstands Slot would be interested in the Liverpool job, although Sporting Lisbon's Ruben Amorim, Brentford's Thomas Frank and Brighton's Roberto De Zerbi have also been discussed.\n\nWhile Liverpool aren't close to making an appointment - indeed it is understood that formal interviews are yet to take place - there is a sense that things are moving at Anfield. Bayer Leverkusen's Xabi Alonso ruled himself out last month while West Ham's links to Amorim came as Liverpool's interest in him cooled.\n\npreviously reported that the Reds were prepared to make an \"out-of-the-box\" appointment ahead of Michael Edwards' reunion with Liverpool owners Fenway Sports Group as CEO of football. Their detailed recruitment process has seen director of research Will Spearman heavily involved - and Slot's inclusion on the shortlist should not come as a surprise.\n\nIndeed his name figured prominently on a list prepared for by data specialists Analytics FC back in February. Their head of content Alex Stewart told Slot is a \"good stylistic fit\" and his teams play with the same aggression as Klopp's side, favouring longer passes and quick breaks.\n\nSlot's CV is impressive; he won the Dutch Cup last weekend with Feyenoord and won the Eredivisie in 2022-23. He is charismatic and adored by the club's supporters, while he was also a contender for the Leeds United and Tottenham Hotspur vacancies last season, although opted against pursuing either.\n\nHis stance would likely change if Liverpool formalise their interest, with the prospect of replacing Klopp understood to appeal. Feyenoord will likely fight to keep him, though.\n\nThe Reds appear to be trying to steal a march on their rivals in what promises to be a busy managerial market in the summer.\n\nAs well as Liverpool, Bayern Munich and Barcelona are trying to fill managerial vacancies, while Manchester United could join that crop of clubs if Ineos decide to dispense with Erik ten Hag.\n\nThe number of potential candidates seems to be dwindling, with Julian Nagelsmann having committed himself to Germany until 2026.\n\nDe Zerbi, who is admired by incoming Liverpool director of football Richard Hughes, also has admirers at Bayern Munich and there was an element of politicking when news of West Ham's interest in Amorim emerged earlier this week. {"uri": "8096341225", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "08:35:10", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T08:35:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T08:35:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.rousingthekop.com/2024/04/25/three-things-arne-slot-definitely-needs-to-change-at-liverpool-after-watching-everton-defeat/", "title": "Three things Arne Slot definitely needs to change at Liverpool after watching Everton defeat", "body": "Arne Slot will need to make changes at Liverpool if he is appointed as the club's next manager.\n\nWednesday night pretty much all but ended Liverpool's hopes of winning the Premier League title this season.\n\nA defeat at Goodison Park for the first time in over a decade is not how Liverpool will have wanted to bow out of the title race.\n\nIt's a horrible and bitter ending to a season that offered so much promise, even just a few weeks ago. Unfortunately, though April has seen the Reds completely collapse.\n\nIt's been proof that Liverpool need changes around Anfield, and Arne Slot could be the man to instil new ideas.\n\nJurgen Klopp seems to have run out of ideas in his final few years at Liverpool. Last season was proof of that and the last few weeks are just a confirmation.\n\nKlopp has been brilliant for so many years, but we cannot deny Liverpool have ran out of gas towards the end of his time at the club.\n\nWhat the Reds need now is a manager with fresh ideas and a new approach. Slot needs to think a little bit differently to Klopp and come up with new ideas that do not leave the Reds open and vulnerable.\n\nThis was very much evident in the defeat to Everton. Liverpool looked completely lost on the pitch.\n\nOne of the key elements that Slot needs to change at Liverpool, which became blatantly obvious last night is the Reds' attack.\n\nSlot needs to find a way for Liverpool's attack to be more clinical in front of goal. He needs to set-up a system where Liverpool's attackers are much better at converting chances.\n\nHe also needs to instil a little bit of confidence in some of the club's attackers, who seem devoid of it at the moment.\n\nThis will be his most difficult task, but it's one that he has to get right in order to make Liverpool competitive again.\n\nAfter Everton, it's becoming obvious that Liverpool also need a major reshuffling in the playing squad again.\n\nThere are some players who are nearing the end of their shelf life at the club. Slot's name has emerged out of nowhere for Liverpool. However, he has been highly regarded back in the Netherlands for quite some time as an innovator.\n\nAnd has achieved a lot of success helping Feyenoord to an unprecedented league title last season, and also taking them to the Europa Conference League final.\n\nBecause he is a relatively unknown figure, when Slot's name initially emerged as a potential candidate to succeed Jurgen Klopp, there was a lot of negative fan reaction on social media.\n\nThat's because most fans were not really aware of who he was and what he was like. Slot has always been a respected player and manager in the Netherlands.\n\nLike Klopp, he has had a pretty unordinary playing career, but he always seemed destined to be a manager. Former teammates have described how he was always questioning things even as a player - very similar to Klopp at Mainz.\n\nIn addition to that, he does play with an exciting level of intensity. {"uri": "8097065243", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "16:02:55", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T16:02:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T16:02:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/04/25/liverpool-coach-speaks-pursuit-feyenoord-boss-arne-slot-20719445/", "title": "Liverpool coach speaks out on club's pursuit of Feyenoord boss Arne Slot", "body": "Liverpool academy coach Jay Spearing is confident Arne Slot would be a great fit for the club, though believes the job of replacing Jurgen Klopp is going to be a 'difficult role' for any incoming manager.\n\nSlot, 45, has emerged as the clear frontrunner to take over the reins from Klopp in the summer, with Feyenoord believed to be holding out for a compensation fee of \u20ac15million (\u00a312.8m) for their head coach.\n\nXabi Alonso had initially been identified as Liverpool's first-choice candidate to take charge on Merseyside but the Spaniard effectively ruled himself out of the running last month as he committed his immediate future to Bayer Leverkusen.\n\nAnd while Sporting boss Ruben Amorim has been linked in recent weeks, it appears the Reds are going all out for Slot and the Dutchman is said to be eager to push through a move to Anfield 'at all costs'.\n\nVirgil van Dijk, speaking after the side's painful 2-0 defeat at Everton, said he felt Slot had the right 'philosophy' and playing style to succeed should the club wrap up a deal for his fellow countryman.\n\nAnd it appears former Liverpool midfielder Spearing, now a coach with the Under-21 team, agrees with Van Dijk's verdict of the Feyenoord manager.\n\n'From what I've looked at and from what I've heard, Arne Slot is very offensive with his football. He's on the front foot, aggressive, attacking, but he also looks at himself as a well drilled coach that wants to defend and keep clean sheets,' Spearing told Stadium Astro.\n\n'He's a manager that would maybe suit the Liverpool style, on the front foot, wanting to score goals, wanting to play attractive football, has a certain way of playing the game, but also wants to be a real nut to crack as well.\n\n'He wants to keep clean sheets, he wants to win things, he's had a very successful season with Feyenoord.\n\n'Whoever comes in to follow Jurgen Klopp is going to have a difficult role, but whoever comes in has to go and take the role on, do it his way and hopefully there are successful times ahead for the club.'\n\nSpearing feels it is important that Liverpool are able to keep hold of their 'key players' as they enter a period of transition in the post-Klopp era.\n\n'I think it's a good sign that Liverpool have reappointed Michael Edwards and obviously Richard Hughes as the sporting director,' he added.\n\n'They're two big appointments and you can see that the club want to sort out the backroom before they go and come forward.\n\n'Liverpool have known about Jurgen's decision for such a long time and I don't think they will be looking now to find a manager. I think things will have been done weeks and months ago. It's a long process.\n\n'They knew Jurgen was on his way and when Jurgen leaves it will be an incredible loss but, for the future of the club, there are going to be big decisions on players.\n\n'Is the manager going to come in and is he going to be happy with the dressing room? Players talk about it, \"Should we have him? Should we have him?\", but Arne Slot is a proven manager.\n\n'He's shown that he can handle a big club, Feyenoord is a big club in Holland, and fingers crossed whoever comes in can keep key players because Liverpool don't want to be in that transition mode where we start losing key players as well as Jurgen Klopp.'\n\nAsked whether he has a preference for the manager position, Spearing replied: 'Do you know what? For me, those big decisions aren't my decision.\n\n'I'm with the U21s, working with the young lads, and obviously my decisions are mainly ran by the academy director Alex Inglethorpe, but whoever comes in, it will be an absolute privilege to work under.\n\n'It's been an incredible 18 months to two years for me to work under Jurgen Klopp and Pepijn Lijnders. The access that we've had to them has been incredible. I've loved every single minute of it.\n\n'But whoever comes in, it will be a new challenge, a fresh challenge, but also a new learning time for me. As well as it being disappointing to see Jurgen leave, it's a really exciting time for the club, a new start and new way of going forward hopefully.'\n\nMORE : Gary Neville says Liverpool players will Liverpool opened negotiations with the Dutch club on Wednesday as they ramp up their efforts to appoint a successor.\n\nWesterveld, who won the treble with the Reds in 2001, was team-mates with Slot at Sparta Rotterdam. The pair made 21 appearances alongside each other during the 2007/08 season, while they remain close friends and regularly golf together to this day.\n\nREAD MORE: Jurgen Klopp will hate Liverpool outcome but he's failed to fix his biggest problem this season\n\nREAD MORE: Darwin Nunez and Virgil van Dijk fume as Liverpool supporters respond to Everton taunt\n\nThe former goalkeeper has spoken to Slot since Liverpool's interest in the Feyenoord boss went public. And while the 45-year-old gave little away regarding his future intentions, Westerveld, who always knew his compatriot would make a good manager, thinks he would be perfect for the Reds.\n\n\"When I played with Arne at Sparta, you could see that he would become a coach,\" Westerveld told The Times. \"He was a leader, a No10 midfielder and someone who would change tactics by himself.\n\n\"I spoke to him this morning and he just said it is not a secret that Liverpool wants him but that he could not say anything. I hope it will happen.\n\n\"The job he has done at Feyenoord makes him the perfect fit for Liverpool... When he signed for Feyenoord they sold the best player, Steven Berghuis, to Ajax and they didn't have lots of money to spend.\n\n\"Everyone said it would be difficult, but Arne said: \"No, no, I will make this happen.\" A year later he became the champion of Holland with this team and that is why I think there are similarities with Liverpool.\n\n\"Liverpool have a lot of potential in the squad, and we don't have the money that Manchester City have to spend, so I think he will get all the potential out of the players.\n\n\"He plays in the same style as Jurgen Klopp: sexy football, forward pressing and the percentage of ball recoveries in the opposition half is the highest in Holland. When he loses the ball, he wants the ball back in three seconds.\n\n\"His personality is perfect for Liverpool. He is a good fit because he is not only the manager of a team, he can manage a club and the fans.\n\n\"He is an intelligent guy, he is a good analyst and when you see his press conferences, he speaks good English and is very respectful.\n\n\"You will not see Arne being like Erik ten Hag was in his recent press conference. He is a respectful guy like Pep Guardiola and he is an ambassador for the club.\n\n\"You need to be a special coach to coach a special club and I think Arne is that.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8095078738", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "14:18:53", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T14:18:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T14:18:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/liverpool-peter-bosz-manager-news/", "title": "Peter Bosz Speaks Out About Liverpool Job", "body": "Liverpool are in the market for a new manager this summer, and PSV Eindhoven manager Peter Bosz has been asked why he's not being linked.\n\nHighlights Feyenoord's Arne Slot has emerged as a prime contender for the Liverpool manager job. PSV's Peter Bosz remains unlinked to the Liverpool role despite leading Eredivisie. Bosz has now spoken to the media about Slot's links to Liverpool.\n\nLiverpool are working behind the scenes to appoint a new manager at Anfield, and PSV Eindhoven coach Peter Bosz has now been asked why he's not being linked with the job, despite Feyenoord's Arne Slot being a strong contender.\n\nIt's understood that Feyenoord manager Slot is now a leading contender for the soon-to-be vacant role at Anfield, with Liverpool entering negotiations with the Dutch club. The 45-year-old has done an impressive job during his tenure, but they currently find themselves nine points behind PSV who occupy first place in the Eredivisie.\n\nPSV, managed by Bosz, look set to lift the Dutch title this season, and it might come as a surprise that the 60-year-old coach hasn't been linked with a move to Liverpool.\n\nPeter Bosz Asked About Liverpool Job He laughed off the question\n\nBosz was asked about the prospect of Liverpool appointing Slot in his press conference on Wednesday, and a journalist from ESPN questioned why he hadn't been linked with the job, despite being nine points above Feyenoord...\n\n\"It would be fantastic for Arne. Liverpool is of course a big club, if it all works out and it would, then that would be great for him. He is more than welcome.\"\n\nHe was then asked whether he expected the Merseyside club to make an approach for him considering PSV's league position this season...\n\n\"That didn't happen, did it? I'm having a great time here, so just let me sit here.\"\n\nBosz has managed some of the biggest clubs around Europe during his career, taking charge of Lyon, Bayer Leverkusen, Borussia Dortmund, and Ajax. He's yet to ply his trade in the Premier League, but it would be interesting to see whether he'd been on a move to England.\n\nJournalist Ben Jacobs has reported that Liverpool are stepping up their pursuit for Slot and things are now moving fast. The Reds appear set on convincing the Feyenoord boss to make the move to Anfield, but they will have to negotiate a fair price with the Dutch outfit. It's understood that it could cost around \u00a38.6m to prise Slot away from the Eredivisie side.\n\nGIVEMESPORT Key Statistic: Peter Bosz has averaged 2.70 points per game in the Eredivisie this season with PSV Eindhoven.\n\nRelated Liverpool's First Offer for Arne Slot 'Will be Rejected' Liverpool's first offer to bring Feyenoord boss Arne Slot to the club is set to be turned down. {"uri": "8095196702", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "15:33:46", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T15:33:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T15:33:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2024/04/24/anfield-hero-shares-interesting-stat-which-shows-why-liverpool-like-arne-slot/", "title": "Anfield hero shares 'interesting' stat which shows why Liverpool like Arne Slot", "body": "For Danny Murphy, two stats stood out when pouring through the record of Arne Slot, the man who looks increasingly likely to end up taking over from Jurgen Klopp in the Liverpool dugout.\n\nOne good and one, well, not bad by any means but maybe a little more subject to debate.\n\nAnyone tasked with stepping into the shoes of Liverpool's most iconic head coach of the modern era would, obviously, need to share the same underlying principles that Klopp brought to Anfield back in 2015. The attacking, front-foot football his Liverpool side have become famous for, of course, but also the fervent ferocity with and without the ball.\n\nAnd there is one metric, provided via The Telegraph, which has one-time Reds playmaker Murphy feeling that Arne Slot might just be the right man to continue Klopp's legacy.\n\n\"(The Liverpool bosses) get a lot right, so you have to put a lot of trust in them,\" Murphy begins, speaking to talkSPORT (24 April, 11am).\n\n\"(Slot) supposed to be quite a bubbly, funny guy. He's not a subdued-type of guy, which is more similar to Klopp than some of the other guys.\"\n\nFeyenoord, Eredivisie champions in 2023 under Slot and for only the second time in the 21st century, have made the most 'high turnovers' in Europe this season. Liverpool are in second, managing 705 compared to Feyenoord's 722.\n\n\"I have been looking at how his team plays,\" Murphy adds. \"It's front-foot stuff. Good, attacking football. He won the league within two years at Feyenoord.\n\n\"The most interesting bit was the turnovers. the highest in all seven leagues over the last season. Liverpool were second! So maybe they're looking at some similarities around energy, attacking football.\n\n\"The other thing is they've got a great stat about coming back from losing positions. I don't know if that's a good thing! But it shows resilience.\"\n\nFeyenoord, it goes without saying, come up against far weaker opposition in the Netherlands than Liverpool do in England.\n\nLike with Eredivisie players, Eredivisie managers have a rather mixed record in English football. Frank de Boer was sacked, as you'll recall, after just four goalless and winless games at Crystal Palace. Erik ten Hag's impressive first season at Manchester United, meanwhile, has given way to a dismal second.\n\nSlot, however, ticks more boxes than most.\n\nHe's a proven league winner, boasts a formidable record when turning good players into great ones, loves to develop hungry, young talent, and instills a high-pressing, high-octane style that will feel very familiar to Liverpool supporters who have spent the best part of a decade rocking out to Klopp's self-professed 'heavy-metal football'\n\nHITC, meanwhile, understands that although Slot's name has emerged relatively recently, he has been on Liverpool's radar from the very beginning of the process. With Slot already said to be looking for houses on Merseyside, his appointment now feels like a matter of time.\n\nConsequently, plenty of opinions have already been shared about the Dutchman, with Jamie Carragher one of the latest to weigh in. But as a former teammate of Slot it's Carragher's old Liverpool colleague, Sander Westerveld, who's opinion may hold more weight.\n\nWesterveld shared a dressing room with Slot for a season at Sparta Rotterdam back in 2007/08.\n\nAnd as he spoke to Sky Sports about the Feyenoord boss yesterday, it was clear that the two have remained friends ever since.\n\nBut as well as giving some insight into what Liverpool can expect from Slot himself, Westerveld also claimed that the manager's assistant - Sipke Hulshoff - could be a huge help at Liverpool.\n\n\"A big factor I think which also helps is that his first assistant is the first assistant of the national team as well under Ronald Koeman,\" said the 49-year-old.\n\n\"So, he already worked with Van Dijk and Gravenberch and Gakpo. That will help.\"\n\nObviously, with nothing official at this point, anything written about Slot and Liverpool is still just speculation.\n\nHowever, it has already been reported that the former AZ Alkmaar manager will indeed be bringing Hulshoff with him to Merseyside.\n\nAs Westerveld mentions, this could be a real help to Slot. The 49-year-old has already worked with three Liverpool players for over a year.\n\nIt's no small matter that one of those just so happens to be the club captain, too. Although there are some question marks over Van Dijk's post-Klopp future, the expectation will be that he's at Liverpool next season.\n\nHis staff being familiar with such an influential player - as well as two more he can build the team around - will no doubt be useful to Slot.
