Xabi Alonso first emerged as the favourite to fill the prospective manager vacancy at Anfield before committing his future to Bayer Leverkusen, forcing the Reds to expand their hunt for a head coach.\n\nThe likes of Ruben Amorim and Roberto De Zerbi have been mooted as potential candidates to take the reins at Liverpool, but a new frontrunner has emerged - none other than Arne Slot. According to The Athletic, the Reds have made the Dutchman their preferred choice to succeed Klopp.\n\nThe report states that Liverpool have already opened talks with Feyenoord. The Athletic add that Slot is 'enthusiastic about a potential move' and there are still other targets on the club's list.\n\nAfter leading the Rotterdam-based outfit to their first Eredivisie title in six years last season, the 45-year-old was heavily linked with a move to Tottenham Hotspur before opting to sign a three-year contract extension at De Kuip. So, the Lilywhites appointed Ange Postecoglou instead.\n\nSpeaking to the official club website, Slot explained why he snubbed Spurs. He said: \"I'm not done here yet. We have had a wonderful season with Feyenoord, with the championship as a wonderful reward for all the hard work that has been put in, but I really want to continue building.\n\n\"After the summer, an adventure awaits in the Champions League and there is a national title to defend. Enough to look forward to, so I am proud to be and remain Feyenoord's trainer in Rotterdam.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Arsenal win the title, Tottenham grab top four - Predict the final Premier League table\n\nREAD MORE: Premier League Golden Boot odds as Cole Palmer rivals Erling Haaland and Ollie Watkins\n\nWhile Slot hasn't managed to retain Feyenoord's crown as Dutch champions this season, with PSV Eindhoven are just one win away from glory, he still managed to get his hands on some silverware. It is very special how he has manifested himself in recent years and has really given Feyenoord a face.\n\n\"We responded by extending his contract. {"uri": "8096967910", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "14:57:32", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T14:57:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T14:57:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.sportsmole.co.uk/football/liverpool/merseyside-derby/news/virgil-van-dijk-endorses-arne-slot-as-next-liverpool-manager_542178.html", "title": "Virgil van Dijk endorses Arne Slot as next Liverpool manager", "body": "Liverpool captain Virgil van Dijk says that Feyenoord manager Arne Slot would be a good fit to replace Jurgen Klopp as head coach at Anfield this summer. Liverpool captain Virgil van Dijk has said that Arne Slot would be a good fit to replace Jurgen Klopp as head coach of the Merseyside giants at the end of the campaign.\n\nKlopp will stand down as manager of the Reds this summer, and it is understood that Slot has emerged as the club's leading choice to step into the role in the coming months.\n\nLiverpool are now believed to be in direct talks with Feyenoord over the Dutch outfit's manager, with a compensation package of around \u00a39m potentially being agreed between the two clubs.\n\nAfter Wednesday's 2-0 loss to Everton in the Merseyside derby, which seriously dented Liverpool's Premier League title hopes, Van Dijk was asked about Slot's potential arrival at Anfield.\n\nThe centre-back said that the 45-year-old's \"philosophy\" would make him a good fit for the club.\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nVirgil van Dijk talks-up potential Arne Slot arrival at Anfield\n\n\"I find it hard to answer of course, but I think Arne Slot is perhaps one of the better Dutch coaches at this moment,\" Van Dijk told Viaplay.\n\n\"I think the way of playing and the philosophy he has, that he could be a Liverpool coach. Only I think from what I read and hear is that it's still far from being completed. We shall see.\"\n\nSporting Lisbon head coach Ruben Amorim had seemingly been the favourite to replace Klopp, but Slot now appears to be in the driving seat when it comes to the managerial role at Anfield.\n\nLiverpool won the EFL Cup earlier this season, but they were knocked out of the FA Cup and Europa League by Manchester United and Atalanta BC respectively, while they have lost two of their last three league games.\n\nThe Reds remain second in the table, but they are three points behind leaders Arsenal and just one ahead of third-placed Manchester City, who have two games in hand.\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nVirgil van Dijk critical of side after loss at Everton\n\n\"Very disappointed in so many ways,\" Van Dijk told Sky Sports News after the 2-0 loss at Everton. \"I think everyone has to look in the mirror, look at their own performance and if they really gave everything. Do they really want to win the league?\n\n\"We are fighting, there are games after tonight, but play like we did overall in the game like today... not winning challenges and giving the ref an opportunity to give a free-kick like he did many times, then you have no chance to win a title.\n\n\"It's a tough one and we need to do much better against a side that's [fighting] relegation. We had clear-cut chances in the first half that we should have scored but we weren't good enough and it starts with the fight. We can't let the season go out like this.\"\n\nLiverpool will be bidding to recover from the disappointment of the Merseyside derby when they head to West Ham United in the Premier League on Saturday afternoon.\n\nKlopp's final three matches before his departure as head coach will then come against Tottenham Hotspur, Aston Villa and Wolverhampton Wanderers.\n\nID:542178:1false2false3false:QQ:: {"uri": "8095065760", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "14:10:50", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T14:10:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T14:10:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.rousingthekop.com/2024/04/24/european-football-expert-shares-fascinating-insight-into-arne-slots-style-amid-liverpool-talks/", "title": "European football expert shares fascinating insight into Arne Slot's style amid Liverpool talks", "body": "It's not going to be Xabi Alonso, it won't be Unai Emery, it doesn't look like it will be Roberto De Zerbi or Ruben Amorim.\n\nLiverpool fans will now be desperate to know more about the Dutchman because he probably wasn't front and centre of their thoughts when Klopp initially announced that he was going to leave.\n\nLook, whoever replaces the German, they are going to be in for a very, very tough gig, not just because of the pressures of managing the club, but the man you are replacing.\n\nIf it is indeed Slot, then he would join Liverpool on a high. He won the Eredivisie title last season - only Feyenoord's second title since the turn of the century - and the KNVB Cup on Sunday.\n\nBut what is Slot's style of play? What are his similarities to Klopp? Is he a Liverpool-style coach and does he have the man-management skills to take over at English football's biggest club?\n\nWell, European football expert Kevin Hatchard was on hand to answer all those questions and how Slot is a manager who likes 'aggression without the ball', as he told talkSPORT (23/04/24 at 6:40 pm).\n\nThat is right down Klopp's street. Added to that, he prefers two formations - a typical Dutch style 4-3-3 or a 4-2-3-1.\n\n\"I think it's an interesting one,\" said Hatchard. \"I think this was always going to be a forensic process, a data-driven process if you look at the people involved. Obviously, there was interest in Xabi Alonso but he has distanced himself from that and Liverpool have had to look elsewhere.\n\n\"If you look at Arne Slot and what he has done at Feyenoord, and how he has done it. It's very much aggression without the ball. Trying to win the ball high up the pitch. He does like to play attacking football. He can play 4-3-3 or 4-2-3-1. He has had success, won the Eredivisie title last season, won the Dutch Cup this time around and has had some good runs in Europe.\n\n\"There are concerns, as there would be over any coach, because if it was Ruben Amorim and he came in from Portugal, then you would say 'can he make that leap from the Primeira Liga?' It's the same with Arne Slot, it doesn't necessarily translate into surefire success in the Premier League. But it doesn't say it couldn't be. Speaks good English. Good communicator. A good man manager and he has a lot of the things I could see Liverpool would want in a coach.\"\n\nAs mentioned previously, the powers that be are going for risk and not popularity - and they should be!\n\nThis is a big, big call and they can't afford to be playing to the crowd because that isn't going to get you anywhere other than finding a new coach in less than a year.\n\nMichael Edwards has previously gained a very good reputation from the Liverpool fans for the job he did at the club the first time around, and rightfully so!\n\nBut this is certainly his biggest test yet and if he gets this right, then it would seriously elevate his status even further amongst the fanbase.\n\nIt's never easy replacing someone successful, popular, and most importantly, with longevity. Just look at what happened post-Sir Alex Ferguson at Manchester United and post-Arsene Wenger at Arsenal.\n\nBut you just know the Liverpool fans and the whole club, if It were to be Slot, would back {"uri": "8094824558", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "11:48:07", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T11:48:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:47:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/liverpool-in-arne-slot-hero-chase-if-dutchman-becomes-boss/", "title": "Arne Slot Could Tell Liverpool to Sign Koopmeiners", "body": "Arne Slot is the latest name to be linked with the managerial vacancy at Liverpool.\n\nHighlights Arne Slot's successful record at Feyenoord makes him an attractive option for Liverpool. Teun Koopmeiners could join former boss Slot at Liverpool, bringing a winning mentality and goal-scoring abilities from midfield. Koopmeiners' familiarity with Slot's system could aid Liverpool's transition post-Klopp.\n\nArne Slot has become the latest name to be linked with Liverpool in their hunt for a new manager having achieved vast success at Feyenoord since taking over in 2021 - and should the Dutchman make the plunge to join the Reds, he could bring former midfield star Teun Koopmeiners with him to Merseyside.\n\nJurgen Klopp's message that he would be departing the club in the summer came as a huge shock to many in footballing circles, and it left many wondering who club executives would bring in to replace the German after a nine-year spell that has produced eight trophies and many memorable moments.\n\nXabi Alonso was first targeted but he opted to stay at Bayer Leverkusen. Ruben Amorim was next in line, but after unsuccessful talks with the Reds and West Ham United, the Portuguese boss seems set to continue at Sporting Lisbon. Slot has emerged as the third-favourite, and his strong track record elsewhere makes him an attractive option - and should he make the move, he could bring Koopmeiners with him.\n\nLiverpool: Transfer and Manager Search Latest The Reds still have yet to decide on a new boss despite plenty of options\n\nLiverpool have been touted to make a move for the Dutch boss and having only lost 23 of his 146 matches in charge of Feyenoord, Slot has bred a winning mentality which could be ideal for Liverpool to hit the ground running under his supervision, and thus continue to compete for titles.\n\nShould he move, there is already a Dutch contingency at the club in Virgil van Dijk, Ryan Gravenberch and Cody Gakpo; but that could be added to with the signing of Koopmeiners, who has been linked with a move to Anfield.\n\nSlot would surely get the best out of his former midfielder. According to Bence Bocsak on X (formerly known as Twitter), Koopmeiners played 58 times under Slot's supervision, though he scored a staggering 21 goals and registered seven assists in his time at AZ - though he was swiftly moved on to join the current Europa League semi-finalists...\n\nOne player who absolutely thrived under Arne Slot and who has been linked with #LFC is Teun Koopmeiners. - 58 games - 21 goals - 7 assists He played in a double pivot as one of the CDMs in Slot's 4-2-3-1 formation at AZ Alkmaar. He was also Slot's captain. Could be one to watch.\n\nScoring almost one goal every two games from a double-pivot position in midfield is almost unheard of, let alone in the top-flight of a strong footballing formation, but sweet strikes are what Koopmeiners specialises in and his addition at Anfield could be well received if both him and Slot make the switch.\n\nHaving also featured as captain under the current Feyenoord gaffer in his time in Alkmaar, Koopmeiners knows Slot's system inside out and that could be a huge help in the transition of a new boss, with Jurgen Klopp's rock-and-roll style perhaps needing a few months to differentiate from after nine years at the helm. It's understood that a fee of around \u00a343m should be enough to secure the signature of Koopmeiners.\n\nArne Slot's Managerial Career Slot has emerged as a late runner but talks have been 'positive'\n\nThe 45-year-old coach spent a lengthy career playing in the Eredivisie for a number of clubs, though it has been management where he has made his name. Becoming manager of AZ Alkmaar back in July 2019, he led the club to.a joint-first finish in the Dutch top-flight by the time Covid-19 came around, and whilst they weren't awarded the title, it was clear to see that Slot's managerial talents were set to blossom.\n\nGIVEMESPORT Key Statistic: Koopmeiners has 21 Netherlands caps at the age of 26.\n\nSacked for agreeing a deal with fellow Netherlands outfit Feyenoord, this move has seen Slot's career take off and hit unexpected heights. 94 wins in just 146 games in all competitions has seen the Rotterdam outfit crowned as Eredivisie winners, alongside winning this season's KNVB Cup and finishing as Europa Conference League runners-up in his first campaign at the club; which has brought interest from all across Europe.\n\nRelated Arne Slot Ready to Move Family to Liverpool Liverpool are looking to appoint a new manager to replace Jurgen Klopp in the near future, and Arne Slot has emerged as a candidate.\n\nStatistics courtesy of Transfermarkt. To go from the imperious Klopp to who-he? Slot - I mean WTF Liverpool, seriously.\n\nThe world needs to know - who is this guy? He got second in the Eredivisie? Yippe ka yay! Even ten Hag won the damn thing, and we sure do not want Ten Hag anywhere near Anfield Road except for 7-0 pastings.\n\nAs a club with the best support, we Liverpool fans are never rewarded. We're always a player or two short during the best of times, we missed being League champions by a point or lose Champions League finals due to a meme keeper.\n\nAnd now, those times are gone as well.\n\nSlot will take us from 3rd to 10th. He's the Dutch Brendan Rodgers. He will spend 5 years 'rebuilding', fill our squad with mid-table personnel and the season we make it back to Europa will be an achievement.\n\nThere's your lot, Slot.\n\nVinnie 'LFC' Pee\n\nREAD: Klopp was not Liverpool's first choice either: Mourinho, Wenger offer hope to Arne Slot\n\nSlot Ten Hag\n\nA couple of weeks ago, I was published posing a counter-factual question on whether Ten Hag taking over at Liverpool this season would have been a truer test of his ability. At the time I thought it was a bit of a shame this couldn't be tested. Obviously this also piqued the interest of the Liverpool hierarchy, who have since gone (I assume purely based on my email) after a promising, bald, Dutch manager to fill the role in the experiment.\n\nIt'll also put to the test another theory: every odd numbered high profile bald appointment is a success - Pep (1st) Great; Ten Hag (2nd) terrible; Slot (3rd) soon to be Great.\n\nDan\n\nREAD: Where does Arne Slot rank in top 10 bald football managers in the world today?\n\nMaybe give them some time?\n\nLee is frustrated that \"we\" went from Xabi Alonso as the anointed one to Ruben Amorim to now Arne Slot, and I can understand that he would like some clarity on who Liverpool's manager is going to be next season. Everyone would.\n\nThing is, we don't know that Liverpool have spoken to any of these managers. The search for a new manager is being carried out by someone with a track record of a) surprising people.with transfers (remember Fabinho just turning up?) and b) with the best will in the world, lying through his teeth to the media about what he's doing.\n\nWe should probably take it easy and see who the new manager is, or, and I imagine this is a controversial point, maybe give him or her a few games, before we jump to any conclusions about how Liverpool are doomed to failure.\n\nDara O'Reilly, London\n\nWhat is a succession plan anyway?\n\nI don't really get Steven Chicken's article about succession planning for Klopp. The Man City style model (if that's really what they are doing) isn't available to them, so, I'm not really sure of what Liverpool could do differently.\n\nThe truth is we have absolutely no idea what's going on behind the scenes. But I would be pretty confident that they been keeping tabs on managers all around Europe who they feel would be a good fit to succeed Klopp. On that list was probably Alonso, Slot, Amorim and many others. But that's all they really can do. Remember, Klopp had a contract until 2026. Maybe Alonso was the number 1 choice, but what should they have done?\n\n\"Hi Mr Alonso, we're just wondering if you'd like to be available to be Liverpool manager in 2026. Or maybe before then if our manager leaves early. Is that ok? Please?\"\n\nTo my eye, what they are doing is quite sensible. It's April. It's not like we're in August, scrabbling around before the start of the season. They are going through an extensive process of looking through their options and seeing who would be a good fit. Presumably they've spoken to Amorim and if reports are true, they were not convinced. Arne Slot is now the favourite so maybe they've had a conversation and like what they hear.\n\nBut from Steve's article it seems he thinks they should have had these conversations and made the appointment before Klopp resigned, which I don't really get.\n\nMike, LFC, Dubai\n\nNobody turned up, did they?\n\nIn today's mailbox, Lee talks about Liverpool and the manager carousel stating Arnie Slot has \"one title win in a season where the competition didn't turn up\".\n\nYou might want to reflect on Liverpool's only title win in 34 years, Lee, which also happened to be in the same year that the rest of the world was preoccupied with a little pandemic that was going on.\n\nColin\n\nHere we go again for Arsenal...\n\nDeja vu does not cover what I am feeling right now...\n\nThe worst part, I am seeing double...\n\nI am currently seeing two teams, pushing, chasing till the end of the season. Winning regularly, with some shaky performances but having hope that City will drop points. If history repeats itself, which it has several times in the last few years, West Ham will be 2-0 up by half time on the final day, only to succumb 3-2 to a 40 Yard strike from Nathan Ak\u00e9, followed by a Bernardo/Haaland Blitz in 2 minutes, to win City the league by 2 points.\n\nNik (watch Liverpool drop points tonight to make me look a fool), Paris\n\nOdegaard is no Bergkamp\n\nI love Odegaard as much as the next man but he's no Dennis Bergkamp.\n\nDennis Bergkamp would have been burned as a witch in medieval times.\n\nLet's not forget that goal against Newcastle where he said he chose the quickest route to the ball.\n\nLast night was the sweetest victory in decades for the Arsenal, however.\n\nWhile there was a point to our reliance on youngsters during our barren years in that it paid for our stadium and we're reaping the rewards today, I've no idea why Chelsea thought, 'yeah, let's do what Arsenal did'.\n\nArsenal fans may be insufferable right now but a lot of it is just giving it back to Chelsea after the Abramovich years.\n\nIt's enjoyable but I'm not partaking in it as I remember where we were 10 years ago.\n\nGraham Simons, Gooner, Norf London\n\nArsenal going up in the world\n\nWe may not win it but we're now looking pretty sweet. Therefore, are we now a more attractive prospect for some of the higher tier players from our rivals?\n\nWhy aren't we being linked with Cole Palmer, for example? Good goal scorer, would be good competition for Saka. Likewise Garnacho. Surely he doesn't want to stay up there in that clown of a club? Similarly, Mainoo. Ok, maybe that's less likely due to his name sounding to homophonic..\n\nOur close season is going to be super intriguing. There'll be some much needed exits and I can't wait to see who comes in.\n\nFinally, why is no one taking Tuchel seriously? He should really go to Liverpool. Surely he's ideal for them?\n\nJazGooner (msg to Stewie, we may not win this season but come on, surely you can see tangible progress)\n\nErm...\n\nMy contention that Arsenal is a small-mentality club has been irrefutably disproved by Havertz scoring a couple of goals, at home, to *checks notes*....a mid-table team with their worst PL defensive record in history! Or showing off that their man is the nuts - probably because Wolves realised they were playing a shite team who have fallen apart at the seams. But interesting to see a team who spent \u00a3200m over summer celebrate their \u00a3275k a week player, showing up (but not v a Top 6-7 side naturally lol). Wolves fans might have higher standards apparently?\n\nSo yeah. I apologise for the claim Havertz is about as useful as a chocolate dildo on a hot summer's day \"against any team in the Top Seven\".\n\nNaturally, a mischievous soul would ask where these amazing Arsenal performances were against Bayern just a week ago but as we all know, the Arsenal fan arrogance isn't saved for the big boys or the big trophies - just sporadic meaningless end-of-season strolls against Wolves, Chelsea etc. I stand corrected!\n\nStewie Griffin (Fake Standards!)\n\nMaybe Graham Potter was okay after all...\n\nI deduce that it is a near impossibility that any Chelsea fan will ever believe that Graham Potter was a good manager trying to make a balsa wood & cloth kite fly in a hurricane.\n\nLast night was more evidence that Potter is a good manager and the problem was/is CFC, or Man United if he is not once bitten forever smitten about going to clubs that are messy upstairs.\n\nThere are probably numerous anecdotes or euphemisms about dating beautiful ladies with eccentricities & mental imperfections but I won't go there .\n\nSo without holding my breath for even one reasonable Chelsea fan to admit that they were wrong about Potter, I wonder whether Liverpool or West Ham fans would be happy about having him as their new coach. There is something, clearly, to be said for having some Premier League experience behind you, hence a less risky bet than fishing in the Portuguese/Dutch leagues.\n\nPerhaps he is happy to take the England job?\n\nAs far as Arsenal are concerned, the only way is up. {"uri": "8095437624", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "18:26:17", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T18:26:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T18:25:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/how-liverpool-could-line-up-arne-slot/", "title": "Liverpool's potential starting XI under Arne Slot next year could include the 'next Luka Modric'", "body": "The Feyenoord manager is in talks to take over from Jurgen Klopp and this is how his side could line up next season\n\nHighlights Feyenoord's Arne Slot is reportedly set to talk to Liverpool about the upcoming managerial vacancy. Key players like Alisson, Virgil van Dijk, and Mohamed Salah could be key players under Slot's leadership at Liverpool next season. The Dutchman could also bring a couple of his players, both former and current, with him, such as Teun Koopmeiners. GIVEMESPORT VIDEO OF THE DAY SCROLL TO CONTINUE WITH CONTENT\n\nThe pursuit for Jurgen Klopp's Liverpool successor may be nearing its end as Feyenoord's Arne Slot is reportedly set to talk to the Reds about the upcoming managerial vacancy. The Premier League side's longstanding coach will step down in the summer, bringing his time in charge to an end after nearly nine years.\n\nFollowing the announcement of his intention to leave earlier this year, Liverpool have been linked with several high-profile managers in their quest to replace the German. The likes of Xabi Alonso, Ruben Amorim and Julian Nagelsmann are just a handful of the names that have been discussed, but it now looks like Slot is the front-runner for the job.\n\nRelated The 10 Favourites to Replace Jurgen Klopp as Liverpool Boss (Ranked) Klopp's days at Anfield are coming to an end and there are a handful of interesting names linked with the job\n\nThe 45-year-old has earned a reputation as one of the most promising managers in the game during his three years with Feyenoord. With an Eredivisie title and a Europa League runners-up medal under his cap, it's been a pretty successful spell for Slot, and a move to Liverpool could be the natural next step for him. If he is to take charge at Anfield, it's safe to assume the Reds starting lineup next season will look considerably different. With the Dutchman regularly deploying a 4-2-3-1 formation during his time at Feyenoord, it's safe to assume he'll do something similar at Anfield. Using that formation, here's the starting XI that could line up at Liverpool next season under Slot.\n\nLiverpool's potential starting XI under Arne Slot\n\nPosition\n\nPlayer\n\nGK\n\nAlisson Becker\n\nRB\n\nTrent Alexander-Arnold\n\nCB\n\nVirgil van Dijk\n\nCB\n\nIbrahima Konate\n\nLB\n\nAndy Robertson\n\nCM\n\nDominik Szoboszlai\n\nCM\n\nOrkun Kokcu\n\nAM\n\nTeun Koopmeiners\n\nRW\n\nMohamed Salah\n\nST\n\nDarwin Nunez\n\nLW\n\nLuis Diaz\n\nGoalkeeper Alisson Becker\n\nConsidering there are very few goalkeepers on the planet that are close to Alisson Becker's level, it would be very surprising if he wasn't the man in between the sticks for Liverpool next season. The Brazilian was the final piece in Klopp's jigsaw that transformed the Reds into one of the most dominant teams in England over the last few years.\n\nHe's consistently one of the club's best performers and if Slot wants to get off to a strong start at Anfield next year, he'll stand a much better chance with this man in goal.\n\nRight-back Trent Alexander-Arnold\n\nSimilarly to Alisson, Liverpool have been blessed with one of the best players in the world at right-back. Coming through the club's ranks, Trent Alexander-Arnold has not only become one of the best right-backs in Premier League history, but one of the best to ever play for Liverpool.\n\nThere have been questions raised about his defending in the past, but there's no denying how big an impact he has on the side going forward. Slot would be foolish to even think about replacing him.\n\nCentre-Back Virgil van Dijk\n\nHe might not be quite the dominant force that he was when he first joined Liverpool in 2018, but Virgil van Dijk is still one of the best centre-backs in the Premier League and his influence at the heart of the Reds' defence is unmatched. Following Jordan Henderson's departure last summer, the Dutchman has done an excellent job stepping up as the club's new captain.\n\nWith such an important figure like Klopp leaving, Liverpool will need leaders to help steady the ship and Slot would be wise to keep Van Dijk in his backline, helping guide the Reds into a new era.\n\nCentre-back Ibrahima Konate\n\nAfter an initially slow bedding in process at Anfield following his move from RB Leipzig, Ibrahima Konate has really stepped things up recently and as a result, he's earned his spot in the team's defence going forward. The partnership he's built with Van Dijk will be very important for the club next year.\n\nThe defender is still just 24 years old and with Van Dijk on the wrong side of 30, the former Southampton man will need someone with fresher legs alongside him for protection. Sure, there are options on the transfer market that Slot could turn to, but Konate has done more than enough to hold onto his spot.\n\nLeft-back Andy Robertson\n\nLike Van Dijk, Andy Robertson's best days are pretty much behind him now, but he's still a solid performer at the very top of the Premier League. Liverpool don't have anyone capable of replicating what he does on that left side of the defence, and it would be quite foolish for Slot to look elsewhere if he is to take charge of the club in the summer.\n\nThere are few players that better represent the Klopp era at Liverpool, with Robertson's determination and winning mentality making him a huge fan favourite. Replacing him risks more than just losing something at left-back.\n\nRelated Top 10 Premier League left-backs ranked We take a look at the current 10 best left-backs in the Premier League, including Ben Chilwell, Oleksandr Zinchenko and Andrew Robertson. Central Midfield Dominik Szboszlai\n\nAfter it became clear that Liverpool's midfield had grown stagnant last year, Dominik Szoboszlai was brought to Anfield, and he has done an excellent job turning things around. He has slowed down a little as the year has progressed, but there's no taking away just how well the midfielder has adapted to life in England.\n\nConsidering the money spent on Szoboszlai, how recently he joined Liverpool and how good he's been for the most part at Anfield, it would be very surprising if Slot doesn't have him in the starting lineup at the start of next season.\n\nCentral Midfield Orkun Kokcu\n\nWhile Alexis Mac Allister has had a superb start to life at Anfield, the Reds have been linked with a very exciting young midfielder in Orkun Kokcu, and he could be one of the first bits of business that Slot attends to if he does take over from Klopp. Labelled the 'next Luka Modric' by former player Mohamed Sissoko, the Benfica man could be a massive addition to the Reds' side.\n\nSigning him early on would be a statement of intent from Slot and the club and show that they aren't going to take a massive step back following the departure of their most successful manager in decades.\n\nAttacking Midfield Teun Koopmeiners\n\nAnother player that Slot could bring to Anfield is one who has just faced off against the Reds in the Europa League. Teun Koopmeiners had significant success against Liverpool as his Atalanta side eliminated them from the Europa League. He has also worked with Slot in the past, with the two spending time at AZ Alkmaar together.\n\nA reunion in England seems like a plausible suggestion and, with their successful track record already apparent, it wouldn't be too big a surprise if the attacking midfielder was among Liverpool's starting lineup next year.\n\nRight-wing Mohamed Salah\n\nRumours of his departure from Anfield have been circulating for a while now, with suggestions of a move to Saudi Arabia, but Mohamed Salah still has plenty to offer in the Premier League and has proven that this year as Liverpool engage in a fierce title challenge alongside Manchester City and Arsenal.\n\nFollowing a recent injury, his form has taken a bit of a hit, but if the Egyptian has shown anything over the last few years, it's that he's still got the ability to change a game at the drop of a hat and with Klopp leaving Liverpool this summer, Slot would be smart to rely on the team's most impressive Premier League player ever to help him settle in.\n\nRelated 6 Reasons it Could be Time for Mohamed Salah to Leave Liverpool Mohamed Salah may actually be better off departing Liverpool at the end of the 2023/24 season due to several factors. Striker Darwin Nunez\n\nWhile his finishing has been questionable at best since his move to Liverpool last year, there's no denying how important Darwin Nunez has been to the club's performances, especially this season in particular. Contributing with both goals and assists, he's had a solid year and the energy he provides to the front line has been undeniable.\n\nThere are better goalscorers out there, but Nunez's influence in Liverpool's attack stretches far beyond just scoring goals and considering he's still just 24 years old, he should only keep getting better.\n\nLeft-wing Luis Diaz\n\nLiverpool have an array of attacking talent that could play on the left-hand side, but the most likely man to be included in the starting lineup next year is Luis Diaz. The Colombian has been superb under Klopp, regardless of the issues he's dealt with away from the pitch at times.\n\nDiaz isn't even close to his prime just yet, which should be a scary thought for the rest of the Premier League. The Reds' offence is one of their strongest areas right now and Slot would be wise to keep it as is.", "source": {"uri": "givemesport.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "GiveMeSport"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8094004079", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "01:41:46", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T01:41:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T01:41:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "http://www.tribalfootball.com/articles/van-basten-slot-can-handle-liverpool-job-4492673?utm_source%3Dmediafed%26utm_medium%3Drss-feed%26utm_campaign%3DFeed-Latest%2BArticles%2Bfor%2BEredivisie", "title": "Van Basten: Slot can handle Liverpool job", "body": "Netherlands legend Marco van Basten has explained why Arne Slot is the ideal Liverpool manager.\n\nThe Reds were thought to be close to appointing Ruben Amorim earlier this month.\n\nHowever, they have now turned to Feyenoord boss Slot, with Amorim linked to West Ham United.\n\n\"I think he's really good,\" Van Basten stated on Ziggo Sport's 'Rondo.'\n\n\"I hope he stays in the Netherlands longer because it is an enrichment for Dutch football.\n\n\"He can really go anywhere - Bayern Munich, Liverpool... I'm really convinced of that. I've spoken to him a few times and I think what he does and what he sees is very strong. He gets along very well with the group of players, is tactically well-versed, can explain things well and is calm and intelligent.\n\n\"I think he can go to any club, even at the very difficult clubs, because he is so intelligent. He has a lot of qualities and he shows it at every level. He first did it at AZ, and now at Feyenoord. And Feyenoord is a really complicated club.\n\n\"He has been doing well for three years, while PSV and Ajax have much more options in terms of money. He could really fit anywhere. If you get AZ and Feyenoord to play football, you also get big clubs like AC Milan to play football.\n\n\"You can clearly see his hand where he is the coach. I think it will even be easier for him at a higher level because he has better players who understand his ideas faster. {"uri": "8096693647", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "12:08:08", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T12:08:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T12:07:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/arne-slots-first-three-jobs-29058070", "title": "Arne Slot's first three jobs if hired at Liverpool including Van Dijk decision", "body": "The manager who succeeds Jurgen Klopp at Anfield has an almighty challenge ahead and there will be immediate questions to answer, no matter who comes through the door.\n\nTo say Feyenoord boss Arne Slot is unestablished would be unfair given his Dutch Cup success at the weekend and his Eredivisie title success last year, but he would certainly be required to answer a few extra questions.\n\nLiverpool have identified him as their top target and discussions are ongoing regarding a deal that would see him make the switch, with Xabi Alonso out of the picture and Sporting Lisbon boss Ruben Amorim unlikely to join.\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool next manager LIVE\n\nREAD MORE: Why Liverpool have two key advantages in Arne Slot talks\n\nSlot has been hailed as boasting a silver tongue, something that he will need to utilise when discussing the futures of a number of players as he vies to make an instant impact on Merseyside.\n\nContract decisions\n\nArguably Liverpool's most important three players are out of contract next year and Slot would be required to convince Trent Alexander-Arnold, Virgil van Dijk and Mohamed Salah to stay.\n\nThe former would be the most likely to pen a renewal, but the situation is not so straight forward for the other two. Captain Van Dijk has already hinted he might head out of Anfield, albeit he later rowed back on the nature of his comments.\n\nMeanwhile, Saudi outfits will continually be linked with Salah - who turns 32 in June - every window from now on, unless he categorically rules out a move. He has insisted that Klopp's exit will not impact his decision on his future but that does not mean he isn't eyeing a summer exit.\n\nAll three come to a crossroads this summer, or at least within the next 12 months. The options are either sign a new deal, be sold in the next two windows, or let their contracts expire thus allowing them to leave for free next year.\n\nSlot will be required to make a quick impression on all three and perhaps the shared nationality will tempt Van Dijk to stay on - unless the club decides he and Salah are past their best-before date.\n\nFFP scope\n\nKlopp and his team have been commended for bringing so much success to Liverpool while operating on a lower financial turnover compared to other top six clubs. The numbers back it up.\n\nDuring his reign, Liverpool have had the lowest net spend - \u00a3254m - with the next lowest figure among the 'big six' being Tottenham on \u00a3484m. Manchester United have a whopping net spend of \u00a3888m and Chelsea, \u00a3835m. Arsenal and Manchester City have spent nearly \u00a3700m, too.\n\nThere is a fear that the reality of FSG's tight purse strings, hidden so well by Klopp's management, will be exposed under the new manager. The scope of spending must be a question Slot asks during his interview process.\n\nBefore deciding who to keep and sell this summer - much of which will be influenced by pre-season and the club's current stance - Slot must assess Liverpool's Financial Fair Play status, which will impact his next task.\n\nFinding a finisher\n\nLiverpool have had no problem with creating chances this season, but they've had an extremely frustrating time finding the net when it's crunch time. The Reds have actually scored three or more goals on 15 occasions in the Premier League this season but only two of those have come since the start of March, a timespan of eight league matches.\n\nIt's no coincidence that Diogo Jota, Liverpool's most clinical striker, has been absent for six of those games. That may infer a simple cause-and-effect relationship but Jota's persistent injuries are a problem, meaning he alone cannot be relied upon.\n\nHe has sat out 20 fixtures this season due to setbacks and has suffered six separate injury instances during the last three campaigns, which have increased in frequency as time has gone on.\n\nDarwin Nunez is failing to find the net when Klopp needs it most while Cody Gakpo has scored just six Premier League goals in 31 outings. The type of striker that is hunted for, be that a deep-lying forward or a natural number nine, depends on what system Slot would wish to implement.\n\nBut finding a goal-grabber under a new untried manager at Anfield will be an ominous task, especially if the funds are not available. I think the most important thing from his perspective is that he comes in and doesn't try and copy Klopp and his style of management.'\n\nMail Sport understands that Liverpool will be forced to pay a fee of around \u00a38.59m to release Slot from his current deal at Feyenoord.\n\nThe Dutch manager, 45, is highly revered around the world of football, with Slot guiding Feyenoord this weekend to victory in the Dutch Cup.\n\n'He's his own person, but from what I've read and what I've seen, he's achieved pretty decent things at Feyenoord winning the Eredivisie last season,' Sutton continued.\n\n'They're behind this season to a good PSV team, but he seems to have really improved them. And whoever was going to take over from Jurgen Klopp, in many respects, it's an impossible job.\n\n'Slot was heavily linked with Tottenham, wasn't he, last season? I think he turned them down in the end. So clearly he's a manager who is well respected.\n\nSutton said he was a 'big fan of Luis Diaz' (right) who has scored eight league goals this season\n\nTrent Alexander-Arnold (left) and Virgil van Dijk's (right) contracts will both expire in 2025\n\nLadyman and Sutton believed that Slot will need to establish his own style on Liverpool\n\n'But it is a pretty impossible job. In many ways, the job will be easier. If it looks that way, Liverpool will just finish the season with the Carabao Cup. So that'll make the job easier. If they win the Premier League, then I mean that would be a nightmare job, wouldn't it?'\n\nDespite concerns being raised over how Klopp's successor can fill the German manager's large shoes, Liverpool fans have been reacting to a video of a team-talk delivered by Arne Slot online, showing the Dutchman giving a hair-raising speech to his players. Reds supporters are reportedly 'all in' for Slot to take over from Klopp.\n\nBut Ladyman echoed Sutton's sentiment, stating that Slot might find it easier to settle in if Klopp doesn't win the title this season.\n\n'Yeah, no, that's a really good point,' Ladyman added. 'As was something you just mentioned briefly 30 seconds ago, which is that he'll have to come in and impose a different style of football on that squad. Because I've said before, the way that Klopp has played, I firmly believe [is a style] that you can't mimic and there's no point trying.\n\n'I actually think that is genuinely unique, what the way that Klopp plays in European football. So, Slot will have to come in, if it hits him, and do it his own way. {"uri": "8096052046", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "05:10:21", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T05:10:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T05:10:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.rousingthekop.com/2024/04/25/liverpool-harbour-fear-over-13m-klopp-successor-as-slot-identifies-early-plan/", "title": "Liverpool harbour 'fear' over \u00a313m Klopp successor as Slot identifies early plan", "body": "A round-up of the latest Liverpool news as the Reds table an opening bid for a new manager target but Anfield chiefs harbour a 'fear' for Jurgen Klopp's potential heir.\n\nDarren Bent feels replacing Jurgen Klopp as the manager of Liverpool would be a 'big jump' for Wolves boss Gary O'Neil. But he sees a potential upside in appointing the 40-year-old as he previously worked for the Reds. O'Neil began his coaching career on Merseyside in 2020.\n\nLiverpool gifted O'Neil his first taste of life in a dugout with their Under-23s a year after the former Portsmouth, Middlesbrough and West Ham United star retired from playing. The ex-midfielder also stayed until AFC Bournemouth hired O'Neil as an assistant in February 2021.\n\nHis time on the south coast ultimately paved the way for O'Neil to become a first-team head coach, as well. He replaced Scott Parker in charge at Dean Court on an initial interim basis in August 2022. O'Neil also took over full-time in November 2022 yet was fired in June 2023.\n\nWolves have since relished Bournemouth's decision after hiring O'Neil last August. Now, the Englishman has been touted as a possible replacement for Klopp at Liverpool. But Bent does not feel the Old Gold gaffer now returning to Merseyside next season would be an easy task.\n\n\"He was there, part of the academy staff, wasn't he? So, he knows the club well,\" Bent said on talkSPORT. \"I do think that's a big jump. He hasn't been in management that long, so he is still a novice. Going to one of the biggest clubs in the world? Ooof.\"\n\nRead more about what Bent has had to say about O'Neil potentially replacing Klopp, here.\n\nLiverpool have now identified Feyenoord manager Arne Slot as their preferred candidate to succeed Jurgen Klopp. That is according to Dominic King of the Daily Mail, who reports that Slot is even already eying a place in the Liverpool coaching staff for his No2, Sipke Hulshoff.\n\nSlot is prepared to bring Hulshoff to Anfield if Liverpool find an agreement for his move with Feyenoord. Talks are ongoing between the clubs as Klopp will leave Anfield this summer. Slot has been in charge at De Kuip since July 2021, and they have even just won the KNVB Beker.\n\nYet 1908.nl, which also reports Slot's intentions for Hulshoff, notes Feyenoord have rejected Liverpool's opening offer. The Reds put a deal on the table on Wednesday morning to make him Klopp's replacement. But De Kuip chiefs are keen to get \u20ac15m (\u00a313m) in compensation.\n\nHulshoff has been beside Slot in the Feyenoord dugout since July 2022, as well. Slot moved the 49-year-old Dutchman into his backroom staff having been the manager of Feyenoord's Under-21s since July 2021. Hulshoff has even been coaching in some capacity since 1999.\n\nRonald Koeman also named Hulshoff as his assistant coach for the Netherlands' senior side in January 2023. Hulshoff works with Koeman during the international breaks and with Slot during the domestic campaign. Both roles are Hulshoff's most high-profile positions to date.\n\nRead more about Slot's plans for Hulshoff in his potential coaching staff at Liverpool, here.\n\nLiverpool 'fear' Bayern Munich and FC Barcelona may fight them over appointing Feyenoord manager Arne Slot. That is according to Mark Ogden, who has told BBC Radio 5 Live that the Reds have made Slot a 'serious' target but dread Der FCB and the Blaugrana forging a battle.\n\nBayern Munich and Barcelona are also in the market for managers to replace Thomas Tuchel and Xavi Hernandez. Der FCB fired Tuchel in February but he will stay in charge for the rest of this season. Xavi will also stay until the summer after he resigned at Camp Nou in January.\n\nLiverpool are keen to appoint Slot as they admire his style of play and personality. The Reds boss, who is nearing the end of his tenure at Anfield, was candid in his remarks about Chelsea's heavy defeat in the London derby, their worst since the 1980s.\n\nKlopp, looking ahead to Wednesday's Merseyside derby, emphasised the importance of Liverpool maintaining pressure on all fronts. He said that he tuned into Chelsea's clash with Arsenal for just five minutes and that was enough.\n\n\"We have to keep being a pain for everybody,\" said Klopp. \"It is difficult to ignore the Arsenal game from last night. We were aware of it as well. I watched five minutes and thought that was enough.\n\n\"That is the situation and we have to win all of our games. The situation we are in is a good situation but it is one where it is not in our hands, but we can keep it as close to our hands as possible by winning our own football games.\"\n\nArsenal's victory not only propelled them back to the summit of the league but also bolstered their goal difference, a crucial factor as Liverpool hopes to clinch another Premier League trophy under Klopp's guidance. However, this ambition hinges on Arsenal dropping points in the remaining fixtures of the season.\n\nIf not, it will mean Klopp's final season in charge of the Reds will end with just one trophy to show for their efforts. {"uri": "8095191834", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "15:30:36", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T15:30:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T15:30:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.rousingthekop.com/2024/04/24/what-dirk-kuyt-has-said-about-feyenoords-arne-slot-amid-liverpool-manager-talks/", "title": "What Dirk Kuyt has said about Feyenoord's Arne Slot amid Liverpool manager talks", "body": "Feyenoord's Arne Slot now seems to be the talk of the town as Liverpool's manager hunt ramps up.\n\nIdeally, from the perspective of Liverpool, you want that new manager signed, sealed and delivered before Jurgen Klopp heads for the exit door for the final time.\n\nMany names have been talked about ever since Klopp decided that this Premier League season was going to be his final at Anfield.\n\nAt one point, Xabi Alonso seemed the overwhelming favourite, he was the one the majority of the fans wanted, but he is now staying put in Germany and has since guided Bayer Leverkusen to a historic first Bundesliga title.\n\nPerhaps he will enter the Liverpool dugout sometime in the near future?!\n\nEither way, talks have been held with Slot and it seems as though the Reds want to push for his signature.\n\nOne man who is familiar to both the Merseyside club and Feyenoord is a certain Dirk Kuyt.\n\nThe former forward played for both clubs during his career - and had very good spells - he first joined the Reds in 2006 from the Dutch outfit, before going on to play for the club again during the latter stages of his career.\n\nKuyt has already spoken highly about Slot and the 'energy' and 'positivity' he provides in the camp when he was invited by the manager to see one of his teams in 2023, as quoted by FR12.NL.\n\nWhilst many fans will be wondering what style of play Slot brings to the table, you feel one of the most important things will be his character and how he deals with internal and external matters.\n\n\"A while ago I was invited by Arne Slot to come visit,\" Kuyt says in conversation with ESPN.\n\n\"I grabbed that opportunity with both hands. It's nice to be part of how things work there. It was a very beautiful experience. For me, it was nice to have been there as a starting trainer.\n\n\"The energy and positivity are very present there. It's very nice to be there now. It was not my intention to talk about my own championship experiences. We didn't talk about that. The team is busy with their own mission. Now it's up to them to finish it themselves. In any case, it feels as if they don't need anything or anyone.\"\n\nIf this goes through, then there are going to be obvious comparisons to a certain struggling Manchester United manager, Erik ten Hag.\n\nThat's understandable, but what could be the difference here is the duo's characters.\n\nSlot is deemed to be more upbeat, he sticks by what he says and is a stronger man-manager than his fellow countryman.\n\nThat's probably one of the reasons why he is being targeted because Klopp built a special relationship with his players and the fans, as well as keeping the media in check.", {"uri": "2024-04-333000581", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "18:49:31", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T18:49:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T18:35:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/statistics-show-why-arne-slot-183547153.html", "title": "Statistics that show why Arne Slot may be perfect fit for Liverpool", "body": "Liverpool's resurgence under J\u00fcrgen Klopp was aided by the smart implementation of data and Arne Slot's emergence as a viable successor suggests the club are once again looking at the numbers.\n\nThe Dutch coach guided Feyenoord to their first league title in six years last season, breaking up Ajax's period of dominance with aggressive, high-octane attacking football.\n\nIt certainly sounds an analogue for the 'heavy metal' style beloved by Klopp, but Slot has also studied Pep Guardiola's training methods and emphasis on control through possession.\n\nA fusion of the two approaches sounds intoxicating, though how Slot's football would scale up to the sharp end of the Premier League is unknown.\n\nThis is the statistical case that may have persuaded Liverpool to move for a relatively left-field managerial option.\n\nDefending from the front\n\nLiverpool tactical identity under Klopp has been built upon 'gegenpressing', hounding opponents both when they build up and in the seconds after Liverpool have lost possession. Since Slot was appointed in 2021, Feyenoord have won possession in the final third more than any team in Europe's top five leagues plus the Eredivisie 722 times. The team just behind them? Liverpool at 706. Over the same period, Feyenoord and Liverpool rank first and second for high turnovers won, and also take the top two places for pressed sequences (though Liverpool are on top in this metric).\n\nCreating from turnovers\n\nKlopp famously said that no playmaker in the world is as good as a well-executed counter-pressing situation, with Liverpool's off-the-ball work an attacking weapon as well as a defensive one. Slot's Feyenoord rank first across Europe's top five leagues plus the Eredivisie for high turnovers resulting in shots with 201. Liverpool rank fourth in this metric with 182. Feyenoord have scored the most goals from high turnovers with 29, exceeding Liverpool's 17. Both teams have scored 19 goals from direct attacks in league football since the start of the 2021-22 league season.\n\nHigh defensive live\n\nPressurising teams high up the pitch requires defenders who are comfortable squeezing in behind their midfielders and attackers, even if it comes with the risk of leaving opponents space in behind. This is something Liverpool defenders Ibrahima Konat\u00e9 and Virgil van Dijk excel at. One way of measuring the height or aggression of a team's defending is start distance, which measures how far upfield a team's open play sequences start in metres.\n\nAcross Europe's top five leagues plus the Eredivisie since 2021, Feyenoord and Liverpool's start distance is near-identical at 44.9 and 44.6 metres respectively. Only Manchester City have recorded a higher start distance. Liverpool have enjoyed more sequences of 10 or more passes than Slot's Feyenoord. Liverpool's passes per defensive action (see below)has been 9.7 to Feynoord's 10.4, suggesting similar levels of intensity out of possession.\n\nExpected goal over-performance\n\nSince the start of the 2021-22 season, Liverpool have scored the third most goals in Europe's top five leagues plus the Eredivisie with 244. Slot's Feyenoord are just behind them with 234. Much like Liverpool at their peak under Klopp between 2018 and 2022, Slot's team have shown signs that they can consistently score more goals than their expected goals produced suggests. This is generally viewed as a negative, with diminishing returns expected further down the line, but Liverpool use more advanced, cutting-edge tools to measure chance quality. They will hope Slot has shown a capacity to produce the hefty goalscoring haul required to challenge City.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, The German leaves the Reds after almost nine years in the summer and a new chapter will begin.\n\nFeyenoord boss Arne Slot is the frontrunner to take over at Anfield and it's understood that he would welcome the opportunity of a move to the Premier League.\n\nSlot's possible arrival will be one of a list of changes at Liverpool. After years of 'Gegenpressing' and high-tempo football under Klopp, the Dutchman's slightly different style weighs heavy on a 4-2-3-1 formation but with more reliance on the wingers to create chances.\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool new manager latest as fresh Arne Slot details emerge after Feyenoord talks\n\nREAD MORE: Five reasons why Arne Slot is perfect next Liverpool manager as expert gives inside view\n\nThe overhaul of the football department at the club is also set to see a switch in the transfer strategy in the summer. Sporting director Richard Hughes, who takes up his role at the club on June 1, will work alongside Michael Edwards and the new head coach in moulding the squad for the 2024/25 campaign.\n\nFortunately for Slot, the current Liverpool team is already full of talent and good enough to compete at the top. But as comes with a new man in the dug-out, fresh ideas in the transfer market are considered.\n\nWith that in mind, the ECHO has taken a look at three players Slot may look to bring with him from the Eredivisie to Anfield.\n\nSantiago Gimenez\n\nFeyenoord striker Gimenez has been a crucial part of Slot's side in recent years. In their title-winning campaign, the 23-year-old scored 28 times and he has carried his form through to this year, adding 24 with four games remaining.\n\nThe Mexico international has been linked with a move to the Premier League for some time with Tottenham reportedly eyeing him up as Harry Kane's replacement. This week, it emerged that West Ham were planning to approach Feyenoord for him with AC Milan and Arsenal keen.\n\nLiverpool's current frontline are all capable of adapting to whatever slot in the front three they are required to play in. However, at times they have lacked an out-and-out number nine and Gimenez could be the perfect candidate.\n\nFormer Liverpool striker Dirk Kuyt has previously been full of praise for the striker. Speaking at the end of last season, he said: \"He's back here in the middle of the defenders and he's really fast. Watching the keeper before he shoots, the rest. In my opinion, he is currently the best striker in the Eredivisie.\"\n\nJohan Bakayoko\n\nA name that Liverpool fans may be familiar with, Johan Bakayoko was linked with a move to Anfield last summer after his breakthrough with PSV Eindhoven. The Belgian winger, 21, contributed to 15 goals last term but has already surpassed that record this season with 26 goal contributions.\n\nThe right-winger, who has been PSV's replacement to Noni Madueke after his move to Chelsea, has been key in Peter Bosz's side's impressive Eredivisie season and has been heavily tipped to move to one of Europe's top leagues.\n\nWith the future of Mohamed Salah uncertain, investing in young talent could be an avenue Liverpool go down in the summer. The wonderkid is already a member of the Belgium national team and is due to play a part in the European Championships in Germany.\n\nPSV sporting director, Ernie Stewart, has already declared that he expects the tricky winger to leave in the summer. \"I don't think Bakayoko will still play at PSV next season,\" he told Voetbalkrant.\n\nLutsharel Geertruida\n\nAlongside Gimenez in this list as one of Slot's trusted individuals is defender Lutsharel Geertruida. The 23-year-old has been at the club since joining them as a teenager and has made nearly 200 appearances for them.\n\nCapable of playing at centre-back and right-back, the Netherlands international is said to be on Manchester United and Real Madrid's radar ahead of the summer. His current deal in Rotterdam runs out in 2025 meaning this summer may be Feyenoord's final chance to cash in on him.\n\nBayern Munich reportedly decided against signing the defender before signing Eric Dier in January meaning he remains available. Listen on Spotify, Apple or anywhere you get your podcasts\n\nJamie Carragher believes there is a rift between outgoing Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp and chief Michael Edwards - citing the return of the latter is because of the German's imminent departure.\n\nLast month, it was announced that Edwards was back at the club after leaving the Merseyside outfit two years ago.\n\nClub owners FSG asked Edwards back to help head up a restructure following in the wake of Klopp's announcement in January that he will be leaving the club at the end of the season.\n\nEdwards spent 10 years at Liverpool from 2012 and has been lauded as one of the most influential figures alongside Klopp in the club's recent glory decade.\n\nHe played a key role in the signings of the likes of Mohamed Salah, Alisson and Virgil van Dijk.\n\nJamie Carragher believes Jurgen Klopp (left) and Michael Edwards (right) have fallen out\n\nCarragher aired his opinion on the Liverpool duo on the latest Stick to Football podcast\n\nPodcast All episodes PODCAST: Listen to our EXCLUSIVE interview with Phil Foden IAKO! - Nottingham Forest are making fools of themselves! It's All Kicking Off! - Can City overcome Chelsea in FA Cup Showdown? It's All Kicking Off! - OFFICIAL Man City win the Premier League again It's All Kicking Off! - Phil Foden a shoo-in for POTY? Play on Apple Spotify\n\nHowever, speaking on the Stick to Football podcast, brought to you by Sky Bet, Carragher is of the opinion that is no coincidence that Edwards has come back to the club in light of Klopp's future.\n\n'What's really interesting here is Michael Edwards, the sporting director, was there at the start with Klopp but they've obviously fallen out for whatever reason and a lot of his team have moved on,' he said.\n\n'As soon as Klopp's gone it's like the band are back together. It's obvious something has happened behind the scenes.\n\n'The owners FSG felt it was more important to get that structure back rather than who the next manager is.\n\n'There is no way Michael Edwards is coming back and not having all the power to run this club. He's not even in the same role, he's in a bigger role as they're going to try and buy other clubs.\n\n'My worry going forward is that the manager, whoever they bring in will just be a coach.'\n\nFeyenoord manager Arne Slot is the frontrunner to succeed Klopp. As detailed by Mail Sport on Wednesday, Anfield officials have contacted the Dutch champions with a first offer of compensation for the 49-year-old, who does not have a release clause in his contract.\n\nCarragher believes it is no coincidence Edwards has returned with Klopp leaving this summer\n\nEdwards has been lauded as one of the most influential figures alongside Klopp in the club's recent glory decade - playing a key role in Virgil van Dijk and Alisson's arrivals among others\n\nIt is expected a fee of more than \u00a310million will be required to land Slot, who will look to bring a number of his staff with him including assistant Sipke Hulshoff.\n\nThe situation is developing quickly and talks to bring Slot to Anfield could even be concluded before the weekend.\n\nHowever, when talking about that potential appointment Carragher raised his concerns - fearing Slot won't have the gravitas among supporters compared to other candidates such as Xabi Alonso or predecessors like Klopp, Rafa Benitez and Gerard Houllier.\n\nAsked by Roy Keane if he thinks that would be an exciting appointment, Carragher bluntly said 'no' before explaining why.\n\n'I would imagine Xabi Alonso was right at the top of the list because of what he's done at Bayer Leverkusen but also because of the connection [with fans]. That's a big thing and it's a little bit worrying for me as a Liverpool fan.\n\n'I think when Liverpool have done well in the Premier League era - Houllier had a good spell of winning trophies over two-three years, Rafa was the same and Klopp has done that - there was this real connection with the fans and then Anfield gets going and you feel like you're moving somewhere.\n\n'I think Liverpool is different to almost any club in that the manager is always the God. The manager is so important.\n\n'It feels like it [Arne] is an appointment you'd make if you were trying to get back in the top four. Liverpool are among the top five or six teams in Europe and have been for a few years.\n\n'You think of a guy, as a Liverpool supporter, standing on the sideline who can go up against Pep Guardiola. Thomas Tuchel has beaten him and got something about him.\n\n'Don't ever forget how big the connection has got to be with a Liverpool supporter and we just haven't got a coach who is a \"yes\" man behind the scenes.'\n\nLiverpool have opened negotiations with Feyenoord as they look to sign head coach Arne Slot\n\nThe 45-year-old recently won the KNVB Cup and previously won the Eredivisie in 2022-23\n\nCarragher has expressed his concerns about Slot's credentials at Anfield if he succeeds Klopp\n\nSlot, who was considered by both Tottenham and Chelsea last summer, has found immense success since joining the Dutch side in 2021 and has become one of the most progressive coaches in European football.\n\nHe recently guided his side Feyenoord to victory in the KNVB Cup; the second trophy he has won in charge of the Rotterdam giants, having made them domestic champions 12 months ago.\n\nHis accolades at the Dutch side have made him an ideal candidate to succeed Klopp at Anfield and the Reds have now stepped up their pursuit of the 45-year-old.\n\nIt should also be noted that Slot's planned press conference to preview Feyenoord's game against Go Ahead Eagles on Thursday night has been cancelled. No official reason was given.\n\nInitial reports suggested that the Reds were considering a move for Alonso, who has done such outstanding work with Bayer Leverkusen.\n\nBut Alonso wanted to stay in Germany and that led to Ruben Amorim assuming bookmakers favouritism.\n\nThe Portuguese, who has \u00a312million release clause in his contract, spoke recently about not being able to give Sporting Lisbon any guarantees on his future.\n\nLiverpool had given him firm consideration, as they have done with Brighton's Roberto De Zerbi, but they are now prepared to move in a different direction from He's out of contract at Lille at the end of the season.\"\n\nFonseca won the league title in each of his three years with Shakhtar before guiding Roma to a fifth place finish and the Europa League semi-finals. {"uri": "8096538307", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:32:07", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:32:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T10:31:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/liverpool-bayern-munich-barcelona-manager-32667974", "title": "Liverpool, Barcelona and Bayern have reached same conclusion in manager hunts", "body": "Liverpool are closing in on appointing Arne Slot as their new manager, having missed out on first choice Xabi Alonso\n\nA case of bad timing has hit Liverpool, Barcelona and Bayern Munich in their respective searches for new managers.\n\nAll three had been looking to appoint a new boss ahead of next season, with Jurgen Klopp and Xavi announcing their intention to step down, while Thomas Tuchel is being sacked. The announcements of those departures sparked a search for a manager at the trio of clubs.\n\nAt first, they all set their sights on high-calibre appointments. Xabi Alonso was heavily linked with both Liverpool and Bayern before ruling himself out of leaving Bayer Leverkusen, where he has won the Bundesliga title.\n\nThe Reds then turned their focus to Ruben Amorim, while Bayern made a push for Unai Emery. Again though, both moves failed to progress, with Liverpool now closing in on appointing Arne Slot instead.\n\nSlot has impressed at Feyenoord, where he has won the Eredivisie title and the KNVB Cup, but he still appears to be a back-up option. Likewise, Bayern have seen Emery instead sign a new contract with Aston Villa.\n\nThat has seen them turn to former Manchester United interim boss Ralf Rangnick, who has confirmed that talks are underway that would see him move to the Allianz Arena from his job with the Austrian national team.\n\nAgain, Rangnick would appear to be a back-up option and is far from the big-name boss Bayern will have wanted to appoint. Then we come to Barca, who also had Amorim in their sights, as well as Brighton boss Roberto De Zerbi and, remarkably, Klopp.\n\nBut with the La Liga giants hardly an attractive destination due to their financial situation, Xavi has been convinced to make a U-turn and will now stay until at least the summer of 2025. It means all three 'big clubs' who had been searching for a boss have had to go to their back-up plans.\n\nHAVE YOUR SAY! Is Arne Slot the right appointment for Liverpool? Comment below.\n\nBayern Munich are in talks with Ralf Rangnick\n\nQuestions will now be raised that they should have waited another year before making a change, with a lack of top managers being willing to take charge this summer. Liverpool legend Jamie Carragher certainly believes choosing a back-up could create problems.\n\n\"What I would say from Feyenoord to Liverpool is a huge jump and I think it shows in this moment a lack of real top managers out there when you look at who Liverpool were going for. Now Arne Slot looks like he is the favourite,\" he told Sky Sports.\n\n\"I don't think it's like Rafa Benitez coming on or Jurgen Klopp coming in. Benitez came off the back of winning two La Liga titles and a UEFA Cup and Jurgen Klopp coming after winning a couple of titles with Borussia Dortmund and getting to a Champions League final.\n\n\"Liverpool are in a different area now and fancy themselves to challenge for the Premier League next season and the Champions League, they will be expected to reach the quarter-finals at least. I think it is a huge jump.\"\n\nXabi Alonso has already confirmed his desire to stay with Bayer Leverkusen for at least one more season\n\nWith Manchester United also likely to be in the hunt in a matter of weeks, demand appears to be significantly outweighing supply. And that all appears to be playing perfectly into the hands of Real Madrid - who for once seem to be in a relatively stable position.\n\nCarlo Ancelotti's future had at one point looked uncertain, but with another La Liga and Champions League double in his sights, he looks set to stay on for at least one more season. That could leave the Spanish giants, with a dressing room sure to include Kylian Mbappe along with their current crop of Galcticos, able to get a free run at their preferred target in 12 month's time. Xabi Alonso anyone?\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community and receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. I hope it will happen.\n\n\"The job he has done at Feyenoord makes him the perfect fit for Liverpool. He arrived there from AZ Alkmaar. AZ had finished higher up the league than Feyenoord but he still went there because he liked the challenge and he thought the coach was not taking all of the potential out of the team.\n\n\"Liverpool have a lot of potential in the squad, and we don't have the money that Manchester City have to spend, so I think he will get all the potential out of the players.\n\n\"He plays in the same style as J\u00fcrgen Klopp: sexy football, forward pressing and the percentage of ball recoveries in the opposition half is the highest in Holland. When he loses the ball, he wants the ball back in three seconds.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Gary Neville explains why Liverpool may avoid repeating Man United mistake after Klopp leaves\n\nREAD MORE: 3/10 'shocker' - Journalist unimpressed with 29-pass Liverpool ace who lost 50% of derby duels\n\nWesterveld's testimony suggests that there could be some striking similarities between Slot and Klopp which may offer encouragement to Liverpool fans.\n\nThe 45-year-old has experience of working wonders with an inferior budget to illustrious domestic rivals and reviving big clubs who'd previously been underperforming, two things the German has achieved at Anfield over the past decade.\n\nThe Dutchman's reputation for intense pressing also has strong echoes of the man from whom he's poised to take over on Merseyside. Indeed, a graph from The Athletic showed that his Feyenoord side rank in the top 4% of teams in Europe's seven biggest leagues for 'intensity', i.e. opposition touches per tackle made.\n\nThey're also in the top 2% for chance creation (i.e. non-penalty xG per 90 minutes), which attests to the 'sexy football' of which Westerveld has spoken.\n\nNo Liverpool fans expects Slot to be Klopp 2.0, certainly not straight away, but there are some encouraging portents to indicate that he could preserve many of the German's best qualities in terms of on-field performance at Liverpool.\n\nIf he can who Michael Edwards could now appoint as Liverpool's next manager", "body": "Michael Edwards has a very good reputation at Liverpool, but you just feel it could completely turn on its head with this next managerial appointment.\n\nMany were surprised to see him return to Anfield this season, but it was a welcome return given his great work in his first stint and how the next chapter of the club is now going to be written.\n\nIn the first chapter, he helped play a key role in Liverpool winning every trophy possible under Jurgen Klopp's stewardship, including their first Premier League title in three decades.\n\nBut you just feel Michael Edwards' upcoming call to appoint a new manager is going to either enhance his reputation even further or completely flatten everything that came before it.\n\nThat's probably why Liverpool are going down the road of a 'brave' appointment, rather than a crowd favourite that would just fall flat on its face after a few months.\n\nGary Neville has watched Manchester United decline and decline post-Sir Alex Ferguson era.\n\nAnd there will be some Liverpool fans fearing that the same could happen to them given how important and integral a man like Klopp has been to them.\n\nBut with talk of Feyenoord coach Arne Slot being the man to come in, it has left some people by surprise because it isn't the obvious call.\n\nNeville is one of them and he thinks Edwards is getting his way in possibly bringing in a man like Slot and how the Englishman didn't see eye-to-eye with Klopp when they previously worked together, as he told Sky Sports.\n\nNonetheless, amid these Slot rumours, the former Manchester United defender also feels the Dutchman wasn't Liverpool's first choice.\n\n\"He's a successful coach in Holland,\" said Neville. \"I love Dutch coaches. There's a way of coaching that comes back through some of the great coaches of the game. Obviously, it's a change going from the Dutch league to the English league. It's a very different approach to Jurgen Klopp, but I don't think they could ever really appoint a manager that's got the personality, character and force of Klopp.\n\n\"It's interesting. It's obviously something that's been driven by Michael Edwards, in terms of them wanting a different approach Maybe that's why Edwards left Liverpool - because he clashed with Klopp. But now he's got his own way and he's bringing in someone he thinks is going to take Liverpool forward. We don't know how that's going to go. The reality of it is that we've seen the post-Arsene Wenger era at Arsenal has been difficult. The post-Sir Alex Ferguson era at Manchester United has been difficult. Klopp is massive in Liverpool so they've got to try to get that right.\n\n\"We thought it was going to be Xabi Alonso originally and then Ruben Amorim. Now it's Arne Slot. They'll still have a good coach.\"\n\nLiverpool isn't a club that splashes crazy money like their rivals, but they have still put money in their pockets and been shrewd in the transfer market.\n\nFrom Andy Robertson to Virgil van Dijk. Alkmaar - 126 were won, 33 were lost and 45 ended as a draw, giving him a win rate of 61.8 per cent.\n\nIn comparison, Ten Hag had a win rate of 63.2 per cent with 232 wins, 67 draws and 68 defeats
