The Reds were well below their best at Goodison Park and now need Arsenal and Manchester City to stumble in the final weeks of the season.\n\nAttention is already turning to next season with Arne Slot emerging as the new frontrunner to take over from J\u00fcrgen Klopp. The Dutchman has done a fine job at Feyenoord and talks are already underway about moving to Anfield, reports BBC Sport.\n\nAlongside new sporting director Richard Hughes, Liverpool's next manager faces some big decisions in the transfer market. And while contract calls will be needed on the likes of Mohamed Salah and Virgil van Dijk, another Reds ace could face an uncertain future.\n\nREAD MORE: Arne Slot takes inspiration from six managers including J\u00fcrgen Klopp and two Liverpool rivals\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool defensive issues broken down as seven players could do more to stop Everton opener\n\nThat is certainly the belief of former defender Jamie Carragher, who isn't convinced Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez is the man to take Liverpool to the next step. The Uruguayan struggled at Goodison Park on Wednesday night and missed a gilt-edged chance in the first-half, firing straight at Jordan Pickford.\n\n\"After two years, I don't think there is going to be a massive improvement in him. He can cause trouble but he is erratic with his finishing. That isn't enough to win the biggest trophies,\" Carragher said on Sky Sports. \"You talk about the first year and these players come in and they're getting up to speed, and you see them improving and getting better.\n\n\"It looked like he was at the start of the season but it has ground to a halt. I think there is a big decision to be made on him in the summer.\"\n\nN\u00fa\u00f1ez has shown signs of improvements this season. He has already beaten last season's goal tally and provided a further 13 assists. When on song, he is an absolute nightmare for opposition defenses with his running in behind.\n\nHis pace means he can often be deployed out wide on the left and there are few players in Europe who cause anywhere near as much chaos. But when his side needs a cool head in front of goal, he remains anything but.\n\nThe comparisons to the central striker that Slot is working with at Feyenoord are stark. Santiago Gim\u00e9nez, who is two years younger than N\u00fa\u00f1ez, has been a revelation since joining from Cruz Azul in 2022. He has averaged a goal every 0.55 matches since arriving with only two players beating his tally of 21 in the Eredivisie this season.\n\nAdmittedly, the standard of opposition defender is not as high as in the Premier League but it is when provided with the chance to score, that Gim\u00e9nez outshines Liverpool's record signing. N\u00fa\u00f1ez has had more shots than any other player in the Premier League (105) but only found the net 11 times. As per FBref, his shot conversion rate stands at 10.4 per cent.\n\nHis opportunity at Goodison Park took his tally of 'big chances missed' to 26, only beaten by Erling Haaland. Meanwhile, Gim\u00e9nez is proving much more effective, scoring 21 of his 101 shots, to take his conversion rate to 20.8 per cent.\n\nAt just 23, the Feyenoord man still has a lot of developing to do but he is already on the radar of a number of clubs. Real Madrid has been keeping tabs on the Mexico international, as have Arsenal, Chelsea and Tottenham, reports 90min.\n\nUnsurprisingly, the Dutch giants want to keep him. It is believed that any club will have to smash the Eredivisie transfer record, which was set by Manchester United to sign Antony, standing at $93m (\u00a387m/\u20ac100m).\n\nShould Slot get the Anfield job, he could well give Liverpool the upper hand in any potential transfer dealings. {"uri": "2024-04-335388833", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "15:26:37", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T15:26:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T15:00:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/liverpool-news-manager-jurgen-klopp-successor-arne-slot-right-choice", "title": "Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp's successor Arne Slot is the right choice", "body": "After Jurgen Klopp's announcement of his departure from Liverpool, the search for his successor began, and Arne Slot answers the call\n\nAfter Jurgen Klopp's announcement of his departure from Liverpool, the search for his successor began. Initially, former midfielder Xabi Alonso seemed poised to take the reins, but his decision to remain at Bayer Leverkusen left a void in the managerial discussion. Sporting CP's Ruben Amorim briefly emerged as a contender, but recent developments suggest a shift in focus towards Feyenoord's Arne Slot, reported by GOAL.\n\nWho is Arne Slot\n\nArne Slot's playing career at FC Zwolle, while not illustrious in terms of trophies, laid the foundation for his coaching journey. His transition from midfielder to coach was evident even during his playing days, with teammates noting his keen tactical insight and leadership on the field. Upon retiring, Slot seamlessly transitioned into coaching, initially at PEC Zwolle's youth level before earning a senior coaching role at AZ Alkmaar.\n\nAt Zwolle, Slot honed his coaching skills, demonstrating a natural understanding for player development and tactical analysis. His meticulous approach to training and innovative tactics caught the attention of AZ Alkmaar, where he was appointed as an assistant coach under John van den Brom. Slot's impact was immediate, contributing to AZ's resurgence in the Eredivisie and earning praise for his tactical contributions.\n\nSlot's time at AZ Alkmaar marked a turning point in his coaching career. When he assumed the role of head coach, AZ Alkmaar was on the verge of a breakthrough, challenging traditional powerhouses like Ajax and PSV Eindhoven for the Eredivisie title. Under Slot's guidance, AZ Alkmaar exhibited a dynamic style of play characterized by fluid attacking movements and relentless pressing. While narrowly missing out on the league title, Slot's impact was undeniable, laying the groundwork for future success.\n\nHis subsequent appointment at Feyenoord started a new chapter in his coaching journey. Tasked with revitalizing a storied club, Slot embraced the challenge with characteristic enthusiasm and ambition. In his first season, Feyenoord experienced a resurgence, finishing third in the Eredivisie and reaching the final of the Europa Conference League. Slot's tactical knowledge and man-management skills were instrumental in transforming Feyenoord into genuine title contenders, earning him widespread acclaim within the footballing community.\n\nArne Slot's vision for football\n\nSlot's tactical approach mirrors that of renowned managers like Pep Guardiola and Jurgen Klopp, emphasizing attacking play and high pressing. His teams deploy an expansive 4-3-3 or 4-2-3-1 formation, with an emphasis on positional rotations and aggressive pressing to disrupt opponents' build-up play. Slot's commitment to expansive football aligns with Liverpool's style, making him a natural fit for the club.\n\nSlot's tactical philosophy is underpinned by a relentless pursuit of excellence and a commitment to proactive, possession-based football. His teams prioritize ball retention and quick transitions, aiming to dominate possession and create scoring opportunities through dynamic attacking movements. Slot's emphasis on positional play and collective pressing enables his teams to control the tempo of the game and dictate play in key areas of the pitch.\n\nBeyond tactics, Slot's coaching style emphasizes clear communication, player development, and effective man-management. His ability to motivate and inspire players has been praised by former colleagues and players, highlighting his diplomatic approach and great leadership qualities. Slot fosters a positive and inclusive team culture, empowering players to express themselves on the field and take ownership of their performances. His hands-on approach and attention to detail enable him to build strong relationships with players and create a cohesive team environment poised for success.\n\nSlot's unconventional training methods, such as one-touch drills and detailed video analysis, contribute to his players' tactical understanding and overall development. He prioritizes individual improvement and collective cohesion, tailoring training sessions to address specific areas of weakness and maximize the players potential. Slot's holistic approach to player development includes physical, technical, and psychological aspects, ensuring that players are fully prepared to excel on matchday.\n\nSlot's strong personality and unwavering conviction are evident in his interactions with players, fellow managers, and the media. His confrontations with notable figures like Jose Mourinho and Diego Simeone underscore his assertiveness and commitment to his footballing principles. Slot's willingness to challenge established norms and defend his beliefs adds depth to his managerial persona, signaling a coach unafraid of confrontation and driven by a desire for success.\n\nArne Slot's potential impact at Liverpool\n\nAs negotiations between Liverpool and Arne Slot progress, the prospect of Slot leading the club into a new era becomes increasingly high. With his track record of success, innovative tactics, and strong leadership qualities, Slot represents a compelling choice to succeed Jurgen Klopp. While following in Jurgen Klopp's footsteps may be daunting, Slot's confidence, ambition, and footballing philosophy suggest he is more than capable of embracing the challenge head-on.\n\nArne Slot's journey from player to coach has been defined by ambition, innovation, and a relentless pursuit of excellence. As he prepares to embark on the next chapter of his managerial career at Liverpool, Slot brings with him a wealth of experience, tactical knowledge, and a winning mentality. With Slot's style and confidence his arrival at Anfield promises a new dawn for the Reds, with the hopes of fixing the holes in their recent form and rise once again as the best team in England.", After they lost to Everton on Wednesday, Liverpool's Premier League title challenge is no more.\n\nAs a result, all eyes are now on who FSG will pick as their replacement for Klopp. It has become apparent over the past couple of days that the chosen one is likely to be Arne Slot, currently in charge at Feyenoord.\n\nOther names may yet still come into the fray, with Thomas Frank one who has reportedly been interviewed alongside Slot. But to all intents and purposes, the 45-year-old is the front-runner.\n\nWith Klopp's coaching team also mainly departing, it will be interesting to see who Slot brings with him if he is appointed. For those remaining at Anfield awaiting his arrival, the excitement has already started.\n\nJay Spearing is not part of the first-team coaching staff at Liverpool, although with others soon to depart, maybe that will change.\n\nEither way, it was still interesting to hear what the former player had to say when asked by Stadium Astro who he'd like to see installed as Klopp's successor.\n\n\"Do you know what, those big decision aren't my decisions,\" said the 35-year-old.\n\n\"I'm obviously under 21s, working with the young lads and my decisions are mainly bound by the academy director Alex Inglethorpe.\n\n\"But whoever comes in it will be an absolute privilege to work under. It's been an incredible 18 months, two years for me to work under Jurgen Klopp, Pep Lijnders and Vitor [Matos]. The access we've had to them has been incredible, I've loved every single minute of it.\n\n\"But whoever comes in will be a new challenge, a fresh challenge, but also a new learning time for me. It's a really exciting time, obviously it's disappointing to see Jurgen leave but it will be a new start for the club and a new way of going forward hopefully.\"\n\nThe two coaches that Spearing mentions - Lijnders and Matos - will both be leaving the club with Klopp.\n\nLijnders has most recently been linked with the Besiktas job, while there are claims that he could take Matos to be part of his team.\n\nAlso departing is Peter Krawietz, who rarely seems to get a mention when these things are spoken about. But he'll be a huge loss nonetheless.\n\nAs a result, Slot - or whoever it may be instead - has a big job on to develop their own culture at the club.\n\nIn terms of Slot, it has been reported that he'd be likely to take his assistant - Sipke Hulshoff - along with him. {"uri": "8097152989", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:06:09", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:06:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:05:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://www.rousingthekop.com/2024/04/25/exclusive-i-played-with-arne-slot-and-i-watched-him-coach-hes-perfect-for-liverpool/", "title": "Exclusive: I played with Arne Slot and I watched him coach, he's 'perfect for Liverpool", "body": "Rousing the Kop speaks exclusively to former AZ Alkmaar and Ajax coach, Julian Jenner, who was teammates with Arne Slot.\n\nEven twenty years ago, Julian Jenner always knew Arne Slot was going to become a coach. Back then Jenner and Slot were teammates at NAC Breda, and Jenner remembers him as a player always curious about the game.\n\n\"He was a personality,\" Jenner recalls.\n\n\"He was always in discussion about why we do this, why I have to play like this. And he was very interested already [in tactics].\n\n\"He was constantly busy with, with tactics, with exercises. That is Arne, you know. He wants to develop himself so bad, so good. And he has an ambition.\"\n\nIn his heyday, Slot was a midfielder, who played in the top flight of Dutch football. Jenner remembers an intelligent player on the pitch.\n\n\"His biggest strength for me was his unbelievable technique, so technical. He was very, very good. He saw already two or three steps before he wants to do something.\n\n\"He was not fast. Because he was very slow. But he always found the right moment and to recognise where he has to be and that's the big strength of him.\n\n\"With him, he makes your team better in possession.\"\n\nJenner also compares Slot in his prime to a player like Sergio Busquets.\n\n\"He was a very underestimated player because he was not fast, you know, and if you want to compare somebody on the top, he was like Busquets. He was something like that. He was a little faster than Busquets. But he was similar.\"\n\nAfter hanging up his boots, Jenner went into coaching and briefly worked at AZ Alkmaar while Arne Slot was the club's assistant manager.\n\nDuring his time at the club, he observed Arne in action as a manager and was impressed by what he saw.\n\n\"I started to watch his trainings and his trainings are based on a lot of possession game but with very, very high intensity but always with thought. That, I think that makes him exceptional. He loves creativity, and he loves attacking football.\n\n\"I remember that before he went to AZ, he went always to different clubs in different countries to watch training sessions.\"\n\nAccording to Jenner, Slot's playing style closely resembles Pep Guardiola rather than Jurgen Klopp.\n\n\"He is similar to Guardiola. Klopp is power play, gegenpressing to get the ball as fast as possible. But with Arne it's more high-speed ball possession, quickly go to the goal, and he's also not shy to defend, so he knows when we are ahead, we are on the pressure and he is not afraid to change things.\n\n\"He can feel the moment when he has to change [things] in games and he can read the game. He's not shy to make good decisions or brave decisions. That's a gift. Not a lot of coaches have that.\"\n\nHaving observed Slot both as a teammate and as a coach at first-hand, Jenner believes Liverpool could be the perfect next step for the 45-year-old coach.\n\n\"I believe if he makes a step that it will be a very good step for Liverpool as well.\n\n\"After a decade with Klopp he is for me the perfect follow-up coach. I think he can give even more flair to Liverpool. You know what Manchester United had in the past.\n\n\"I believe when Arne goes there [Liverpool] with that kind of style of play. In that public, in my eyes, they will be unbeatable.\"", "source": {"uri": "rousingthekop.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Rousing The Kop"}, "authors": [{"uri": "bence_bocsak@rousingthekop.com", {"uri": "8096885181", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "14:04:17", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T14:04:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T14:04:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4431372582912445, "url": "https://www.planetfootball.com/stats-tables/arne-slot-liverpool-managerial-record-statistics-eredivisie-compared-erik-ten-hag", "title": "Next Liverpool manager: Comparing Arne Slot and Erik ten Hag's Eredivisie records", "body": "Arne Slot looks set to become Liverpool's next manager - though some fans might be forgiven for being a little apprehensive given the last highly-thought-of bald Dutch tactician to go from the Eredivisie to a high-profile Premier League job is currently under immense pressure.\n\nIt looks increasingly unlikely that Ten Hag will remain in his post at Old Trafford next season, his stock having fallen considerably since he was regarded among European football's next great coaches whilst he was consistently delivering silverware at Ajax.\n\nTen Hag built more than one very good Ajax side during his five-year stint in the Dutch capital. He brought through a number of talented players, won three Eredivisie titles and two KNVB Cups. He came seconds away from leading the club to the 2019 Champions League final, having knocked out both Real Madrid and Juventus en route to the semis.\n\nIn recent weeks he's gone on the defensive in his press conferences, pointing out that he's taken Manchester United to three of four domestic cup finals during his two seasons at Old Trafford.\n\nWhile there were some notable question marks - that 7-0 against Liverpool, a very poor away record against top sides - there was plenty to be encouraged about from Ten Hag's first season in English football. He ended United's six-year trophy drought with the League Cup, showed leadership in binning off Cristiano Ronaldo and got them back into the Champions League.\n\nBut he might need to lead United to an unlikely victory over Man City in next month's FA Cup final to salvage something from a much more underwhelming second year.\n\nSome hapless displays resulted in them failing to make it out of their Champions League group, while results in the Premier League have left them almost certain to finish outside the top four. Performances have arguably been ever worse, with underlying numbers painting a picture of a solidly bottom-half side. They might yet register their worst placing and points tally of the Premier League era.\n\nSo there's a degree of logic in looking at their biggest rivals and fearing the same will happen with Slot at Anfield. It is worth considering Jose Mourinho's famous 'football heritage' spiel, however; United have struggled for over a decade since Sir Alex Ferguson's departure and Ten Hag's tenure is merely a continuation of that at a club that have been run questionably - to put it mildly - behind the scenes.\n\nLiverpool have tended to fare considerably better in recent years. And with recruitment specialist Michael Edwards returning to the fore, there's an argument that the hierarchy will give Slot a better chance of success.\n\nLike Ten Hag two years ago, Slot boasts a strong reputation at Feyenoord. He's won at Eredivisie title and a KNVB Cup and led them to the UEFA Conference League finals in 2021-22. He reportedly turned down Leeds and Tottenham last year but is believed to be keen on the opportunity at Liverpool.\n\nTen Hag and Slot actually boast remarkably similar records in the Eredivisie, although the former had more experience with almost a hundred more games under his belt. Slot's win percentage and points-per-game is marginally better, although Ten Hag's side scored at a slightly greater rate and conceded fewer.\n\nHere's how their records in the Dutch top flight stack {"uri": "2024-04-334756025", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "06:29:09", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T06:29:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T05:14:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.43529412150383, "url": "https://www.empireofthekop.com/2024/04/25/neville-liverpool-setup-klopp-leaving/", "title": "Gary Neville explains why Liverpool may avoid repeating Man United mistake after Klopp leaves", "body": "Gary Neville has explained why he feels Liverpool may be able to avoid the prolonged downturn experienced by two rival Premier League clubs after the departure of a long-serving and hugely successful manager.\n\nJurgen Klopp now has just four matches remaining in charge of the Reds, with his glorious reign in danger of ending with a whimper after a miserable April for his team.\n\nArne Slot is currently the frontrunner to replace him, having reportedly spoken to LFC already (Fabrizio Romano), and the ex-Manchester United defender has been discussing what lies ahead for the Anfield club after the German's departure.\n\nSpeaking on Sky Sports, Neville said: \"We don't know how that's going to go. The reality of it is that we've seen the post-Arsene Wenger era at Arsenal has been difficult. The post-Sir Alex Ferguson era at Manchester United has been difficult. Klopp is massive in Liverpool so they've got to try to get that right.\"\n\nFOLLOW Empire of the Kop on Instagram (@empireofthekop) HERE\n\nHowever, the 48-year-old thinks that the Reds are better equipped to cope with Klopp leaving than United and Arsenal were after the respective exits of Ferguson and Wenger, saying: \"What Manchester United and Arsenal had when they replaced those two managers was a quite traditional, old-school approach, where the managers ran the club.\n\n\"They didn't really have a sporting department beneath them. They were the heads of the sporting department. They were the heads of recruitment, sporting director, manager and coach - all in one.\n\n\"Liverpool have a better setup, with more depth and more structure. There's still going to be an element of risk replacing Klopp with anybody but it has to happen. Klopp is leaving.\"\n\nREAD MORE: 3/10 'shocker' - Journalist unimpressed with 29-pass Liverpool ace who lost 50% of derby duels\n\nREAD MORE: (Video) Jamie Carragher was raging at Liverpool player's 'unforgivable' moment v Everton\n\nThe two precedents cited by Neville serve as case studies for Liverpool as to what can happen after a legendary manager leaves, with neither David Moyes at Old Trafford nor Unai Emery at the Emirates Stadium even coming close to replicating the impact of their immediate predecessors.\n\nThat's the challenge which awaits Slot if he's ultimately given the Anfield job, although he'll be fully aware of how tall an order it'll be to follow on immediately from an iconic figure in Klopp.\n\nAt least if he comes to Merseyside, he'll benefit from having some shrewd operators with whom to work, as Neville has referenced.\n\nCEO of Football Michael Edwards is widely regarded as one of the sharpest boardroom executives in world football, while new sporting director Richard Hughes arrives from Bournemouth with a glowing reputation.\n\nLiverpool are facing into a period of uncertainly after Klopp, that's for sure, but at least there's a strong backroom {"uri": "8096350101", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "08:41:16", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T08:41:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T08:41:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4196078479290009, "url": "https://www.football365.com/news/arne-slot-neville-liverpool-boss-man-utd-decline-post-klopp-era", "title": "Arne Slot: Neville explains why new Liverpool boss won't experience Man Utd decline in post-Klopp era", "body": "Gary Neville has offered hope for Liverpool post-Jurgen Klopp.\n\nGary Neville believes Arne Slot, of whoever takes over at Liverpool, has a better chance of success at Anfield post-Jurgen Klopp despite Manchester United and Arsenal's struggles after the departures of their legacy managers.\n\nReports on Wednesday confirmed Liverpool are in talks with Feyenoord boss Slot over replacing Klopp at the end of the season, and the Dutchman will have quite the job on his hands following one of the club's all-time greats.\n\nKlopp's farewell tour looks set to end in disappointment after his side limped to a 2-0 defeat to Everton on Wednesday, to all-but end their hopes of winning the Premier League this season.\n\nBut there's little doubt the German's departure will leave a gaping hole at the football club, and there will be huge concerns among the fanbase over the next appointment given the struggles at Manchester United post-Sir Alex Ferguson and Arsenal post-Arsene Wenger.\n\nNeville believes Liverpool are in a better place to succeed than their rivals though, given they have \"more structure\" in place, with Michael Edwards returning as CEO and Richard Hughes hired as sporting director to reduce the workload of an incoming manager or head coach.\n\nSpeaking on Sky Sports, Neville said: \"We don't know how that's going to go. The reality of it is that we've seen the post-Arsene Wenger era at Arsenal has been difficult. The post-Sir Alex Ferguson era at Manchester United has been difficult. Klopp is massive in Liverpool so they've got to try to get that right.\n\n\"What Manchester United and Arsenal had when they replaced those two managers was a quite traditional, old-school approach, where the managers ran the club.\n\n\"They didn't really have a sporting department beneath them. They were the heads of the sporting department. They were the heads of recruitment, sporting director, manager and coach - all in one.\n\n\"Liverpool have a better setup, with more depth and more structure. There's still going to be an element of risk replacing Klopp with anybody but it has to happen.
